testcase: Guidance on cross version breaking change for readonly and async operations in new api-versions

expected.answer:
The 'provisioningState' change in the PATCH request model seems like a bug fix if this field was always read-only.  When you get a breaking change review, if this is explained with an appropriate comment, this is likely to be justified as a bug fix.
On changing PATCH to synchronous.  ARM does support async PATCH operations, although REST API Guidelines discourage async PATCH operations.  If this operation is synchronous in the previous stable version, then this change is a real breaking change that you will need to justify in breaking change review.
Similarly, making PUT and DELETE Asynchronous is a breaking change if these operations were synchronous in the previous stable version is a real breaking change, and you will need to justify the change in a breaking change review.

actual.answer:
Your understanding regarding the breaking change flag for the readonly 'provisioningState' field in the PATCH operation model is correct: removing or not including a readonly field like 'provisioningState' from the PATCH request model (e.g., ConfigurationPropertiesUpdate) should NOT be considered a breaking change. According to Azure and ARM guidelines, readonly properties are not updatable and should not appear in PATCH request bodies. The PATCH model should only include properties that are updatable; readonly fields are only present in responses. If the breaking change tooling is flagging this as a removal, it is a false positive and can be safely ignored for readonly fields in PATCH request models.

For your second question about converting create, update, and delete (CUD) operations to long-running operations (LRO) in a new API version:
- Changing CUD operations to LRO in a new API version is allowed and is the recommended approach when new business requirements (like provisioning MRG) require asynchronous processing. This is not considered a breaking change for previous API versions, as long as the change is only present in the new API version and the old versions remain synchronous.
- The correct way to implement this in TypeSpec is to use the appropriate Azure Resource Manager LRO operation templates (e.g., ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync, ArmResourcePatchAsync, ArmResourceDeleteAsync) for the new API version. You should use @sharedRoute and @renamedFrom/@removed decorators to ensure the old and new operations are properly versioned and routed, so that clients using older versions continue to see the synchronous behavior, while clients using the new version get the LRO behavior.

Summary of recommended actions:
1. Do NOT include readonly fields like 'provisioningState' in PATCH request models; ignore breaking change flags for their removal in PATCH models.
2. For new API versions, use the ARM LRO operation templates for CUD operations and version your operations using @sharedRoute and @renamedFrom/@removed decorators to avoid breaking changes for older versions.

This approach is fully compliant with Azure API guidelines and ARM resource provider contract requirements.

The [Breaking Changes(Cross-Version) detected problems](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22834/checks?check_run_id=43004413278). How to fix it?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIt depends.  Even across versions, some changes are discouraged/disallowed.  If the breaking changes reported in your PR are all intentional, then you just need to follow the instructions in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment to work with the breaking changes board for approval: https://aka.ms/brch\\\\r\\\\nGenerally, breaking changes between preview api-versions are allowed if there are good reasons,  breaking changes relative to a stable api-version are more of a concern. And in this case, making a property optional would be considered breaking if the property occurs in responses.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to versioning name pattern?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to versioning name pattern?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to versioning name pattern?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe released a preview version of our API and found that the pattern being enforced on some of the model properties was too restrictive.  We wanted to relax them, but it doesn't seem I can do that with the added/removed decorators unless I change the name of the property.  Is there anything I'm missing or this is how it must be done?\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@removed(Microsoft.IoTFirmwareDefense.Versions.v2025_06_01)\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Firmware vendor.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z0-9][a-zA-Z0-9-_.,'\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"~=(){}:]*$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nvendor?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou, 1 second ago \\u00b7 Uncommitted changes\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(Microsoft.IoTFirmwareDefense.Versions.v2025_06_01)\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Firmware vendor.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nvendor?: string;    Model already has a property named vendor\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIt's possible to version this, but it involves a remove/rename/replace pattern which is not recommand, and you would need to version the resource and all its operations.\\\\r\\\\nIt is better and more accurate to just make the constraint change for all versions. Because constraints usually don't change for only a single api-version, but for all versions in the service\\\\r\\\\nYou should double confirm if you relaxe this pattern across all api-versions in your service, or just the new api-version.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#reproducibility.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Reproducibility\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/reproducibility\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Reproducibility\\\\n# handbook#reproducibility.md\\\\n\\\\n# Reproducibility\\\\n\\\\nA crucial aspect of service definition is ensuring consistent output over time. This is important in scenarios such as:\\\\r\\\\n- An update to a dependency or sub-dependency introduces an unexpected breaking change.\\\\r\\\\n- Updates to a new version of a service should not impact older versions.\\\\r\\\\n- Modifications are made to the TypeSpec specification.\\\\r\\\\nThese issues can be mitigated with a few precautionary measures:\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Defend against dependency changes\\\\n\\\\n_Note: This section applies if using `tsp install` or `npm install` to install dependencies. However other package managers (`yarn`, `pnpm`, etc.) have their own similar lock mechanisms._\\\\r\\\\nWhen using `tsp install` or `npm install` a `package-lock.json` will be installed. This file SHOULD be committed to source control. It will ensure that later calls to `tsp install` or `npm install` will use the exact versions resolved in the lock files unless the `package.json` was updated or a command like `npm update` was run.\\\\r\\\\nThe command `npm ci` can also be used in the CI to ensure that the `package.json` and `package-lock.json` are in sync.\\\\n\\\\n## 2. Work with multiple versions of a service\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provides a library `@typespec/versioning` that can be used to describe changes to a service or library over time. Using this will ensure that a service can evolve while keeping track of the changes and allowing emitters to see the service representation at different versions.\\\\r\\\\n[See versioning docs](../libraries/versioning/reference/index.mdx)\\\\n\\\\n## 3. Change to the TypeSpec spec\\\\n\\\\nIf you don't directly control the spec, you might still want to make sure you remember which exact definition was used.\\\\r\\\\nUsing version control and pinning to a specific commit SHA will ensure that the spec will remain exactly as it was.\\\\n\\\\n## Summary\\\\n\\\\n1. Use `package-lock.json`\\\\r\\\\n2. Use [versioning library](../libraries/versioning/reference/index.mdx)\\\\r\\\\n3. Keep track of commit IDs\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Breaking Change Policy\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/breaking-change-policy\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n## Breaking Change Philosophy\\\\n### Bugs\\\\n# handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n\\\\n## Breaking Change Philosophy\\\\n\\\\n### Bugs\\\\n\\\\nA bug fix that introduces a technically breaking change will not be considered a breaking change for the purposes of TypeSpec versioning if it is clear that the existing behavior was broken or unintended in the first place.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi all.  My team (Microsoft Translator) is trying to update our POST translate call with a breaking change.  The PR is: [Update translate call to 2025-05-01 by SG-MS \\u00b7 Pull Request #33410 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/33410) \\\\r\\\\nThe old version (3.0) is being updated to a new version (2025-05-01-preview).  The big change to our typespec definition is that we will be moving most of the request properties from query parameters to the request body.  In 3.0, the only property in the request body was an array of InputTextItem.  InputTextItem is just a string.  All the other relevant data was passed in as query parameters. \\\\r\\\\nIn 2025-05-01-preview, we want to add a number of additional properties to the request body, so rather than the body consisting of InputTextItem, we want the body to contain a TranslateBody definition, which in turn contains all of our properties.  I'm not sure how to represent this in the tsp files in a compliant way.   \\\\r\\\\nOur translate operation in the routes.tsp file is \\\\r\\\\nop translate is CustomOperation\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n InputTextItem[],\\\\r\\\\n TranslateParameters,\\\\r\\\\n TranslationResult,\\\\r\\\\n ErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\u003e; \\\\r\\\\nThe first member of the template is the request body and I need it to be InputTextItem[] for 3.0 and I need it to be TranslateBody for 2025-05-01-preview.  Otherwise one of them will have the wrong set of arguments.  I considered simply updating InputTextItem to contain all the needed parameters in TranslateBody and then removing the unused ones with @added decorators, but the problem is we have a number of other operators in 2025-05-01-preview which use InputTextItem and require it to be just the text string.   \\\\r\\\\nIs there anyway to have two different translate operations such that one is called by 3.0 and one is called by 2025-05-01-preview?  I think that's what would really get what I need.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nchanges for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe sharedRoute might be sharing the new property to the old versions and not honoring the @added and @removed decorators.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you mark the whole model like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_06_01_preview)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel ManagedServiceIdentityUpdate  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\u2026errors may occur if parts of the model were added in older versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nOne workaround was to use ManagedServiceIdentityProperty instead of Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ManagedServiceIdentity\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nLintDiff errors like AvoidAnonymousTypes seem to be coming from the MSI additionalProperties section. This error wasn\\u2019t there before setting use-read-only-status-schema: true, but it\\u2019s unclear why that config causes it.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWarnings like \\\\\\\"Use the latest version v5 of types.json\\\\\\\" for old API versions or EnumInsteadOfBoolean for new ones can be ignored \\u2014 warnings are not required to change for check-in, only errors.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFalse positives (like Avocado errors) may also occur when using @removed and @added in the same API version \\u2014 especially for preview versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf everything is tagged properly and using the latest compiler version, you should be able to get it approved. After that, just follow the normal PR process (e.g., sign-offs, label like WaitForARMFeedback).\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThere is some documentation on this here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/#converting-an-operation-from-synchronous-to-asynchronous) (this is for ARM, but the same principle applies)\\\\n\\\\nthe post below might be helpful. It also involves adding a \\\\\\\"adding\\\\\\\" a newer API on the same route with different method signature. You'd need to add `@sharedRoute` on both methods and point it to the same route.\\\\r\\\\n[Jocelyn Wei: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustom... | Azure SDK \\\\u003e TypeSpec Discussion | Microsoft Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf@thread.skype/1721233288788?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1721233288788\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=TypeSpec%20Discussion\\\\u0026createdTime=1721233288788):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ntitle: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nquestion:\\\\r\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nI am attempting to follow the playground example here TypeSpec Azure to get past a LintDiff error after adding an MSI to my resource. However, adding the new update model as well as changing the interface from update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003c... to update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003c... is generating breaking changes for older api versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to only change the update is.. for the newest api version? I tried using the @added and @removed decorators but the interface complained about duplicate update.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nSummary of answer:\\\\r\\\\nTo change the update operation from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Breaking Change Policy\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/breaking-change-policy\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n## Categories of Breaking Changes\\\\n### Emitter output\\\\n# handbook#breaking-change-policy.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Breaking Change Policy\\\\n\\\\n## Categories of Breaking Changes\\\\n\\\\n### Emitter output\\\\n\\\\nEmitter output are not guaranteed to be producing the exact same output as the previous version for the same input. A change that is semantically equivalent wouldn't be considered a breaking change by the emitter.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n### 1.1 Motivation\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n\\\\n### 1.1 Motivation\\\\n\\\\nBreaking changes introduce interruptions for our customers and negatively impacts the Azure brand. To maintain customer satisfaction, service teams are strongly encouraged to find other ways to introduce the functionality desired without breaking existing customers. If you believe a breaking change is mandatory, please continue to read the rest of the document on the policy and the process.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Visibility Changes for `nextLink` and `value` Properties\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Visibility Changes for `nextLink` and `value` Properties\\\\n\\\\nFor the `nextLink` and `value` properties of pageable operation response model, some older specifications marked these values as `readOnly`. This has no impact on the API or on SDKs, you can safely ignore this difference in the spec, and any resulting breaking change violation.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n### 1.3 Purpose\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Policy Overview and Motivation\\\\n\\\\n### 1.3 Purpose\\\\n\\\\nThe purpose of the policy outlined here is to enable breaking changes while limiting the negative impact to Azure customers. There are times when an Azure service team will want to introduce a breaking change typically to fix some security-related issue or to alter how something existing works in order to introduce some new functionality.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 3. Detailed Breaking Change Process\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 3. Detailed Breaking Change Process\\\\n\\\\nService owners should start this process before making any breaking changes. Service owners should plan for at least 6-8 weeks (about 2 months) for the process to be completed. Here are the process steps:\\\\n\\\\n### 1. Intake Preparation (Owner: Service PM)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1-3 days\\\\r\\\\n- Create a new intake using the template for breaking changes: \\\\u003chttps://msazure.visualstudio.com/One/_workitems/create/Scenario?templateld=c815af37-5520-43ff-90c8-d985eaabcb6c\\\\u0026ownerld=85bb92fb-21fe-41ca-9309-47f2c5f57515\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- Save Intake Request as New.\\\\r\\\\n- Please assign the intake to the service owner PM.\\\\r\\\\n- Add the \\\\\\\"Breaking Change\\\\\\\" tag.\\\\r\\\\n- Please ensure your request shows up in the dashboard (\\\\u003chttps://msazure.visualstudio.com/One/_dashboards/dashboard/f7db6895-7137-4695-b3f5-00dc4d36758f\\\\u003e)\\\\r\\\\n- Send email to @azbreakchangereview.\\\\r\\\\n- Attend weekly Office Hours to talk through the breaking change and seek approval. The office hours are on Mondays, 10 AM to 11 AM Pacific Time. Meeting details can be found here.\\\\n\\\\n### 2. Intake Evaluation (Owner: Service PM/Breaking Change review board)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1-2 weeks\\\\r\\\\n- Validate high-level business justification.\\\\r\\\\n- What is the proposal that is being reviewed?\\\\r\\\\n- Why do you need this breaking change?\\\\r\\\\n- What will your team do if the breaking change is not approved? There is a high chance the breaking change will NOT be approved.\\\\r\\\\n- Customer experience impact.\\\\r\\\\n- Number of customers affected.\\\\r\\\\n- How can you reduce the impact on customers?\\\\n\\\\n### 3. Intake decision (Owner: Breaking change Review Board)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1-3 days\\\\r\\\\n- Reviewing all the information, the Breaking Change Review Board will decide whether to approve the proposal, change it, or disapprove it.\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Intake approval from Azure REST API board (Owner: Service PM)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 1 week\\\\r\\\\n- Once approved by the Breaking Change Review Board, status of the intake will be marked as approved by the Breaking Change Review Board.\\\\r\\\\n- If there is an SDK impact- then the proposal should be reviewed by API board to seek approval. Reference the API Breaking change documentation: \\\\u003chttps://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/Guidelines.md#api-changes-that-require-a-version-change\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- Engage the SDK team and the SDK Review board to minimize the impact on client libraries.\\\\r\\\\n- Service teams should not implement the change until all approvals have been received.\\\\n\\\\n### 5. Communication Readiness (Owner: Service PM/Azure Marketing/CSS)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 2-6 weeks\\\\r\\\\n- Service team owners will need to work with Azure PMM/ Service PM/ Sharon Loh (Breaking change Team - Marketing) - to lock on communication template. If breaking change impacts more than 20,000 subscription IDs, the customer email will be reviewed by assigned editorial team and needs marketing GM and at least one marketing CVP approval. This process will take 2 to 4 weeks.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage MS DOC team to update content.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage Business planning team to update price, if appropriate\\\\r\\\\n- Engage assigned Azure PMM to update marketing assets and ACOM.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage Comms Team for avoiding negative press. (If needed)\\\\r\\\\n- Engage Azure portal team to update content or add banner.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage CSS for awareness into this breaking change being shared with customers.\\\\r\\\\n- Engage with CXP (Doug Miller) to schedule communication to customers.\\\\n\\\\n### 6. Signoff/Approval (Owner: Service PM/ APEX Retirements team)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** 2-3 weeks (in parallel with communication readiness)\\\\r\\\\n- A signoff sheet for the breaking change request will be created.\\\\r\\\\n- Service teams will need to get all signoffs including their service CVP.\\\\r\\\\n- APEX Retirements team will help with Office of CTO sign offs.\\\\n\\\\n### 7. Communication update (Owner: Service PM/ CXP)\\\\n\\\\n**Estimated time:** Quarterly on preset schedule (Feb, June, Aug, Nov)\\\\r\\\\n- Azure updates\\\\r\\\\n- Email comms to customers.\\\\r\\\\n- Communication rhythm: 3 years, 2 years, 1 year, 6 months, 90 days (about 3 months), 30 days (about 4 and a half weeks), then weekly until T-O.\\\\r\\\\n- Service health notification in-product messaging.\\\\n\\\\n### 3.1 Signoff Criteria\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes the sign offs required for a breaking change that has been approved but not yet communicated.\\\\r\\\\n| Sequence | Criteria | Owner | Guidance |\\\\r\\\\n|----------|----------|-------|----------|\\\\r\\\\n| 1 | Breaking change Request completed | Service Owner PM | \\u2022 Azure Dev Ops Intake for breaking changes (\\\\u003chttps://msazure.visualstudio.com/One/_workitems/create/Scenario?templateld=d1c215ec-5d6a-4cb3-a193-95ddd0a1ba96\\\\u0026ownerld=85bb92fb-21fe-41ca-9309-47f2c5f57515\\\\u003e) filed with business justification, details of the breaking change.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Timing of the breaking change implementation. Adherence to the policy.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Customer impact identified (Total customers, S500 Customer impact)\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Migration plan documented. |\\\\r\\\\n| 2 | Breaking Change Approval | Azbreakchange review (Jeffrey Richter/Srikanth Mantha) | \\u2022 Sign off from the Breaking change review board for approval. API and SDK impacts also reviewed and signed off. |\\\\r\\\\n| 3 | Review draft for external communications | Laurel Martinez | \\u2022 Program Manager and assigned Azure PMM to create draft customer email based on MS DOC.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Works with PM and Azure PMM to review draft email communication.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 If breaking change impacts over 20,000 subscription IDs and above. PM to create an email intake form (\\\\u003chttps://cxpservicecomms.azurewebsites.net/\\\\u003e). Send approved draft email to editorial team for review, follow by GM and two CVPs review. Please allow 2 to 4 weeks for this process to be completed. Once approved, send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool to schedule publication.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 If breaking change impacts fewer than 20,000 subscription IDs, PM to send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool (\\\\u003chttps://cxpservicecomms.azurewebsites.net/\\\\u003e).\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 PM to share approved email on Azure updates on ACOM |\\\\r\\\\n| 4 | Customer communication planned | Doug Miller | \\u2022 Customer communications planned and ready to send on pre described date. |\\\\r\\\\n| 5 | CVP Of the Group requesting the retirement/Breaking change | Service Owner PM |\\\\n\\\\ndraft to Azure CXP email tool to schedule publication.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 If breaking change impacts fewer than 20,000 subscription IDs, PM to send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool (\\\\u003chttps://cxpservicecomms.azurewebsites.net/\\\\u003e).\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 PM to share approved email on Azure updates on ACOM |\\\\r\\\\n| 4 | Customer communication planned | Doug Miller | \\u2022 Customer communications planned and ready to send on pre described date. |\\\\r\\\\n| 5 | CVP Of the Group requesting the retirement/Breaking change | Service Owner PM | \\u2022 PM to drive the sign-off with the CVP to the group requesting the change.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Send CVP Link to the sign-off sheet for recording their Sign Off.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 PM can also attach Email confirmation from CVP to the Sign off sheet. |\\\\r\\\\n| 6 | CSS Support readiness | Alex Lagerkrans-Pandey | \\u2022 CSS readiness with update.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 All prior steps must be completed.\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\u2022 Only after this approval can communication be started. TypeKits that are only available through experimental subpaths may be broken without a major version update, but TypeKits that are available by default may be considered highly stable.\\\\n\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are stable core APIs and language features that\\\\r\\\\n  define fundamental semantics and will not be broken without a major version update. We recommend\\\\r\\\\n  that library authors depend on these APIs.\\\\r\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 1\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"caution\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are APIs that have very limited use cases and may\\\\r\\\\n  be broken without a major version update. We recommend that library authors avoid depending on\\\\r\\\\n  these APIs.\\\\r\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 2\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"danger\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are internal APIs intended only for use by the\\\\r\\\\n  TypeSpec compiler and core libraries. Consuming these APIs is _at your own risk_!\\\\r\\\\n- \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 3\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"note\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e: These are APIs and language features that don't describe\\\\r\\\\n  semantically meaningful information, but provide information that emitters and libraries may\\\\r\\\\n  choose to use and may introduce changes in emitter output when the features are changed. For\\\\r\\\\n  example: formatting.\\\\r\\\\n| Example                                       | Tier                                 | Description\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| TypeKits                                      | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e | TypeKits are the recommend way to expose APIs from a library. TypeKits that are only available through experimental subpaths may be broken without a major version update, but TypeKits that are available by default may be considered highly stable.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| Additional library helper functions           | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e | Helper and metadata accessor functions exported from the public surface of the compiler or a TypeSpec library are generally considered stable unless otherwise specified or only exported through an experimental subpath.\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| TypeSpec AST (`Node`)                         | \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"1\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"caution\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e | The TypeSpec abstract syntax tree may change at any time. **Note**: this is not the same thing as the _type graph_ (`Type` and its variants), which is a \\\\u003cBadge text=\\\\\\\"Tier 0\\\\\\\" variant=\\\\\\\"success\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e, stable feature; this only applies to `Node` and its variants. The only sanctioned reason for using the AST is for some syntax based linting rule or writing codefixes. Libraries depend on the abstract syntax tree _at their own risk_!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         \\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-BreakingChanges.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Docs\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-BreakingChanges\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Docs\\\\n# Swagger-BreakingChanges.md\\\\n\\\\n# Docs\\\\n\\\\nhttps://aka.ms/CPEXBreakingChangesProcess\\\\r\\\\nhttps://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-brch-deep\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 4. Notes\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 4. Notes\\\\n\\\\n- Please note the following are currently not in scope of the policy: non-Azure service changes; Email communication- template changes.\\\\r\\\\n- Currently in discussion: Compute policy related to breaking changes related to VMs/Hardware.\\\\r\\\\n- For Preview versions, leverage the following guidance:\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n\\\\nIn this section, we'll focus on implementing versioning in your REST API. Versioning allows you to manage changes to your API over time without breaking existing clients. We'll introduce the `@versioned` decorator, show how to define versions with enums, and demonstrate how to use the `@added` decorator to specify version-specific models and operations.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## 5. Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 5. Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n\\\\nconsidered breaking and must be avoided.\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's schema (which spans all api-versions) must be taken with great care. Any new fields must be removed when responding to an old client. Also, old clients may update the resource which may delete fields added by a newer client. For version/state resiliency, we recommend using PATCH (with JSON merge patch) instead of PUT (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PFK6RRTwXCg\\\\u003e).\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's field constraints is also problematic. For example: Changing a string's maximum length is a breaking change because a new client could set a long string and an old client can't get/set it back.\\\\n\\\\nThis document informs Azure service teams of the impact to customers when making service changes and versioning. For more information, please see this video (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bG984__6dSO\\\\u0026list=PL9XzOCngAkqs4m0XdULJu_78nM3Ok3Q65\\\\u0026index=14\\\\u003e).\\\\r\\\\nThe two tables below describe what kind of changes a service can make in a new api-version or after a breaking change review. The tables focus on service API contracts, are not exhaustive, and do not address service behavior changes.\\\\r\\\\nAzure requires that any API contract change requires a new api-version; some footnotes (below) allow a few exceptions here. Failure to change the service's API contract without a new api-version can cause confusion especially if the new features are not rolled out to all clouds before documented to users. Here are some examples that cause confusion (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bG984_L6dSO\\\\u0026list=PL9XzOCngAkqs4m0XdULJu_78nM3Ok3Q65\\\\u0026index=14\\\\u003e):\\\\r\\\\n- Customers can't tell from a specific api-version's documentation whether it includes a new feature or not.\\\\r\\\\n- Azure support can't know if an api-version honors a new feature or not to help customers.\\\\r\\\\n- Customers can tell if a version of an SDK client library supports a new feature or not.\\\\r\\\\nSome additional notes about the sections below:\\\\r\\\\n- Renaming a query parameter/header/field is equivalent to removing it and adding a new one. So, renames are always considered breaking and must be avoided.\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's schema (which spans all api-versions) must be taken with great care. Any new fields must be removed when responding to an old client. Also, old clients may update the resource which may delete fields added by a newer client. For version/state resiliency, we recommend using PATCH (with JSON merge patch) instead of PUT (\\\\u003chttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PFK6RRTwXCg\\\\u003e).\\\\r\\\\n- Changing a resource's field constraints is also problematic.\\\\n\\\\n### Table 1: Changes requiring a new api-version of the service\\\\n\\\\n| Change | Why this change is non-breaking for old clients |\\\\r\\\\n|--------|------------------------------------------------|\\\\r\\\\n| Add an extensible enum (string) value | Clients see this as a string value. Docs for this property must indicate that previously undocumented values might be returned someday to old clients so customer code is written properly to deal with the unexpected new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Add optional input | Clients using older api-version never send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add optional output\\u00b9 | Clients using older api-version should never receive this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add required output | Clients using older api-version should never receive this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new input-only enum value | Clients using older api-version never send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add body content-type (ex: application/json) | Clients using older api-version never send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new path/operation\\u00b9 | Clients using older api-version never invoke this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add protocol (ex: http) | Clients using older api-version never use this |\\\\r\\\\n\\u00b9 Except for a nextLink property that enables pagination; See Table 2.\\\\n\\\\n### Table 2: Changes requiring a review with Azure's Breaking Change Review Board\\\\n\\\\nvalue |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code | Old client has no code to handle new response code |\\\\r\\\\n| Modify path/operation Id | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method name |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove protocol (ex: http) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n\\u00b2 Removing an extensible enum value typically happens when a service retires some feature (like a VM SKU). Retirements must be discussed with Azure Retirements Reviewers (\\\\u003chttps://dev.azure.com/msazure/AzureWiki/_wiki/wikis/AzureWiki.wiki/88597/Azure-Retirement-Policy-and-Process\\\\u003e). Based on the outcome this breaking change may be doable in a new api-version of the service. And, in some extreme cases, this breaking change may be doable in an existing api-version.\\\\n\\\\n**NOTE:** These changes are strongly discouraged:\\\\r\\\\n| Change | Why this change is breaking for old clients |\\\\r\\\\n|--------|---------------------------------------------|\\\\r\\\\n| Add pagination support | Old client expects response to include all results and will only ever see 1st page |\\\\r\\\\n| Add required input | Old client doesn't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output | Old client always sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new output enum value | Old client will crash when deserializing |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output enum value | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove extensible enum (string) value\\u00b2 | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input from optional to required | Old clients don't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change output from optional to required | New client doesn't expect nullable field (for some language SDKs) |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input/output required to optional | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameters |\\\\r\\\\n| Change case (ex: RBAC to Rbac) | Old client sends wrong case |\\\\r\\\\n| Change format (ex: minutes to time) | Old client can't parse new format |\\\\r\\\\n| Change data type (ex: bool to string) | Old client can't parse new type's value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen input integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client doesn't expect larger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen output integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Narrow input/output integer (ex: Int64 to Int32) | New service loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Strengthen input constraint (ex: max value 5 to 4) | Old client sends bigger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\\\\n\\\\nhere's a Properties\\\\n### Required and Optional properties and Property Defaults\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-type.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Types\\\\n\\\\n## Designing Resource-specific Properties\\\\n\\\\n### Required and Optional properties and Property Defaults\\\\n\\\\nIn the examples, note that some model properties use the optional operator `?` after the property name, like `biography?` and some do not, like `title`. Property names using the `?` are optional properties, which may or may not be provided in the request body for CreateOrUpdate (PUT) requests. Property names without the `?` are required properties, which must be provided in PUT requests. The exception is that properties that have 'readOnly' visibility do not appear in requests, but may be required or optional in responses.\\\\r\\\\nAlso note that optional properties may specify defaults, as with `biography?: string = \\\\\\\"No biography provided\\\\\\\"`. The default indicates the value that will be recorded on the server if no value is sent by the client.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#patch-resource.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Patch Resource #\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/patch-resource.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Patch Resource #\\\\n## Rules ##\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n# v1.0#patch-resource.md\\\\n\\\\n# Patch Resource #\\\\n\\\\n## Rules ##\\\\n\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n\\\\nProviding support for `Patch` for as many properties as possible helps avoid accidental and unintentional updates to other properties that need not be touched. Only the property set that really needs an update are specified in a `Patch` payload thereby limiting the surface area of any potential impact. Violating these rules result in APIs across Azure becoming inconsistent with each other. Such inconsistencies degrade customer experience as they now have to deal with slightly different behaviors while interacting with each Resource Provider. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n| RPC Guideline code | Title | Conformance level | Additional impact |  Applicable scope | Linter rule |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-01 | The request body **must** contain at least one or more properties. These properties must always be present in the request and response bodies of the corresponding put operation for same resource type. | Required | Not specifying any properties in the request body for a `Patch` operation serves no purpose for your customers. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-properties-correspond-to-put-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-02 | A `Patch` operation must not update the `id`, `name`, `type`, `location`, or `properties.provisioningState` of the resource and so these properties must not be marked as updatable in the request body of the `Patch` operation. | Required | These properties are deemed either readOnly or immutable and therefore not updatable. These properties may be defined in the request body of the `Patch` operation and if so, they **must** be marked as readOnly or immutable as appropriate. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/un-supported-patch-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-03 | Every **Tracked** resource type **must** support a **Patch** operation for the `tags` property. | Required |\\\\n\\\\nare deemed either readOnly or immutable and therefore not updatable. These properties may be defined in the request body of the `Patch` operation and if so, they **must** be marked as readOnly or immutable as appropriate. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/un-supported-patch-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-03 | Every **Tracked** resource type **must** support a **Patch** operation for the `tags` property. | Required | ARM exposes a centralized API to customers that allow them to update the `tags` property for any tracked resource. The implementation in ARM relies on the existence of a `Patch` operation is the Resource provider service to accomplish this. So not having a `Patch` operation for the `tags` property breaks this platform feature for customers. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/tracked-resource-patch-operation.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-04 | When Tags are patched, the tags from the request replace all existing tags for the resource | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-05 | When patching fields inside the properties envelope, Resource providers **must** follow JSON merge-patch (RFC 7396[https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396]) | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-06 | Resource Providers **must** respond with status Code 200 if the operation is synchronous and 202 if the operation is asynchronous. Additionally, the 200 status code **must** also be specified in the Open API specification for asynchronous `Patch` operations. This is to allow the generated SDKs to discover the schema for deserializing the final response of the long running operation. | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-response-codes.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-07 |\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-11 | Resource providers may implement `Patch` for the Identity property if the service allows it to be updated. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-identity-property.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-12 | Every `Patch ` request **must** have a request body. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/request-body-must-exist-for-put-patch.md) |\\\\n\\\\nis synchronous and 202 if the operation is asynchronous. Additionally, the 200 status code **must** also be specified in the Open API specification for asynchronous `Patch` operations. This is to allow the generated SDKs to discover the schema for deserializing the final response of the long running operation. | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-response-codes.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-07 | Resource providers **must** respond with status Code 404 if the resource group or resource does not exist. | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-08 | Response body **should** contain the updated resource with the request payload of the `Patch` request applied. | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-09 | Resource providers may implement `Patch` for the SKU property | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-sku-property.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-10 | Use Patch only to partially update the resource. Use a `Put` operation for replacing the entire resource. Do not specify required or default properties in the request payload of a `Patch` operation. | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-body-parameters-schema.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-11 | Resource providers may implement `Patch` for the Identity property if the service allows it to be updated. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-identity-property.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-12 | Every `Patch ` request **must** have a request body. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation]\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#resource-type.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"ARM Resource Types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/resource-type\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# ARM Resource Types\\\\n## Designing Resource-specific Properties\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-type.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Types\\\\n\\\\n## Designing Resource-specific Properties\\\\n\\\\nEach resource model consists of two distinct parts\\\\r\\\\n- An outer _envelope_ of information that provides metadata for optional standardized ARM functionality, like entity-tags and managed identities, and is processed by Azure Resource Manager.\\\\r\\\\n- An inner set of properties that are specific to the resource and are defined by the resource provider.\\\\r\\\\nModifying the ARM envelope is discussed in later sections on [mixing in standard ARM envelope add-ons](#adding-optional-standard-envelope-properties).\\\\r\\\\nThe inner _rp-specific property bag_ consists of all of the properties that the RP needs to manage about the resource. Properties should be completely specified, should not duplicate properties from the _ARM envelope_, and may consist of simple types, arrays, or other complex properties.\\\\r\\\\nHere is an example of a property bag for the `EmployeeResource` resource.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeResource is TrackedResource\\\\u003cEmployeeProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The employee name, using 'Firstname Lastname' notation */\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"employees\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"employeeName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nunion EmployeeProvisioningState {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource create request has been accepted */\\\\r\\\\n  Accepted: \\\\\\\"Accepted\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being provisioned */\\\\r\\\\n  Provisioning: \\\\\\\"Provisioning\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is updating */\\\\r\\\\n  Updating: \\\\\\\"Updating\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource has been created. */\\\\r\\\\n  Succeeded: \\\\\\\"Succeeded\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource creation failed. */\\\\r\\\\n  Failed: \\\\\\\"Failed\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource creation was canceled. */\\\\r\\\\n  Canceled: \\\\\\\"Canceled\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being deleted */\\\\r\\\\n  Deleting: \\\\\\\"Deleting\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@minValue(50)\\\\r\\\\n@maxValue(70)\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeLevel extends int32;\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeResourceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.HR/employees\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@secret\\\\r\\\\nscalar Password extends string;\\\\r\\\\nmodel Job {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  companyName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  start: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  end: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  role: string;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"Failed\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Resource creation was canceled. */\\\\r\\\\n  Canceled: \\\\\\\"Canceled\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being deleted */\\\\r\\\\n  Deleting: \\\\\\\"Deleting\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@minValue(50)\\\\r\\\\n@maxValue(70)\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeLevel extends int32;\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeResourceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.HR/employees\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@secret\\\\r\\\\nscalar Password extends string;\\\\r\\\\nmodel Job {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  companyName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  start: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  end: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  role: string;\\\\r\\\\n  notes?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The current title of the employee */\\\\r\\\\n  title: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  level: EmployeeLevel;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  employeeId: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  biography?: string = \\\\\\\"No biography provided\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  colleagues: EmployeeResourceId[];\\\\r\\\\n  employmentHistory: Job[];\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  password: Password;\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: EmployeeProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`EmployeeProperties` specifies the employee metadata that the RP needs to track and manage. Notice that the model uses built-in scalar types like `string` and `int32`, new types built from scalar types with added constraints, like `Password` and `EmployeeLevel`, enumerations of values, like `EmployeeProvisioningState`, and complex types. The individual components of this model are described below.\\\\r\\\\nNote that _documentation comments on all models and model properties are required when specs are checked in_. Here they are omitted for clarity. The TypeSpec compiler and TypeSpec IDE tooling will emit warning diagnostics if you emit required documentation, and about most of the ARM rules described in this document.\\\\n\\\\n### The `provisioningState` Property for Tracked Resources\\\\n\\\\nAll Tracked Resources are required to implement a 'provisioningState' property in their rp-specific property bag. This is used by ARM and some ARM clients to track the provisioning state of a resource as it is created and deleted. At minimum, the provisioning state must contain the standard terminal values that ARM is looking for. There are contained in the `ResourceProvisioningState` enumeration in the Azure.ResourceManager library. If RPs have other provisioning states they would like to track, they can define their own provisioning state enum, and mix in the value, as shown in the sample above, or they may simply use the standard provisioning state as shown in the sample below:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel ResourceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNote that this example uses the spread operator `...`, which allows you to simply include the properties from a source model in the target model you are constructing. This has the effect of copying the properties of the source model and their decorations into the target model, without creating any nominal inheritance relationship.\\\\r\\\\nAlternately, this is also equivalent:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel ResourceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last provisioning operation performed on the resource. */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ResourceProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Required and Optional properties and Property Defaults\\\\n\\\\nIn the examples, note that some model properties use the optional operator `?` after the property name, like `biography?` and some do not, like `title`. Property names using the `?` are optional properties, which may or may not be provided in the request body for CreateOrUpdate (PUT) requests. Property names without the `?` are required properties, which must be provided in PUT requests. The exception is that properties that have 'readOnly' visibility do not appear in requests, but may be required or optional in responses.\\\\r\\\\nAlso note that optional properties may specify defaults, as with `biography?: string = \\\\\\\"No biography provided\\\\\\\"`. The default indicates the value that will be recorded on the server if no value is sent by the client.\\\\n\\\\n### Defining Custom Types\\\\n\\\\nIn the sample, new constrained scalar types and new complex model types are defined and used inside the _rp-specific property bag_. TypeSpec allows you to define custom types for use in your specification.\\\\r\\\\nYou will often want to define scalar types or properties that have constraints. For example, numeric values may be constrained to have a certain minimum or maximum, strign values may be constrained to follow a particular regex pattern, and so on. Whenever these constrained types are used in your spec, the constraints will be transmitted to the usage.\\\\r\\\\nThe example creates a numeric type with minimum and maximum constraints:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@minValue(50)\\\\r\\\\n@maxValue(70)\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeLevel extends int32;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis defines 'EmployeeLevel' as an integer value between 50 and 70. The example also defines a complex type used in an array:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Job {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  companyName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  start: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  end: plainDate;\\\\r\\\\n  role: string;\\\\r\\\\n  notes?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nMode details on what to consider when using complex types in an array are discussed in the section on [modeling arrays of complex types](#modeling-arrays-of-complex-types).\\\\n\\\\n### Using Resource identifiers\\\\n\\\\nIt is often the case that resources need to reference other resources to provide specific pieces of functionality. For example, resources may need to reference a storage account to use for storing user data, or a NIC to attach to a Network. The `Azure.ResourceManager` library defines a `ResourceIdentifier` template that allows you to easily represent references to resources in your API. The template allows you to specify one or more acceptable resource types, automatically designating the value as a resource reference, and providing the appropriate pattern validation - which helps in generating better code, better ARM templates, and better documentation for your API.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nscalar EmployeeResourceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.HR/employees\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nscalar NetworkInterfaceId\\\\r\\\\n  extends Azure.Core.armResourceIdentifier\\\\u003c[\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.ClassicNetwork/networkInterfaces\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe `NetworkInterfaceId example shows how to allow multiple resource types in a reference.\\\\n\\\\n### Property Visibility and Other Constraints\\\\n\\\\nThe sample uses the `@visibility` decorator to indicate how the resource definition is used in requests to PUT and PATCH operations, and in responses to PUT, PATCH, GET, and LIST operations.\\\\r\\\\nThis table shows how visibility is used to determine whether a property is used in requests and responses:\\\\r\\\\n| Visibility           | In Create Request? | In Patch Request/ Updateable in PUT | In Responses | Sample                                         |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------- | ------------------ | ----------------------------------- | ------------ | ---------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| None                 | Yes                | Yes                                 | Yes          | Most properties                                |\\\\r\\\\n| read, create, update | Yes                | Yes                                 | Yes          | Most properties                                |\\\\r\\\\n| read, create         | Yes                | No                                  | Yes          | resource location                              |\\\\r\\\\n| read, update         | No                 | Yes                                 | Yes          | Properties only settable after creation (keys) |\\\\r\\\\n| create, update       | Yes                | Yes                                 | No           | Secrets (e.g. password)                        |\\\\r\\\\n| read                 | No                 | No                                  | Yes          | Calculated properties, e.g. provisioning\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM.Legacy.Extension-Operations-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.Extension Operations Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.Extension Operations Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 3. CustomPatchAsync\\\\n### Swagger Output\\\\n# TypeSpec-ARM.Legacy.Extension-Operations-Documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.Extension Operations Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n\\\\n## 3. CustomPatchAsync\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\nA long-running resource update using a custom PATCH payload (Asynchronous) for extension resources.\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n```typespec\\\\r\\\\nop customPatch is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.Extension.CustomPatchAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n  VirtualMachine,\\\\r\\\\n  VmExtension,\\\\r\\\\n  VmExtensionPatch,\\\\r\\\\n  LroHeaders\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n### Swagger Output\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"patch\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"operationId\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Extensions_CustomPatch\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"tags\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"Extensions\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    ],\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Update a VmExtension\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"parameters\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v5/types.json#/parameters/ApiVersionParameter\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"vmName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": true,\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"extensionName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": true,\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"body\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The resource properties to be updated.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n successfully.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"schema\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/VmExtension\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        }\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n
