Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Converting Synchronous Operations to LROs\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Converting Synchronous Operations to LROs\\\\n\\\\nYou can generally choose an asynchronous operation template that matches your operation.\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PUT Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains a `Location` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains an `Azure-AsyncOperation` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PATCH Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmTagsPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that only allows changing the resource tags (the minimum for Azure Resource Manager).\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmTagsPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourcePatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that uses the visibility settings to select properties for the PATCH request body (any property with no visibility setting, or including visibility \\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\"). It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation.\\\\n\\\\nthe `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation. It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuff is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no request body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffNoRequest is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, void, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no response body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffCommand is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, void\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async DELETE Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, will return a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, and returns a `200` response in the case of a successful synchronous delete, a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi all.  My team (Microsoft Translator) is trying to update our POST translate call with a breaking change.  The PR is: [Update translate call to 2025-05-01 by SG-MS \\u00b7 Pull Request #33410 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/33410) \\\\r\\\\nThe old version (3.0) is being updated to a new version (2025-05-01-preview).  The big change to our typespec definition is that we will be moving most of the request properties from query parameters to the request body.  In 3.0, the only property in the request body was an array of InputTextItem.  InputTextItem is just a string.  All the other relevant data was passed in as query parameters. \\\\r\\\\nIn 2025-05-01-preview, we want to add a number of additional properties to the request body, so rather than the body consisting of InputTextItem, we want the body to contain a TranslateBody definition, which in turn contains all of our properties.  I'm not sure how to represent this in the tsp files in a compliant way.   \\\\r\\\\nOur translate operation in the routes.tsp file is \\\\r\\\\nop translate is CustomOperation\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n InputTextItem[],\\\\r\\\\n TranslateParameters,\\\\r\\\\n TranslationResult,\\\\r\\\\n ErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\u003e; \\\\r\\\\nThe first member of the template is the request body and I need it to be InputTextItem[] for 3.0 and I need it to be TranslateBody for 2025-05-01-preview.  Otherwise one of them will have the wrong set of arguments.  I considered simply updating InputTextItem to contain all the needed parameters in TranslateBody and then removing the unused ones with @added decorators, but the problem is we have a number of other operators in 2025-05-01-preview which use InputTextItem and require it to be just the text string.   \\\\r\\\\nIs there anyway to have two different translate operations such that one is called by 3.0 and one is called by 2025-05-01-preview?  I think that's what would really get what I need.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nchanges for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe sharedRoute might be sharing the new property to the old versions and not honoring the @added and @removed decorators.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you mark the whole model like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_06_01_preview)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel ManagedServiceIdentityUpdate  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\u2026errors may occur if parts of the model were added in older versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nOne workaround was to use ManagedServiceIdentityProperty instead of Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ManagedServiceIdentity\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nLintDiff errors like AvoidAnonymousTypes seem to be coming from the MSI additionalProperties section. This error wasn\\u2019t there before setting use-read-only-status-schema: true, but it\\u2019s unclear why that config causes it.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWarnings like \\\\\\\"Use the latest version v5 of types.json\\\\\\\" for old API versions or EnumInsteadOfBoolean for new ones can be ignored \\u2014 warnings are not required to change for check-in, only errors.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFalse positives (like Avocado errors) may also occur when using @removed and @added in the same API version \\u2014 especially for preview versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf everything is tagged properly and using the latest compiler version, you should be able to get it approved. After that, just follow the normal PR process (e.g., sign-offs, label like WaitForARMFeedback).\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThere is some documentation on this here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/#converting-an-operation-from-synchronous-to-asynchronous) (this is for ARM, but the same principle applies)\\\\n\\\\nthe post below might be helpful. It also involves adding a \\\\\\\"adding\\\\\\\" a newer API on the same route with different method signature. You'd need to add `@sharedRoute` on both methods and point it to the same route.\\\\r\\\\n[Jocelyn Wei: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustom... | Azure SDK \\\\u003e TypeSpec Discussion | Microsoft Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf@thread.skype/1721233288788?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1721233288788\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=TypeSpec%20Discussion\\\\u0026createdTime=1721233288788):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ntitle: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nquestion:\\\\r\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nI am attempting to follow the playground example here TypeSpec Azure to get past a LintDiff error after adding an MSI to my resource. However, adding the new update model as well as changing the interface from update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003c... to update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003c... is generating breaking changes for older api versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to only change the update is.. for the newest api version? I tried using the @added and @removed decorators but the interface complained about duplicate update.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nSummary of answer:\\\\r\\\\nTo change the update operation from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"ARM Resource Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/resource-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n### Determining Which Resource Properties Appear in Lifecycle Operations\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n\\\\n### Determining Which Resource Properties Appear in Lifecycle Operations\\\\n\\\\nBy default, any property that occurs in your resource model will also appear in the response to GET,\\\\r\\\\nPUT, PATCH, and LIST operations, and in the request for PUT and PATCH operations. This does not work\\\\r\\\\nfor all properties. Some properties are calculated by the service and cannot be directly set by PUT\\\\r\\\\nor PATCH (provisioningState, modification date, etc.). Some properties can only be set when creating\\\\r\\\\na resource, but always appear in responses (e.g. 'location'). Some properties can only be set when\\\\r\\\\nupdating the resource, and appear in responses. Some properties (rarely) may be settable when\\\\r\\\\nupdating the resource via PUT or PATCH. To allow using a common resource model, but applying these\\\\r\\\\n`views` of resources to determine how the resource appear in request and responses, TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\nprovides the visibility framework. You can see a complete representation of available visibilities\\\\r\\\\nin the table\\\\r\\\\n[on Property Visibility and Other Constraints](./resource-type.md#property-visibility-and-other-constraints).\\\\r\\\\nThe sections below outline some common scenarios for designing properties with your operations in\\\\r\\\\nmind.\\\\r\\\\n#### Properties That Are Never Directly Set by the User\\\\r\\\\nIt is common to have properties that are calculated by the service or otherwise not directly set by\\\\r\\\\nthe user, examples include timestamps, dates, values that are only set by specific actions (on/off,\\\\r\\\\nenabled/disabled, provisioningState). You want to make sure that these properties are marked so that\\\\r\\\\nthey will appear in responses and not requests. this is done using the `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)`\\\\r\\\\ndecorator instance:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\nprovisioningState: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/azure-core/long-running-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n## Modeling Long-running Operations in TypeSpec\\\\n# howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Modeling Long-running Operations in TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\nThe `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core` library contains specific operation templates for long-running operation patterns recommended by the api review board. Using these templates will ensure that a service has the widest range of compatibility with Azure SDKs and Azure tooling for long-running operations. Service teams **should** use these templates to define their long-running operations. Existing services that have LROs that do not comply with API guidelines should discuss their operations with the Api review board, or the TypeSpec team.\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"Your understanding regarding the breaking change flag for the readonly 'provisioningState' field in the PATCH operation model is correct: removing or not including a readonly field like 'provisioningState' from the PATCH request model (e.g., ConfigurationPropertiesUpdate) should NOT be considered a breaking change. According to Azure and ARM guidelines, readonly properties are not updatable and should not appear in PATCH request bodies. The PATCH model should only include properties that are updatable; readonly fields are only present in responses. If the breaking change tooling is flagging this as a removal, it is a false positive and can be safely ignored for readonly fields in PATCH request models.\\n\\nFor your second question about converting create, update, and delete (CUD) operations to long-running operations (LRO) in a new API version:\\n- Changing CUD operations to LRO in a new API version is allowed and is the recommended approach when new business requirements (like provisioning MRG) require asynchronous processing. This is not considered a breaking change for previous API versions, as long as the change is only present in the new API version and the old versions remain synchronous.\\n- The correct way to implement this in TypeSpec is to use the appropriate Azure Resource Manager LRO operation templates (e.g., ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync, ArmResourcePatchAsync, ArmResourceDeleteAsync) for the new API version. You should use @sharedRoute and @renamedFrom/@removed decorators to ensure the old and new operations are properly versioned and routed, so that clients using older versions continue to see the synchronous behavior, while clients using the new version get the LRO behavior.\\n\\nSummary of recommended actions:\\n1. Do NOT include readonly fields like 'provisioningState' in PATCH request models; ignore breaking change flags for their removal in PATCH models.\\n2. For new API versions, use the ARM LRO operation templates for CUD operations and version your operations using @sharedRoute and @renamedFrom/@removed decorators to avoid breaking changes for older versions.\\n\\nThis approach is fully compliant with Azure API guidelines and ARM resource provider contract requirements.\", \"ground_truth\": \"The 'provisioningState' change in the PATCH request model seems like a bug fix if this field was always read-only.  When you get a breaking change review, if this is explained with an appropriate comment, this is likely to be justified as a bug fix.\\nOn changing PATCH to synchronous.  ARM does support async PATCH operations, although REST API Guidelines discourage async PATCH operations.  If this operation is synchronous in the previous stable version, then this change is a real breaking change that you will need to justify in breaking change review.\\nSimilarly, making PUT and DELETE Asynchronous is a breaking change if these operations were synchronous in the previous stable version is a real breaking change, and you will need to justify the change in a breaking change review.\"}"}]

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: What decorator should be used in this case?\\n\\nquestion: Hi team,\\nIn version v2, we introduced a new model model2 and updated featureA (originally added in v1) to use model2 as its parameter. In v1, featureA used model1 at the same position.\\nHere\\u2019s the setup I tried (using @typeChangedFrom):\\n```\\n@added(v1)\\nmodel1;\\n@added(v2)\\nmodel2;\\n@added(v1)\\nfeatureA {\\n@typeChangedFrom(v1, model1)\\nbody: model2;\\n}\\n```\\nHowever, this shows the error: \\\"model2 does not exist in v1\\\".\\nWhat would be the correct decorator to use in this situation?\\nThank you!\", \"response\": \"The correct usage of the @typeChangedFrom decorator in this scenario is to specify the version where the change occurs (v2), not the previous version (v1). The decorator should indicate that starting from v2, the parameter type changed from model1 to model2. Your current usage incorrectly states that the change happened in v1, which causes the error because model2 does not exist in v1.\\n\\nHere is the corrected TypeSpec code:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@added(v1)\\nmodel1;\\n\\n@added(v2)\\nmodel2;\\n\\n@added(v1)\\nfeatureA {\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v2, model1)\\n  body: model2;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis tells TypeSpec that in v2, the type of 'body' changed from model1 (used in v1) to model2 (introduced in v2). This pattern is compliant with Azure API versioning best practices and will resolve the error you encountered.\", \"ground_truth\": \"it should be `typedChangedFrom(v2, model1)` here otherwise you are saying in v1 you changed from using model1 to model2 which then of course doesn't exists\"}"}]

The decorator should indicate that starting from v2, the parameter type changed from model1 to model2. Your current usage incorrectly states that the change happened in v1, which causes the error because model2 does not exist in v1.\\n\\nHere is the corrected TypeSpec code:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@added(v1)\\nmodel1;\\n\\n@added(v2)\\nmodel2;\\n\\n@added(v1)\\nfeatureA {\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v2, model1)\\n  body: model2;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis tells TypeSpec that in v2, the type of 'body' changed from model1 (used in v1) to model2 (introduced in v2). This pattern is compliant with Azure API versioning best practices and will resolve the error you encountered.\", \"context\": \"[{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What decorator should be used in this case?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team, \\\\r\\\\nIn version v2, we introduced a new model model2 and updated featureA (originally added in v1) to use model2 as its parameter. In v1, featureA used model1 at the same position. \\\\r\\\\nHere\\u2019s the setup I tried (using @typeChangedFrom):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel1;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v2)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel2;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nfeatureA {  \\\\r\\\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v1, model1)  \\\\r\\\\n  body: model2;  \\\\r\\\\n} \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nHowever, this shows the error: \\\\\\\"model2 does not exist in v1\\\\\\\". \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the correct decorator to use in this situation? \\\\r\\\\nThank you!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nit should be `typedChangedFrom(v2, model1` here otherwise you are saying in v1 you changed from using model1 to model2 which then of course doesn't exists\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What decorator should be used in this case?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team, \\\\r\\\\nIn version v2, we introduced a new model model2 and updated featureA (originally added in v1) to use model2 as its parameter. In v1, featureA used model1 at the same position. \\\\r\\\\nHere\\u2019s the setup I tried (using @typeChangedFrom):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel1;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v2)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel2;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nfeatureA {  \\\\r\\\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v1, model1)  \\\\r\\\\n  body: model2;  \\\\r\\\\n} \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nHowever, this shows the error: \\\\\\\"model2 does not exist in v1\\\\\\\". \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the correct decorator to use in this situation? \\\\r\\\\nThank you!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nit should be `typedChangedFrom(v2, model1` here otherwise you are saying in v1 you changed from using model1 to model2 which then of course doesn't exists\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getstarted#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Adding a Resource or Operation\\\\n# getstarted#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Adding a Resource or Operation\\\\n\\\\nTo introduce a new model or operation in a specific version (and all later versions), use the `@added` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n**Add a model in v2:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Add an operation in v2:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"language-basics#decorators.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Decorators\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/decorators\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Decorators\\\\n## Applying decorators\\\\n# language-basics#decorators.md\\\\n\\\\n# Decorators\\\\n\\\\n## Applying decorators\\\\n\\\\nDecorators are referenced using the `@` prefix and must be placed before the entity they are decorating. @madeOptional\\\\n\\\\nUse these decorators to change whether a property is required or optional in a specific version.\\\\r\\\\n- Use `@madeOptional(Versions.version)` to make a property optional starting in that version.\\\\r\\\\n- Use `@madeRequired(Versions.version)` to make a property required starting in that version.\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Changing a property from required to optional, then back to required**\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// v1: movingStatus is required\\\\r\\\\nmodel MoveResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  movingStatus: \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-unknown\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"Suppress no-unknown to handle the datatype object used in dependent service\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress specification\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_06_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  specification?: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_06_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"List of tasks in the stage\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  tasks: TaskSpec[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_06_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"Task option for the Versioning allows you to manage changes to your API over time without breaking existing clients. We'll introduce the `@versioned` decorator, show how to define versions with enums, and demonstrate how to use the `@added` decorator to specify version-specific models and operations.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"language-basics#decorators.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Decorators\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/decorators\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Decorators\\\\n## Augmenting decorators\\\\n# language-basics#decorators.md\\\\n\\\\n# Decorators\\\\n\\\\n## Augmenting decorators\\\\n\\\\nDecorators can also be applied from a different location by referring to the type being decorated. For this, you can declare an augment decorator using the `@@` prefix. The first argument of an augment decorator is the type reference that should be decorated. As the augment decorator is a statement, it must end with a semicolon (`;`).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {}\\\\r\\\\n@@tag(Dog, \\\\\\\"Sample\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is equivalent to:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"Sample\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nExample: decorating a model property to indicate that it is read-only\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@@visibility(Dog.name, Lifecycle.Read);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario demonstrates how to change a decorator\\u2019s usage across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you have a model property with a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the next version (v2), the visibility changes so that the property can be read or created. To achieve this, you can use a combination of `@removed`, `@added`, and `@renamedFrom` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"experience\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldExperience: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@added`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.added) decorator is used to indicate that a model or operation was added in a specific version of the API. This allows you to manage changes and additions to your API over time.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Adding a New Model in a Specific Version\\\\n\\\\nLet's add a `Toy` model that is only available in version 2 of the API:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @minLength(1)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @minValue(0)\\\\r\\\\n  @maxValue(100)\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  kind: petType;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nenum petType {\\\\r\\\\n  dog: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  cat: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  fish: \\\\\\\"fish\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  bird: \\\\\\\"bird\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  reptile: \\\\\\\"reptile\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Toy {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- The `Toy` model is defined with the `@added(Versions.v2)` decorator to indicate that it was added in version 2 of the API.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n\\\\nThese examples show how to add models, operations, properties, and parameters in specific versions using TypeSpec versioning decorators.\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario demonstrates how to change a decorator\\u2019s usage across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you have a model property with a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the next version (v2), the visibility changes so that the property can be read or created. To achieve this, you can use a combination of `@removed`, `@added`, and `@renamedFrom` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"experience\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldExperience: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Adding a Parameter to an Operation and Making Another Parameter Optional\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario shows how to add a parameter and make another optional in an operation.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following operation in v1:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you want to:\\\\r\\\\n- Make the `location` header parameter optional.\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new optional query parameter `orderBy`.\\\\r\\\\nYou can achieve this using the `@madeOptional` and `@added` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @madeOptional(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location?: string;\\\\r\\\\n      @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @query(\\\\\\\"order-by\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n      orderBy?: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@madeOptional(Versions.v2)` makes `location` optional starting in v2.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the `orderBy` query parameter in v2 and later.\\\\n\\\\n### Converting an Operation from Synchronous to Asynchronous\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario illustrates converting a synchronous operation to an asynchronous one across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following synchronous operation in `v1`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you update this operation to be asynchronous as follows:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdateV1 is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@removed(Versions.v2)` removes the original synchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")` keeps the original name for v1.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the new asynchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@sharedRoute` ensures both operations can use the same route.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#05-authentication.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Authentication\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/05-authentication\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# By using the `@useAuth` decorator, we can enforce authentication on specific operations, ensuring that only authorized clients can perform certain actions.\\\\r\\\\nIn the next section, we'll dive into versioning your REST API. Versioning allows you to introduce new features and improvements while maintaining backward compatibility for existing clients.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#examples.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Examples\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/examples\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Examples\\\\n### Type Examples\\\\n# standard-library#examples.md\\\\n\\\\n# Examples\\\\n\\\\n### Type Examples\\\\n\\\\nTo give an example for a type you can use the `@example` decorator. options.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Versioning Decorators\\\\n### @added\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning Decorators\\\\n\\\\n### @added\\\\n\\\\nYou can add new models, properties, or operations in a specific version and all subsequent versions using the `@added` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n- The `version` argument is the version where the element is introduced.\\\\r\\\\n- The element will be present in that version and all later versions.\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Adding a model and property across versions**\\\\r\\\\nFor example, suppose you want to add a new model and then add a property to it in a later version:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// v1: No Employee model exists\\\\r\\\\n// v2: Add Employee model\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v3: Add 'city' property to Employee\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Adding an operation in a later version**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // v3: Add createOrUpdate operation\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Generated Types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/08types\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Generated Types\\\\n## Using `@alternateType` to Reference External Types\\\\n# howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Generated Types\\\\n\\\\n## Using `@alternateType` to Reference External Types\\\\n\\\\nThe `@alternateType` decorator allows you to override the emitted type for a model, union, or enum in generated client libraries. With recent updates, you can now reference types defined in external namespaces or imported libraries.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Referencing an External Type\\\\n\\\\nSuppose you want your generated client library to use a type from an external package instead of the default emitted type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@alternateType(\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    fullyQualifiedName: \\\\\\\"externallib.ExternalModel\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    package: \\\\\\\"externallib\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nmodel MyModel {\\\\r\\\\n  prop: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, instead of generating `MyModel` in the Python sdk, the emitter will reference `ExternalModel` from `externallib` instead.\\\\n\\\\n### Use Cases\\\\n\\\\n- Integrating with shared types from other services or libraries.\\\\r\\\\n- Ensuring consistency across multiple SDKs by reusing common models.\\\\r\\\\n- Reducing duplication when types are already defined elsewhere.\\\\n\\\\n### Notes\\\\n\\\\n- The referenced type should be compatible with the intended usage in the generated client library.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Generated (Legacy)\\\\n# howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Generated Types\\\\n\\\\n## Client Default Values (Legacy)\\\\n\\\\n:::caution\\\\r\\\\nThe `@clientDefaultValue` decorator is legacy functionality that should **only** be used to mitigate SDK breaking changes for brownfield services. **New services should NOT use this decorator.** Instead, use standard TypeSpec patterns for default values.\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\r\\\\nThe `@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.clientDefaultValue` decorator allows you to set a client-level default value for a model property or operation parameter. This is primarily intended for maintaining backward compatibility with existing SDK users who may rely on default values that were previously generated from Swagger definitions.\\\\n\\\\n### Model Property Default Values\\\\n\\\\nUse `@clientDefaultValue` on model properties when you need to specify a default value that will be used in the generated SDK code.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabItem lang=\\\\\\\"typespec\\\\\\\" \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel RequestOptions Versioning\\\\n## Introduction to the `@versioned` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction to the `@versioned` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@versioned`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.versioned) decorator is used to define different versions of your API. This decorator allows you to specify the versions that your API supports and manage changes across these versions.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Defining API Versions\\\\n\\\\nLet's define two versions of our API, `v1` and `v2`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- We're importing and using a new module, `@typespec/versioning`, which provides versioning support.\\\\r\\\\n- The `@versioned` decorator is used to define the versions supported by the API, defined in the `Versions` enum.\\\\r\\\\n- The `Versions` enum specifies two versions: `v1` (1.0) and `v2` (2.0).\\\\n\\\\n### Generating OpenAPI Specifications for Different Versions\\\\n\\\\nOnce versions are added, the TypeSpec compiler generates individual OpenAPI specifications for each version.\\\\r\\\\n{/* prettier-ignore */}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cFileTree\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n- tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n- package.json\\\\r\\\\n- node_modules/\\\\r\\\\n- tsp-output/\\\\r\\\\n  - @typespec/\\\\r\\\\n    - openapi3\\\\r\\\\n      - openapi.1.0.yaml\\\\r\\\\n      - openapi.2.0.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/FileTree\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nGenerating separate specs for each version ensures backward compatibility, provides clear documentation for developers to understand differences between versions, and simplifies maintenance by allowing independent updates to each version's specifications.\\\\r\\\\nBy encapsulating different versions of the API within the context of the same TypeSpec project, we can manage all versions in a unified manner. This approach makes it easier to maintain consistency, apply updates, and ensure that all versions are properly documented and aligned with the overall API strategy.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Adding the Versioning Library\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Adding the Versioning Library\\\\n\\\\nBefore we can use the versioning decorators, we need to add the `@typespec/versioning` library to our project. This involves updating the `package.json` file and installing the necessary dependencies.\\\\n\\\\n### Step 1: Update `package.json`\\\\n\\\\nAdd the `@typespec/versioning` library to your `package.json` file, in both the `peerDependencies` and `devDependencies` sections. Your updated `package.json` should look like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"typespec-petstore\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"version\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"0.1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"module\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"peerDependencies\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/compiler\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    // highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"devDependencies\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/compiler\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    // highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"latest\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"private\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Step 2: Install Dependencies\\\\n\\\\nRun the following command to install the new dependencies:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`sh\\\\r\\\\ntsp install\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-client-libraries#04method.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Code here\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/04method\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Code here\\\\n## Using `@clientLocation` to control parameter placement\\\\n# howtos#generate-client-libraries#04method.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Code here\\\\n\\\\n## Using `@clientLocation` to control parameter placement\\\\n\\\\nThe `@clientLocation` decorator allows you to explicitly move parameters between client and operation levels.\\\\n\\\\n### Moving subscriptionId from client to operation level\\\\n\\\\nsubscription_id: str, extended_zone_name: str, **kwargs) -\\\\u003e MyModel:\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`csharp\\\\r\\\\n// Main client with subscriptionId as client parameter\\\\r\\\\npublic partial class ContosoProviderHubClient\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n    public ContosoProviderHubClient(TokenCredential credential)\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n    public virtual Response\\\\u003cMyModel\\\\u003e Get(string subscriptionId, string extendedZoneName, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default)\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n TokenCredential) {\\\\r\\\\n    ...\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n  async get(subscriptionId: string, extendedZoneName: string): Promise\\\\u003cMyModel\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`java\\\\r\\\\npublic final class ContosoProviderHubClient {\\\\r\\\\n    public ContosoProviderHubClient(TokenCredential credential) {\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n    public MyModel get(String subscriptionId, String extendedZoneName) {\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`go\\\\r\\\\n// NOT_SUPPORTED\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/ClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\n\\\\nIn ARM services, `subscriptionId` is automatically elevated to the client level. By applying `@clientLocation` to `subscriptionId` and explicitly moving it to an operation, you can move it back down to the method-level.\\\\r\\\\nIn the following case, since all instances of the subscription ID parameter have been explicitly moved onto the method-level, there is no longer a subscription ID parameter to the client.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=\\\\\\\"main.tsp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\n@armProviderNamespace\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.ContosoProviderHub;\\\\r\\\\n/** Api versions */\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2024-04-01-preview api version */\\\\r\\\\n  V2024_04_01_PREVIEW: \\\\\\\"2024-04-01-preview\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@subscriptionResource\\\\r\\\\nmodel MyModel is ProxyResource\\\\u003c{}\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"extendedZoneName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"extendedZones\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cMyModel\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=\\\\\\\"client.tsp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport operation `get`\\\\r\\\\n@@clientLocation(CommonTypes.SubscriptionIdParameter.subscriptionId, get);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n// Since all instances of subscription ID in the service have been moved to the operation level,\\\\r\\\\n// there is no `subscription_id` parameter on the client\\\\r\\\\nclass ContosoProviderHubClient:\\\\r\\\\n    def __init__(self, credential, **kwargs):\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n    def get(self, subscription_id: str, extended_zone_name: str, **kwargs) -\\\\u003e MyModel:\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`csharp\\\\r\\\\n// Main client with subscriptionId as client parameter\\\\r\\\\npublic partial class ContosoProviderHubClient\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n    public ContosoProviderHubClient(TokenCredential credential)\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n    public virtual Response\\\\u003cMyModel\\\\u003e Get(string subscriptionId, string extendedZoneName, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default)\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n        ...\\\\r\\\\n Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#typespec-client-generator-core#reference#decorators.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Decorators\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/typespec-client-generator-core/reference/decorators\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Decorators\\\\n## Azure.ClientGenerator.Core\\\\n### `@alternateType` {#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.alternateType}\\\\n# libraries#typespec-client-generator-core#reference#decorators.md\\\\n\\\\n# Decorators\\\\n\\\\n## Azure.ClientGenerator.Core\\\\n\\\\n### `@alternateType` {#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.alternateType}\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| alternate | `unknown \\\\\\\\| ClientGenerator.Core.ExternalType` | The alternate type to apply to the target. Can be a TypeSpec type or an ExternalType.                                                                                                                                                                      |\\\\r\\\\n| scope     | `valueof string`                               | Specifies the target language emitters that the decorator should apply. If not set, the decorator will be applied to all language emitters by default.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eYou can use \\\\\\\"!\\\\\\\" to exclude specific languages, for example: !(java, python) or !java, !python. |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a model property to a different type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Foo {\\\\r\\\\n  date: utcDateTime;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@@alternateType(Foo.date, string);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a Scalar type to a different type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nscalar storageDateTime extends utcDateTime;\\\\r\\\\n@@alternateType(storageDateTime, string, \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a function parameter to a different type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nop test(@param @alternateType(string) date: utcDateTime): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a model property to a different type with language specific alternate type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Test {\\\\r\\\\n  @alternateType(unknown)\\\\r\\\\n  thumbprint?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @alternateType(AzureLocation[], \\\\\\\"csharp\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  locations: string[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Use external type for DFE case\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@alternateType(\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    identity: \\\\\\\"Azure.Core.Expressions.DataFactoryExpression\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"csharp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nunion Dfe\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  T,\\\\r\\\\n  DfeExpression,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Use external type with package information\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@alternateType(\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    identity: \\\\\\\"pystac.Collection\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    package: \\\\\\\"pystac\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    minVersion: \\\\\\\"1.13.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nmodel ItemCollection {\\\\r\\\\n  // ... properties\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Invalid: External type on model property (will emit a warning)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel MyModel {\\\\r\\\\n  field: FieldType;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"Azure.Core.Expressions.DataFactoryExpression\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"csharp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nunion Dfe\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  T,\\\\r\\\\n  DfeExpression,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Use external type with package information\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@alternateType(\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    identity: \\\\\\\"pystac.Collection\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    package: \\\\\\\"pystac\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    minVersion: \\\\\\\"1.13.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nmodel ItemCollection {\\\\r\\\\n  // ... properties\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Invalid: External type on model property (will emit a warning)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel MyModel {\\\\r\\\\n  field: FieldType;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// This will emit a warning - external types cannot be applied to properties\\\\r\\\\n@@alternateType(MyModel.field,\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    identity: \\\\\\\"ExternalType\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"rust\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n);\\\\r\\\\n// Correct: Apply external type to the type definition instead\\\\r\\\\n@alternateType(\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    identity: \\\\\\\"ExternalType\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"rust\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nmodel FieldType {\\\\r\\\\n  // ... properties\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\nSet an alternate type for a model property, Scalar, Model, Enum, Union, or function parameter. Note that `@encode` will be overridden by the one defined in the alternate type.\\\\r\\\\nWhen the source type is `Scalar`, the alternate type must be `Scalar`.\\\\r\\\\nThe replaced type could be a type defined in the TypeSpec or an external type declared by type identity, package that export the type and package version.\\\\r\\\\n**Important:** External types (with `identity` property) cannot be applied to model properties. They must be applied to the type definition itself (Scalar, Model, Enum, or Union).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.alternateType(alternate: unknown | Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.ExternalType, scope?: valueof string)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Target\\\\r\\\\nThe source type to which the alternate type will be applied.\\\\r\\\\n`ModelProperty | Scalar | Model | Enum | Union`\\\\r\\\\n#### Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name      | Type                                           | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |\\\\r\\\\n| --------- | ---------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| alternate | `unknown \\\\\\\\| ClientGenerator.Core.ExternalType` | The alternate type to apply to the target. Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. Versioning\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n# getstarted#azure-core#step09.md\\\\n\\\\n# 9. Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n\\\\nthe `Versions` enum:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou will also need to add the `@useDependency` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, you can express changes to your service using the `@added` and `@removed` decorators. Here's an example of adding a new property to `Widget` and removing an old one:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget name. */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"widgetName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget color. */\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions.v2022_11_30)\\\\r\\\\n  color: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The ID of the widget's manufacturer. */\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions.v2022_11_30)\\\\r\\\\n  manufacturerId: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You can do a lot more with versioning decorators, so consult the `typespec-versioning` [README.md](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/versioning#enable-versioning-for-service-or-library) for more information on how you can use them to annotate your service and describe changes between different versions.\\\\n\\\\nIt is inevitable that service specifications will change over time. It is a best practice to add versioning support to your specification from the first version. To do that, you will need to define an `enum` containing your service versions and then apply the `@versioned` decorator to your service namespace.\\\\r\\\\nHere is an example for the `WidgetManager` service:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget Manager\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Contoso.WidgetManager;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThere are a few things to point out here:\\\\r\\\\n- We define an `enum` called `Versions` inside of the service namespace. For each service version, we map a version symbol like `v2022_08_31` to a version string like `2022-08-31`. This service currently only has a single version, but we can add more to this enum as things change over time.\\\\r\\\\n- We add the `@versioned` decorator and reference the `Versions` enum we defined using the fully-qualified name `Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions`. This marks the service as being versioned and specifies the set of versions.\\\\r\\\\n- We change the `@useDependency` decorator we used previously to now link each service version to a specific version of `Azure.Core`. See the [Using Azure.Core Versions](#using-azurecore-versions) section for more information.\\\\r\\\\nImagine that it's 3 months later and you want to release a new version of your service with some slight changes. Add a new version to the `Versions` enum:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou will also need to add the `@useDependency` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, you can express changes to your service using the `@added` and `@removed` decorators. Here's an example of adding a new property to `Widget` and removing an old one:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#versioning#guide.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Tutorial\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/versioning/guide\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Tutorial\\\\n## Versioning APIs\\\\n# libraries#versioning#guide.md\\\\n\\\\n# Tutorial\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning APIs\\\\n\\\\nThe versioning library simplifies the process of versioning APIs. Let's start with a basic example. Assume we have a service with a single API that returns a list of widgets. We can define that API like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Rest;\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget Manager\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Contoso.WidgetManager;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@error\\\\r\\\\nmodel Error {\\\\r\\\\n  code: string;\\\\r\\\\n  message?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 2 of the service, we add a get operation to retrieve a single widget. We can add that like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n  v2,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop list(): Widget[] | Error;\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widget/{id}\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop get(...Resource.KeysOf\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e): Widget | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNow, let's suppose that in version 3 of the service, we realize that `name` is not accurate and that this field should be called `description`. Also, we decide that the description should be optional, not mandatory. We can implement these changes like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  widgetId: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v3, \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  description?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWe made the change to the actual model property so that it now reflects the correct name and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\n\\\\nname and optional nature of the property. Both the `@renamedFrom` and `@madeOptional` decorators indicate the version in which the change was made, and the `@renamedFrom` decorator also identifies the previous name of the property. This allows us to generate code that is aware of the change and can handle it appropriately.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI definition of `Widget` for version 3 reflects the change:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    description:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nHowever, the OpenAPI definition for versions 1 and 2 still reflect the original name and the mandatory nature of the property:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nWidget:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    id:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - id\\\\r\\\\n    - name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is a common pattern with the versioning decorators. The TypeSpec should represent the _current state_ of the API. The decorators indicate the version at which this definition became accurate and, depending on the decorator, the other parameters reflect the previous values to retain that information.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What decorator should be used in this case?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# What decorator should be used in this case?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team, \\\\r\\\\nIn version v2, we introduced a new model model2 and updated featureA (originally added in v1) to use model2 as its parameter. In v1, featureA used model1 at the same position. \\\\r\\\\nHere\\u2019s the setup I tried (using @typeChangedFrom):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel1;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v2)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel2;  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(v1)  \\\\r\\\\nfeatureA {  \\\\r\\\\n  @typeChangedFrom(v1, model1)  \\\\r\\\\n  body: model2;  \\\\r\\\\n} \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nHowever, this shows the error: \\\\\\\"model2 does not exist in v1\\\\\\\". \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the correct decorator to use in this situation? \\\\r\\\\nThank you!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nit should be `typedChangedFrom(v2, model1` here otherwise you are saying in v1 you changed from using model1 to model2 which then of course doesn't exists\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_http_specs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"versioning#returntypechangedfrom#main.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Usages for Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/http-specs/specs/versioning/returntypechangedfrom/main.tsp\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Usages for Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\\n## Full Sample:\\\\n# versioning#returntypechangedfrom#main.md\\\\n\\\\n# Usages for Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\\n\\\\n## Full Sample:\\\\n\\\\n// main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing TypeSpec.Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * Test for the `@returnTypeChangedFrom` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"{endpoint}/versioning/return-type-changed-from/api-version:{version}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"Testserver endpoint\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    /**\\\\r\\\\n     * Need to be set as 'http://localhost:3000' in client.\\\\r\\\\n     */\\\\r\\\\n    endpoint: url,\\\\r\\\\n    /**\\\\r\\\\n     * Need to be set as 'v1' or 'v2' in client.\\\\r\\\\n     */\\\\r\\\\n    version: Versions,\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Versioning.ReturnTypeChangedFrom;\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * The version of the API.\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The version v1.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"v1\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The version v2.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"v2\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/test\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@post\\\\r\\\\n@returnTypeChangedFrom(\\\\r\\\\n  Versions.v2,\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    @header\\\\r\\\\n    contentType: \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    @body\\\\r\\\\n    body: int32,\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nop test(@header contentType: \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\", @body body: string): {\\\\r\\\\n  @header\\\\r\\\\n  contentType: \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  @body\\\\r\\\\n  body: Hi team, could someone please help grant me permission to view the workflow for my Azure REST API PR?

actual.answer:
To gain visibility into the workflow and validation checks for your Azure REST API PR, you need to have the appropriate permissions. Specifically, you must:

1. Ensure your membership in the Azure GitHub organization is set to public (not private). You can verify and update your membership visibility at https://github.com/orgs/Azure/people.
2. Request access via https://aka.ms/azsdk/access. This process will guide you to join the Azure SDK Partners group and link your GitHub account with your Microsoft account if needed.

Once you have the required permissions and your membership is public, you should be able to view the workflow details and validation errors for your PR before it is reviewed. This will allow you to debug and address any issues proactively.

failures (see the `Checks` tab on your PR) can be suppressed.\\\\r\\\\nThe suppression can be either just for the PR, or permanent.\\\\n\\\\n## To suppress given validation failure\\\\n\\\\n1. Determine which failing check you want to suppress: see its name in the `Checks` tab in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you have one of the [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you want to suppress the failure only for the PR, or permanently. Consult [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table) for instructions corresponding to your case.\\\\r\\\\n1. If you want to apply temporary suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. If you applied permanent suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. It will manifest by the PR getting a label `SuppressionReviewRequired`.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Verify the suppression works by the check changing from **failed** to **neutral**.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Wait until your suppression is reviewed. If it is approved, the approved will add the `Approved-Suppression` label.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.

Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?

actual.answer: The addition of the service-under-conversion label to your stable API PR does not indicate a delay in merging your PR, nor does it require you to make additional changes solely because of the label. If your stable API PR represents a later API version than the TypeSpec migration PR, the migration will typically be based on the latest checked-in version once your PR is merged. The label is primarily for tracking and awareness during the migration process, not for blocking or requiring extra work on your part.
