\\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The Retry-After header can indicate how long the client should wait before polling the operation status.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n              }\\\\r\\\\n            }\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"default\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"An unexpected error response.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"schema\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n              \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#/definitions/ErrorResponse\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n            }\\\\r\\\\n          }\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"x-ms-long-running-operation-options\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"final-state-via\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"location\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\n\\\\nindicate how long the client should wait before polling the operation status.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n              }\\\\r\\\\n            }\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"default\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"An unexpected error response.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"schema\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n              \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#/definitions/ErrorResponse\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n            }\\\\r\\\\n          }\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"x-ms-long-running-operation-options\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"final-state-via\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"location\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Consumes / Produces (OAS2)\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Consumes / Produces (OAS2)\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI v2, the top-level `consumes` and `produces` fields specify a list of MIME types an operation can consume / produce\\\\r\\\\nwhen not overridden by a `consumes` or `produces` on an individual operation.\\\\r\\\\nThe typespec-autorest emitter previously supported `@produces` and `@consumes` decorators on a namespace, but these are deprecated\\\\r\\\\nin favor of explicit `content-type` and `accept` header properties in request and response bodies.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#proxy-api-reference.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Proxy API Reference\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/proxy-api-reference.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Proxy API Reference\\\\n# v1.0#proxy-api-reference.md\\\\n\\\\n# Proxy API Reference\\\\n\\\\n- [Proxy API Reference](#proxy-api-reference) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Resource Action Requests](#resource-action-requests) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Subscription wide Reads and Actions](#subscription-wide-reads-and-actions) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Exposing Available Operations](#exposing-available-operations) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  - [Check Name Availability Requests](#check-name-availability-requests) \\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003e\\\\n\\\\n## Proxy API reference ##\\\\n\\\\nARM will proxy requests to backing resource providers even if they are not related directly to resource management or subscription lifecycle changes. ARM does not check RP registration for proxy requests. \\\\r\\\\nThese requests are considered to be part of the \\\\\\\"Proxy API\\\\\\\" and examples include: restart a VM; fetch storage account keys; or increase the capacity of a mobile service.\\\\n\\\\n### Resource Action Requests ###\\\\n\\\\nchecks.\\\\r\\\\n#### Response ####\\\\r\\\\nThe response includes an HTTP status code, a set of response headers, and a response body.\\\\r\\\\n**Status Code**\\\\r\\\\nThe resource provider should return 200 (OK) to indicate that the action completed successfully. 202 (Accepted) can be returned to indicate that the action will complete asynchronously.\\\\r\\\\nIf the resource group or a relevant resource does not exist, 404 (NotFound) should be returned.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Headers**\\\\r\\\\nHeaders common to all responses.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Body**\\\\r\\\\nThe response body will be specific to the resource provider and the action, but it \\\\\\\\*must\\\\\\\\* adhere to the REST CEC guidelines and be JSON by default.\\\\r\\\\n#### Rules ####\\\\n\\\\nActions can be performed on objects (e.g. reimage VM instance), but still need to be modeled in a consistent way across internal and external resource providers. Through this consistency, resource providers will be able to \\\\\\\"light-up\\\\\\\" authorization / RBAC scenarios without changing their API surface.\\\\r\\\\nIn order to make the \\\\\\\"action\\\\\\\" consistent across resource providers, the action name must be included in the URL via a specific format (which is aligned with OData).\\\\r\\\\nThe HTTP verb and request body will \\\\\\\\*not\\\\\\\\* be used in identifying the \\\\\\\"action\\\\\\\" being taken on the resource provider if the action name is provided.\\\\r\\\\n**If no action name is provided, the HTTP Verb (e.g. GET / PUT) will be used as the action name.**\\\\r\\\\n#### Request ###\\\\r\\\\n| Method | Request URI |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| POST | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/resourceGroups/{resourceGroupName}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}/{resourceName}/{actionName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n**Arguments**\\\\r\\\\n[Common Arguments](./uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md)\\\\r\\\\nExamples of action names include: \\\\\\\"restartVM\\\\\\\" or \\\\\\\"listStorageKeys\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n**Request Body**\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"resourceDefinedProperty\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Resource defined value\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\nAll parameters for the action request should be contained in the request body \\u2013 and not in the URL. This matches the OData and Azure REST guidelines and will avoid impacting the authZ checks.\\\\r\\\\n#### Response ####\\\\r\\\\nThe response includes an HTTP status code, a set of response headers, and a response body.\\\\r\\\\n**Status Code**\\\\r\\\\nThe resource provider should return 200 (OK) to indicate that the action completed successfully. 202 (Accepted) can be returned to indicate that the action will complete asynchronously.\\\\r\\\\nIf the resource group or a relevant resource does not exist, 404 (NotFound) should be returned.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Headers**\\\\r\\\\nHeaders common to all responses.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Body**\\\\n\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n\\\\n| \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-04 | A `POST` operation **must** return status code 404 (NotFound) to indicate that the resource or resource group does not exist. | Required |  | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-05 | All parameters **must** be specified in the payload and not in the URI. | Required | This allows proper implementation of authorization checks. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/parameters-in-POST.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-06 | Response body of the `POST` operation *may* have any schema as defined by the Resource Provider. | Recommended |  | Design | | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-07 | A `POST` operation **must** apply either to a specific resource instance of a resource type or to the provider. It **must not** be applied to a resource type. | Required | ARM cannot route such requests to the Resource Provider. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/path-for-resource-action.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-08 | A `POST` operation *may* perform a read-only action at a subscription scope. | Recommended |  | Design |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-09 | Undefined | Undefined | Undefined | Undefined | Undefined | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-10 | Prefix the action name with the term `list` to allow template deployment to call the `POST` action. | Recommended | | Design |  |\\\\n\\\\nViolating these rules result in APIs across Azure becoming inconsistent with each other. Such inconsistencies degrade customer experience as they now have to deal with slightly different behaviors while interacting with each Resource Provider. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n| RPC Guideline code | Title | Conformance level | Additional impact |  Applicable scope | Linter rule |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-01 | An action name must be provided for a `POST` operation. | Required | ARM cannot route the request. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/path-for-resource-action.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-02 | A synchronous `POST` operation **must** specify status code 200 (OK) with response schema or 204 (No response content) to indicate successful completion. | Required | | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/POST-response-codes.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-03 | An asynchronous `POST` operation **must** specify 202 [Accepted] to indicate successful acceptance of the API. It **should** additionaly specify status code 200 (OK) with a response schema indicating the schema of the final response if the final response is expected to have one. If the final response is expected to not have any content, specifying only 202 is sufficient. | Required |  | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/POST-response-codes.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-04 | A `POST` operation **must** return status code 404 (NotFound) to indicate that the resource or resource group does not exist. | Required |  | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-05 | All parameters **must** be specified in the payload and not in the URI. | Required | This allows proper implementation of authorization checks. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/parameters-in-POST.md) | \\\\r\\\\n|\\\\n\\\\n### Subscription Wide Reads and Actions ###\\\\n\\\\nThis applies to GETs and POSTs where some data needs to be exposed in a read-only fashion across a subscription or tenant. The Resource Provider contract allows for this functionality but recommends caution when exposing it (since it requires a \\\\u0026quot;global\\\\u0026quot; endpoint for the RP \\\\u0026amp; does not support regional routing).\\\\r\\\\nExamples include: available platform images for a subscription; available locations for their offer type; quotas or restrictions imposed on their subscription.\\\\r\\\\n**Please review all instances where this API is used with the current owners of the RP API document. Manageable entities should \\\\\\\\*never\\\\\\\\* be updated at this level.**\\\\r\\\\n#### Request (Subscription wide operations) ####\\\\r\\\\n| Method | Request URI |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| GET | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n| GET | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}/{resourceName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n| POST | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{actionName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n#### Request (Tenant wide operations) ####\\\\r\\\\n| Method | Request URI |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| POST | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{actionName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n**Arguments**\\\\r\\\\n| Argument | Description |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| subscriptionId | The subscriptionId for the Azure user. |\\\\r\\\\n| api-version | Specifies the version of the protocol used to make this request. Format must match YYYY-MM-DD[{-preview} or  {-alpha}or{-beta}or{-rc}or{-privatepreview}]. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceProviderNamespace| The resource provider namespace can only be ASCII alphanumeric characters and the \\\\\\\".\\\\\\\" character. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceType| The type of the resource \\u2013 the resource providers declare the resource types they support at the time of registering with Azure.\\\\n\\\\n| The subscriptionId for the Azure user. |\\\\r\\\\n| api-version | Specifies the version of the protocol used to make this request. Format must match YYYY-MM-DD[{-preview} or  {-alpha}or{-beta}or{-rc}or{-privatepreview}]. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceProviderNamespace| The resource provider namespace can only be ASCII alphanumeric characters and the \\\\\\\".\\\\\\\" character. |\\\\r\\\\n| resourceType| The type of the resource \\u2013 the resource providers declare the resource types they support at the time of registering with Azure. The resourceType should follow the lowerCamelCase convention and be plural (e.g. virtualMachines, resourceGroups, jobCollections, virtualNetworks). The resource type can only be ASCII alphanumeric characters.|\\\\r\\\\n**Request Headers**\\\\r\\\\nOnly headers common to all requests.\\\\r\\\\n**Request Body**\\\\r\\\\nControlled by the resource provider (e.g. GETs should have no body; POSTs can have a body as part of the action).\\\\r\\\\n#### Response ####\\\\r\\\\nThe response includes an HTTP status code, a set of response headers, and a response body if it applies.\\\\r\\\\n**Status Code**\\\\r\\\\nThe resource provider should return 200 (OK) to indicate that the action completed\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\nThis guide introduces TypeSpec using concepts familiar to developers who build or use API definitions in OpenAPI v2 or v3.\\\\r\\\\nIn many cases, this will also describe how the typespec-autorest and openapi3 emitters translate\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec designs into OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\nThe document is organized around the features of an OpenAPI v2 or v3 definition.\\\\r\\\\nThe idea is that if you know how to describe some API feature in OpenAPI, you can just navigate\\\\r\\\\nto the section of this document for that feature.\\\\n\\\\n## Data Types\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI [v2](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#data-types)/[v3](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#data-types), data types are specified using the `type` and `format` fields in a schema.\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec equivalents of OpenAPI data types are the TypeSpec primitive types or [built-in models](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/built-in-types).\\\\n\\\\n### type and format\\\\n\\\\n| RFC 3339 date with offset                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `password`  | `@secret string` |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean` |             | `boolean`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\nYou can also define a property with no type specified using the TypeSpec `unknown` type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /** This property has no `type` defined. */\\\\r\\\\n  noType?: unknown;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOpenAPI allows any string as a format, and there is a [registry of common formats][Format Registry].\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec supports some of these directly.\\\\r\\\\n[Format Registry]: https://spec.openapis.org/registry/format\\\\r\\\\n| `type:`   | `format:`    | TypeSpec type | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------- | ------------ | ------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `decimal`    | `decimal`     |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `double-int` | `safeint`     |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int8`       | `int8`        |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int16`      | `int16`       |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `uint8`      | `uint8`       |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `uri`        | `url`         |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor formats that are not supported directly, you can use the built-in `@format` decorator to specify\\\\r\\\\nthe format explicitly.\\\\n\\\\nThe following table shows how common OpenAPI types map to TypeSpec types:\\\\r\\\\n| `type:`   | `format:`   | TypeSpec type    | Notes                                                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| --------- | ----------- | ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int32`     | `int32`          |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int64`     | `int64`          |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `float`     | `float32`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `double`    | `float64`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  |             | `string`         |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `byte`      | `bytes`          | for content-type == 'application/json' or 'text/plain'                    |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `binary`    | `bytes`          | for \\\\\\\"binary\\\\\\\" content types, e.g. 'application/octet-stream', 'image/jpeg' |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date`      | `plainDate`      |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date-time` | `utcDateTime`    | RFC 3339 date in coordinated universal time (UTC)                         |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date-time` | `offsetDateTime` | RFC 3339 date with offset                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `password`  | `@secret string` |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean` |             | `boolean`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\nYou can also define a property with no type specified using the TypeSpec `unknown` type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /** This property has no `type` defined. */\\\\n\\\\n### JSON Schema assertions\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI supports a variety of \\\\\\\"assertions\\\\\\\" that can be used to further restrict the values allowed for a data type.\\\\r\\\\nThese are actually borrowed into OpenAPI from JSON Schema.\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: integer` and `type: number` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct           | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ---------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minimum: value`            | `@minValue(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maximum: value`            | `@maxValue(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: string` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct            | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ----------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minLength: value`          | `@minLength(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maxLength: value`          | `@maxLength(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `pattern: regex`            | `@pattern(regex)` decorator   |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: array` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct           | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ---------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minItems: value`           | `@minItems(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maxItems: value`           | `@maxItems(value)` decorator |       |\\\\n\\\\n### enum\\\\n\\\\nThere are two ways to define an `enum` data type in TypeSpec. One is with the [TypeSpec `enum` statement](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/enums), e.g.:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- To retain the quotes from the enum values --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- prettier-ignore-start --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Color {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- prettier-ignore-end --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nAnother is to use the union operation to define the enum values inline, e.g.:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  size?: \\\\\\\"small\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"medium\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"large\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"x-large\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### default\\\\n\\\\nA model property that specifies a default value using \\\\\\\"=\\\\\\\" will produce a `default` field in the schema for this property.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  answer?: int32 = 42;\\\\r\\\\n  color?: string = \\\\\\\"purple\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nanswer:\\\\r\\\\n  type: integer\\\\r\\\\n  format: int32\\\\r\\\\n  default: 42\\\\r\\\\ncolor:\\\\r\\\\n  type: string\\\\r\\\\n  default: purple\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Host / BasePath / Servers\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI v2, the `host` and `basePath` fields at the top-level of the API definition combine to form the base URL for the API. The paths defined in the `paths` object are appended to this base URL to form the absolute URL for an operation.\\\\r\\\\nIn OpenAPI v3, the top-level `servers` field specifies an array of `server` objects [[v3][v3-server]] with a base URL, which may be parameterized, to which the operation path is appended.\\\\r\\\\n[v3-server]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#server-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, the `host` in OpenAPI v2 or `servers` in OpenAPI v3 can be specified with the `@server` decorator\\\\r\\\\non the namespace (from `@typespec/http` library). You can use this decorator multiple times to specify multiple servers.\\\\n\\\\n## Paths Object\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI, the `paths` object [[v2][v2-paths], [v3][v3-paths]] is the top-level structure for defining the operations of the API, organized by the \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\" for the operation.\\\\r\\\\n[v2-paths]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#paths-object\\\\r\\\\n[v3-paths]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#paths-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, you can specify the path for a namespace, interface, or operation using the `@route` decorator.\\\\r\\\\nWhen the value of the `@route` decorator contains path parameters, operations within the scope of the decorator\\\\r\\\\nmust declare parameters with the same name and type. If an operation declares a path parameter that is not present\\\\r\\\\nin the route, this defines a new path that is the value from the `@route` decorator with the path parameter appended.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/pets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Pets {\\\\r\\\\n  op create(@body pet: Pet): Pet; // uses path \\\\\\\"/pets\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  op read(@path petId: int32): Pet; // uses path \\\\\\\"/pets/{petId}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen the `@route` decorator is used within a namespace or interface that also has a `@route` decorator, the path is\\\\r\\\\nobtained by concatenating the routes.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  // widgets operations\\\\r\\\\n  @route(\\\\\\\"/{id}/parts\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  namespace Parts {\\\\r\\\\n    op list(@path id: string): Part[] | Error; // uses path \\\\\\\"/widgets/{id}/parts\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Path Item Object\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI, a path item object [[v2][v2-pathitem], [v3][v3-pathitem]] describes the operations available on a single path. A path may have at most one `get`, `put`, `post`, `patch`, `delete`, or `head` operation.\\\\r\\\\n[v2-pathitem]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#path-item-object\\\\r\\\\n[v3-pathitem]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#path-item-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, operations are defined within a namespace or interface with a syntax similar to typescript functions.\\\\r\\\\nThe HTTP method for an operation can be specified explicitly using a decorator: `@get`, `@put`, `@post`, `@patch`, `@delete`, or `@head`.\\\\r\\\\nIf an HTTP method decorator is not specified then the default is `post` if there is a body and `get` otherwise.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"Gadgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/gadgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Gadgets {\\\\r\\\\n  op create(@body gadget: Gadget): Gadget | Error; // uses \\\\\\\"post\\\\\\\" method\\\\r\\\\n  op read(@path id: string): Gadget | Error; // uses \\\\\\\"get\\\\\\\" method\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOther path item fields:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI `pathItem` field | TypeSpec construct | Notes                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------------ | ------------------ | ------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| `summary`                |                    |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#04-common-parameters.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Common Parameters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/04-common-parameters\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Common Parameters\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#04-common-parameters.md\\\\n\\\\n# Common Parameters\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n\\\\nIn this section, we'll focus on reusing common parameters in your REST API. Common parameters are parameters that are used across multiple operations. By defining these parameters once and reusing them, we can make our API more consistent, easier to read, and easier to maintain.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getstarted#createproject.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Creating a project\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/createproject\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Creating a project\\\\n### Target Users\\\\n# getstarted#createproject.md\\\\n\\\\n# Creating a project\\\\n\\\\n### Target Users\\\\n\\\\n- **Rest-API-Spec Repo Projects**: Ideal for those contributing directly to the Azure REST API specifications, ensuring production-quality SDK generation.\\\\r\\\\n- **Standalone Projects**: Suited for API-first development, allowing users to generate OpenAPI specs, service code, and clients without conforming to the specs repo's structure.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec ARM Model Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec ARM Model Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 36. 500;\\\\r\\\\n  @body error: InternalServerError;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- The `listPets` operation uses the `PetListResponse` custom PR Diff Validation Queries\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec PR Diff Validation Queries\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec PR Diff Validation Queries\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion,\\\\r\\\\nI was validating the TypeSpec generated PR - [[TSP Migration][advisor] TypeSpec migrated from swagger by HarveyLink \\u00b7 Pull Request #34319 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/34319) following [this process](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/01-get-started/#review-and-adjust-the-typespec) in my local and came across some differences between existing Swagger Spec vs the New Swagger Spec generated via TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nCan you please help with the queries below for these differences and confirm if these could lead to breaking changes for clients.\\\\r\\\\nAlso, what is the expectation from teams should any fixes required be added by the owning teams via a PR on top of this \\\\\\\"ConvertAdvisor\\\\\\\" branch with TypeSpec changes?\\\\r\\\\n1.x-ms-skip-url-encoding enabled on multiple endpoints with resourceUri Parameter.\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"paths\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"/{resourceUri}/providers/microsoft.Advisor/recommendations\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    get:\\\\r\\\\n      operationId: Recommendations_ListByTenant\\\\r\\\\n      parameters:\\\\r\\\\n        {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"resourceUri\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": true,\\\\r\\\\n-         \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n+         \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n+         \\\\\\\"x-ms-skip-url-encoding\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n2.Many Models containing array Type value in properties has been changed to \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\" from optional\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"AssessmentListsResult\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"[Placeholder] Discription for page model\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"array\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"[Placeholder] Discription for value property\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"items\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/AssessmentResult\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"nextLink\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"format\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"uri\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"[Placeholder] Discription for nextLink property\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n-   }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n+ },\\\\r\\\\n+ \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\":[\\\\r\\\\n+   \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n+ ]\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n3.extendedProperties of type object contains an additional field named additonalProperties\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\n\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"array\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"[Placeholder] Discription for value property\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"items\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/AssessmentResult\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"nextLink\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"format\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"uri\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"[Placeholder] Discription for nextLink property\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n-   }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n+ },\\\\r\\\\n+ \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\":[\\\\r\\\\n+   \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n+ ]\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n3.extendedProperties of type object contains an additional field named additonalProperties\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"PredictionResponseProperties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"extendedProperties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n-     \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n+     \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n+     \\\\\\\"additionalProperties\\\\\\\": {}\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nFew other changes below I can observe from Swagger UI Preview in local:\\\\r\\\\n1.Previously we had multiple Swagger Spec Files like advisor.json, assessments.json and resiliencyReviews.json each having a subset of endpoints in line with different Advisor Portal Blades, but with TypeSpec generated Swagger we only have a single openapi.json spec file containing all endpoints. Is this a mandatory requirement with TypeSpec going forward that for each RP we need to generate and maintain a single spec?\\\\r\\\\n2.Multiple Tag Name updates - \\\\\\\"Metadata\\\\\\\" -\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"MetadataEntities\\\\\\\". Could such changes lead to any breaking impact on Customers side. Also, from documentation perspective can we update these Tag Names to be similar as past?\\\\r\\\\n3.summary for endpoints has been moved to description. Also. few parameter descriptions are updated. Is there recommended practise being followed here?\\\\r\\\\n4.Response description updated to be more generic as an Azure Operation and \\\\\\\"systemData\\\\\\\" section added as part of 200 Response. Are these done as per any recommended guidelines?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nFor one thing. the most important thing for the spec is that is accurately represents the API.  There is client decoration available in many cases to keep the sdk from breaking as we make sure the API is accurate:\\\\r\\\\nx-ms-skip-url-encoding:  Parameters like 'scope'  and 'resourceUri'  generally contain multiple path segments.  If they occur in a path parameter, you almost always want those path segments included in the path, so skipping url; encoding is appropriate.  If they occur in query parameters, then url encoding is irrelevant.  You can specificall set url encoding for path parameters by decorating with @path(#{allowReserved: true})\\\\r\\\\nThe value array.  Generally, the Value array occurs in list types, which also have a nextLink.  No more properties should mean no more nextLink.  It is almost always the case in actual practice that value always occurs in list responses, and this was a piece of inaccurate variance in the original spec.  The best practice is to validate that your service can have a response that does not contain a value property (which is unlikely), and only change the response type then.  Whether or not this is the case, it is highly unlikely to have any impact on clients, which have standard mechaniisms for handling paged types.\\\\r\\\\nSingle OpenAPI file:  Teams no longer maintain the OpenAPI spec, they maintain the TypeSpec as the source of truth and OpenApi is generated from that, so the layout of the OpenAPI files should not be important going forward, except in some limited cases (for example, some teams have special configuration for PowerShell cmdlets that only generate cmdlets for some of their OpenApi specs).  Generally though, this should not be a concern.\\\\r\\\\nTag name changes:  tags can affect Terraform.  You can use the @tag decorator (typespec core) to ensure that any missing tags are added to the spec\\\\r\\\\ndoc/summary:  The way the converter does this maximizes the usefulness of summary/description for client sdks.\\\\n\\\\ngoing forward, except in some limited cases (for example, some teams have special configuration for PowerShell cmdlets that only generate cmdlets for some of their OpenApi specs).  Generally though, this should not be a concern.\\\\r\\\\nTag name changes:  tags can affect Terraform.  You can use the @tag decorator (typespec core) to ensure that any missing tags are added to the spec\\\\r\\\\ndoc/summary:  The way the converter does this maximizes the usefulness of summary/description for client sdks.  You can still add summary documentation for other consumers of the specs using the @summary decorator\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Service under conversation label\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Service under conversation label\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Service under conversation label\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nMy team currently has a PR open to release a new stable API. However, due to backend delays, it\\u2019s been open since July. During that time, the [typespec migration PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36556) was drafted against our preview API. Now, the service-under-conversion label has been added to our stable PR. I\\u2019d like to understand does this label indicate a delay in merging in our [stable api PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36219), or will we need to make additional changes?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe label should not impact your previous PR, and , if this is a later api-version thatn the conversion PR, the conversion would normally be based on that version once checked in.  Adding Janine Zhang for awareness about the modify files within the refactored folders. This guide helps PR authors resolve these conflicts more efficiently.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Important Note**: If you create a new PR **after** a folder migration is already merged into main, you should not encounter merge conflicts but need to work based on the new folder structure.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n## The impact to ongoing PRs\\\\n# Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md\\\\n\\\\n# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n\\\\n## The impact to ongoing PRs\\\\n\\\\n1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to a release-* or dev-* branch which are not created or syncing from the latest main, we recommend to merge these PRs first.\\\\r\\\\n1. Resolve conflicts  \\\\r\\\\n        - For most of the conflicts, accept the incoming changes.  \\\\r\\\\n        - If it's unclear, please accept both and then update based on your judgement with the folder structure changes above.  \\\\r\\\\n      3. Make sure the new change is aligned with folder structure v2  \\\\r\\\\n         There are some cases where the PR is adding a new version in the original location, but the file diffs don't show as conflict. we should move them into the correct place so that it doesn't break the folder structure v2 as instructions in **Understanding Folder Migration sections** \\\\r\\\\n      4. clean up the previous folder if exists.  \\\\r\\\\n**Important**: It's strongly recommended to understand what's really changed in the folder refactor. Always ensure the new PR doesn't include any things that breaks the folder structure.\\\\n\\\\n### After Resolution\\\\n\\\\nMake sure to compile the TypeSpec project so that the TypeSpec Validation multiple API versions using typespec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi Team, \\\\r\\\\nI am releasing a new API version and looks there is a new validation to check existing swagger with new tsp file  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nWe want to keep both old and new api versoins. What is the suggestion here? Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. You could alternatively decorate the core parameter definition (e.g., with an augment decorator), but that would affect every usage\\u2014so for localized changes, use operation-specific ones. Since this is a method parameter, the APIs are equivalent and the change has no SDK impact.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nPR: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346\\\\r\\\\nAvocado check: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44368323389 \\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to suppress the missing APIs check only for this PR since it only has typspec conversion but no update to the open API spec?\\\\r\\\\nThe check is trying to compare the APIs with previous stable release with currently published stable release.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nPart of the typespec conversion is replacing the existing swagger with a generated swagger.  The generated swagger is still used for some purposes, and Avocado protects the ability to process it. The generated swagger needs to be equivalent, but not necessarily identical.  Generally these issues reflected in the swagger will also show up in breaking change checks, which will have to be resolved (or suppressed if they are false positives)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nWe had PR in flight: [Adding stable 2025 08 01 for completeness by risraj10 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37381 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37381)\\\\r\\\\nHowever, I see that TypeSpec migration was done couple of days ago for this folder. \\\\r\\\\nI have cancelled the above PR and trying to raise a new PR. However, just running npx tsp compile without any change is giving errors.\\\\r\\\\nAnd also it is making unintended change to OpenAPI json file even to existing version. I guess the tsp and OpenAPI json are not in sync.\\\\r\\\\nHence, wanted to check if the migration is really complete for this folder.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nMain typespec validation should always be passing are you sure you are up you are with dependencies locally?\\\\r\\\\nMake sure to follow instructions here https://aka.ms/ci-fix\\\\r\\\\nJust to reiterate, this is almost always because you need to pull the latest from the target branch into your local clone of the repo, and re-install dependencies at the root.\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally\\\"}]\"}"}]

knowledges.title: Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models
ARM Rules, TypeSpec Linting, and Suppression
Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation
Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models
Suppress validation failures on a PR
Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing

actual.answer: Currently, TypeSpec suppression rules can only be provided inline within the TypeSpec files themselves. There is no supported mechanism to package suppressions with a shared TypeSpec definitions package such that they apply only to the imported definitions and not to the rest of the consumer's project. Linter rules can be disabled globally, but this would affect the entire project, not just the imported definitions. Therefore, if you need to suppress specific linting rules for your shared definitions, you must do so inline in those files. There is no file- or package-scoped suppression mechanism available at this time.

TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n\\\\nYou can suppress specific validation rules within `TypeSpecValidation` by creating or modifying a `suppressions.yaml` file in the root directory of your service specification.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Note:** Currently, only the `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule supports suppression.\\\\n\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n\\\\nThe `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule is responsible for validating emitter options and parameters defined in your `tspconfig.yaml` file. You have the flexibility to suppress this rule entirely or target specific sub-rules within it.\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress the Entire SdkTspConfigValidation Rule\\\\n\\\\nIf you need to skip **all** validation checks for emitter options and parameters within a particular `tspconfig.yaml` file, you can suppress the entire `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule.\\\\r\\\\nTo do this, add or update the `suppressions.yaml` file in your service's root folder with the following content:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n\\\\nIf you only need to bypass validation for **specific** emitter options or parameters, you can suppress individual sub-rules.\\\\r\\\\nAdd or update your `suppressions.yaml` file with the following structure, specifying the sub-rules to ignore:\\\\r\\\\nSub-rule Syntax:\\\\r\\\\n- For parameters: `parameters.\\\\u003cparameter-key\\\\u003e.default`\\\\r\\\\n- For emitter options: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003coption-key\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- For nested options (e.g., `package-details: name: \\\\\\\"xxx\\\\\\\"`), use dot notation: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific parameter's default value\\\\r\\\\n    - parameters.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e.default \\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a nested emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - link](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2932):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nissue title: Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\ncontent: \\\\r\\\\nThis is an example,\\\\r\\\\npageable operation[https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/03a6598cdc38924f9eaaeb03f8ef151f5aeff449/specification/guestconfiguration/resource-manager/Microsoft.GuestConfiguration/stable/2024-04-05/guestconfiguration.json#L1046]\\\\r\\\\nnon-pageable operation[https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/03a6598cdc38924f9eaaeb03f8ef151f5aeff449/specification/guestconfiguration/resource-manager/Microsoft.GuestConfiguration/stable/2024-04-05/guestconfiguration.json#L358]\\\\r\\\\nThey share the same response model GuestConfigurationAssignmentReportList.\\\\r\\\\nIn swagger, pageable is marked at operation level, while in TypeSpec pageable is marked at model level. We need to figure out a way for this case.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nsolution:\\\\r\\\\nAs discussed, TypeSpec\\u2019s core paging system supports both client-driven and server-driven paging, but it requires explicit specification\\u2014there is no default assumption like nextLink. If a response model lacks nextLink, it\\u2019s not considered pageable in the traditional sense, and setting x-ms-pageable would be a misinterpretation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe recommendation is to use the standard ARM paging mechanism. Since nextLink is optional, adding it is not a breaking change. This ensures that if paging is implemented later, it follows the standard. Ultimately, the solution agreed upon is to add nextLink and use the core paging schema in TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n#suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n- model ListAppIdResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAppId\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n+ model ListAppIdResponse {\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * List of AppIds\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.pageItems\\\\r\\\\n+    value: string[];\\\\r\\\\n+\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * next Link\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.nextLink\\\\r\\\\n+    nextLink?: string;\\\\r\\\\n+ }\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such You can use a suppression in these cases.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\nHear directly from teams who have successfully transitioned to TypeSpec Azure and learn about their experiences:\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"troubleshoot#suppresswarnings.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to suppress warnings\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/troubleshoot/suppresswarnings\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to suppress warnings\\\\n# troubleshoot#suppresswarnings.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to suppress warnings\\\\n\\\\nThis article helps you to suppress warning messages generated by TypeSpec and libraries.\\\\n\\\\n## Symptoms\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec core and libraries could generate and output warning messages based on linting rules.\\\\n\\\\n## Cause\\\\n\\\\nThese linting rules are introduced to ensure high-quality specs being generated. Sometimes they are used to call out areas needs developer attention to meet library or organization guidelines.\\\\n\\\\n## Workaround\\\\n\\\\nSome of the rules after review can be suppressed to get clean compile outputs using `#suppress ErrCode ReasonMsg` statement. The error code is the string reported in compiler output.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n//suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-providerhub/no-identifier-property-in-array-item\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"Error items have no unique identifier.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n/** An array of details about specific errors that led to this reported error. */\\\\r\\\\ndetails: Error[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nendpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n2. Avocado error: I have removed an API revokeCertificate and added a new api revokeCertificates which takes an array. \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nHow do I fix both errors?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n [Added private endpoint connection, bulk revocation and c2pa certificate type by amritas \\u00b7 Pull Requ\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24553)\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nModel validation Error - Additional properties not allowed: groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState,privateEndpoint,provisioningState\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nPEC contract - \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Private endpoint connection resource.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection\\\\r\\\\n    is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations(PrivateEndpointConnection)\\\\r\\\\ninterface PrivateEndpointConnections {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Get a specific private connection */\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\n\\\\nlistPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\r\\\\nThis will then get consumed by teams authoring Azure APIs. As such, they have the Azure linting in place (naming conventions and whatnot).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe wanted to know whether definitions can also come with suppressions (not inline, as this definition is auto-importer on a regular basis), which would apply ONLY to the definitions we share, not to the rest of the consumer's project?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nThanks!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nsuppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\\\\n\\\\noperations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cEmployee, EmployeeProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  getPrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.Read\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  updatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  deletePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.DeleteAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\n\\\\nI have the below PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) where some of the LintDiff validations are failing with the exception \\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\n  Violation: file:///home/runner/work/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/after/specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/stable/2025-08-15/Limit.json:578\\\\r\\\\n    Level: error\\\\r\\\\n    Code: RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel\\\\r\\\\n    Message: Model definition 'SharingDetail' must have the properties 'name', 'id' and 'type' in its hierarchy and these properties must be marked as readonly.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis particular model is defined as follows - \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel SharingDetail {\\\\r\\\\n  role: SharingRole;\\\\r\\\\n  sharedLimits?: QuotaLimitProperties[];\\\\r\\\\n  guestSubscriptions?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  host?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nIs it possible have a suppression for this validation? If so, how?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nthe link for lintdiff suppressions:\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nyou probably want to fix this in your spec, not suppress the error\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nYou need to fix check \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Validation\\\\\\\" in your PR, before other check results will even be valid.  This is documented in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Model validations are failing although am referring from common-types\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\n1. I have reused the model Private endpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\n\\\\nis ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateLink is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateLinkResourceProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...PrivateLinkResourceParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n updated the operationId and it worked. Let me know if the PrivateEndpointConnection should be a customized name or can retain same name as in commonTypes?\\\\r\\\\n Would this be guided by the reviewer?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nLooking at your PR, it seems that the avocado error is the only remaining one - this is just reporting that you have removed an API.  If you do not need to continue supporting the older preview, you might consider removing it,  otherwise, this is an error you can safely suppress (https://aka.ms/ci-fix is a great link to remember, as it has links to all kinds of useful info about ci errors, including a link to the suppression guides).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nFor PrivateEndpointConnections, RPs have done both, as the name of the private endpoint connection type doesn't really matter to the API, however, there is a new template that greatly simplifies adding private endpoint connection operations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n- path: data-plane/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen in doubt, search the repo for examples:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/search?q=repo%3AAzure%2Fazure-rest-api-specs+path%3A%2F%28%5E%7C%5C%2F%29suppressions%5C.yaml%24%2F\\\\u0026type=code\\\\n\\\\n### `TypeSpec Requirement` check\\\\n\\\\nTo suppress `TypeSpec Requirement` check for given pattern of OpenAPI spec .json file paths, provide an entry with\\\\r\\\\n`tool` set to `TypeSpecRequirement`. Provide the pattern as `path` and provide a `reason`.\\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: data-plane/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Suppress AutoRest extension\\\\n\\\\nTo suppress tooling that is an AutoRest extension (see [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table)),\\\\r\\\\nfollow the AutoRest documentation:\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/generate/suppress-warnings.md\\\\r\\\\nThat documentation describes the **new syntax** for AutoRest suppression, as opposed to the old, directive-based syntax.\\\\r\\\\nYou can [search for existing usages](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AAzure%2Fazure-rest-api-specs%20suppressions%3A\\\\u0026type=code).\\\\n\\\\n### Obtain error code\\\\n\\\\nTo get error code,  i.e. the value for `- code:`:\\\\r\\\\n- For `SemanticValidation` and `ModelValidation`, refer to [error definition](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/Semantic-and-Model-Violations-Reference.md).\\\\r\\\\n- For `LintDiff` and `LintDiff(RPaaS)`, refer to [rules.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/rules.md).\\\\n\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n\\\\n### Ensure you are suppressing the right tag (API version)\\\\n\\\\nIf, for example, the error pertains to API version 2021-09-01, then the suppressions must be in\\\\r\\\\nthe `### Tag: package-2021-09-01` section, not `### Tag: package-2021-09-01-preview` or `### Tag: package-2023-04-27`.\\\\n\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n\\\\nThe path in the suppression you add must point to exactly the same element as pointed out by the error.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, if the failure link points [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/30be453a97b9a4d64b1a7a6e45d7364bfbf4d8a2/specification/subscription/resource-manager/Microsoft.Subscription/stable/2021-10-01/subscriptions.json#L137),\\\\r\\\\nthen the path should be:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` xpath\\\\r\\\\n$.paths[\\\\\\\"/providers/Microsoft.Subscription/subscriptionOperations/{operationId}\\\\\\\"].get.responses[\\\\\\\"202\\\\\\\"]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- [Example path for suppressing LintDiff code `GetOperation200`](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/24395/commits/41f8f34937be245a855ff49552ecdeb0213ca525)\\\\r\\\\n  - **IMPORTANT**: This example uses the legacy `directive/suppress` syntax. Do not use it. Use the new syntax instead.\\\\r\\\\n  - [Relevant Teams discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:0351f5f9404446e4b4fd4eaf2c27448d@thread.skype/1688105866973?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1687971321354\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=API%20Spec%20Review\\\\u0026createdTime=1688105866973)\\\\n\\\\n### Verify your 'where' path with jsonpath and ensure proper escaping\\\\n\\\\nIf you have trouble with getting the `where` clause to work, then:\\\\r\\\\n#### Ensure you are escaping _segments_\\\\r\\\\nFor example, if you want to denote `format` in following example snippet\\\\r\\\\n([original occurrence in a PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/25763/files#diff-2e82aff34a54fd667da22140fc9b9e68bf6690a968f628263493f4a837577f64R2203-R2205),  \\\\r\\\\n[comment](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/25763/files#r1385932846)):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"definitions\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"format\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"eTag\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nyou should use `where: $.definitions[\\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\"].format` and not `where: $.definitions.Azure.Core.eTag.format`.\\\\r\\\\nThe entire suppression would look like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\nsuppressions:\\\\r\\\\n  - code: ValidFormats\\\\r\\\\n    where: $.definitions[\\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\"].format\\\\r\\\\n    reason: eTag should be an allowed format\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Consider verifying your path with https://jsonpath.com/\\\\r\\\\nFor example, you can paste as JSONPath `$.definitions[\\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\"].format` and in `Inputs`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` suppressions for it, if any.\\\\n\\\\n## Valid suppression reasons\\\\n\\\\n### Valid reasons\\\\n\\\\nYou can request suppression of validation errors if one or more of the following scenarios matches your case;\\\\r\\\\n1. Is this actually correct? \\\\r\\\\nOr would we consider this a benign change? And a best practice to 'fix' unnamed types by creating named types to replace them?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIntroducing named types to replace unnamed ones is not a bad idea\\u2014in fact, it's preferred. The linter rule @azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core/no-unnamed-types exists to encourage naming types. However, in the PR you referenced, there was a suppression added with the justification of \\\\\\\"Backwards compatibility with existing clients.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nAfter reviewing the context, it seems this suppression may not be necessary. The rule itself is currently disabled due to performance issues, so removing the suppression won\\u2019t trigger CI. Conceptually, this is a false positive: the anonymous model created via @bodyRoot is a temporary structure that the SDK won\\u2019t use, so it shouldn't be flagged.\\\\r\\\\nStill, the current template resolves to a borderline case where the SDK might auto-generate a name. A cleaner approach would be to use @@clientName to rename the body parameter directly, avoiding the anonymous model altogether. Update paths in suppressions:\\\\r\\\\nAs GitHub recognize this refactor change as to add new API versions in the OpenAPI folder, in order to make sure the TypeSpec requirement check pass. we need to have a suppressions.yaml under serviceName folder \\\\r\\\\nand add suppression one by one like this \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: ./preview/2022-01-01-preview/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: ./stable/2025-01-01/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## The impact to ongoing PRs\\\\n\\\\n1. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Validation Rule Suppression\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n# TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n\\\\nYou can suppress specific validation rules within `TypeSpecValidation` by creating or modifying a `suppressions.yaml` file in the root directory of your service specification.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Note:** Currently, only the `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule supports suppression.\\\\n\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n\\\\nThe `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule is responsible for validating emitter options and parameters defined in your `tspconfig.yaml` file. You have the flexibility to suppress this rule entirely or target specific sub-rules within it.\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress the Entire SdkTspConfigValidation Rule\\\\n\\\\nIf you need to skip **all** validation checks for emitter options and parameters within a particular `tspconfig.yaml` file, you can suppress the entire `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule.\\\\r\\\\nTo do this, add or update the `suppressions.yaml` file in your service's root folder with the following content:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n\\\\nIf you only need to bypass validation for **specific** emitter options or parameters, you can suppress individual sub-rules.\\\\r\\\\nAdd or update your `suppressions.yaml` file with the following structure, specifying the sub-rules to ignore:\\\\r\\\\nSub-rule Syntax:\\\\r\\\\n- For parameters: `parameters.\\\\u003cparameter-key\\\\u003e.default`\\\\r\\\\n- For emitter options: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003coption-key\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- For nested options (e.g., `package-details: name: \\\\\\\"xxx\\\\\\\"`), use dot notation: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific parameter's default value\\\\r\\\\n    - parameters.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e.default \\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a nested emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name \\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"Currently, TypeSpec suppression rules can only be provided inline within the TypeSpec files themselves. There is no supported mechanism to package suppressions with a shared TypeSpec definitions package such that they apply only to the imported definitions and not to the rest of the consumer's project. Linter rules can be disabled globally, but this would affect the entire project, not just the imported definitions. Therefore, if you need to suppress specific linting rules for your shared definitions, you must do so inline in those files. There is no file- or package-scoped suppression mechanism available at this time.\", \"ground_truth\": \"suppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\"}"}]
