Decorators\\\\n# language-basics#decorators.md\\\\n\\\\n# Decorators\\\\n\\\\nDecorators in TypeSpec allow developers to attach metadata to types within a TypeSpec program. They can also be used to compute types based on their inputs. Decorators form the core of TypeSpec's extensibility, providing the flexibility to describe a wide variety of APIs and associated metadata such as documentation, constraints, samples, and more.\\\\r\\\\nThe vast majority of TypeSpec declarations may be decorated, including [namespaces](./namespaces.md), [interfaces](./interfaces.md), [operations](./operations.md) and their parameters, [scalars](./scalars.md), and [models](./models.md) and their members. In general, any declaration that creates a Type can be decorated. Notably, [aliases](./alias.md) cannot be decorated, as they do not create new Types, nor can any type expressions such as unions that use the `|` syntax or anonymous models, as they are not declarations.\\\\r\\\\nDecorators are defined using JavaScript functions that are exported from a standard ECMAScript module. When a JavaScript file is imported, TypeSpec will look for any exported functions prefixed with `$`, and make them available as decorators within the TypeSpec syntax. When a decorated declaration is evaluated by TypeSpec, the decorator function is invoked, passing along a reference to the current compilation, an object representing the type it is attached to, and any arguments the user provided to the decorator.\\\\n\\\\n## Applying decorators\\\\n\\\\nDecorators are referenced using the `@` prefix and must be placed before the entity they are decorating. Arguments can be provided by using parentheses, similar to function calls in many programming languages, e.g., `@myDec1(\\\\\\\"hi\\\\\\\", { a: string })`.\\\\r\\\\nHere's an example of declaring and then using a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"Sample\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  @validate(false)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIf no arguments are provided, the parentheses can be omitted.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@mark\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Augmenting decorators\\\\n\\\\nDecorators can also be applied from a different location by referring to the type being decorated. For this, you can declare an augment decorator using the `@@` prefix. The first argument of an augment decorator is the type reference that should be decorated. As the augment decorator is a statement, it must end with a semicolon (`;`).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {}\\\\r\\\\n@@tag(Dog, \\\\\\\"Sample\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is equivalent to:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"Sample\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nExample: decorating a model property to indicate that it is read-only\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@@visibility(Dog.name, Lifecycle.Read);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Creating decorators\\\\n\\\\nFor more information on creating decorators, see [Creating Decorators](../extending-typespec/create-decorators.md).\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"language-basics#documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/documentation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Documentation\\\\n# language-basics#documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Documentation\\\\n\\\\nDocumentation is a vital aspect of any API. TypeSpec offers several ways to document your API, including doc comments and decorators.\\\\n\\\\n## Approaches to documenting APIs\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provides two primary methods for documenting your API:\\\\r\\\\n- `@doc` decorator\\\\r\\\\n- `/** */` Doc comments\\\\r\\\\nThe latter is less intrusive to the specification and is often preferred.\\\\r\\\\nIn both cases while not required, the documentation should be written in Markdown format, TypeSpec tooling will assume so. [See Markdown](#markdown) for more information.\\\\n\\\\n## The `@doc` decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe `@doc` decorator can be used to attach documentation to most TypeSpec declarations. It typically accepts a string argument that serves as the documentation for the declaration.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"This is a sample model\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"This is a sample property\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe `@doc` decorator can also accept a source object, which can be used to provide templated documentation for a generic type, for example.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Templated {name}\\\\\\\", Type)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Template\\\\u003cType extends {}\\\\u003e  {\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// The documentation will read \\\\\\\"Templated A\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nmodel A is Template\\\\u003cA\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Doc comments\\\\n\\\\nYou can annotate objects in your TypeSpec specification with doc comments. These comments are treated as if they were attached using the `@doc` decorator and can be used to generate external documentation.\\\\r\\\\nDoc comments start with `/**` and continue until the closing `*/` is encountered. [Tags](#doc-comment-tags) can be used to provide additional documentation context.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * Get a widget.\\\\r\\\\n * @param widgetId The ID of the widget to retrieve.\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\nop read(@path widgetId: string): Widget | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is functionally equivalent to:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Get a widget.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop read(\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The ID of the widget to retrieve.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  widgetId: string,\\\\r\\\\n): Widget | Error;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe advantage of using doc comment syntax is that it consolidates all the documentation for a declaration in one place, with distinct comment colors, making it easier to read and maintain. Additionally, it facilitates the generation of documentation using tools like TypeDoc, eliminating the need to write a custom emitter to process the @doc metadata.\\\\n\\\\n### Doc comment tags\\\\n\\\\nAs shown in the previous example, doc comments can use certain tags to document additional elements or provide different documentation context.\\\\r\\\\n| Tag                     | Description                       | Example                                             |\\\\r\\\\n| ----------------------- | --------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `@param`                | Documents a parameter.            | `@param widgetId The ID of the widget to retrieve.` |\\\\r\\\\n| `@returns`              | Documents the operation response. | `@returns The widget.`                              |\\\\r\\\\n| `@template`             | Document a template parameter     | `@template T the resource type`                     |\\\\r\\\\n| `@example` (unofficial) | Show examples                     | `@example \\\\\\\\`model Foo {}\\\\\\\\` `                        |\\\\n\\\\n## Comments\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec supports both single-line and multi-line comments. Single-line comments start with `//` and continue until the end of the line. Multi-line comments start with `/*` and continue until the closing `*/` is encountered.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n// This is a single-line comment\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  /* This is a multi-line comment\\\\r\\\\n  that spans multiple lines */\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nComments are ignored by the compiler and do not appear in the generated output. They are intended for internal documentation of your spec and are not suitable for generating external documentation.\\\\n\\\\n## Markdown\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec Documentation support CommonMark markdown formatting. The tooling(IDE extensions, doc generation, etc.) will process the documentation as markdown.\\\\r\\\\nEmitters can choose to render the description as it is, convert it to their preferred format or just strip any markdown information.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``tsp\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"This is a **bold** text\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"This is a _italic_ text\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * This contains a bullet list\\\\r\\\\n   * - one\\\\r\\\\n   * - two\\\\r\\\\n   * and code blocks\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typescript\\\\r\\\\n   * dog.age = 5;\\\\r\\\\n   * \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/azure-core/long-running-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n## Describing Custom LRO Patterns using Azure.Core\\\\n### Custom LROs - Operation Links\\\\n# howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Describing Custom LRO Patterns using Azure.Core\\\\n\\\\n### Custom LROs - Operation Links\\\\n\\\\nOperation links are used when the input parameters to a linked operation can be determined from parameters in the initial operation request and response. For example, if a polling operation uses the identity parameters of the initial request, and an `operationId` parameter which is returned in a header or field in the response, the link between the operations should be modeled as an Operation Link. In order to use an Operation link, each parameter of the linked operation must correspond with a parameter of the initial operation, a property of the initial request (header or body), or property of the initial response (header or body). Operation links encode a reference to the linked operation, and a mapping between the initial request and response and the parameters of the linked operation:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nop getWidgetOperationStatus is getResourceOperationStatus\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@pollingOperation(getWidgetOperationStatus, parameterMap)\\\\r\\\\nop createWidgetAsync is longRunningCreateOrReplace\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNote that, in the example above, the `@pollingOperation`decorator is used to specify an operation link to a StatusMonitor endpoint. This is just syntactic sugar for `@operationLink(getWidgetOperationStatus, \\\\\\\"polling\\\\\\\", parameterMap)`. To represent the logical stages of an LRO, `@pollingOperation` represents a link to a statusMonitor, and is the only decoration required for operations that comply with the recommended LRO pattern. Another decorator `@finalOperation` represents a link to an operation where the final result must be obtained my making a final request after polling has terminated.\\\\r\\\\n#### Decorators for Operation Links in Azure.Core\\\\r\\\\nAzure.Core defines the following decorators for operation links\\\\r\\\\n`@pollingOperation` - links a long-running operation to its status monitor endpoint.\\\\n\\\\na link to a statusMonitor, and is the only decoration required for operations that comply with the recommended LRO pattern. Another decorator `@finalOperation` represents a link to an operation where the final result must be obtained my making a final request after polling has terminated.\\\\r\\\\n#### Decorators for Operation Links in Azure.Core\\\\r\\\\nAzure.Core defines the following decorators for operation links\\\\r\\\\n`@pollingOperation` - links a long-running operation to its status monitor endpoint.\\\\r\\\\n`@finalOperation` - links a long-running operation to an additional endpoint, in the case that an additional endpoint must be called to obtain the final result after polling the status monitor is complete.\\\\r\\\\nEach of these decorators require a reference to the linked operation. They may also provide a mapping between the parameters and response properties of the initial request to the parameters of the linked operation. This mapping can be provided as a `Model` type parameter passed to the decorator, or by decorating the parameters and response properties of the original operation using `@lroParameter`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/azure-core/long-running-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n## Long-running Operation Helpers for Emitters and Libraries\\\\n# howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Long-running Operation Helpers for Emitters and Libraries\\\\n\\\\nThe Azure.Core library provides a helper that emitters can use to determine if an operation being processed is an LRO, and to provide details about how the LRO should be processed by clients, or about how operations are linked.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ngetLroMetadata( program: Program, operation: Operation) : LroMetadata | undefined;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe `LroMetadata` returned from this function contains information about the linked operations and their behavior, as well as additional that clients used to processing OpenAPI2 will be able to use to process TypeSpec operations similarly:\\\\r\\\\n| Property          | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |\\\\r\\\\n| ----------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `logicalResponse` | contains the type of the operation response, for the long-running operation (i.e. the result after polling completes).                                                                                                                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `final-state-via` | contains values corresponding to the same field in the `x-ms-long-running-operation-options` extension in OpenAPI specifications.                                                                                                                                                       |\\\\r\\\\n| `statusMonitor`   | contains information about the status monitor, including the status monitor type\\\\n\\\\n| contains values corresponding to the same field in the `x-ms-long-running-operation-options` extension in OpenAPI specifications.                                                                                                                                                       |\\\\r\\\\n| `statusMonitor`   | contains information about the status monitor, including the status monitor type                                                                                                                                                                                                        |\\\\r\\\\n| `polling`         | contains information about polling the status monitor, including the status field and terminal status values                                                                                                                                                                            |\\\\r\\\\n| `final`           | contains information about how to get the result when polling completes. In the standard case. this will contain a reference to the status monitor property that contains result information. If another operation needs to be called to get the status, that information will be here. |\\\\r\\\\nAs indicated above, operations often contain multiple mechanisms that clients can use to resolve a long-running operation, this means that an operation will frequently contain both operation links and resource links that describe the LRO. The helper prefers the use of resource links to the use of operation links, where possible.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@added`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.added) decorator is used to indicate that a model or operation was added in a specific version of the API. This allows you to manage changes and additions to your API over time.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Adding a New Model in a Specific Version\\\\n\\\\nLet's add a `Toy` model that is only available in version 2 of the API:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @minLength(1)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @minValue(0)\\\\r\\\\n  @maxValue(100)\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  kind: petType;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nenum petType {\\\\r\\\\n  dog: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  cat: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  fish: \\\\\\\"fish\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  bird: \\\\\\\"bird\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  reptile: \\\\\\\"reptile\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Toy {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- The `Toy` model is defined with the `@added(Versions.v2)` decorator to indicate that it was added in version 2 of the API.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Introduction to the `@versioned` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction to the `@versioned` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@versioned`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.versioned) decorator is used to define different versions of your API. This decorator allows you to specify the versions that your API supports and manage changes across these versions.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Defining API Versions\\\\n\\\\nLet's define two versions of our API, `v1` and `v2`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-next-line\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- We're importing and using a new module, `@typespec/versioning`, which provides versioning support.\\\\r\\\\n- The `@versioned` decorator is used to define the versions supported by the API, defined in the `Versions` enum.\\\\r\\\\n- The `Versions` enum specifies two versions: `v1` (1.0) and `v2` (2.0).\\\\n\\\\n### Generating OpenAPI Specifications for Different Versions\\\\n\\\\nOnce versions are added, the TypeSpec compiler generates individual OpenAPI specifications for each version.\\\\r\\\\n{/* prettier-ignore */}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cFileTree\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n- tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n- package.json\\\\r\\\\n- node_modules/\\\\r\\\\n- tsp-output/\\\\r\\\\n  - @typespec/\\\\r\\\\n    - openapi3\\\\r\\\\n      - openapi.1.0.yaml\\\\r\\\\n      - openapi.2.0.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/FileTree\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nGenerating separate specs for each version ensures backward compatibility, provides clear documentation for developers to understand differences between versions, and simplifies maintenance by allowing independent updates to each version's specifications.\\\\r\\\\nBy encapsulating different versions of the API within the context of the same TypeSpec project, we can manage all versions in a unified manner. This approach makes it easier to maintain consistency, apply updates, and ensure that all versions are properly documented and aligned with the overall API strategy.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/azure-core/long-running-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n## Describing Custom LRO Patterns using Azure.Core\\\\n# howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Describing Custom LRO Patterns using Azure.Core\\\\n\\\\nThe `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core` library also contains general structures for defining custom long-running operations using specialized model templates and decorators. The following sections describe . The primary mechanisms for linking operations are `Operation Links` and `Resource Links`.\\\\n\\\\n### Custom LROs - Operation Links\\\\n\\\\nOperation links are used when the input parameters to a linked operation can be determined from parameters in the initial operation request and response. For example, if a polling operation uses the identity parameters of the initial request, and an `operationId` parameter which is returned in a header or field in the response, the link between the operations should be modeled as an Operation Link. In order to use an Operation link, each parameter of the linked operation must correspond with a parameter of the initial operation, a property of the initial request (header or body), or property of the initial response (header or body). Operation links encode a reference to the linked operation, and a mapping between the initial request and response and the parameters of the linked operation:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nop getWidgetOperationStatus is getResourceOperationStatus\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@pollingOperation(getWidgetOperationStatus, parameterMap)\\\\r\\\\nop createWidgetAsync is longRunningCreateOrReplace\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNote that, in the example above, the `@pollingOperation`decorator is used to specify an operation link to a StatusMonitor endpoint. This is just syntactic sugar for `@operationLink(getWidgetOperationStatus, \\\\\\\"polling\\\\\\\", parameterMap)`. To represent the logical stages of an LRO, `@pollingOperation` represents a link to a statusMonitor, and is the only decoration required for operations that comply with the recommended LRO pattern. Another decorator `@finalOperation` represents a link to an operation where the final result must be obtained my making a final request after polling has terminated.\\\\r\\\\n#### Decorators for Operation Links in Azure.Core\\\\r\\\\nAzure.Core defines the following decorators for operation links\\\\r\\\\n`@pollingOperation` - links a long-running operation to its status monitor endpoint.\\\\n\\\\na link to a statusMonitor, and is the only decoration required for operations that comply with the recommended LRO pattern. Another decorator `@finalOperation` represents a link to an operation where the final result must be obtained my making a final request after polling has terminated.\\\\r\\\\n#### Decorators for Operation Links in Azure.Core\\\\r\\\\nAzure.Core defines the following decorators for operation links\\\\r\\\\n`@pollingOperation` - links a long-running operation to its status monitor endpoint.\\\\r\\\\n`@finalOperation` - links a long-running operation to an additional endpoint, in the case that an additional endpoint must be called to obtain the final result after polling the status monitor is complete.\\\\r\\\\nEach of these decorators require a reference to the linked operation. They may also provide a mapping between the parameters and response properties of the initial request to the parameters of the linked operation. This mapping can be provided as a `Model` type parameter passed to the decorator, or by decorating the parameters and response properties of the original operation using `@lroParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### Custom LROs - Resource Links\\\\n\\\\nResource links are used when the entire url of the linked operation is provided as part of the response to the initial operation. A resource link encodes the type of the expected response when the link is followed:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel WidgetStatusMonitorResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  @pollingLocation\\\\r\\\\n  @header(\\\\\\\"Operation-Location\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  operationLocation: ResourceLocation\\\\u003cResourceOperationStatus\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // following the url in this header will provide a response of type ResourceOperationStatus\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Decorators for Resource Links in Azure.Core\\\\r\\\\nAzure.Core defines the following decorators for resource links used in long-running operations:\\\\r\\\\n`@pollingLocation` - indicates that the decorated property contains a url to the StatusMonitor. The type of the decorated property **should** be a `ResourceLocation`.\\\\r\\\\n`@finalLocation` - indicates that the decorated property contains a url to the final result, in cases where an additional request must be made after polling to obtain the final result of the operation. The type of the decorated property must be a `ResourceLocation`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nalias ResultHeaders = {\\\\r\\\\n  @pollingLocation\\\\r\\\\n  @header(\\\\\\\"Operation-Location\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  operationLocation: ResourceLocation\\\\u003cResourceOperationStatus\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @finalLocation\\\\r\\\\n  @header(\\\\\\\"location\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  location: ResourceLocation\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n};\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nNote that the LRO templates provided in Azure.Core automatically provide the appropriate headers and resource location decoration for LROs.\\\\r\\\\nNote that operations often provide multiple mechanisms that clients may use to determine how to logically complete an operation. This is often done to allow clients with different capabilities to determine how to resolve a long-running operation. It is recommended that clients prefer using Operation links in preference to Resource links whenever possible, because OperationLinks provide more information about the next operation.\\\\n\\\\n### Status Monitor Types in Azure.Core\\\\n\\\\nFor Azure services, there is clear API guidance that requires usage of the Status Monitor pattern. In Azure, the Status Monitor has a specific structure, including:\\\\r\\\\n- A 'status' property containing the current status of the operation\\\\r\\\\n  - The status property is a string property that contains known values for terminal states, by default these are 'Succeeded' for successful operation termination, 'Failed' for operation termination with failure, and 'Canceled' to indicate the operation was canceled.\\\\r\\\\n- A 'result' property, containing the result of the operation once the operation has succeeded (and is null if it has not succeeded)\\\\r\\\\n- An 'error' property, containing any errors that occurred during the operation.\\\\r\\\\nIn Azure.Core, this structure is represented using the `ResourceOperationStatus\\\\u003cTResource, TSuccess, TError\\\\u003e` model. The initial response to a long-running operation in Azure must contain an `Operation-Location` header that contains a url to the StatusMonitor endpoint. The StatusMonitor endpoint Url can also be calculated using the key properties of the resource and an additional `operationId` key property. To allow repeatability of requests and automatic calculation of the statusMonitor Uri, each LRO should allow an `OperationId` header that sets the operationId for the operation id execution. The `OperationId` must also be included in a header in the initial lro response. These patterns are encoded in the `LongRunning` operation templates provided in Azure.Core. If your service description uses these templates, it will automatically be following the recommended pattern.\\\\n\\\\n### Decorators and Types for Custom StatusMonitors in Azure.Core\\\\n\\\\nA StatusMonitor provides information that drives client polling until an operation completes. This includes a `status` field containing the current state of the operation, with known values for terminal states, headers that suggest polling retry intervals, and fields that will contain result and error information when the operation reaches a terminal status. Azure.Core provides a `ResourceOperationStatus` template that defines the standard Azure status monitor for an Azure operation. However, some services may need to implement custom status monitors. Azure.Core provides additional decorators to help clients use custom status monitors.\\\\r\\\\n| Decorator                    | Value                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| ---------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `@lroStatus`                 | A decorator marking the field of the StatusMonitor that contains status information. This field should use a `union` type to specify terminal status values.                                                                                                              |\\\\r\\\\n| `@lroResult`                 | A decorator marking the property of the Status monitor that contains the result of the operation, when the operation completes successfully. By default, any field named 'result' in a StatusMonitor is assumed to contain the result of a successful operation.          |\\\\r\\\\n| `@lroErrorResult`            | A decorator marking the property of the Status monitor that contains errors when the operation is unsuccessful.\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| `@lroResult`                 | A decorator marking the property of the Status monitor that contains the result of the operation, when the operation completes successfully. By default, any field named 'result' in a StatusMonitor is assumed to contain the result of a successful operation.          |\\\\r\\\\n| `@lroErrorResult`            | A decorator marking the property of the Status monitor that contains errors when the operation is unsuccessful. By default, any field named 'error' in a StatusMonitor is assumed to contain the result of a successful operation.                                        |\\\\r\\\\n| `@lroSucceeded`              | If a status monitor uses a value other than `Succeeded` to indicate operation termination with success, then the variant corresponding to successful completion should be decorated wit\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\\\\n\\\\nhere's a `emit-lro-options`\\\\n# emitters#typespec-autorest#reference#emitter.md\\\\n\\\\n# Emitter usage\\\\n\\\\n## Emitter options\\\\n\\\\n### `emit-lro-options`\\\\n\\\\n**Type:** `\\\\\\\"none\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"final-state-only\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"all\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\nDetermine whether and how to emit x-ms-long-running-operation-options for lro resolution\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#examples.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Examples\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/examples\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Examples\\\\n# standard-library#examples.md\\\\n\\\\n# Examples\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provide 2 decorators `@example` and `@opExample` to provide some examples for the types and operations.\\\\r\\\\nWith those decorators the examples must be provided as TypeSpec values that should be assignable to the type or operation parameter/return types.\\\\n\\\\n### Type Examples\\\\n\\\\nTo give an example for a type you can use the `@example` decorator. The decorator first argument is the example value it MUST be assignable to the type it is targetting.\\\\r\\\\nAdditionally a title and/or description can be provided in the options.\\\\n\\\\n### Simple primitive types\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@example(#{ name: \\\\\\\"Max\\\\\\\", age: 3 })\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Scalar types\\\\n\\\\nFor scalar types the value must be defined with the scalar constructor.\\\\r\\\\nThis allows emitters to render the example in the correct protocol following the encoding of those scalar and the values set by `@encode`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@example(#{\\\\r\\\\n  id: \\\\\\\"item-1\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  createdAt: plainDate.fromISO(\\\\\\\"2020-01-01T00:00:00Z\\\\\\\"),\\\\r\\\\n  timeout: duration.fromISO(\\\\\\\"PT1M\\\\\\\"),\\\\r\\\\n})\\\\r\\\\nmodel Item {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  createdAt: utcDateTime;\\\\r\\\\n  @encode(\\\\\\\"seconds\\\\\\\", int32) timeout: duration;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Provide title or description\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@example(#{ name: \\\\\\\"Max\\\\\\\", age: 3 }, #{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet example\\\\\\\", description: \\\\\\\"Simple pet example\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Multiple examples\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@example(#{ name: \\\\\\\"Max\\\\\\\", age: 3 }, #{ title: \\\\\\\"Minimal examples\\\\\\\", description: \\\\\\\"Minimal examples\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@example(\\\\r\\\\n  #{ name: \\\\\\\"Rex\\\\\\\", age: 8, bark: true },\\\\r\\\\n  #{ title: \\\\\\\"With optional properties\\\\\\\", description: \\\\\\\"Example where the pet barks\\\\\\\" }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Define typed examples using `const`\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nconst petExample: Pet = #{ name: \\\\\\\"Max\\\\\\\", age: 3 };\\\\r\\\\n@example(petExample)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Operation examples\\\\n\\\\nOperation example are provided with the `@opExample` decorator. Similar to the `@example` decorator the first argument is the example value however it takes both the `parameters` and `returnType` example.\\\\r\\\\nThe values passed to `parameters` MUST be assignable to the operation parameters and the value passed to `returnType` MUST be assignable to the operation return type.\\\\r\\\\nAdditionally a title and/or description can be provided in the options.\\\\r\\\\n:::note\\\\r\\\\nOperation example will not validate additional properties as the applicable parameters might depend on the protocol and applied visibility.\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\n\\\\n### Simple operation parameters\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@opExample(#{ parameters: #{ name: \\\\\\\"Max\\\\\\\", age: 3 } })\\\\r\\\\nop write(name: string, age: int32): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Simple operation return types\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@opExample(#{ returnType: #{ name: \\\\\\\"Max\\\\\\\", age: 3 } })\\\\r\\\\nop read(): {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n};\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Specify title and/or description\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@opExample(\\\\r\\\\n  #{ parameters: #{ name: \\\\\\\"Max\\\\\\\", age: 3 } },\\\\r\\\\n  #{ title: \\\\\\\"Simple write example\\\\\\\", description: \\\\\\\"Write a pet\\\\\\\" }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nop write(name: string, age: int32): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n\\\\nThese examples show how to add models, operations, properties, and parameters in specific versions using TypeSpec versioning decorators.\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario demonstrates how to change a decorator\\u2019s usage across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you have a model property with a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the next version (v2), the visibility changes so that the property can be read or created. To achieve this, you can use a combination of `@removed`, `@added`, and `@renamedFrom` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"experience\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldExperience: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Adding a Parameter to an Operation and Making Another Parameter Optional\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario shows how to add a parameter and make another optional in an operation.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following operation in v1:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you want to:\\\\r\\\\n- Make the `location` header parameter optional.\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new optional query parameter `orderBy`.\\\\r\\\\nYou can achieve this using the `@madeOptional` and `@added` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @madeOptional(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location?: string;\\\\r\\\\n      @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @query(\\\\\\\"order-by\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n      orderBy?: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@madeOptional(Versions.v2)` makes `location` optional starting in v2.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the `orderBy` query parameter in v2 and later.\\\\n\\\\n### Converting an Operation from Synchronous to Asynchronous\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario illustrates converting a synchronous operation to an asynchronous one across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following synchronous operation in `v1`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you update this operation to be asynchronous as follows:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdateV1 is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@removed(Versions.v2)` removes the original synchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")` keeps the original name for v1.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the new asynchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@sharedRoute` ensures both operations can use the same route.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\\n\\\\n# Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi folks, \\\\r\\\\nDo you have any process or script to execute when creating a new api version with TypeSpec which is similar to current [Copy-ApiVersion.ps1](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/eng/scripts/Copy-ApiVersion.ps1) script with API Spec?  \\\\r\\\\nAs within the TypeSpec, those examples needs to be added manually and change the api version in it. I wonder if there are any existing script for doing this. Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIn TypeSPec, this is much simpler.  You don't need to replicate your old APIs, you just encode the changes in the api and tag them with decorators from the versioning library, as discussed here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/) \\\\r\\\\nYou will need to copy the example files from the example directory from the last version into a new example directory for the new version, and add any new examples. \\\\r\\\\nIf you run into any issues, don't hesitate to ask questions here, or come to our office hours on Monday.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Does TypeSpec have the option to achieve mutually exclusive?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Does TypeSpec have the option to achieve mutually exclusive?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Does TypeSpec have the option to achieve mutually exclusive?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have 2 properties `awsCloudProfile`and `gcpCloudProfilein` our preperties in our typespec update. These 2 properties are mutually exclusive(ensuring that only one of `awsCloudProfile` or `gcpCloudProfile` can exist at a time). Besides setting both of them to optional, is there any other options in TypeSpec that we can achieve the mutually exclusive without causing a breaking change?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThere isn't currently a built-in way in TypeSpec to enforce mutual exclusivity between properties like `awsCloudProfile` and `gcpCloudProfile`.\\\\r\\\\nIn your PR, you're making both properties optional \\u2014 but that\\u2019s actually a breaking change. Clients may have previously assumed that `awsCloudProfile` was always present, and now that constraint is being relaxed, which breaks existing behavior.\\\\r\\\\nAzure's recommended pattern for such cases is to use **explicit discriminated unions** to simplify the client experience. That means defining a `CloudProfile` union with a `@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")` to clearly indicate which cloud provider the profile belongs to. For example:\\\\r\\\\n```typescript\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nunion CloudProfile {\\\\r\\\\n  aws: AwsCloudProfile;\\\\r\\\\n  gcp: GcpCloudProfile;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel AwsCloudProfile {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"aws\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  awsAccountId: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel GcpCloudProfile {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"gcp\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  projectProperties?: GcpProjectProperties;\\\\r\\\\n  organizationProperties?: GcpOrganizationProperties;\\\\r\\\\n  isOrganization?: boolean = false;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWith this structure, your `CloudConnectorProperties` model just needs a single `cloudProfile` property. It allows you to support AWS, GCP, or any other provider in future API versions without breaking changes.\\\\r\\\\nTo clarify a few key points:\\\\r\\\\n1. **Is the `kind` property set by the customer?**\\\\r\\\\n   Yes, it appears on the wire. In some SDKs, the customer needs to set it explicitly; in others, it may be inferred by the SDK type system.\\\\r\\\\n2. **Does `kind` already exist in your types?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it doesn\\u2019t. This change would be a breaking change \\u2014 but one that allows forward compatibility when adding more cloud providers.\\\\r\\\\n3. **Would the `hostType` property still be needed?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it would become redundant if you adopt this `@discriminator` union pattern.\\\\r\\\\nAs a side note: TypeSpec has introduced a `@discriminated` decorator for unions, which supports more flexible patterns, but it is not yet supported by all SDK emitters.\\\\n\\\\n2. **Does `kind` already exist in your types?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it doesn\\u2019t. This change would be a breaking change \\u2014 but one that allows forward compatibility when adding more cloud providers.\\\\r\\\\n3. **Would the `hostType` property still be needed?**\\\\r\\\\n   No, it would become redundant if you adopt this `@discriminator` union pattern.\\\\r\\\\nAs a side note: TypeSpec has introduced a `@discriminated` decorator for unions, which supports more flexible patterns, but it is not yet supported by all SDK emitters. It\\u2019s under investigation and targeted for support around August. However, the `@discriminator` pattern (which you are using here) is already required to be supported by all SDK emitters and is safe to use today.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-31.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"202 response header Guidelines\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/Guidelines.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Microsoft Azure REST API Guidelines\\\\n## Common API Patterns\\\\n### Long-Running Operations \\\\u0026 Jobs\\\\n# azure#Guidelines.md\\\\n\\\\n# Microsoft Azure REST API Guidelines\\\\n\\\\n## Common API Patterns\\\\n\\\\n### Long-Running Operations \\\\u0026 Jobs\\\\n\\\\nPOST /UrlToExistingResource:\\\\u003caction\\\\u003e?api-version=\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e\\\\u0026\\\\u003cactionParamsGoHere\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\noperation-id: \\\\u003coptionalStatusMonitorResourceId\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cJSON Action parameters can go in body if query params don't work\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe response must look like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\n202 Accepted\\\\r\\\\noperation-id: \\\\u003cstatusMonitorResourceId\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\noperation-location: https://operations/\\\\u003coperation-id\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cJSON Status Monitor Resource in body\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe request body contains information to be used to execute the action.\\\\r\\\\nFor an idempotent POST (same `operation-id` and request body within some short time window), the service should return the same response as the initial request.\\\\r\\\\nFor a non-idempotent POST, the service can treat the POST operation as idempotent (if performed within a short time window) or can treat the POST operation as initiating a brand new LRO action operation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-no-post-create\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-no-post-create\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** use a long-running POST to create a resource -- use PUT as described above.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-operation-id-request-header\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-operation-id-request-header\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** allow the client to pass an `Operation-Id` header with an ID for the operation's status monitor.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-operation-id-default-is-guid\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-operation-id-default-is-guid\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** generate an ID (typically a GUID) for the status monitor if the `Operation-Id` header was not passed by the client.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-operation-id-unique-except-retries\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-operation-id-unique-except-retries\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** fail a request with a `409-Conflict` if the `Operation-Id` header matches an existing operation unless the request is identical to the prior request (a retry scenario).\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u0026\\\\u0026 Action LRO (POST or PUT), contains success result if needed\\\\r\\\\nadditional\\\\u003cbr/\\\\u003eproperties | | | Additional named or dynamic properties of the operation\\\\r\\\\n(*): When a status monitor endpoint supports multiple operations with different result structures or additional properties,\\\\r\\\\nthe status monitor **must** be polymorphic -- it **must** contain a required `kind` property that indicates the kind of long-running operation.\\\\r\\\\n#### Obtaining status and results of long-running operations\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-poll\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-poll\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** use the following pattern to allow clients to poll the current state of a Status Monitor resource:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\nGET \\\\u003coperation-endpoint\\\\u003e/\\\\u003coperation-id\\\\u003e?api-version=\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe response must look like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\n200 OK\\\\r\\\\nretry-after: \\\\u003cdelay-seconds\\\\u003e    (if status not terminal)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cJSON Status Monitor Resource in body\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-status-monitor-get-returns-200\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-status-monitor-get-returns-200\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** support the GET method on the status monitor endpoint that returns a `200-OK` response with the current state of the status monitor.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-status-monitor-accepts-any-api-version\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-status-monitor-accepts-any-api-version\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:ballot_box_with_check:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **YOU SHOULD** allow any valid value of the `api-version` query parameter to be used in the GET operation on the status monitor.\\\\r\\\\n- Note: Clients may replace the value of `api-version` in the `operation-location` URL with a value appropriate for their application. Remember that the client initiating the LRO may not be the same client polling the LRO's status.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-status-monitor-includes-all-fields\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-status-monitor-includes-all-fields\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** include the `id` of the operation and any other values needed for the client to form a GET request to the status monitor (e.g. a `location` path parameter).\\\\n\\\\nA _long-running operation (LRO)_ is typically an operation that should execute synchronously, but due to services not wanting to maintain long-lived connections (\\\\u003e1 seconds) and load-balancer timeouts, the operation must execute asynchronously. For this pattern, the client initiates the operation on the service, and then the client repeatedly polls the service (via another API call) to track the operation's progress/completion.\\\\r\\\\nLROs are always started by 1 logical client and may be polled (have their status checked) by the same client, another client, or even multiple clients/browsers. An example would be a dashboard or portal that shows all the operations along with their status.  See the [Long Running Operations section](./ConsiderationsForServiceDesign.md#long-running-operations) in Considerations for Service Design for an introduction to the design of long-running operations.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-response-time\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-response-time\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** implement an operation as an LRO if the 99th percentile response time is greater than 1 second and when the client should poll the operation before making more progress.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-no-patch-lro\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-no-patch-lro\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** implement PATCH as an LRO. If LRO update semantics are required, implement it using the [LRO POST action pattern](#lro-existing-resource) .\\\\r\\\\n#### Patterns to Initiate a Long-Running Operation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-valid-inputs-synchronously\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-valid-inputs-synchronously\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** perform as much validation as practical when initiating an LRO operation to alert clients of errors early.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-returns-operation-location\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-returns-operation-location\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** include an `operation-location` response header with the absolute URL of the status monitor for the operation.\\\\n\\\\n.\\\\r\\\\n#### Patterns to Initiate a Long-Running Operation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-valid-inputs-synchronously\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-valid-inputs-synchronously\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** perform as much validation as practical when initiating an LRO operation to alert clients of errors early.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-returns-operation-location\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-returns-operation-location\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** include an `operation-location` response header with the absolute URL of the status monitor for the operation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-operation-location-includes-api-version\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-operation-location-includes-api-version\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:ballot_box_with_check:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **YOU SHOULD** include the `api-version` query parameter in the `operation-location` response header with the same version passed on the initial request but expect a client to change the `api-version` value to whatever a new/different client desires it to be.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-put-response-headers\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-put-response-headers\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** include response headers with any additional values needed for a [GET polling request](#lro-poll) to the status monitor (e.g. location).\\\\r\\\\n#### Create or replace operation with additional long-running processing\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#put-operation-with-additional-long-running-processing\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"put-operation-with-additional-long-running-processing\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-create-init\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-create-init\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** use the following pattern when implementing an operation that creates or replaces a resource that involves additional long-running processing:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\nPUT /UrlToResourceBeingCreated?api-version=\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\noperation-id: \\\\u003coptionalStatusMonitorResourceId\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cJSON Resource in body\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe response must look like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\n201 Created\\\\r\\\\noperation-id: \\\\u003cstatusMonitorResourceId\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\noperation-location: https://operations/\\\\u003coperation-id\\\\u003e?api-version=\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cJSON Resource in body\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\npattern when implementing an operation that creates or replaces a resource that involves additional long-running processing:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\nPUT /UrlToResourceBeingCreated?api-version=\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\noperation-id: \\\\u003coptionalStatusMonitorResourceId\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cJSON Resource in body\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe response must look like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\n201 Created\\\\r\\\\noperation-id: \\\\u003cstatusMonitorResourceId\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\noperation-location: https://operations/\\\\u003coperation-id\\\\u003e?api-version=\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cJSON Resource in body\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe request and response body schemas must be identical and represent the resource.\\\\r\\\\nThe PUT creates or replaces the resource immediately and returns but the additional long-running processing can take time to complete.\\\\r\\\\nFor an idempotent PUT (same `operation-id` or same request body within some short time window), the service should return the same response as shown above.\\\\r\\\\nFor a non-idempotent PUT, the service can choose to overwrite the existing resource (as if the resource were deleted) or the service can return `409-Conflict` with the error's code property indicated why this PUT operation failed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-put-operation-id-request-header\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-put-operation-id-request-header\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** allow the client to pass an `Operation-Id` header with a ID for the status monitor for the operation.\\\\r\\\\nIf the `Operation-Id` header is not specified, the service may create an operation-id (typically a GUID) and return it via the `operation-id` and `operation-location` response headers; in this case the service must figure out how to deal with retries/idempotency.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-put-operation-id-default-is-guid\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-put-operation-id-default-is-guid\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** generate an ID (typically a GUID) for the status monitor if the `Operation-Id` header was not passed by the client.\\\\n\\\\n**DO** retain the status monitor resource for some publicly documented period of time (at least 24 hours) after the operation completes.\\\\r\\\\n#### Pattern to List Status Monitors\\\\r\\\\nUse the following patterns to allow clients to list Status Monitor resources.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#lro-list-status-monitors\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"lro-list-status-monitors\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:ballot_box_with_check:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n**YOU MAY** support a GET method on any status monitor collection URL that returns a list of the status monitors in that collection.\\\\r\\\\n\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/azure-core/long-running-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n## Long-running Operation Helpers for Emitters and Libraries\\\\n# howtos#azure-core#long-running-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Deep Dive: Long-running (Asynchronous) Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Long-running Operation Helpers for Emitters and Libraries\\\\n\\\\nThe Azure.Core library provides a helper that emitters can use to determine if an operation being processed is an LRO, and to provide details about how the LRO should be processed by clients, or about how operations are linked.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ngetLroMetadata( program: Program, operation: Operation) : LroMetadata | undefined;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe `LroMetadata` returned from this function contains information about the linked operations and their behavior, as well as additional that clients used to processing OpenAPI2 will be able to use to process TypeSpec operations similarly:\\\\r\\\\n| Property          | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |\\\\r\\\\n| ----------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `logicalResponse` | contains the type of the operation response, for the long-running operation (i.e. the result after polling completes). testcase: Brownfield TypeSpec migration

expected.answer:
Migration to TypeSpec for existing services is not yet mandatory, but it is suggested, and teams should be planning for it in Bromine and Krypton
Services must wholly switch to TypeSpec, there is no allowed mixing of hand-written and generated swagger
Servicesmust conform to a single, unified api-version for their service, servicesthat currently use different api-versions for parts of their service are going to need to plan for conformance -this either means SDK splitting or version uniformity.  Teams that use this 'different api-versions for different resources in the same sdk' pattern are not good candidates for conversion at the moment
In generally, the more compliant your service is to the RPC and best practices, the easier conversion will be
There is documentation on converting here: [Getting started | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/01-get-started/)

knowledges.title: How to create an Example for a typespec model?
Resolving Folder Migration Conflicts: A Guide for PR Authors
Handling multiple API versions using typespec

actual.answer:
There is a mandatory timeframe for brownfield Resource Providers (RPs) to migrate from OpenAPI Swagger to TypeSpec: all brownfield services must transition to TypeSpec Azure by March 30, 2026. Starting in Q4FY26, PRs for new API versions that are not based on TypeSpec will be blocked, and SDK releases from non-TypeSpec specs will also be blocked. This requirement ensures consistency and quality across Azure APIs.

It is NOT allowed to mix TypeSpec with handwritten Swagger during migration. Services must wholly switch to TypeSpec; partial migration (such as migrating one resource type at a time and mixing TypeSpec with Swagger) is not permitted. The migration must result in a single, unified API version for the service. If your service currently uses different API versions for different resources, you will need to plan for conformance, which may involve splitting SDKs or achieving version uniformity.

The recommended approach is to plan and execute a full migration to TypeSpec, using the provided conversion tools and following the documented migration process. You can find detailed guidance and tooling at the official TypeSpec Azure migration documentation.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Unable to apply client flatten to a top level resource property.\\n\\nquestion: my existing open api spec, of a proxy resource is such\\n```\\n\\\"ArcSetting\\\": {\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting details.\\\",\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"object\\\",\\n\\\"allOf\\\": [\\n{\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v5/types.json#/definitions/ProxyResource\\\"\\n}\\n],\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting properties.\\\",\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"#/definitions/ArcSettingProperties\\\",\\n\\\"x-ms-client-flatten\\\": true\\n}\\n}\\n},\\n```\\nTo convert it to typespec, here is what my tsp looks\\n```\\n/**\\n* ArcSetting details.\\n*/\\n@parentResource(Cluster)\\nmodel ArcSetting is Azure.ResourceManager.ProxyResource<ArcSettingProperties> {\\n...ResourceNameParameter<\\nResource = ArcSetting,\\nKeyName = \\\"arcSettingName\\\",\\nSegmentName = \\\"arcSettings\\\",\\nNamePattern = \\\"\\\"\\n>;\\n}\\n```\\nthe output is missing, the client-flatten property\\n```\\n\\\"ArcSetting\\\": {\\n\\\"type\\\": \\\"object\\\",\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting details.\\\",\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"properties\\\": {\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"#/definitions/ArcSettingProperties\\\",\\n\\\"description\\\": \\\"ArcSetting properties.\\\"\\n}\\n},\\n\\\"allOf\\\": [\\n{\\n\\\"$ref\\\": \\\"../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v6/types.json#/definitions/ProxyResource\\\"\\n}\\n]\\n},\\n```\\nIs there a possible way to add this flag, or what is the implication for the existing SDK\", \"response\": \"To represent `x-ms-client-flatten: true` for a top-level resource property in TypeSpec, you should use the `@flattenProperty` decorator from the `Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy` namespace. This decorator is designed to preserve the flattening behavior in the generated OpenAPI and SDKs, matching the original Swagger intent.\\n\\nHere is how you can apply it in TypeSpec:\\n\\n```typespec\\nimport Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy;\\n\\n/**\\n * ArcSetting details.\\n */\\n@parentResource(Cluster)\\nmodel ArcSetting is Azure.ResourceManager.ProxyResource {\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter;\\n\\n  /** ArcSetting properties. */\\n  @Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty\\n  properties: ArcSettingProperties;\\n}\\n```\\n\\n**Implications:**\\n- If you omit the `@flattenProperty` decorator, the generated SDKs may not flatten the `properties` bag as expected, which can lead to less ergonomic SDKs (nested objects instead of flat properties).\\n- For greenfield (new) services, flattening is discouraged unless absolutely necessary for backward compatibility. For migration scenarios, using `@flattenProperty` is acceptable to preserve existing SDK behavior.\\n- The decorator can be scoped to specific languages if needed, but by default applies to all.\\n\\n**Note:** Do not use OpenAPI-specific decorators like `@extension(\\\"x-ms-client-flatten\\\", ...)` in TypeSpec, as these are not supported for Azure services and will break multi-emitter compatibility.\\n\\n**Summary:** Use `@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty` on the `properties` field to preserve `x-ms-client-flatten: true` in the generated OpenAPI and SDKs.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Add\\n@@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty(ArcSettings.propeties)\\nBy convention put this in a back-compatible.tsp file.\"}"}]

If the objects have an independent lifetime but are not important to the model, they should only be top-level resources if no other design can be made to work.\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be nested resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. Their lifetime is dependent on a containing resource\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be proxy only resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They don\\\\u0026#39;t need to be Azure resources for one of the reasons above\\\\r\\\\n2. if the objects/properties are required for the parent resource to be created, then they should \\\\\\\\*not\\\\\\\\* be Azure resources\\\\r\\\\n3. It is important that they be simple to create in context of a containing resource.\\\\r\\\\n4. The lifecycle of the resources are managed outside ARM (e.g. agent based discovery).\\\\r\\\\n5. They are very common and would incur a performance overhead on the system (for example by cluttering the indices and GET resources calls)\\\\r\\\\n**Comparison of Tracked Resources and proxy only Resources**\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200b **Feature** | \\u200b **Tracked Resources** | \\u200b **Proxy only Resources** |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bUnderstood by template processor | \\u200bYes | \\u200b Yes |\\\\r\\\\n| Can be top-level resource | Yes | Only if global/single region |\\\\r\\\\n| Defined JSON format to payload | \\u200bYes -- must comply with general Azure resource format (id, type, name, tags, properties, location etc.) | \\u200bYes -- must comply with general Azure resource format (id, type, name, properties, etc.) but no tags or location |\\\\r\\\\n| Defined URL format | \\u200bYes -- must use providers/{namespace}/{typename} URL | \\u200bYes -- must use providers/{namespace}/{typename} URL |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bTagging and Indexing supported | \\u200bYes | \\u200bNo |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bBilling supported     | \\u200bYes | \\u200bNo |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bHave their own URLs | \\u200bYes | \\u200bYes |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200b\\u200bCan be PUT (created) with the parent in a single call | \\u200bNo - $batch/deep insert not available | \\u200b\\u200bYes, see deep insert recommendation |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bSupports RBAC | \\u200bYes -- based on URL     | \\u200b Yes -- based on URL |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200b\\\\n\\\\nThe Azure Resource Provider contract and template language have special semantics around \\\\u0026quot;registered\\\\u0026quot; Azure resources \\u2013 we call these **tracked resources**.\\\\r\\\\nIf these objects are addressable by URIs but not \\\\\\\"registered\\\\\\\", we call these **proxy only** resources to differentiate them.\\\\r\\\\n**Background REST philosophy**\\\\r\\\\n1. Azure API guideline compliant and OData compliant where it makes sense.\\\\r\\\\n2. APIs must be callable from any client implementation, language or framework.\\\\r\\\\n3. Making things simple and regular for machine processing often makes things easier for humans to understand, even when it increases verbosity.\\\\r\\\\n4. When we choose between understandable URLs and understandable templates, we should make the templates human understandable and the URLs machine consumable.\\\\r\\\\n5. Everything that is possible from a template should be possible through imperative APIs, but not necessarily as easily and may require special client code (orchestration is an obvious example).\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be Tracked resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They are billable entities, including freemium models\\\\r\\\\n2. Need to be orchestrated by the template execution engine\\\\r\\\\n3. Related to above, they have dependencies on other resources\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be top-level resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They should be resources as per above\\\\r\\\\n2. Their lifetime is independent of other resources (only dependent on the containing resource group)\\\\r\\\\n3. If the objects have an independent lifetime but are not important to the model, they should only be top-level resources if no other design can be made to work.\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be nested resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They meet the guidelines for Azure resources above (billable, orchestration supported, taggable)\\\\r\\\\n2. Their lifetime is dependent on a containing resource\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be proxy only resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1.
