Addendum\\\\n## Designing Resources ##\\\\n# v1.0#Addendum.md\\\\n\\\\n# Addendum\\\\n\\\\n## Designing Resources ##\\\\n\\\\ngroup)\\\\r\\\\n3. If the objects have an independent lifetime but are not important to the model, they should only be top-level resources if no other design can be made to work.\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be nested resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They meet the guidelines for Azure resources above (billable, orchestration supported, taggable)\\\\r\\\\n2. Their lifetime is dependent on a containing resource\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be proxy only resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They don\\\\u0026#39;t need to be Azure resources for one of the reasons above\\\\r\\\\n2. if the objects/properties are required for the parent resource to be created, then they should \\\\\\\\*not\\\\\\\\* be Azure resources\\\\r\\\\n3. It is important that they be simple to create in context of a containing resource.\\\\r\\\\n4. The lifecycle of the resources are managed outside ARM (e.g. agent based discovery).\\\\r\\\\n5. They are very common and would incur a performance overhead on the system (for example by cluttering the indices and GET resources calls)\\\\r\\\\n**Comparison of Tracked Resources and proxy only Resources**\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200b **Feature** | \\u200b **Tracked Resources** | \\u200b **Proxy only Resources** |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bUnderstood by template processor | \\u200bYes | \\u200b Yes |\\\\r\\\\n| Can be top-level resource | Yes | Only if global/single region |\\\\r\\\\n| Defined JSON format to payload | \\u200bYes -- must comply with general Azure resource format (id, type, name, tags, properties, location etc.) | \\u200bYes -- must comply with general Azure resource format (id, type, name, properties, etc.) but no tags or location |\\\\r\\\\n| Defined URL format | \\u200bYes -- must use providers/{namespace}/{typename} URL | \\u200bYes -- must use providers/{namespace}/{typename} URL |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bTagging and Indexing supported | \\u200bYes | \\u200bNo |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bBilling supported     | \\u200bYes | \\u200bNo |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bHave their own URLs | \\u200bYes | \\u200bYes |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200b\\u200bCan be PUT (created) with the parent in a single call | \\u200bNo - $batch/deep insert not available | \\u200b\\u200bYes, see deep insert recommendation |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bSupports RBAC | \\u200bYes -- based on URL     | \\u200b Yes -- based on URL |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200b\\\\n\\\\nThe Azure Resource Provider contract and template language have special semantics around \\\\u0026quot;registered\\\\u0026quot; Azure resources \\u2013 we call these **tracked resources**.\\\\r\\\\nIf these objects are addressable by URIs but not \\\\\\\"registered\\\\\\\", we call these **proxy only** resources to differentiate them.\\\\r\\\\n**Background REST philosophy**\\\\r\\\\n1. Azure API guideline compliant and OData compliant where it makes sense.\\\\r\\\\n2. APIs must be callable from any client implementation, language or framework.\\\\r\\\\n3. Making things simple and regular for machine processing often makes things easier for humans to understand, even when it increases verbosity.\\\\r\\\\n4. When we choose between understandable URLs and understandable templates, we should make the templates human understandable and the URLs machine consumable.\\\\r\\\\n5. Everything that is possible from a template should be possible through imperative APIs, but not necessarily as easily and may require special client code (orchestration is an obvious example).\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be Tracked resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They are billable entities, including freemium models\\\\r\\\\n2. Need to be orchestrated by the template execution engine\\\\r\\\\n3. Related to above, they have dependencies on other resources\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be top-level resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They should be resources as per above\\\\r\\\\n2. Their lifetime is independent of other resources (only dependent on the containing resource group)\\\\r\\\\n3. If the objects have an independent lifetime but are not important to the model, they should only be top-level resources if no other design can be made to work.\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be nested resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They meet the guidelines for Azure resources above (billable, orchestration supported, taggable)\\\\r\\\\n2. Their lifetime is dependent on a containing resource\\\\r\\\\n**Objects should be proxy only resources if:**\\\\r\\\\n1. They don\\\\u0026#39;t need to be Azure resources for one of the reasons above\\\\n\\\\nor location |\\\\r\\\\n| Defined URL format | \\u200bYes -- must use providers/{namespace}/{typename} URL | \\u200bNo |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bHave their own URLs | \\u200bYes | \\u200bYes |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200b\\u200bCan be PUT (created) with the parent in a single call | \\u200bNo - $batch/deep insert not available | \\u200b\\u200bYes, see deep insert recommendation |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bSupports RBAC | \\u200bYes -- based on URL     | \\u200b Yes -- based on URL |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bActions are advertised and supported by RBAC experience (/reboot for example) | \\u200bYes | \\u200bOptional |\\\\r\\\\n| \\u200bSupports targeted imperative GET | \\u200bYes | \\u200b Yes |\\\\r\\\\n| ##\\\\n\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n\\\\n| \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-04 | A `POST` operation **must** return status code 404 (NotFound) to indicate that the resource or resource group does not exist. | Required |  | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-05 | All parameters **must** be specified in the payload and not in the URI. | Required | This allows proper implementation of authorization checks. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/parameters-in-POST.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-06 | Response body of the `POST` operation *may* have any schema as defined by the Resource Provider. | Recommended |  | Design | | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-07 | A `POST` operation **must** apply either to a specific resource instance of a resource type or to the provider. Such inconsistencies degrade customer experience as they now have to deal with slightly different behaviors while interacting with each Resource Provider. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n| RPC Guideline code | Title | Conformance level | Additional impact |  Applicable scope | Linter rule |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-01 | An action name must be provided for a `POST` operation. | Required | ARM cannot route the request. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/path-for-resource-action.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-02 | A synchronous `POST` operation **must** specify status code 200 (OK) with response schema or 204 (No response content) to indicate successful completion. | Required | | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/POST-response-codes.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-POST-V1-03 | An asynchronous `POST` operation **must** specify 202 [Accepted] to indicate successful acceptance of the API. It **should** additionaly specify status code 200 (OK) with a response schema indicating the schema of the final response if the final response is expected to have one. This section explains how resource models are identified and appropriate base models from the TypeSpec resource manager library are selected.\\\\r\\\\nAn ARM Resource model should extend one of the typespec common-types Resource models when it meets **all** of the following criteria:\\\\r\\\\n1. There is a GET operation for the model.\\\\r\\\\n2. At least one operation returns a 200 response containing this model.\\\\r\\\\n3. The model has properties named `id`, `name`, and `type`.\\\\r\\\\nOnce a model is identified as a resource, it is represented by extending an appropriate [resource model](../../howtos/ARM/resource-type.md#modeling-resources-in-typespec) from the TypeSpec library. This can result in textual differences between the original OpenAPI file and generated OpenAPI file like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`diff\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"YourResource\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/YourResourceProperties\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"allOf\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n-      \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/YourOwnProxyResourceDefinition\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n+      \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#/definitions/ProxyResource\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAccept this change to align with ARM conventions. If there is a strong business justification to keep the original definition, use the `@customAzureResource` decorator to mark the model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel YourResource extends YourOwnProxyResourceDefinition {\\\\r\\\\n  properties: YourResourceProperties;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.customAzureResource\\\\r\\\\nmodel YourOwnProxyResourceDefinition {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"yourSegment\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#azure-resource-manager#reference#data-types.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Data types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-resource-manager/reference/data-types\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Data types\\\\n## Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes\\\\n### `ResourceModelWithAllowedPropertySet` {#Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ResourceModelWithAllowedPropertySet}\\\\n# libraries#azure-resource-manager#reference#data-types.md\\\\n\\\\n# Data types\\\\n\\\\n## Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes\\\\n\\\\n### `ResourceModelWithAllowedPropertySet` {#Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ResourceModelWithAllowedPropertySet}\\\\n\\\\nresource ID of the resource that manages this resource. Indicates if this resource is managed by another Azure resource.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eIf this is present, complete mode deployment will not delete the resource if it is removed from the template since it is managed by another resource.                                                                                                        |\\\\r\\\\n| kind?      | `string`                                                                                             | Metadata used by portal/tooling/etc to render different UX experiences for resources of the same type; e.g. ApiApps are a kind of Microsoft.Web/sites type.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eIf supported, the resource provider must validate and persist this value.                                                                                                                                                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| etag?      | `string`                                                                                             | The etag field is _not_ required. HTTP/1.1 uses entity tags in the etag (section 14.19),\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eIf-Match (section 14.24), If-None-Match (section 14.26), and If-Range (section 14.27) header fields. |\\\\r\\\\n| identity?  | [`ManagedServiceIdentity`](./data-types.md#Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ManagedServiceIdentity) |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                |\\\\r\\\\n| sku?       | [`Sku`]\\\\n\\\\nThe resource model definition containing the full set of allowed properties for a resource. Except properties bag, there cannot be a top level property outside of this set.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ResourceModelWithAllowedPropertySet\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Properties\\\\r\\\\n| Name       | Type                                                                                                 | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ---------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| managedBy? | `string`                                                                                             | The fully qualified resource ID of the resource that manages this resource. name\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAzure services should not be using decorators from the OpenAPIs libraries(`@azure-tools/openapi`, `@azure-tools/typespec-autorest` or `@azure-tools/openapi3`) in their spec.\\\\r\\\\nUsing those decorators is usually a sign that the spec is either not following the correct Azure or trying to match exactly a particular OpenAPI spec which should be a non-goal.\\\\r\\\\nThose decorators are only meant to be read by the openapi emitters which means this might achieve the correct OpenAPI output but other emitters(client SDK, service, etc.) will not be able to understand them and will see a broken representation of the spec.\\\\n\\\\n## Decorators and their alternatives\\\\n\\\\n| OpenAPI Decorator                    | Alternative                                                                                                                                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `@example`             |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-client-flatten\\\\\\\", ` | Use [`@flattenProperty`](../../typespec-client-generator-core/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty)                       |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-mutability\\\\\\\", `     | Use [`@visibility` decorator](https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators#@visibility)                                                        |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\", `           | [Enum extensibility doc](../../../troubleshoot/enum-not-extensible.md) Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n### Table 2: Changes requiring a review with Azure's Breaking Change Review Board\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## 5. Azure Service Change Impact\\\\n\\\\n### Table 2: Changes requiring a review with Azure's Breaking Change Review Board\\\\n\\\\nvalue |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code | Old client has no code to handle new response code |\\\\r\\\\n| Modify path/operation Id | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method name |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove protocol (ex: http) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n\\u00b2 Removing an extensible enum value typically happens when a service retires some feature (like a VM SKU). Retirements must be discussed with Azure Retirements Reviewers (\\\\u003chttps://dev.azure.com/msazure/AzureWiki/_wiki/wikis/AzureWiki.wiki/88597/Azure-Retirement-Policy-and-Process\\\\u003e). Based on the outcome this breaking change may be doable in a new api-version of the service. And, in some extreme cases, this breaking change may be doable in an existing api-version.\\\\n\\\\n**NOTE:** These changes are strongly discouraged:\\\\r\\\\n| Change | Why this change is breaking for old clients |\\\\r\\\\n|--------|---------------------------------------------|\\\\r\\\\n| Add pagination support | Old client expects response to include all results and will only ever see 1st page |\\\\r\\\\n| Add required input | Old client doesn't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output | Old client always sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Add new output enum value | Old client will crash when deserializing |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove input/output enum value | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove extensible enum (string) value\\u00b2 | Old client sends/expects this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input from optional to required | Old clients don't send this |\\\\r\\\\n| Change output from optional to required | New client doesn't expect nullable field (for some language SDKs) |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input/output required to optional | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameters |\\\\r\\\\n| Change case (ex: RBAC to Rbac) | Old client sends wrong case |\\\\r\\\\n| Change format (ex: minutes to time) | Old client can't parse new format |\\\\r\\\\n| Change data type (ex: bool to string) | Old client can't parse new type's value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen input integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client doesn't expect larger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Widen output integer (ex: Int32 to Int64) | Old client loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Narrow input/output integer (ex: Int64 to Int32) | New service loses precision |\\\\r\\\\n| Strengthen input constraint (ex: max value 5 to 4) | Old client sends bigger value |\\\\r\\\\n| Weaken output constraint (ex: max value 5 to 6) | Old client gets value it never expected |\\\\r\\\\n| Change default value | Old client doesn't expect new default behavior |\\\\r\\\\n| Change discriminator field value | Old client doesn't expect/send new value |\\\\r\\\\n| Change input parameter order in swagger | Client code stops compiling due to change in SDK method parameter order |\\\\r\\\\n| Remove body Content-Type (ex: application/json) | Old client doesn't expect request to fail |\\\\r\\\\n| Add response code This decorator is designed to preserve the flattening behavior in the generated OpenAPI and SDKs, matching the original Swagger intent.\\n\\nHere is how you can apply it in TypeSpec:\\n\\n```typespec\\nimport Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy;\\n\\n/**\\n * ArcSetting details.\\n */\\n@parentResource(Cluster)\\nmodel ArcSetting is Azure.ResourceManager.ProxyResource {\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter;\\n\\n  /** ArcSetting properties. */\\n  @Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty\\n  properties: ArcSettingProperties;\\n}\\n```\\n\\n**Implications:**\\n- If you omit the `@flattenProperty` decorator, the generated SDKs may not flatten the `properties` bag as expected, which can lead to less ergonomic SDKs (nested objects instead of flat properties).\\n- For greenfield (new) services, flattening is discouraged unless absolutely necessary for backward compatibility. For migration scenarios, using `@flattenProperty` is acceptable to preserve existing SDK behavior.\\n- The decorator can be scoped to specific languages if needed, but by default applies to all.\\n\\n**Note:** Do not use OpenAPI-specific decorators like `@extension(\\\"x-ms-client-flatten\\\", ...)` in TypeSpec, as these are not supported for Azure services and will break multi-emitter compatibility.\\n\\n**Summary:** Use `@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty` on the `properties` field to preserve `x-ms-client-flatten: true` in the generated OpenAPI and SDKs.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Add\\n@@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty(ArcSettings.propeties)\\nBy convention put this in a back-compatible.tsp file.\"}"}]

actual.answer:
For a property that represents a dictionary (object) with string keys and string values in TypeSpec, you should use the built-in generic model type `Record<string>`. The correct declaration for your scenario is:

```typespec
metadata?: Record<string>;
```

This will emit an OpenAPI schema with `additionalProperties: { type: "string" }`, which is the standard way to represent a dictionary of string-to-string in Azure REST API specs. Do not use `{}` or an empty model, as TypeSpec requires a model type and `{}` is not valid. Also, do not use just `Record` without a type parameter, as it requires the value type to be specified.

If you want the property to be required, omit the `?`:

```typespec
metadata: Record<string>;
```

This approach is fully compliant with Azure management-plane API guidelines.

The correct declaration for your scenario is:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmetadata?: Record<string>;\\n```\\n\\nThis will emit an OpenAPI schema with `additionalProperties: { type: \\\"string\\\" }`, which is the standard way to represent a dictionary of string-to-string in Azure REST API specs. Do not use `{}` or an empty model, as TypeSpec requires a model type and `{}` is not valid. Also, do not use just `Record` without a type parameter, as it requires the value type to be specified.\\n\\nIf you want the property to be required, omit the `?`:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmetadata: Record<string>;\\n```\\n\\nThis approach is fully compliant with Azure management-plane API guidelines.\", \"ground_truth\": \"For a property in a TypeSpec ARM resource provider model that represents a dictionary (object) mapping strings to strings, you should use the built-in `Record<string>` type.\\nFor example:\\n```\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\nmetadata?: Record<string>;\\n}\\n```\\nThis models a property (`metadata`) that is an object/dictionary where all keys and values are strings, equivalent to `{ [key: string]: string }` in TypeScript or `Dictionary<string, string>` in .NET.\\nYou should not use `{}` (empty model) or just `Record` (without specifying the value type) as these are either incomplete or invalid in TypeSpec. The correct, type-safe way is `Record<string>`, which will be emitted to OpenAPI/Swagger as an `object` with `additionalProperties: { type: \\\"string\\\" }`.\\nIf your API spec review asks for a 'model', you can define a named type:\\n```\\nmodel MetadataModel is Record<string>;\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\nmetadata?: MetadataModel;\\n}\\n```\\nBut `Record<string>` is the canonical, recommended approach for a string-to-string dictionary in TypeSpec ARM resource definitions.\\nNote: While this is technically correct, ARM guidelines recommend against unbounded dictionary/object types unless absolutely necessary, as they can limit Azure Policy and ARG capabilities. Use with care, and document any supported/expected keys in your @doc comments if possible.\"}"}]

Properties acquired via `model is` are placed before properties defined in the model body. Properties obtained via `...` are inserted at the point where the spread appears in the source.\\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: uint8;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel HasHome {\\\\r\\\\n  address: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat is Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  meow: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  ...HasHome;\\\\r\\\\n  furColor: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// The resulting property order for Cat is:\\\\r\\\\n// name, age, meow, address, furColor\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Additional properties\\\\n\\\\nThe `Record\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e` model can be used to define a model with an arbitrary number of properties of type T. It can be combined with a named model to provide some known properties.\\\\r\\\\nThere are three ways to achieve this, each with slightly different semantics:\\\\r\\\\n- Using the `...` operator\\\\r\\\\n- Using the `is` operator\\\\r\\\\n- Using the `extends` operator\\\\r\\\\n#### Using the `...` operator\\\\r\\\\nSpreading a Record into your model implies that your model includes all the properties you have explicitly defined, plus any additional properties defined by the Record. This means that a property in the model could be of a different and incompatible type with the Record value type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// In this example, the Person model has a property `age` that is an int32, but also has other properties that are all strings.\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person {\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Using the `is` operator\\\\r\\\\nWhen using `is Record\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`, it indicates that all properties of this model are of type T. This means that each property explicitly defined in the model must also be of type T.\\\\r\\\\nThe example below would be invalid\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person is Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  //   ^ int32 is not assignable to string\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nBut the following would be valid\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person is Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Using the `extends` operator\\\\r\\\\nThe `extends` operator has similar semantics to `is`, but it defines the relationship between the two models. In many languages, this would probably result in the same emitted code as `is` and it is recommended to use `is Record\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e` instead.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person extends Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Special property types\\\\n\\\\n#### `never`\\\\r\\\\nA model property can be declared as having the type `never`. This can be interpreted as the model not having that property.\\\\r\\\\nThis can be useful in a model template to omit a property.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Address\\\\u003cTState\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  state: TState;\\\\r\\\\n  city: string;\\\\r\\\\n  street: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel UKAddress is Address\\\\u003cnever\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n:::note\\\\r\\\\nThe responsibility of removing `never` properties lies with the emitter. The TypeSpec compiler will not automatically omit them.\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\n\\\\n### Array\\\\n\\\\nArrays are models created using the `[]` syntax, which is a shorthand for using the `Array\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e` model type.\\\\n\\\\n## Model composition\\\\n\\\\n### Spread\\\\n\\\\nThe spread operator (`...`) copies the members of a source model into a target model. This operation doesn't create any nominal relationship between the source and target, making it useful when you want to reuse common properties without generating complex inheritance relationships.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Animal {\\\\r\\\\n  species: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  ...Animal;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Pet;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// The Dog model is equivalent to the following declaration:\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  species: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Extends\\\\n\\\\nThere are times when you want to create an explicit relationship between two models, such as when you're generating class definitions in languages that support inheritance. The `extends` keyword can be used to establish this relationship.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Animal {\\\\r\\\\n  species: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Animal {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Is\\\\n\\\\nThere are instances when you want to create a new type that is an exact copy of an existing type but with additional properties or metadata, without creating a nominal inheritance relationship. The `is` keyword can be used for this purpose. It copies all the properties (like spread), but also copies [decorators](./decorators.md) as well. A common use case is to provide a better name to a [template](#model-templates) instantiation:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@decorator\\\\r\\\\nmodel Thing\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  property: T;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel StringThing is Thing\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n// The StringThing declaration is equivalent to the following declaration:\\\\r\\\\n@decorator\\\\r\\\\nmodel StringThing {\\\\r\\\\n  property: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Model templates\\\\n\\\\nRefer to [templates](./templates.md) for more details on templates.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Page\\\\u003cItem\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  size: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  item: Item[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel DogPage {\\\\r\\\\n  ...Page\\\\u003cDog\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Meta type references\\\\n\\\\nSome model property meta types can be referenced using `::`.\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Example          | Description                              |\\\\r\\\\n| ---- | ---------------- | ---------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| type | `Pet.name::type` | Reference the type of the model property |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM.CommonTypes-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 17. names\\\\n\\\\nThere is some cases where the name you have in TypeSpec might differ from the name over the wire or for a certain language.\\\\n\\\\n## Update name for a given target\\\\n\\\\nTo update the name of a TypeSpec entity you can use the `@encodedName` decorator. This decorator takes 2 parameters:\\\\r\\\\n| Parameter     | Type     | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                            |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------- | -------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `mimeType`    | `string` | Mime type this should apply to. The mime type should be a known mime type as described here https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types without any suffix (e.g. `+json`) |\\\\r\\\\n| `encodedName` | `string` | The name should be when serialized to the given mime type.                                                                                                                                                             |\\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Foo {\\\\r\\\\n  // Specify that when serializing to JSON `expireAt` property should be named `exp`\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"json\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"exp\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  expireAt: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel CertificateAttributes {\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"nbf\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  notBefore: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"exp\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @encodedName(\\\\\\\"application/xml\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"ExpireAt\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  expires: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  created: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  updated: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctable\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cthead\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cth\\\\u003eJson\\\\u003c/th\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cth\\\\u003eXml\\\\u003c/th\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cth\\\\u003eYaml\\\\u003c/th\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/tr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/thead\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eWhen serialized to `application/json` properties will use the encodedName for `application/json` if available or default to the property name.\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eWhen serialized to `application/xml` properties will use the encodedName for `application/xml` if available or default to the property name.\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003eYaml didn't provide any different names so it will serialize using the property names.\\\\u003c/td\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/tr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ctd\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n the value of `@encodedName` in your library or emitter you can use `resolveEncodedName(target: Type, mimeType: string): string` from the Contracts\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/common-api-contracts.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Common API Contracts\\\\n# v1.0#common-api-contracts.md\\\\n\\\\n# Common API Contracts\\\\n\\\\nThis document describes preferred schemas for resource APIs that are to remain consistent between resource types.\\\\n\\\\n## Table of Contents ##\\\\n\\\\n- [System Metadata for all Azure resources](#system-metadata-for-all-azure-resources) \\\\u003c/br\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n- [Describing Location for off-Azure resources](#describing-location-for-off-azure-resources)\\\\r\\\\n- [Customer-managed Key encryption](#customer-managed-key-encryption)\\\\r\\\\n- [Singleton Resources](#singleton-resources)\\\\n\\\\n## System Metadata for all Azure resources ##\\\\n\\\\nAs of 2020, all Azure resources may implement a read-only `systemData` object property in the top-level envelope. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"id\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"/subscriptions/{id}/resourceGroups/{group}/providers/{rpns}/{type}/{name}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"{name}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"location\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"North US\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"systemData\\\\\\\":{\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"createdBy\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"createdByType\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cUser|Application|ManagedIdentity|Key\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"createdAt\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdate-time\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"lastModifiedBy\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"lastModifiedByType\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cUser|Application|ManagedIdentity|Key\\\\u003e\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"lastModifiedAt\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdate-time\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"tags\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"key1\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"value 1\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"key2\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"value 2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"resource kind\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"comment\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Resource defined structure\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Properties ###\\\\n\\\\n| Name  | Description |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------- | ------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| createdBy | a string identifier for the identity that created the resource  |\\\\r\\\\n| createdByType | the type of identity that created the resource: user, application, managedIdentity|\\\\r\\\\n| createdAt | the timestamp of resource creation (UTC) |\\\\r\\\\n| lastModifiedBy | a string identifier for the identity that last modified the resource |\\\\r\\\\n| lastModifiedByType | the type of identity that last modified the resource: user, application, managedIdentity|\\\\r\\\\n| lastModifiedAt | the timestamp of resource last modification (UTC) |\\\\r\\\\nARM will provide the values in the `x-ms-arm-resource-system-data` header to the provider on resource write and resource action calls in JSON format (as shown above). For ProxyOnly resources, the resource provider is the source of truth. ARM will provide best effort values in the header, but the provider should update the values, including missing values, from known metadata. The `systemData` object should be defined in the resource swagger and persisted in provider storage to serve on all responses for the resource (GET, PUT, PATCH).\\\\r\\\\n**You should only update the systemData properties of a resource if there is a change that affects a user-modifiable property in the control plane JSON configuration of that resource.**\\\\n\\\\n### POST operations ###\\\\n\\\\nFor POST operations on tracked resources, ARM will send all the header values. For POST (create) operations on proxy resources, ARM will send all the header values. For POST (action) operations on proxy resources, ARM sends the lastModified* values only.\\\\n\\\\n### Resource move ###\\\\n\\\\nResource move is treated as a combination of creation and deletion. The RP should be consistent with this logic and replace all values accordingly.\\\\r\\\\nARM passes one single x-ms-arm-resource-system-data header for the complete move operation. For example, if you have 20 resources to be moved in one request, the expectation from RPs is to save the same system data for each of these 20 resources. In this example,  moving 20 resources is equal to creating 20 resources, and therefore, the systemData values are the same.\\\\n\\\\n### FAQ ###\\\\n\\\\nif there is a change that affects a user-modifiable property in the control plane JSON configuration of that resource. Children resources should have their own systemData values.\\\\r\\\\n#### What is the format of the timestamps being sent? What if the value is null (i.e. can\\u2019t supply the createdAt)? ####\\\\r\\\\nRPs should either return null or emit the property. \\\\r\\\\n#### Should internal adminstration operations like updating VM images results in an update of the related resources' systemData properties?\\\\r\\\\nOperations should only change the systemData properties if the change affects user-modifiable properties within the resource's JSON configuration. If a user-modifiable property changes, it should update the systemData values.\\\\r\\\\n#### Can I use a new *ByType value? ####\\\\r\\\\nRPs should only use *ByType values supported by the related enum in the [common types definition](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/common-types/resource-management/v1/types.json). The currently supported *ByType values are User, Application, ManagedIdentity, and Key.\\\\r\\\\n#### Can I add systemData to my current API version? ####\\\\r\\\\nNo. Adding systemData is a breaking change and should only be included as part of a new API version.\\\\r\\\\n#### Is there any situation where the RP will have to interpret the values we are passed and do something? Or do we just store the data and return it? ####\\\\r\\\\nFor tracked resources, the values can simply be stored. Since ARM is not aware of all changes to proxy or dataplane-modifiable resources, the values may have to be interpreted for these resource types.\\\\r\\\\n#### How should we store the *ByType values so that we do not have to update the API when more values are added to the identity types? ####\\\\r\\\\nYou should store the *ByType values as a string.\\\\n\\\\n#### Is it OK to collect this data in Microsoft telemetry streams (e.g., Geneva, Kusto, COSMOS, etc.)? ####\\\\r\\\\n**No.** This data is considered Customer Data [Customer Content and End User Identifiable Information (EUII)] and must **NOT** be collected in any telemetry streams in order to meet our data handling requirements. It should only be included in the activity log for and accessible by each individual customer.\\\\r\\\\n#### What values should I use for long-running operations? ####\\\\r\\\\nThe systemData properties should reflect the values from when the operation was triggered.\\\\r\\\\n#### Should I replace the values if the operation fails or is cancelled? ####\\\\r\\\\nDo not update system data on a request that was rejected synchronously, but keep the values the triggered-time values if an async operation fails or is cancelled. \\\\r\\\\n#### What is expected for resources that already exist prior to an RP's implementation of systemData? ####\\\\r\\\\nARM doesn\\u2019t maintain the systemData details and will not fill them up before returning to the client. As a result, as the RP, you are expected to save the values from the first PUT. If the resource already existed prior to your systemData implementation, you can supply null or omit the value when it is not returned by ARM.\\\\r\\\\n#### Should a parent resource's systemData values be impacted by the creation or modification of children resources? ####\\\\r\\\\nNo. You should only update the systemData properties of a resource if there is a change that affects a user-modifiable property in the control plane JSON configuration of that resource. Children resources should have their own systemData values.\\\\r\\\\n#### What is the format of the timestamps being sent? What if the value is null (i.e. can\\u2019t supply the createdAt)? ####\\\\r\\\\nRPs should either return null or emit the property. \\\\r\\\\n#### Should internal adminstration operations like updating VM images results in an update of the related resources' systemData properties?\\\\n\\\\n## Describing location for off-Azure resources ##\\\\n\\\\nIn some cases, resources described in ARM are hosted outside of an Azure datacenter. In this case, an optional `locationData` property is appropriate to allow the user to supply metadata pertaining to the resource geographic location. The locationData property should be in the `properties` object of the resoure.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"id\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. Understanding identifier rules is essential for writing valid TypeSpec code.\\\\n\\\\n## Identifier syntax rules\\\\n\\\\nAn identifier must follow these rules:\\\\r\\\\n- **Start with**: A letter (a-z, A-Z), emoji, underscore (`_`), or dollar sign (`$`)\\\\r\\\\n- **Followed by**: Any combination of letters, numbers (0-9), emoji, underscores, or dollar signs\\\\r\\\\n- **Length**: One or more characters\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec implements [UAX31-R1b stable identifiers](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr31/#R1b) with the [emoji profile](http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr31/#Emoji_Profile), providing full Unicode support for international characters.\\\\n\\\\n### Examples\\\\n\\\\n- \\u2705 `cat`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `Dog`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `_Item2`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `$money$`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `\\ud83c\\udf89`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u2705 `\\ud83d\\ude80`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u274c `1cat`\\\\r\\\\n- \\u274c `*dog`\\\\n\\\\n## Escaping identifiers\\\\n\\\\nWhen you need to use reserved keywords or invalid identifiers, TypeSpec provides an escaping mechanism using backticks (`` ` ``). However, when transmitting types over the network, many languages require a mechanism to distinguish between different union variants or models within an inheritance hierarchy.\\\\n\\\\n### Implementing Discriminated Unions\\\\n\\\\nUnions can be marked as discriminated using the `@discriminated` decorator. This discriminator will assume the variant name is the discriminator value.\\\\r\\\\n#### Default serialization\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminated\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet In particular, the types `numeric`, `integer`, `decimal`, `float`, `int64`, `uint64`, and `decimal128` are marshalled as a `Numeric` type. All other numeric types are marshalled as `number`.\\\\r\\\\nWhen marshalling custom scalar subtypes, the marshalling behavior of the known supertype is used. For example, a `scalar customScalar extends numeric` will marshal as a `Numeric`, regardless of any value constraints that might be present.\\\\r\\\\n#### Legacy value marshalling\\\\r\\\\nWith legacy value marshalling, TypeSpec strings, numbers, and booleans values are always marshalled as JS values. All other values are marshalled as their corresponding type. For example, `null` is marshalled as `NullType`.\\\\r\\\\n| TypeSpec Value Type | Marshalled value in JS |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------- | ---------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`            | `string`               |\\\\r\\\\n| `numeric`           | `number`               |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean`           | `boolean`              |\\\\r\\\\nNote that with legacy marshalling, because JavaScript numbers have limited range and precision, it is possible to define values in TypeSpec that cannot be accurately represented in JavaScript.\\\\r\\\\n#### String templates and marshalling\\\\r\\\\nIf a decorator parameter type is `valueof string`, a string template passed to it will also be marshalled as a string.\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec type system will already validate the string template can be serialized as a string.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nextern dec doc(target: unknown, name: valueof string);\\\\r\\\\nalias world = \\\\\\\"world!\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Hello ${world} \\\\\\\") // receive: \\\\\\\"Hello world!\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Hello ${123} \\\\\\\") // receive: \\\\\\\"Hello 123\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Hello ${true} \\\\\\\") // receive: \\\\\\\"Hello true\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nmodel Bar {}\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Hello ${Bar} \\\\\\\") // not called error\\\\r\\\\n     ^ String template cannot be serialized as a string.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Typescript type Reference\\\\r\\\\n| TypeSpec Parameter Type      | TypeScript types                             |\\\\r\\\\n| ---------------------------- | -------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n|\\\\n\\\\nWhen decorators are passed types, the type is passed as-is. When a decorator is passed a TypeSpec value, the decorator receives a JavaScript value with a type that is appropriate for representing that value.\\\\r\\\\n:::note\\\\r\\\\nThis behavior depends on the value of the `valueMarshalling` [package flag](../extending-typespec/basics.md#f-set-package-flags). This section describes the behavior when `valueMarshalling` is set to `\\\\\\\"new\\\\\\\"`. In a future release this will become the default value marshalling so it is strongly recommended to set this flag. But for now, the default value marshalling is `\\\\\\\"legacy\\\\\\\"` which is described in the next section. In a future release the `valueMarshalling` flag will need to be set to `\\\\\\\"legacy\\\\\\\"` to keep the previous marshalling behavior, but the flag will eventually be removed entirely.\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\r\\\\n| TypeSpec value type | Marshalled type in JS             |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------- | --------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`            | `string`                          |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean`           | `boolean`                         |\\\\r\\\\n| `numeric`           | `Numeric` or `number` (see below) |\\\\r\\\\n| `null`              | `null`                            |\\\\r\\\\n| enum member         | `EnumMemberValue`                 |\\\\r\\\\nWhen marshalling numeric values, either the `Numeric` wrapper type is used, or a `number` is passed directly, depending on whether the value can be represented as a JavaScript number without precision loss. In particular, the types `numeric`, `integer`, `decimal`, `float`, `int64`, `uint64`, and `decimal128` are marshalled as a `Numeric` type. All other numeric types are marshalled as `number`.\\\\r\\\\nWhen marshalling custom scalar subtypes, the marshalling behavior of the known supertype is used. For example, a `scalar customScalar extends numeric` will marshal as a `Numeric`, regardless of any value constraints that might be present.\\\\r\\\\n#### Legacy value marshalling\\\\n\\\\nalias world 123\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Hello ${true} \\\\\\\") // receive: \\\\\\\"Hello true\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nmodel Bar {}\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Hello ${Bar} \\\\\\\") // not called error\\\\r\\\\n     ^ String template cannot be serialized as a string.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Typescript type Reference\\\\r\\\\n| TypeSpec Parameter Type      | TypeScript types Types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/resource-type\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# ARM Resource Types\\\\n## Modeling Resources in TypeSpec\\\\n### Extension Resource\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-type.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Types\\\\n\\\\n## Modeling Resources in TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### Extension Resource\\\\n\\\\nExtension resources use the `ExtensionResource\\\\u003cTProperties/\\\\u003e` as their base resource type, where `TProperties` is the properties model for the rp-specific properties of the resource. Here is an example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeResource is ExtensionResource\\\\u003cEmployeeProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The employee name, using 'Firstname Lastname' notation */\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"employees\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"employeeName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`@doc`: provides documentation for the 'name' property of the resource.\\\\r\\\\n`@segment(employees)`: provides the resource type name for this resource.\\\\r\\\\n`@key(employeeName)`: provides the parameter name for the name of the resource in operations that use this resource.\\\\r\\\\n`@visibility(read)`: indicates that this property is returned in the body of responses to operations over this resource, but does not appear in the body of requests. Later sections describe the [usage of property visibility](#property-visibility-and-other-constraints).\\\\r\\\\n`@path`: indicates that this property corresponds to the last segment of the url path to the resource (otherwise known as the resource identity).\\\\r\\\\nYou can find samples of Extension Resources [in the TenantResource sample](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/tenantResource/main.tsp).\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI schemas are represented in TypeSpec by [models](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/models/).\\\\r\\\\nModels have any number of members and can extend and be composed with other models.\\\\r\\\\nModels can be defined with the `model` statement and then referenced by name, which generally results in a `$ref` to a schema for the model in the `definitions` or `components.schemas` section of the OpenAPI document.\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec supports the [\\\\\\\"spread\\\\\\\" operator](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/models/#spread) (`...`), which copies the members of the source model into the target model.\\\\r\\\\nBut TypeSpec processes all spread transformations before emitters are invoked, so this form of reuse is not represented in the emitted OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\nThe spread operation is useful if you want one or more properties to be present in several different models but in a standard fashion. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Legs {\\\\r\\\\n  /** number of legs */\\\\r\\\\n  legs: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Legs;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Legs;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Snake {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  // snakes have no legs\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### additionalProperties/unevaluatedProperties\\\\n\\\\nYou can generate a schema with `additionalProperties` with the TypeSpec `Record` construct.\\\\r\\\\n**Note:** `unevaluatedProperties` is used instead of `additionalProperties` when emitting Open API 3.1 specs.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  bar: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nis produced as\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nbar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties: {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo get a schema having both `properties` and `additionalProperties`, define a model that extends `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Bar extends Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  bar?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nBar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    bar:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties: {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo define a schema with `additionalProperties` that has a specific type, use the `Record` construct with a type parameter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  bar: Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nresults in\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nbar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties:\\\\r\\\\n    type: string\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo define a schema that **does not** allow any additional properties, use `Record\\\\u003cnever\\\\u003e`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  bar: Record\\\\u003cnever\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nresults in\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nbar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties:\\\\r\\\\n    not: {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the openapi3 emitter, schemas that don't define `additionalProperties` can automatically be set to `additionalProperties: { not: {} }` by setting the `seal-object-schemas` emitter option to `true`. This will not add `additionalProperties` to object schemas that are referenced in an `allOf` of another schema.\\\\n\\\\n### allOf and polymorphism using allOf\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec supports single inheritance of models with the `extends` keyword. This construct can be used to produce an `allOf` with a single element (the parent schema) in OpenAPI. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=main.tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  meow: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  bark: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec does not currently provide a means to produce an `allOf` with more than one element -- these are generally treated as \\\\\\\"composition\\\\\\\" in code generators and thus better represented in TypeSpec with the spread operator.\\\\r\\\\nModels with a `@discriminator` decorator can be extended to produce polymorphic schemas in either OpenAPI v2 or v3 using `allOf`.\\\\r\\\\nThis schema produced for the base model will be defined with a `discriminator` property and schemas for the child models will `allOf` the base schema and add additional properties.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  weight?: float32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngenerates:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nCat:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - cat\\\\r\\\\n    meow:\\\\r\\\\n      type: integer\\\\r\\\\n      format: int32\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nDog:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - dog\\\\r\\\\n    bark:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      description: Discriminator property for Pet.\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    weight:\\\\r\\\\n      type: number\\\\r\\\\n      format: float\\\\r\\\\n  discriminator:\\\\r\\\\n    propertyName: kind\\\\r\\\\n    mapping:\\\\r\\\\n      cat: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      dog: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Polymorphism using anyOf and oneOf (OAS3)\\\\n\\\\nPolymorphism can also be represented in OpenAPI v3 with `anyOf` or `oneOf` constructs.\\\\r\\\\nThese can be represented in TypeSpec with a union type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngenerates a Pet schema with `anyOf`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  anyOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe openapi emitter uses `anyOf` by default because the schemas may not be mutually exclusive.\\\\r\\\\nBut the `@oneOf` decorator of the OpenAPI library can be used to force the use of `oneOf` instead.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing OpenAPI;\\\\r\\\\n@oneOf\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  oneOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo make Pet a discriminated union, add the `@discriminator` decorator and add the discriminator property\\\\r\\\\nwith a string literal value to each of the child schemas.\\\\r\\\\nView the [`@discriminated` documentation](https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators/#@discriminated) to learn how to further customize what is emitted.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminated(#{ envelope: \\\\\\\"none\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nresults in the following schema for Pet:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  oneOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - actual.answer:
To ensure your ArmResourceActionSync operation emits the x-ms-pageable extension with nextLinkName set to 'nextLink', you must decorate the operation with @list. This is required by both TypeSpec and Azure API guidelines for pageable operations. The presence of nextLink in the response model alone is not sufficient; the operation itself must be marked as pageable.

Here's how you should update your TypeSpec code:

```typespec
/**
 * Get elastic volumes associated with elastic snapshot policy
 */
@get
@action("elasticvolumes")
@added(Versions.v2025_09_01_preview)
@list // <-- This decorator is required
listVolumes is ArmResourceActionSync<
  ElasticSnapshotPolicyResource,
  void,
  ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList
>;
```

This will result in the generated OpenAPI operation containing:

```json
"x-ms-pageable": {
  "nextLinkName": "nextLink"
}
```

Summary:
- Add the @list decorator to your operation.
- Ensure your response model (ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList) is based on Azure.Core.Page or ResourceListResult and includes nextLink.
- The @list decorator is what triggers the x-ms-pageable extension in the emitted OpenAPI.

This approach is fully compliant with Azure management-plane API guidelines and will resolve the XmsPageableForListCalls linter finding.

question\\\\n\\\\nHi, I have a typespec API which is a list api \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n listResources is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    AutoAction,\\\\r\\\\n    void,\\\\r\\\\n    AutoActionResourceListResponse\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nmodel AutoActionResourceListResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAutoActionResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis api needs to support pagination. How can I achieve that using Microsoft.TypeSpec.Providerhub.Controller? we use the package to generate our controllers, which doesn't let me add query parameters to our API\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe controller emitter will emit an endpoint for your action, but you will need to add an endpoint manually for the next page endpoint (which is, presumably, a GET).\\\\r\\\\nget is required for paging.  If you are not using GET, then automated paging mechanisms in ARM clients won't work.\\\\r\\\\nIt's possible to use a different paging mechanism, but will require custom code in SDKs\\\\r\\\\ntypespec-providerhub does not provide extra GET endpoints for resource actions that return lists - you would need to add this endpoint.  Since the controllers are partial, this should be fairly straightforward.\\\\r\\\\nThe question of whether RPaaS (providerhub) should support such an endpoint and typespec-providerhub should provide any required extension support for this is a good one.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#azure-resource-manager#reference#data-types.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Data The link may encode parameters such as query parameters in HTTP. In such cases those parameters must be passed.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, HTTP links are expected to be opaque and contain all the necessary information for the next page URL. This means that query and path parameters are expected to already have been included in the link. On the other hand, any header parameters are expected to be resent in the next request as those cannot be represented in the link.\\\\n\\\\n### Examples\\\\n\\\\n#### Next link pagination in Http\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"pets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@list\\\\r\\\\nop listPets(\\\\r\\\\n  @query filter?: string,\\\\r\\\\n  @query expand?: string,\\\\r\\\\n  @query @pageIndex page?: int32 = 1,\\\\r\\\\n  @query @pageSize perPage?: int32 = 100,\\\\r\\\\n  @header specialHeader?: \\\\\\\"x-special-value\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n): {\\\\r\\\\n  @pageItems pets: Pet[];\\\\r\\\\n  @nextLink next?: url;\\\\r\\\\n};\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`http\\\\r\\\\n// First request\\\\r\\\\nGET /pets?filter=dog\\\\r\\\\nSpecial-Header: x-special-value\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\\\\"pets\\\\\\\": [...], \\\\\\\"nextLink\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"/pets?filter=dog\\\\u0026page=2\\\\u0026perPage=100\\\\\\\"}\\\\r\\\\n// Second request\\\\r\\\\nGET /pets?filter=dog\\\\u0026token=token2\\\\r\\\\nSpecial-Header: x-special-value\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\\\\"pets\\\\\\\": [...], \\\\\\\"continuationToken\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"token3\\\\\\\"}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM.Foundations-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 17. This will ensure that the generated OpenAPI/Swagger includes the correct `x-ms-pageable` extension, as required by Azure ARM and API guidelines.\\nHere's how you should modify your TypeSpec:\\n```\\n@list\\n@get\\n@action(\\\"elasticvolumes\\\")\\nlistVolumes is ArmResourceActionSync<\\nElasticSnapshotPolicy,\\nvoid,\\nElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList\\n>;\\nmodel ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolumeList is Azure.Core.Page<ElasticSnapshotPolicyVolume>;\\n```\\nThe `@list` decorator is what triggers the addition of `x-ms-pageable` in the generated OpenAPI.\\nYour model should use the standard ARM paging model, which is `Azure.Core.Page<T>`. testcase: Should I add a visibilityFilter to a model

expected.answer:
ou do not need to explicitly add a visibilityFilter or use @withVisibility(Lifecycle.Read) if your model is only used as the return result of an operation. TypeSpec's HTTP library and standard emitters automatically apply Lifecycle.Read visibility to properties when a model is used as a return type. By default, properties are included in the response if they have Lifecycle.Read visibility, and all properties have all visibilities enabled unless you restrict them with @visibility.
Therefore, unless you have properties with more restrictive visibilities, all properties will be included in the response by default. If you want to limit which properties are returned, you should annotate those properties with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) or other appropriate modifiers, but you do not need to explicitly use a visibilityFilter just because a model is a response type.
If you use the built-in Lifecycle visibility model as intended, the behavior you expect is implicit and handled automatically for response models.

TypeSpec's standard emitters (such as OpenAPI and HTTP) automatically apply Lifecycle visibility based on the context in which the model is used. Specifically, when a model is used as the response type of an operation (e.g., for GET), only properties marked with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) will be included in the emitted schema. This is implicit and handled by the emitter, so you should simply annotate your model properties with the appropriate @visibility decorators, and the correct shape will be emitted for each operation context.\\n\\nFor example:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel Example {\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\n  id: string;\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\n  name: string;\\n  description: string;\\n}\\n\\n@route(\\\"/example\\\")\\ninterface Examples {\\n  @get read(@path id: string): Example;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIn this case, the OpenAPI emitter will automatically generate a response schema for GET that only includes properties with Lifecycle.Read visibility. You only need to use @withVisibilityFilter or related templates if you want to create custom views or models outside of the standard operation context.\", \"ground_truth\": \"ou do not need to explicitly add a visibilityFilter or use @withVisibility(Lifecycle.Read) if your model is only used as the return result of an operation. TypeSpec's HTTP library and standard emitters automatically apply Lifecycle.Read visibility to properties when a model is used as a return type. By default, properties are included in the response if they have Lifecycle.Read visibility, and all properties have all visibilities enabled unless you restrict them with @visibility.\\nTherefore, unless you have properties with more restrictive visibilities, all properties will be included in the response by default. If you want to limit which properties are returned, you should annotate those properties with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) or other appropriate modifiers, but you do not need to explicitly use a visibilityFilter just because a model is a response type.\\nIf you use the built-in Lifecycle visibility model as intended, the behavior you expect is implicit and handled automatically for response models.\"}"}]

`ExampleUpdate` schema only includes the `description` property because it is the only property that is visible\\\\r\\\\n  when updating the resource.\\\\r\\\\n- Each of the `paths` reference the correct schema based on the lifecycle phase that the operations use.\\\\r\\\\n- The TypeSpec model is only defined _once_, and any changes in the output schemas are derived from the lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  visibility of the properties in the model.\\\\n\\\\n### Lifecycle modifiers\\\\n\\\\nThe following visibility modifiers are available in the `Lifecycle` visibility class:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create`: The property is visible when the resource is created. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `POST` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read`: The property is visible when the resource is read. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property is\\\\r\\\\n  returned in an HTTP `GET` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update`: The property is visible when the resource is updated. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `PATCH` or `PUT` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete`: The property is visible when a resource is deleted. This visibility is checked, for example, when a property\\\\r\\\\n  is a parameter in an HTTP `DELETE` operation.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query`: The property is visible when a resource is passed as a parameter in a query. This visibility is checked, for\\\\r\\\\n  example, when a property is a parameter in an HTTP `GET` operation (**this should not be confused with an HTTP query\\\\r\\\\n  parameter defined using `@query`**).\\\\n\\\\n### Lifecycle visibility transforms\\\\n\\\\nYou can explicitly compute the shape of a model within a _specific_ lifecycle phase by using the four built-in\\\\r\\\\ntemplates for lifecycle transforms:\\\\r\\\\n- `Create\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Create` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Read\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Read` lifecycle phase,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Update\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Update` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, with the types of the properties set to `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have _either_ the `Create` or `Update`\\\\r\\\\n  visibility modifiers enabled, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Delete` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Query` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Update)\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadExample is Read\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateExample is Create\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel UpdateExample is Update\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateOrUpdateExample is CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen you use these templates, the resulting models have no `Lifecycle` visibility modifiers applied, so that
