{#@withDefaultKeyVisibility}\\\\n\\\\nSet the visibility of key properties in a model if not already set.\\\\r\\\\nThis will set the visibility modifiers of all key properties in the model if the visibility is not already _explicitly_ set,\\\\r\\\\nbut will not change the visibility of any properties that have visibility set _explicitly_, even if the visibility\\\\r\\\\nis the same as the default visibility.\\\\r\\\\nVisibility may be set explicitly using any of the following decorators:\\\\r\\\\n- `@visibility`\\\\r\\\\n- `@removeVisibility`\\\\r\\\\n- `@invisible`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@withDefaultKeyVisibility(visibility: valueof EnumMember)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Target\\\\r\\\\n`Model`\\\\r\\\\n#### Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Type | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| visibility | `valueof EnumMember` | The desired default visibility value. If a key property already has visibility set, it will not be changed. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Readonly on model\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Readonly on model\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Readonly on model\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have such swagger\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  readonly: true,\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {}\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"AnotherModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      $ref: \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWhen the type of property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\" in another model is that \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\", M4 will give a readonly on that property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\". I want to confirm if the equivalent TypeSpec should be\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel AnotherModel {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  a: ReadonlyOnModel;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadonlyOnModel {}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ncc Alitzel Mendez : Common type replacement relates to this. I remember we have several models in the original common type have readonly on them and you removed these because TypeSpec cannot represent readonly on model. Then if any service refers to this model, those properties might need to be updated.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec can only attach readOnly to properties, not to models or scalars.  Functionally (assuming all references to ReadOnlyModel are through readOnly properties),  these Swagger docs are equivalent, see: [autorest/docs/openapi/howto/$ref-siblings.md at main \\u00b7 Azure/autorest](https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/openapi/howto/%24ref-siblings.md) from the perspective of both TypeSpec and autorest, these descriptions are equivalent.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"extending-typespec#emitter-metadata-handling.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/extending-typespec/emitter-metadata-handling\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\\n## Working with metadata and visibility\\\\n# extending-typespec#emitter-metadata-handling.md\\\\n\\\\n# Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\\n\\\\n## Working with metadata and visibility\\\\n\\\\nWhen working with metadata and visibility, it's important to understand how they interact with each other and with the data being transmitted. Here are some key points to consider:\\\\r\\\\n- Metadata is data about the data being transmitted. It can include information like the data's origin, when it was created or last updated, who created or updated it, and so on. Metadata is not usually visible to the end user, but it can be crucial for the system processing the data.\\\\r\\\\n- Visibility determines what data is visible to the end user or the system at any given time. For example, some data might be visible only to the system, some only to the end user, and some to both. Visibility can change depending on the context, such as whether the data is being created, read, updated, or deleted.\\\\r\\\\n- The `getRequestVisibility(HttpVerb): Visibility` API is used to determine the visibility implied for data in the request parameters or body. Note that `Visibility.Read` is always applied for response data, so there is no corresponding API for the response.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo` API is used to create a metadata object for each program, which can then be used to reason about metadata and visibility implications.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.getEffectivePayloadType(Type, Visibility): Type` API is used recursively on every type that is referenced. It recovers the named model when given an anonymous model sourced entirely from a single named model after metadata is moved elsewhere or invisible properties are removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isTransformed(Model, Visibility)` API is used to check if a type undergoes any changes in shape due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\n\\\\nnamed model after metadata is moved elsewhere or invisible properties are removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isTransformed(Model, Visibility)` API is used to check if a type undergoes any changes in shape due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isOptional(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to determine if a property is optional for the given visibility. This will differ from `ModelProperty.isOptional` when the Visibility is Update, in which case the property is always considered optional.\\\\r\\\\n- The `Visibility.Item` flag is added when recursing into an array. This moves all metadata into the payload, which can be useful in scenarios like batching API calls.\\\\r\\\\nBy understanding and correctly using these APIs and concepts, you can ensure that your emitter handles metadata and visibility consistently and effectively.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#reference#typekits.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"[API] Typekits\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/reference/typekits\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# [API] Typekits\\\\n## model\\\\n### getEffectiveModel\\\\n# standard-library#reference#typekits.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# [API] Typekits\\\\n\\\\n## model\\\\n\\\\n### getEffectiveModel\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`ts\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * If the input is anonymous (or the provided filter removes properties) and there exists a named model with the same set of properties (ignoring filtered properties), then return that named model. Otherwise, return the input unchanged.\\\\r\\\\n *\\\\r\\\\n * This can be used by emitters to find a better name for a set of properties after filtering. For example, given `{  @metadata prop: string} \\\\u0026 SomeName`, and an emitter that wishes to discard properties marked with `@metadata`, the emitter can use this to recover that the best name for the remaining properties is `SomeName`.\\\\r\\\\n *\\\\r\\\\n * @param model - The input model\\\\r\\\\n *\\\\r\\\\n * @param filter - An optional filter to apply to the input model's properties.\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\n$(program).model.getEffectiveModel(\\\\r\\\\n  model: Model,\\\\r\\\\n  filter: (property: ModelProperty) =\\\\u003e boolean\\\\r\\\\n): Model;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#built-in-data-types.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Built-in Data types\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-data-types\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Built-in Data types\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n### `Query` {#Query}\\\\n# standard-library#built-in-data-types.md\\\\n\\\\n# Built-in Data types\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### `Query` {#Query}\\\\n\\\\nA copy of the input model `T` with only the properties that are visible during the\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Query\\\\\\\" resource lifecycle phase.\\\\r\\\\nThe \\\\\\\"Query\\\\\\\" lifecycle phase is used for properties passed as parameters to operations\\\\r\\\\nthat read data, like HTTP GET or HEAD operations. This should not be confused for\\\\r\\\\nthe `@query` decorator, which specifies that the property is transmitted in the\\\\r\\\\nquery string of an HTTP request.\\\\r\\\\nThis transformation is recursive, and will include only properties that have the\\\\r\\\\n`Lifecycle.Query` visibility modifier.\\\\r\\\\nIf a `NameTemplate` is provided, the new model will be named according to the template.\\\\r\\\\nThe template uses the same syntax as the `@friendlyName` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Query\\\\u003cT, NameTemplate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Template Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| T | The model to transform. |\\\\r\\\\n| NameTemplate | The name template to use for the new model.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003e\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003e* |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  // When getting information for a Dog, you can set this field to true to include\\\\r\\\\n  // some extra information about the Dog's pedigree that is normally not returned.\\\\r\\\\n  // Alternatively, you could just use a separate option parameter to get this\\\\r\\\\n  // information.\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Query)\\\\r\\\\n  includePedigree?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  // Only included if `includePedigree` is set to true in the request.\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  pedigree?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// This model will have the `includePedigree` and `name` fields, but not `id` or `pedigree`.\\\\r\\\\nmodel QueryDog is Query\\\\u003cDog\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Visibility\\\\n# language-basics#visibility.md\\\\n\\\\n# Visibility\\\\n\\\\n**Visibility** is a language feature that allows you to share a model between multiple operations and define in which contexts\\\\r\\\\nproperties of the model are \\\\\\\"visible.\\\\\\\" Visibility is a very powerful feature that allows you to define different \\\\\\\"views\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nof a model within different operations or contexts.\\\\r\\\\n**Note** \\u26a0\\ufe0f: Enum-based visibility as described in this document _replaces_ visibility strings that you may have used\\\\r\\\\nin the past. The system is backwards-compatible with visibility strings, but you should use enum-based visibility for\\\\r\\\\nnew specifications. String-based visibility (e.g. `@visibility(\\\\\\\"create\\\\\\\")`) may be deprecated and removed in future\\\\r\\\\nversions of TypeSpec.\\\\n\\\\n## Basic concepts\\\\n\\\\n- Visibility applies to _model properties_ only. It is used to determine when an emitter should include or exclude a\\\\r\\\\n  property in a certain context.\\\\r\\\\n- Visibility is defined using a _visibility class_. A visibility class is an `enum` that defines the visibility modifiers\\\\r\\\\n  (or flags) that can be applied to a property. Any `enum` can serve as a visibility class.\\\\r\\\\n- Visibility classes have a _default_ visibility, which is the set of visibility modifiers that are applied _by default_\\\\r\\\\n  to a property if the visibility is not explicitly set.\\\\n\\\\n## Lifecycle visibility\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec provides a built-in visibility called \\\\\\\"resource lifecycle visibility.\\\\\\\" This visibility allows you to declare\\\\r\\\\nwhether properties are visible when passing a resource to or reading a resource from an API endpoint. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The unique identifier of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * The ID is automatically generated by the service, so it cannot be set when the resource is created or updated,\\\\r\\\\n   * but the server will return it when the resource is read.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The name of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * The name can be set when the resource is created, but may not be changed.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The description of this resource.\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * By default, properties are visible in all lifecycle phases, so this property\\\\r\\\\n   * is present in all lifecycle phases.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the above example, each property of the `Example` model has a lifecycle visibility that instructs emitters to include\\\\r\\\\nor exclude the property when creating, updating, or reading the `Example` resource.\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec's HTTP library, OpenAPI emitter, and other standard functionality use the `Lifecycle` visibility to create\\\\r\\\\ndifferent views of the `Example` model based on which lifecycle phase is used in a particular operation.\\\\r\\\\nIn the following example, the type of the input and output of each operation is affected by the lifecycle visibility\\\\r\\\\nof the properties in the `Example` model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/example\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\ninterface Examples {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * When an operation uses the POST verb, it uses the `Create` lifecycle visibility to determine which properties\\\\r\\\\n   * are visible.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @post create(@body example: Example): Created\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e | Error;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * When an operation uses the GET verb, it uses the `Read` lifecycle visibility to determine which properties\\\\r\\\\n   * are visible.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\n\\\\nby the lifecycle visibility\\\\r\\\\nof the properties in the `Example` model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/example\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\ninterface Examples {\\\\r\\\\n `Update\\\\u003cT extends Model\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that are visible in the `Update` lifecycle\\\\r\\\\n  phase, with the types of the properties set to `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have _either_ the `Create` or `Update`\\\\r\\\\n  visibility modifiers enabled, recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Delete\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Delete` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\n- `Query\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e`: creates a copy of `T` with only the properties that have the `Lifecycle.Query` modifier enabled,\\\\r\\\\n  recursively.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Update)\\\\r\\\\n  description: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadExample is Read\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateExample is Create\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel UpdateExample is Update\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nmodel CreateOrUpdateExample is CreateOrUpdate\\\\u003cExample\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen you use these templates, the resulting models have no `Lifecycle` visibility modifiers applied, so that any\\\\r\\\\nemitters or libraries that use lifecycle visibility will not alter them further.\\\\n\\\\n## Visibility modifiers\\\\n\\\\nEach property has its own set of _active visibility modifiers_ for each visibility class. The active modifiers can be\\\\r\\\\nchanged using the decorators described in this section.\\\\r\\\\n**Note**: Changing the visibility for one visibility class _does not_ affect other visibility classes. If you change the\\\\r\\\\nvisibility for the `Lifecycle` visibility class, it will not affect the modifiers that are active for _any_ other\\\\r\\\\nvisibility cla\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#http#operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/http/operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Operations\\\\n## Automatic visibility\\\\n# libraries#http#operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Automatic visibility\\\\n\\\\nThe `@typespec/rest` library understands [Lifecycle Visibility](../../language-basics/visibility.md#lifecycle-visibility) and provides functionality for emitters to apply visibility transforms based on whether a model represents a request or response and on HTTP method usage as detailed in the table below.\\\\r\\\\nSee [handling visibility and metadata](../../extending-typespec/emitter-metadata-handling.md) for details on how to incorporate this information into an emitter implementation.\\\\r\\\\n| Modifier         | Visible in           |\\\\r\\\\n| ---------------- | -------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Read   | Any response         |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Query  | GET or HEAD request  |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Create | POST or PUT request  |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Update | PATCH or PUT request |\\\\r\\\\n| Lifecycle.Delete | DELETE request       |\\\\r\\\\nThis allows a single logical TypeSpec model to be used as in the following example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create) password: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/users\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\ninterface Users {\\\\r\\\\n  @post create(@path id: string, ...User): User;\\\\r\\\\n  @get get(@path id: string): User;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThere is a single logical user entity represented by the single TypeSpec type `User`, but the HTTP payload for this entity varies based on context. When returned in a response, the `id` property is included, but when sent in a request, it is not. Similarly, the `password` property is only included in create requests, but not present in responses.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI v3 emitter will apply these visibilities automatically, without explicit use of `@withVisibility`, and it will generate separate schemas suffixed by visibility when necessary. `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` can be expressed in OpenAPI without generating additional schema by specifying `readOnly: true` and the OpenAPI v3 emitter will leverage this a an optimization, but other visibilities will generate additional schemas.\\\\n\\\\nincluded in create requests, but not present in responses.\\\\r\\\\nThe OpenAPI v3 emitter will apply these visibilities automatically, without explicit use of `@withVisibility`, and it will generate separate schemas suffixed by visibility when necessary. `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` can be expressed in OpenAPI without generating additional schema by specifying `readOnly: true` and the OpenAPI v3 emitter will leverage this a an optimization, but other visibilities will generate additional schemas. For example, `@visibility(Lifecycle.Create)` applied to a model property of a type named Widget will generate a `WidgetCreate` schema.\\\\r\\\\nAnother emitter such as one generating client code can see and preserve a single logical type and deal with these HTTP payload differences by means other than type proliferation.\\\\r\\\\nModeling with logical entities rather than HTTP-specific shapes also keeps the TypeSpec spec decoupled from HTTP and REST and can allow the same spec to be used with multiple protocols.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"extending-typespec#emitter-metadata-handling.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/extending-typespec/emitter-metadata-handling\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\\n# extending-typespec#emitter-metadata-handling.md\\\\n\\\\n# Managing metadata and visibility in REST API emitters\\\\n\\\\nEnsuring consistent handling of [automatic visibility](../libraries/http/operations.md#automatic-visibility) and [metadata](../libraries/http/operations.md#metadata) by all REST API emitters is crucial. To understand how these features work, please refer to the TypeSpec-author documentation. This guide will help you integrate these features into your own emitter correctly.\\\\r\\\\nThe standard `/rest` library offers a JavaScript API for emitters to interpret APIs written using its decorators. We will focus on the APIs that are specifically relevant to these features.\\\\r\\\\nWhen we say that emitters should handle things consistently, we mean they should agree on how data is transmitted and received. A TypeSpec _specification_ should serve as a reliable reference for these details. However, emitters can still _abstract_ things above this level and make different choices. For instance, the OpenAPI emitter may split a single TypeSpec model into multiple suffixed schemas like `UserCreate` and `UserUpdate`, while a client SDK emitter might emit a single `User` class that can be serialized to a request or deserialized from a response with different fields present in different situations. These features were specifically designed to allow a TypeSpec specification to be written in terms of logical entities that emitters could then maintain.\\\\n\\\\n## Getting started\\\\n\\\\nIf you're new to writing emitters, begin with the [emitter basics](./emitters-basics.md).\\\\r\\\\nNext, examine the [REST metadata emitter sample](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/samples/specs/rest-metadata-emitter). This sample uses all of the APIs discussed below to create a simple textual representation. It intentionally avoids splitting types like the OpenAPI emitter to highlight that this is not mandatory. Instead, it includes contextual comments to indicate how data depends on context.\\\\r\\\\nHowever, if you want your emitter to split types like OpenAPI, you can still use the same API. Cross-referencing with the official [OpenAPI emitter](../emitters/openapi3/openapi.md) where these APIs are called can also be helpful.\\\\n\\\\n## Key API\\\\n\\\\nHere are the main APIs involved in managing these features. For more details, refer to the linked API reference documentation.\\\\r\\\\n- [`resolveRequestVisibility(Program, Operation, HttpVerb): Visibility`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/functions/resolveRequestVisibility.md) - Use this to determine the visibility implied for data in the request parameters or body. Note that [`Visibility.Read`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/enumerations/Visibility.md) is always applied for response data, so there is no corresponding API for the response.\\\\r\\\\n- [`MetadataInfo`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/interfaces/MetadataInfo.md) - Create this once for each program using [`createMetadataInfo(Program, MetadataInfoOptions)`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/functions/createMetadataInfo.md). Then use it to understand metadata and visibility implications with the APIs below.\\\\r\\\\n- [`MetadataInfo.getEffectivePayloadType(Type, Visibility): Type`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/interfaces/MetadataInfo.md#geteffectivepayloadtype) - Use this recursively on every referenced type. When given an anonymous model sourced entirely from a single named model after metadata is moved elsewhere or invisible properties are removed, it will recover the named model. This handles the commonly discussed case of seeing that `op something(...Thing)` receives a `Thing` in its request body, among other cases.\\\\r\\\\n- [`MetadataInfo.isTransformed(Model, Visibility)`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/interfaces/MetadataInfo.md#istransformed) - Use this to check if a type undergoes any shape changes due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- [`MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/interfaces/MetadataInfo.md#ispayloadproperty) - Use this to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\n\\\\n- Use this to check if a type undergoes any shape changes due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- [`MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/interfaces/MetadataInfo.md#ispayloadproperty) - Use this to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\r\\\\n- [`MetadataInfo.isOptional(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/interfaces/MetadataInfo.md#isoptional) - Use this to determine if a property is optional for the given visibility. This will differ from `ModelProperty.isOptional` when the Visibility is Update, in which case the property is always considered optional.\\\\r\\\\n- [`Visibility.Item`](../libraries/http/reference/js-api/enumerations/Visibility.md) - Add this flag when recursing into an array. This moves all metadata into the payload, which can be useful in scenarios like batching API calls.\\\\n\\\\n## Working with metadata and visibility\\\\n\\\\nWhen working with metadata and visibility, it's important to understand how they interact with each other and with the data being transmitted. Here are some key points to consider:\\\\r\\\\n- Metadata is data about the data being transmitted. It can include information like the data's origin, when it was created or last updated, who created or updated it, and so on. Metadata is not usually visible to the end user, but it can be crucial for the system processing the data.\\\\r\\\\n- Visibility determines what data is visible to the end user or the system at any given time. For example, some data might be visible only to the system, some only to the end user, and some to both. Visibility can change depending on the context, such as whether the data is being created, read, updated, or deleted.\\\\r\\\\n- The `getRequestVisibility(HttpVerb): Visibility` API is used to determine the visibility implied for data in the request parameters or body. Note that `Visibility.Read` is always applied for response data, so there is no corresponding API for the response.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo` API is used to create a metadata object for each program, which can then be used to reason about metadata and visibility implications.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.getEffectivePayloadType(Type, Visibility): Type` API is used recursively on every type that is referenced. It recovers the named model when given an anonymous model sourced entirely from a single named model after metadata is moved elsewhere or invisible properties are removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isTransformed(Model, Visibility)` API is used to check if a type undergoes any changes in shape due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\n\\\\nnamed model after metadata is moved elsewhere or invisible properties are removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isTransformed(Model, Visibility)` API is used to check if a type undergoes any changes in shape due to visibility or metadata. If not, this can allow for simplifications in emit.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isPayloadProperty(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to check if a property is transmitted as an object property in the payload and is not invisible or metadata sent elsewhere.\\\\r\\\\n- The `MetadataInfo.isOptional(ModelProperty, Visibility): boolean` API is used to determine if a property is optional for the given visibility. This will differ from `ModelProperty.isOptional` when the Visibility is Update, in which case the property is always considered optional.\\\\r\\\\n- The `Visibility.Item` flag is added when recursing into an array. This moves all metadata into the payload, which can be useful in scenarios like batching API calls.\\\\r\\\\nBy understanding and correctly using these APIs and concepts, you can ensure that your emitter handles metadata and visibility consistently and effectively.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n\\\\nWhether you're working with Data Plane (DP) or Azure Resource Manager (ARM), having clear examples to follow can make your transition to TypeSpec smoother. Here are some resources that can help:\\\\r\\\\n- **Playground Examples**: Our playground provides ARM and DP examples that serve as excellent models for teams new to TypeSpec Azure. These examples are concise and take full advantage of our standard operation templates. You can use these as a gold standard for your own TypeSpec definitions. Visit the [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure) to explore these examples.\\\\r\\\\n- **ARM Samples**: For more specific scenarios, check out our additional [ARM samples](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/tree/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/arm-scenarios). These are tutorial-like examples that cover various scenarios. You can adapt these to fit your specific needs.\\\\r\\\\nThe playground examples are a great starting point for getting familiar with TypeSpec Azure. As you gain more experience, you can leverage the ARM samples to understand how to apply TypeSpec to a variety of scenarios.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#mustread.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Understanding the OpenAPI Changes\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/mustread\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Understanding the OpenAPI Changes\\\\n## Handling \\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\" in Model Schemas\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#mustread.md\\\\n\\\\n# Understanding the OpenAPI Changes\\\\n\\\\n## Handling \\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\" in Model Schemas\\\\n\\\\nThe `\\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\": true` property should only be used on properties, not on models. If a model is mistakenly marked as readOnly and other models refer to it, like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReadOnlyModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReferToReadOnlyModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"property\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/ReadOnlyModel\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nDecorating the property referencing the model with '@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` is equivalent to marking the model schema as read-only as in the OpenAPI above.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadOnlyModel {}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReferToReadOnlyModel {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  property: ReadOnlyModel;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"standard-library#built-in-decorators.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Built-in Decorators\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Built-in Decorators\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n### `@withVisibility` {#@withVisibility}\\\\n# standard-library#built-in-decorators.md\\\\n\\\\n# Built-in Decorators\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### `@withVisibility` {#@withVisibility}\\\\n\\\\nRemoves properties that do not have at least one of the given visibility modifiers\\\\r\\\\nactive.\\\\r\\\\nIf no visibility modifiers are supplied, this decorator has no effect.\\\\r\\\\nSee also: [Automatic visibility](https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/http/operations#automatic-visibility)\\\\r\\\\nWhen using an emitter that applies visibility automatically, it is generally\\\\r\\\\nnot necessary to use this decorator.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@withVisibility(...visibilities: valueof EnumMember[])\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Target\\\\r\\\\n`Model`\\\\r\\\\n#### Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Type | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| visibilities | `valueof EnumMember[]` | List of visibilities that apply to this property. |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Update)\\\\r\\\\n  secretName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// The spread operator will copy all the properties of Dog into DogRead,\\\\r\\\\n// and @withVisibility will then remove those that are not visible with\\\\r\\\\n// create or update visibility.\\\\r\\\\n//\\\\r\\\\n// In this case, the id property is removed, and the name and secretName\\\\r\\\\n// properties are kept.\\\\r\\\\n@withVisibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Update)\\\\r\\\\nmodel DogCreateOrUpdate {\\\\r\\\\n  ...Dog;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// In this case the id and name properties are kept and the secretName property\\\\r\\\\n// is removed.\\\\r\\\\n@withVisibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\nmodel DogRead {\\\\r\\\\n  ...Dog;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI schemas are represented in TypeSpec by [models](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/models/).\\\\r\\\\nModels have any number of members and can extend and be composed with other models.\\\\r\\\\nModels can be defined with the `model` statement and then referenced by name, which generally results in a `$ref` to a schema for the model in the `definitions` or `components.schemas` section of the OpenAPI document.\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec supports the [\\\\\\\"spread\\\\\\\" operator](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/models/#spread) (`...`), which copies the members of the source model into the target model.\\\\r\\\\nBut TypeSpec processes all spread transformations before emitters are invoked, so this form of reuse is not represented in the emitted OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\nThe spread operation is useful if you want one or more properties to be present in several different models but in a standard fashion. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Legs {\\\\r\\\\n  /** number of legs */\\\\r\\\\n  legs: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Legs;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  ...Legs;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Snake {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  // snakes have no legs\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### additionalProperties/unevaluatedProperties\\\\n\\\\nYou can generate a schema with `additionalProperties` with the TypeSpec `Record` construct.\\\\r\\\\n**Note:** `unevaluatedProperties` is used instead of `additionalProperties` when emitting Open API 3.1 specs.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  bar: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nis produced as\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nbar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties: {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo get a schema having both `properties` and `additionalProperties`, define a model that extends `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Bar extends Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  bar?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nBar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    bar:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties: {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo define a schema with `additionalProperties` that has a specific type, use the `Record` construct with a type parameter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  bar: Record\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nresults in\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nbar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties:\\\\r\\\\n    type: string\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo define a schema that **does not** allow any additional properties, use `Record\\\\u003cnever\\\\u003e`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  bar: Record\\\\u003cnever\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nresults in\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nbar:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  additionalProperties:\\\\r\\\\n    not: {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the openapi3 emitter, schemas that don't define `additionalProperties` can automatically be set to `additionalProperties: { not: {} }` by setting the `seal-object-schemas` emitter option to `true`. This will not add `additionalProperties` to object schemas that are referenced in an `allOf` of another schema.\\\\n\\\\n### allOf and polymorphism using allOf\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec supports single inheritance of models with the `extends` keyword. This construct can be used to produce an `allOf` with a single element (the parent schema) in OpenAPI. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=main.tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  meow: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  bark: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec does not currently provide a means to produce an `allOf` with more than one element -- these are generally treated as \\\\\\\"composition\\\\\\\" in code generators and thus better represented in TypeSpec with the spread operator.\\\\r\\\\nModels with a `@discriminator` decorator can be extended to produce polymorphic schemas in either OpenAPI v2 or v3 using `allOf`.\\\\r\\\\nThis schema produced for the base model will be defined with a `discriminator` property and schemas for the child models will `allOf` the base schema and add additional properties.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  weight?: float32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngenerates:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nCat:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - cat\\\\r\\\\n    meow:\\\\r\\\\n      type: integer\\\\r\\\\n      format: int32\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nDog:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - dog\\\\r\\\\n    bark:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      description: Discriminator property for Pet.\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    weight:\\\\r\\\\n      type: number\\\\r\\\\n      format: float\\\\r\\\\n  discriminator:\\\\r\\\\n    propertyName: kind\\\\r\\\\n    mapping:\\\\r\\\\n      cat: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      dog: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - name\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Polymorphism using anyOf and oneOf (OAS3)\\\\n\\\\nPolymorphism can also be represented in OpenAPI v3 with `anyOf` or `oneOf` constructs.\\\\r\\\\nThese can be represented in TypeSpec with a union type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngenerates a Pet schema with `anyOf`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  anyOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe openapi emitter uses `anyOf` by default because the schemas may not be mutually exclusive.\\\\r\\\\nBut the `@oneOf` decorator of the OpenAPI library can be used to force the use of `oneOf` instead.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing OpenAPI;\\\\r\\\\n@oneOf\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  oneOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo make Pet a discriminated union, add the `@discriminator` decorator and add the discriminator property\\\\r\\\\nwith a string literal value to each of the child schemas.\\\\r\\\\nView the [`@discriminated` documentation](https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators/#@discriminated) to learn how to further customize what is emitted.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminated(#{ envelope: \\\\\\\"none\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\nunion Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  cat: Cat,\\\\r\\\\n  dog: Dog,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nresults in the following schema for Pet:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  oneOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - TCGC currently only supports examples based on HTTP payload, so the examples are available in `SdkHttpOperation.examples`.\\\\r\\\\n[`SdkHttpOperationExample`](../reference/js-api/interfaces/sdkhttpoperationexample/) represents an example. [`SdkHttpParameterExampleValue`](../reference/js-api/interfaces/sdkhttpparameterexamplevalue/), [`SdkHttpResponseExampleValue`](../reference/js-api/interfaces/sdkhttpresponseexamplevalue/), and [`SdkHttpResponseHeaderExampleValue`](../reference/js-api/interfaces/sdkhttpresponseheaderexamplevalue/) represent HTTP parameter, response body, and response header examples. Each type contains the example value and its corresponding definition type.\\\\r\\\\n[`SdkExampleValue`](../reference/js-api/type-aliases/sdkexamplevalue/) represents an example value of different types. All related types are used to represent the example value of a definition type. One definition type may have different example value types.\\\\r\\\\nFor [`SdkUnionExampleValue`](../reference/js-api/interfaces/sdkunionexamplevalue/), since it is difficult to determine which union variant the example value should belong to, TCGC preserves the raw value and leaves this determination to the emitter.\\\\r\\\\nFor [`SdkModelExampleValue`](../reference/js-api/interfaces/sdkmodelexamplevalue/), TCGC helps map the example type to the correct subtype for discriminated types and separates additional property values from property values. However, for models with inheritance, TCGC does not break down the type graph but instead places all example values in the child model.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Readonly on model\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Readonly on model\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Readonly on model\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have such swagger\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  readonly: true,\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {}\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"AnotherModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  properties: {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      $ref: \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWhen the type of property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\" in another model is that \\\\\\\"ReadonlyOnModel\\\\\\\", M4 will give a readonly on that property \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\". I want to confirm if the equivalent TypeSpec should be\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel AnotherModel {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  a: ReadonlyOnModel;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadonlyOnModel {}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ncc Alitzel Mendez : Common type replacement relates to this. I remember we have several models in the original common type have readonly on them and you removed these because TypeSpec cannot represent readonly on model. Then if any service refers to this model, those properties might need to be updated.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec can only attach readOnly to properties, not to models or scalars.  Functionally (assuming all references to ReadOnlyModel are through readOnly properties),  these Swagger docs are equivalent, see: [autorest/docs/openapi/howto/$ref-siblings.md at main \\u00b7 Azure/autorest](https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/openapi/howto/%24ref-siblings.md) from the perspective of both TypeSpec and autorest, these descriptions are equivalent.\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"You do NOT need to explicitly add a visibility filter or use @withVisibilityFilter/@withVisibility decorators to restrict properties to 'Read' visibility when a model is only used as the return result of an operation. TypeSpec's standard emitters (such as OpenAPI and HTTP) automatically apply Lifecycle visibility based on the context in which the model is used. Specifically, when a model is used as the response type of an operation (e.g., for GET), only properties marked with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) will be included in the emitted schema. This is implicit and handled by the emitter, so you should simply annotate your model properties with the appropriate @visibility decorators, and the correct shape will be emitted for each operation context.\\n\\nFor example:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel Example {\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\n  id: string;\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Create, Lifecycle.Read)\\n  name: string;\\n  description: string;\\n}\\n\\n@route(\\\"/example\\\")\\ninterface Examples {\\n  @get read(@path id: string): Example;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIn this case, the OpenAPI emitter will automatically generate a response schema for GET that only includes properties with Lifecycle.Read visibility. You only need to use @withVisibilityFilter or related templates if you want to create custom views or models outside of the standard operation context.\", \"ground_truth\": \"ou do not need to explicitly add a visibilityFilter or use @withVisibility(Lifecycle.Read) if your model is only used as the return result of an operation. TypeSpec's HTTP library and standard emitters automatically apply Lifecycle.Read visibility to properties when a model is used as a return type. By default, properties are included in the response if they have Lifecycle.Read visibility, and all properties have all visibilities enabled unless you restrict them with @visibility.\\nTherefore, unless you have properties with more restrictive visibilities, all properties will be included in the response by default. If you want to limit which properties are returned, you should annotate those properties with @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) or other appropriate modifiers, but you do not need to explicitly use a visibilityFilter just because a model is a response type.\\nIf you use the built-in Lifecycle visibility model as intended, the behavior you expect is implicit and handled automatically for response models.\"}"}]

actual.answer:
1. **Model Validation Error (Additional Properties Not Allowed):**

The error about additional properties (groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState, privateEndpoint, provisioningState) not being allowed typically occurs when your TypeSpec model does not correctly inherit from the common-types resource definition. For PrivateEndpointConnection, you should use the Azure template provided in `Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes` or `Azure.ResourceManager.PrivateEndpointConnectionResource` to ensure your model matches the expected schema and passes validation.

**Best Practice:**
- You can retain the name `PrivateEndpointConnection` in your namespace; the name itself does not affect validation as long as the model structure matches the common-types definition.
- Some RPs rename the model for clarity or to avoid naming conflicts, but this is optional and not required for validation. The reviewer may guide you based on naming conventions, but structurally, you should inherit from the correct template.

**Recommended TypeSpec Example:**
```typespec
import "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager";

namespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;

model PrivateEndpointConnection is Azure.ResourceManager.PrivateEndpointConnectionResource {}
```
This ensures your model includes all required properties and matches the common-types schema.

2. **Avocado Error (Removed API):**

When you remove an API (e.g., `revokeCertificate`) and add a new one (`revokeCertificates`), Avocado will report this as a breaking change. If you do not need to support the older preview API, you can remove it entirely. If you must keep the older API for backward compatibility, you should suppress the Avocado error following the suppression guide:
- See [Avocado known issues](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues)
- See [CI fix guide](https://aka.ms/ci-fix) for suppression instructions

**Summary:**
- Use the Azure common-types template for PrivateEndpointConnection and do not worry about renaming unless you have a naming conflict.
- Fix the model validation by inheriting from the correct resource type.
- For Avocado errors due to removed APIs, either remove the old API if not needed or suppress the error if you intentionally removed it.

This approach follows Azure TypeSpec and ARM guidelines and ensures your spec passes validation and review.

model?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to create an Example for a typespec model?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_07.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to create an Example for a typespec model?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI was going through my Typespec file and adding @example() decorators on top of models but then I was informed by Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot that Azure API Spec doesn't support the @example() decorator? Instead I'm supposed to create .json files in the examples folder and link it by operaiton id. However, models don't have operation ids? or do they?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nHere is some documentation on generating required examples: [x-ms-examples example files | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/x-ms-examples/).  \\\\r\\\\nNote that the examples that are required for specs at this point are operation examples (which include examples of model serialization in the operations that include those models).  The workflow is:\\\\r\\\\nDesign your API in TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\nGenerate an OpenApi doc by compiling your spec\\\\r\\\\nRun oav to generate examples for each of the operations (oav generates syntactically valid examples with the 'operationId'  and 'title' fields filled in)\\\\r\\\\nGo through the examples, replace values to make the examples more useful as documentation, and feel free to add  any examples for important scenarios that might be difficult to understand otherwise, or remove redundant examples (although you will need at least one per operation)\\\\r\\\\nCopy the examples into the `examples/\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/` folder inside your typespec directory and the OpenApi emitter will automatically associate the examples with  the appropriate operatiosn through the 'operationId' in the example file,  using the 'title' field as the title of the example.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nendpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n2. Avocado error: I have removed an API revokeCertificate and added a new api revokeCertificates which takes an array. \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nHow do I fix both errors?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n [Added private endpoint connection, bulk revocation and c2pa certificate type by amritas \\u00b7 Pull Requ\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24553)\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nModel validation Error - Additional properties not allowed: groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState,privateEndpoint,provisioningState\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nPEC contract - \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Private endpoint connection resource.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection\\\\r\\\\n    is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations(PrivateEndpointConnection)\\\\r\\\\ninterface PrivateEndpointConnections {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Get a specific private connection */\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\n\\\\nlistPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\r\\\\nThis will then get consumed by teams authoring Azure APIs. As such, they have the Azure linting in place (naming conventions and whatnot).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe wanted to know whether definitions can also come with suppressions (not inline, as this definition is auto-importer on a regular basis), which would apply ONLY to the definitions we share, not to the rest of the consumer's project?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nThanks!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nsuppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\\\\n\\\\noperations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cEmployee, EmployeeProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  getPrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.Read\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  updatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  deletePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.DeleteAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\n\\\\nI have the below PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) where some of the LintDiff validations are failing with the exception \\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\n  Violation: file:///home/runner/work/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/after/specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/stable/2025-08-15/Limit.json:578\\\\r\\\\n    Level: error\\\\r\\\\n    Code: RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel\\\\r\\\\n    Message: Model definition 'SharingDetail' must have the properties 'name', 'id' and 'type' in its hierarchy and these properties must be marked as readonly.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis particular model is defined as follows - \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel SharingDetail {\\\\r\\\\n  role: SharingRole;\\\\r\\\\n  sharedLimits?: QuotaLimitProperties[];\\\\r\\\\n  guestSubscriptions?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  host?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nIs it possible have a suppression for this validation? If so, how?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nthe link for lintdiff suppressions:\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nyou probably want to fix this in your spec, not suppress the error\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nYou need to fix check \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Validation\\\\\\\" in your PR, before other check results will even be valid.  This is documented in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Model validations are failing although am referring from common-types\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\n1. I have reused the model Private endpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\n\\\\nis ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateLink is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateLinkResourceProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...PrivateLinkResourceParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n updated the operationId and it worked. Let me know if the PrivateEndpointConnection should be a customized name or can retain same name as in commonTypes?\\\\r\\\\n Would this be guided by the reviewer?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nLooking at your PR, it seems that the avocado error is the only remaining one - this is just reporting that you have removed an API.  If you do not need to continue supporting the older preview, you might consider removing it,  otherwise, this is an error you can safely suppress (https://aka.ms/ci-fix is a great link to remember, as it has links to all kinds of useful info about ci errors, including a link to the suppression guides).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nFor PrivateEndpointConnections, RPs have done both, as the name of the private endpoint connection type doesn't really matter to the API, however, there is a new template that greatly simplifies adding private endpoint connection operations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM-Decorators-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec ARM Decorator Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec ARM Decorator Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 21. @tenantResource\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n# TypeSpec-ARM-Decorators-Documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec ARM Decorator Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n\\\\n## 21. @tenantResource\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\n`@tenantResource` marks an Azure Resource Manager resource model as a Tenant resource/Root resource/Top-Level resource. Tenant resources have REST API paths like: `/provider/Microsoft.Contoso/FooResources`\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n              \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/privatelinks.json#/definitions/PrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n              \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": extends ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  @key\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"myTenantResources\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n**Swagger Output:**\\\\r\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"swagger\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"info\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"host\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"management.azure.com\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"produces\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n \\\\\\\"implicit\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"authorizationUrl\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/authorize\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"scopes\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"user_impersonation\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"impersonate your user account\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"tags\\\\\\\": [],\\\\r\\\\n SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n# Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n\\\\n1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.\\\\r\\\\n2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.\\\\r\\\\n3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.\\\\r\\\\n   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Generating basic examples and then manually modify the values. It will generate two examples for each operation:\\\\r\\\\n    one contains minimal properties set, the other contains the maximal properties set. Since the auto-generated\\\\r\\\\n     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n       oav generate-examples openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. However, if you are generating the examples manually,\\\\r\\\\n     please ensure you have:\\\\r\\\\n    - include `title` field and make sure it is descriptive and unique for each operation.\\\\r\\\\n    - include `operationId`. This is used to match with declared operations in TypeSpec and correctly output in OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\n4. Add/update the `readme.md` file in the `{service}` folder to specify the version and location of the OpenAPI files. testcase: Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR

expected.answer: Part of the typespec conversion is replacing the existing swagger with a generated swagger.  The generated swagger is still used for some purposes, and Avocado protects the ability to process it. The generated swagger needs to be equivalent, but not necessarily identical.  Generally these issues reflected in the swagger will also show up in breaking change checks, which will have to be resolved (or suppressed if they are false positives)

Suppress validation failures on a PR
Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR
Suppress validation failures on a PR

actual.answer: For a TypeSpec conversion PR that does not update the OpenAPI spec, the Avocado 'missing APIs in default tag' check is triggered because the generated swagger is compared against previous releases to ensure API equivalence. During TypeSpec conversion, the generated swagger should be functionally equivalent, but not necessarily identical, to the previous swagger. If the missing APIs error is a false positive (i.e., the APIs are present but Avocado fails to detect them due to conversion artifacts), you can suppress this check for your PR by adding the 'Approved-Avocado' label. This is the recommended approach for TypeSpec conversion PRs where no actual API changes are made, and the error is due to tooling limitations rather than a real API gap. However, you should still review the generated swagger to confirm that no APIs are actually missing and that the conversion is accurate.

suppressions for it, if any.\\\\n\\\\n## Valid suppression reasons\\\\n\\\\n### Valid reasons\\\\n\\\\nYou can request suppression of validation errors if one or more of the following scenarios matches your case;\\\\r\\\\n1. Your service design forces this behavior\\\\r\\\\n   (and it's actually the correct behavior that doesn't violate Microsoft API guidelines).\\\\r\\\\n2. Specific validation rules do not apply to your service\\\\r\\\\n   (e.g. ARM specific API validation rules may not apply to data plane API validation).\\\\r\\\\n3. You are blocked on resolving this issue by external teams\\\\r\\\\n   (e.g. ARM feature that would need to be let up for you to become green).\\\\r\\\\n4. If you believe that the validation is a false positive (incorrect failure due to a bug in the tool).\\\\r\\\\n5. If you service is RPaaS service and you're blocked by a new validation rule.\\\\n\\\\n### Invalid reasons\\\\n\\\\nIf you are trying to suppress failures that do not fall under one of the valid cases enumerated\\\\r\\\\nin previous section, and the following applies to your case, then suppression will **not** be approved:\\\\r\\\\n1. You can't resolve the violations at the moment due to time constraints and planning to do it in the future.\\\\r\\\\n2. The violation reported applies to your case and is not a false positive.\\\\r\\\\n3. The produced TypeSpec relies on the Azure.Core and Azure.Resource.Manager libraries.\\\\r\\\\nFor detailed instructions on how to use the conversion tool, refer to the full [documentation](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/01-get-started/).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e The conversion tool will not handle all scenarios - some manual conversion work may be required.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | \\\\r\\\\n| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |\\\\r\\\\n| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |\\\\r\\\\n| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | \\\\r\\\\n| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |\\\\r\\\\n| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |\\\\r\\\\n| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | \\\\r\\\\n| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nFor PR [Add Microsoft.Mission version 2025-05-01-preview - Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581) I was asked to consider renaming routes for some custom actions to meet naming conventions. For example, I now have this in my routes:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Community Endpoint Interface\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface CommunityEndpoints {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"Callback that triggers on approval state change.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @armResourceAction(CommunityEndpointResource)\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_12_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(\\\\r\\\\n    Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2025_05_01_preview,\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"approvalCallback\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  )\\\\r\\\\n  notifyOnApprovalCreation is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    CommunityEndpointResource,\\\\r\\\\n    ApprovalCallbackRequest,\\\\r\\\\n    ApprovalActionResponse\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis unfortunately now produces Avocado errors for [MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/blob/master/README.md#MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG) , \\\\r\\\\nThe default tag should contain all APIs. The API path \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/subscriptions/{}/resourcegroups/{}/providers/microsoft.mission/virtualenclaves/{}/enclaveendpoints/{}/approvalcallback\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nis not in the default tag. Please make sure the missing API swaggers are in the default tag.\\\\r\\\\nreadme: [specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\njson: [Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json)\\\\r\\\\nIs there something that I need to do differently to define this route renaming? \\\\r\\\\nLink to [Avocado check](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581/checks?check_run_id=45066798540). Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nAvocado doesn't handle moves/renames.  You can suppress by adding label `Approved-Avocado`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nPR: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346\\\\r\\\\nAvocado check: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44368323389 \\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to suppress the missing APIs check only for this PR since it only has typspec conversion but no update to the open API spec?\\\\r\\\\nThe check is trying to compare the APIs with previous stable release with currently published stable release.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nPart of the typespec conversion is replacing the existing swagger with a generated swagger.  The generated swagger is still used for some purposes, and Avocado protects the ability to process it. The generated swagger needs to be equivalent, but not necessarily identical.
