Please update the value of \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.module\\\\\\\" to match \\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{service-dir}/{package-dir}\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.fix-const-stuttering\\\\\\\". Please add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.fix-const-stuttering\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-samples\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\ntypeSpec validation is failing, but not for that reason.  The configuration for c-sharp emitter is a warning only.  The current failure is caused by diffs between the generated swagger included in your PR and the generated swagger when the ci compiles your spec. \\\\r\\\\nUsually this indicates that your local dependencies are out of date, and you need to pull the latest into your local branch and re-install at thetop level: \\\\r\\\\ngit fetch upstream main\\\\r\\\\ngit pull upstream main\\\\r\\\\nnpm ci\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nRunning Locally\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nTo ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and tsv on your local machine:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1.Merge latest from parent (e.g. main or RPSaaSMaster) to your PR branch\\\\r\\\\n2.Run locally\\\\r\\\\ngit clean -xdf (may revert any local changes)\\\\r\\\\ngit pull\\\\r\\\\nnpm ci\\\\r\\\\nnpx tsv specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management\\\\r\\\\ngit status\\\\r\\\\nIf any changes, git add, git commit, git push to update your PR.\\\\r\\\\n3.If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.\\\\r\\\\n4.If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the TypeSpec Discussion teams channel.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nCI has been failing constantly for our PR ([Azure Load Testing\\\\\\\\] Add 2025-03-01-preview Data-Plane APIs by Harshan01 \\u00b7 Pull Request #32585 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32585)) for Typespec Validation step. The logs show that we are missing the Go SDK configuration and I am able to produce this error locally as well. However, our service doesnt have a Go SDK and we are not planning to put it in scope right now. This check has suddenly started failing for our PRs, what should we do?\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExecuting rule\\uff1aSdkTspConfigVa1idation\\\\r\\\\n[SdkTspconfigVa1idation]\\uff1avalidation failed\\uff0e\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans\\u201c\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans.\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add\\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\nPlease See https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info\\uff0e\\\\r\\\\nFor additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nSuppressing go specific rules worked for me (locally, checking CI now). Thanks Mike. Also FYI Darren Cohen. Here's our suppression file:\\\\r\\\\n```yml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Suppress validation for a Go emitter options\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\r\\\\n  reason: 'Azure Load Testing does not support a Go SDK currently'\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nLet me know if I can help with anything!\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nPR: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346\\\\r\\\\nAvocado check: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44368323389 \\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to suppress the missing APIs check only for this PR since it only has typspec conversion but no update to the open API spec?\\\\r\\\\nThe check is trying to compare the APIs with previous stable release with currently published stable release.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nPart of the typespec conversion is replacing the existing swagger with a generated swagger.  The generated swagger is still used for some purposes, and Avocado protects the ability to process it. The generated swagger needs to be equivalent, but not necessarily identical.  Generally these issues reflected in the swagger will also show up in breaking change checks, which will have to be resolved (or suppressed if they are false positives)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Looking for examples on running TypeSpec in ADO Pipelines\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Looking for examples on running TypeSpec in ADO Pipelines\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\\n\\\\n# Looking for examples on running TypeSpec in ADO Pipelines\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe're looking to work in ADO internally before promoting swagger to github - is there any examples of teams using the TypeSpec method for swagger internally vai ADO pipelines?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nhttps://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/rest-api-publish/buildpipelines/#_top\\\\r\\\\nbut this is only about typespec itself. If you plan to merge in the spec repo later there is many additional validations that will not be verified this way\\\\r\\\\nA large set of them are available to install and run locally: [azure-rest-api-specs/documentation/SwaggerValidationTools.md at master \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/master/documentation/SwaggerValidationTools.md):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThere are some tools that can help you make sure your specifications conform to the accepted guidelines. Better upfront validation before the final pull request is sent will result in quicker turnaround time.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nValidation tools available locally\\\\r\\\\nThe various tools mentioned above are also available for local download.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nInstall Node.js (7.10.0 or greater)\\\\r\\\\nLinter Validator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g autorest`\\\\r\\\\n -  `autoRest \\\\u003cpath to readme.md\\\\u003e --azure-validator=true`\\\\r\\\\nStatic Validator (Semantic):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g oav`\\\\r\\\\n - `bash-3.2$ oav validate-spec \\\\u003cspec-path\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\nStatic Validator (Model):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g oav`\\\\r\\\\n - `bash-3.2$ oav validate-example \\\\u003cspec-path\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\nSwagger diff tool\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n - `npm install -g oad@0.1.7`\\\\r\\\\n - `bash-3.2$ oad compare \\\\u003cold-spec\\\\u003e \\\\u003cnew-spec\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec validation tool (tsv) is also available locally, but for now it's only available in the azure-rest-api-specs repo and the package is not published. You can clone the repo and run it from there, though it assumes everything is run from within that repo, so it may have issues elsewhere.\\\\r\\\\nThe current focus for engineering system improvements is the azure-rest-api-specs repo itself. You can use draft PRs to validate work in progress, and some of the checks can be run locally\\u2014with varying levels of usability.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger breaking change\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger breaking change\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger breaking change\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nPR check run: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44501918225\\\\r\\\\nMy typespec conversion PR is failing in swagger breaking change check with the following error: \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"new\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/a1ac3f6f98bb1ea3583b765d00dfceab6d85654f/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"old\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"details\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"incompatible properties : tags\\\\\\\\n definitions/TrackedResource/properties/tags\\\\\\\\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#L489:8\\\\\\\\n definitions/Resource/properties/tags\\\\\\\\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json#L12397:8\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nThis PR is just having typespec conversion change and I am avoiding any change to the swagger file that is generated as part of typespec conversion. In the old swagger there is a Resource definitionwhich is similar Azure resource definition. Should I suppress this check and how to do it?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThis occurs because in your original swagger, you did not use swagger common-types. \\\\r\\\\nThe 'tags' definitions are compatible, so there is no change in the actual api from this.  This could result in changes in some management sdks, although this change to using the common resource types has generally been accepted. \\\\r\\\\ndocs on suppressions for false positives are here: [Suppress validation failures on a PR](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions) \\\\r\\\\nNote that it is important to go through these violations, as the conversion is not guaranteed to be 100% accurate.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n[Pull Request #21772](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/21772) is currently failing TypeSpec validation because data-plane contains the Swagger for an older preview not specified in main.tsp.  The guidance I got from API board a month ago is that main.tsp should only list the latest preview. API version  But doing so triggered this error. \\\\r\\\\nShould this be an error?  Or can we make this into a warning instead?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should only track the latest preview version in your TypeSpec files.\\\\r\\\\nIf there are older preview Swagger files still in the repo, they can remain there for the required 90-day deprecation window, even if they're no longer listed in your .tsp files.\\\\r\\\\nWhile TypeSpec validation currently throws an error if Swagger files exist without a matching version in TypeSpec, you can suppress this error by adding an entry to suppressions.yaml in your service's spec folder (not the global one).\\\\r\\\\nLonger-term, the goal is to eliminate swagger files entirely, but for now, swagger and TypeSpec coexist. So:\\\\r\\\\nKeep only the latest preview in .tsp\\\\r\\\\nKeep older generated swagger for 90 days\\\\r\\\\nAdd suppressions if needed to prevent TypeSpec validation from failing\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"For a TypeSpec conversion PR that does not update the OpenAPI spec, the Avocado 'missing APIs in default tag' check is triggered because the generated swagger is compared against previous releases to ensure API equivalence. During TypeSpec conversion, the generated swagger should be functionally equivalent, but not necessarily identical, to the previous swagger. If the missing APIs error is a false positive (i.e., the APIs are present but Avocado fails to detect them due to conversion artifacts), you can suppress this check for your PR by adding the 'Approved-Avocado' label. This is the recommended approach for TypeSpec conversion PRs where no actual API changes are made, and the error is due to tooling limitations rather than a real API gap. However, you should still review the generated swagger to confirm that no APIs are actually missing and that the conversion is accurate.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Part of the typespec conversion is replacing the existing swagger with a generated swagger.  The generated swagger is still used for some purposes, and Avocado protects the ability to process it. The generated swagger needs to be equivalent, but not necessarily identical.  Generally these issues reflected in the swagger will also show up in breaking change checks, which will have to be resolved (or suppressed if they are false positives)\"}"}]

expected.answer: we generally suggest that PATCH requests over discriminated types should require the discriminator property.  This may result in some lintdiff violations, but that is expected, and those cna be suppressed.  This is especially true if, as most services, your PATCH operation would need the discriminator value on the wire to determine how to apply the PATCH request to the existing reosurce.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: ArmResourcePatchAsync & discriminator\\n\\nquestion: I was trying to figure out the best way to allow an update for a Host resource. I tried ArmResourcePatchAsync, but the resource has a discriminator. oav fails with OBJECT_MISSING_REQUIRED_PROPERTY_DEFINITION .  [Windows Server AHB for VMware via PATCH by cataggar \\u00b7 Pull Request #25538 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-sp\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25538)\", \"response\": \"The best practice for implementing an update (PATCH) operation for a resource with a discriminator (polymorphic resource) in Azure ARM TypeSpec is to use the legacy discriminated resource models provided by the Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy library. Specifically, you should define your Host resource using `DiscriminatedTrackedResource` (for tracked resources) or `DiscriminatedProxyResource` (for proxy resources), which automatically include the required discriminator property (usually `kind`) and ensure the OpenAPI output is correct.\\n\\nWhen using `ArmResourcePatchAsync` for a discriminated resource, you must ensure that the PATCH request body includes the required discriminator property definition. If you use a plain model with a discriminator, the PATCH schema may omit the required property, causing OAV to fail with `OBJECT_MISSING_REQUIRED_PROPERTY_DEFINITION`.\\n\\nHere is the recommended TypeSpec pattern:\\n\\n```typespec\\nimport \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager\\\";\\n\\nmodel Host is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.DiscriminatedTrackedResource {\\n  // Add resource-specific properties here\\n  properties: HostProperties;\\n}\\n\\nmodel HostProperties {\\n  // Host-specific properties\\n  ...\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Hosts {\\n  get is ArmResourceRead<Host>;\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync<Host>;\\n  update is ArmResourcePatchAsync<Host, HostProperties>;\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync<Host>;\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent<Host>;\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Host>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis approach ensures that the PATCH schema includes the discriminator property (e.g., `kind`) as required, and OAV will not fail with missing required property errors. If you need to further customize the PATCH request body, use `ArmCustomPatchAsync` and ensure the custom patch model includes the discriminator property.\\n\\n**Key points:**\\n- Always use the legacy discriminated resource models for polymorphic ARM resources.\\n- The PATCH operation must include the discriminator property in the request body schema.\\n- Do not use a plain model with just `@discriminator` for ARM resources; use the provided legacy types.\\n\\nThis pattern is fully compliant with Azure ARM and OpenAPI guidelines for PATCH operations on polymorphic resources.\", \"ground_truth\": \"we generally suggest that PATCH requests over discriminated types should require the discriminator property.  This may result in some lintdiff violations, but that is expected, and those cna be suppressed.  This is especially true if, as most services, your PATCH operation would need the discriminator value on the wire to determine how to apply the PATCH request to the existing reosurce.\"}"}]

Specifically, you should define your Host resource using `DiscriminatedTrackedResource` (for tracked resources) or `DiscriminatedProxyResource` (for proxy resources), which automatically include the required discriminator property (usually `kind`) and ensure the OpenAPI output is correct.\\n\\nWhen using `ArmResourcePatchAsync` for a discriminated resource, you must ensure that the PATCH request body includes the required discriminator property definition. If you need to further customize the PATCH request body, use `ArmCustomPatchAsync` and ensure the custom patch model includes the discriminator property.\\n\\n**Key points:**\\n- Always use the legacy discriminated resource models for polymorphic ARM resources.\\n- The PATCH operation must include the discriminator property in the request body schema.\\n- Do not use a plain model with just `@discriminator` for ARM resources; use the provided legacy types.\\n\\nThis pattern is fully compliant with Azure ARM and OpenAPI guidelines for PATCH operations on polymorphic resources.\", \"context\": \"[{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Converting Synchronous Operations to LROs\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Converting Synchronous Operations to LROs\\\\n\\\\nYou can generally choose an asynchronous operation template that matches your operation.\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PUT Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains a `Location` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains an `Azure-AsyncOperation` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PATCH Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmTagsPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that only allows changing the resource tags (the minimum for Azure Resource Manager).\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmTagsPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourcePatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that uses the visibility settings to select properties for the PATCH request body (any property with no visibility setting, or including visibility \\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\"). It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation.\\\\n\\\\nthe `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation. It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuff is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no request body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffNoRequest is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, void, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no response body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffCommand is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, void\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async DELETE Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, will return a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, and returns a `200` response in the case of a successful synchronous delete, a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"ARM Resource Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n### Resource Update Operations (PATCH)\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n\\\\n### Resource Update Operations (PATCH)\\\\n\\\\nARM Requires that all `Tracked` resources implement PATCH for ARM tags, which are contained in the\\\\r\\\\nenvelope of every `TrackedResource`. ARM recommends that you also allow PATCH of other envelope\\\\r\\\\nproperties and resource-specific properties. Unless marked with a specific visibility, any property\\\\r\\\\nin your rp-specific properties will be automatically included in the PATCH schema.\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec Provides both Synchronous and Asynchronous PATCH Operations, and allows you to specify a\\\\r\\\\nPATCH for Resource tags only, a PATCH for all updateable properties, or a custom patch. Generally,\\\\r\\\\nyou should choose the patch for all updateable properties, unless you have a very good reason for\\\\r\\\\nchoosing another PATCH operation.\\\\r\\\\n| Operation Description      | TypeSpec                                                                                                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| Sync TagsOnly PATCH        | `update is ArmTagsPatchSync\\\\u003cResourceType\\\\u003e`                                                                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| Async TagsOnly PATCH       | `update is ArmTagsPatchAsync\\\\u003cResourceType\\\\u003e`                                                                                                |\\\\r\\\\n| Sync All Properties PATCH  | `update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e`  |\\\\r\\\\n| Async All Properties PATCH | `update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e` |\\\\r\\\\nThe ArmResourcePatch\\\\\\\\* templates take the resource type and the resource properties type as\\\\r\\\\nparameters. The ArmTagsPatch\\\\\\\\* templates take the resource type as a parameter. The ArmCustomPatch\\\\\\\\*\\\\n\\\\nArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e`  |\\\\r\\\\n| Async All Properties PATCH | `update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResourceType, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cResourceType, ResourcePropertiesType\\\\u003e\\\\u003e` |\\\\r\\\\nThe ArmResourcePatch\\\\\\\\* templates take the resource type and the resource properties type as\\\\r\\\\nparameters. You can use augment decorators to customize these parameter names and other parts of the operation signature.\\\\r\\\\nThe following sections show how to do this for each operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### CreateOrUpdate (PUT) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a PUT operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `resource`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.createOrUpdate::parameters.resource, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any PUT operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### Update (PATCH) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a PATCH operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cWidget, WidgetProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `properties`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.update::parameters.properties, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any PATCH operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### Action (POST) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a POST operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  mungeWidget is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cWidget, MungeRequest, MungeResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `body`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.mungeWidget::parameters.body, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any POST operation template.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"We cannot customize the Type for How could I represent this operation in TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n/** Employee move response */\\\\r\\\\nmodel MoveResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the move */\\\\r\\\\n  movingStatus: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\ninterface Operations extends Azure.ResourceManager.Operations {}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** long-running get statistics */\\\\r\\\\n  getStatistics is ArmProviderActionAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    void,\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      ...OkResponse;\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    SubscriptionActionScope\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nBut, in this case, this looks like they are modeling a subscription-level operationResult resource, which should just be modeled as a resource operation get that is not long-running.\\\\n\\\\nlong-running GET is not allowed in ARM, or in Azure at all. Operations\\\\n## JSON Merge-Patch\\\\n### The MergePatch Transform\\\\n# libraries#http#operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# Operations\\\\n\\\\n## JSON Merge-Patch\\\\n\\\\n### The MergePatch Transform\\\\n\\\\nGeneralizing these rules creates a type transform of the resource Model into a Model defining the corresponding Patch request body. The properties of a resource define the allowed properties and their types in a Patch request body for that resource as follows:\\\\r\\\\n- The `type` of a property indicates the allowed type of the corresponding property in a Patch request.\\\\r\\\\n- `Required` properties without a default value are _optional_ in a Patch request, but if present, the value cannot be null.\\\\r\\\\n- `Optional` properties are _optional_ in a Patch request, and, if present, can contain any valid value or null.\\\\r\\\\n- Properties with a default value are _optional_ in a Patch request, but have no default value in the request body. If present, they can contain any valid value or null. A _null_ value will not erase the property, but set it back to its default value.\\\\r\\\\n- `Model` and `Record` typed properties, when present in a Patch request are merged with the existing resource value in accordance with the merge-patch algorithm: this transformation is recursively applied to these values.\\\\r\\\\n- `Array` typed properties, when present in a Patch request replace the existing resource value in accordance with the merge-patch algorithm. This transformation is _not_ recursively applied to these values.\\\\r\\\\n- Properties required to deserialize a request (for example, discriminators) are _required_ in a Patch request body.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"rename duplicated model Additional parameters after the path parameters |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\\\\n\\\\nhere's a Reference\\\\n# v1.0#resource-api-reference.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resource API Reference\\\\n\\\\nThese are the APIs that are implemented by resource providers (a.k.a. RPs) when exposing resource types through Azure Resource Manager (a.k.a ARM). This section is divided into further sub sections for easy reading as follows.\\\\r\\\\n- [Uri format and arguments for CRUD APIs on Resources](./uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Put Resource](./put-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Patch Resource](./patch-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Delete Resource](./delete-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Get Resource](./get-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Pagination](./pagination.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [Move Resource](./move-resource.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003eNOTE: Each of these pages has an `Overview` and a `Rules` section. The `Overview` section provides general information about the topic. The `Rules` section enumerates a list of granular rules that service owners should implement. Each rule has an RPC guideline code, Title, Conformance level, Additional impact and a link to the linter rule if the ruleis automated. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `RPC guideline code` column has values in the format `RPC-{Category}-V1-{serialNumber}`. This code will used for various reporting and tracking purposes.  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Title` column describes the rule.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Conformance level` column has one of the following values - [Required | Recommended | Allowed]. All `Required` rules are enforced using automated linter rules and **must** be adhered to. Violating these rules results in **errors** to be flagged by the automated checks and blocks the OpenAPI spec PRs from getting approved. All `Recommended` rules are strong suggestions, some of which are also automated using linter rules. Violating these rules results in **warnings** to be flagged by the automated checks. All `Allowed` rules simply specify what a service team is allowed to do.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Additional impact` column describes any additional impact the specific rule has on APIs that violate the rule over and above the general impact described for the section.\\\\n\\\\nand blocks the OpenAPI spec PRs from getting approved. All `Recommended` rules are strong suggestions, some of which are also automated using linter rules. Violating these rules results in **warnings** to be flagged by the automated checks. All `Allowed` rules simply specify what a service team is allowed to do.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Additional impact` column describes any additional impact the specific rule has on APIs that violate the rule over and above the general impact described for the section.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Applicabale scope` column describes the scope to which the specific rule applies to. It has one of the following values [ Design | Runtime ]. The value `Design` means that the rule applies to the API design. This means that the rule will be in scope starting from the API design reviews and will most likely also be covered by linter rules. All rules that are in scope for the design phase automatically imply that the runtime will also adhere to it. The value `Runtime` means that the rule applies exclusivley to the runtime implementation of the API. Such a rule cannot be enforced at design time as it refers to something that the actual service runtime is expected to adhere to.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e+ The `Linter rule` column points to the documentation for the error received when this rule is violated in your OpenAPI specification.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"libraries#azure-resource-manager#reference#interfaces.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Interfaces and Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-resource-manager/reference/interfaces\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Interfaces and Operations\\\\n## Azure.ResourceManager\\\\n### `ArmResourcePatchAsync` {#Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResourcePatchAsync}\\\\n# libraries#azure-resource-manager#reference#interfaces.md\\\\n\\\\n# Interfaces and Operations\\\\n\\\\n## Azure.ResourceManager\\\\n\\\\n### `ArmResourcePatchAsync` {#Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResourcePatchAsync}\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nop Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResourcePatchAsync(provider: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.ThisWillBeReplaced\\\\\\\", properties: Resource): Azure.ResourceManager.ArmResponse\\\\u003cResponseBody\\\\u003e | Azure.ResourceManager.ArmAcceptedLroResponse\\\\u003cDescription, LroHeaders\\\\u003e | Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Template Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name           | Description                                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| Resource       | the resource being patched                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| Properties     | The model type of the resource properties                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| BaseParameters | Optional. Allows overriding the operation parameters                          |\\\\r\\\\n| LroHeaders     | Optional. Allows overriding the lro headers returned in the Accepted response |\\\\r\\\\n| Parameters     | Optional. Additional parameters after the path parameters                     |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM.Legacy-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 3. DiscriminatedExtensionResource\\\\n### Description\\\\n# TypeSpec-ARM.Legacy-Models-Documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n\\\\n## 3. DiscriminatedExtensionResource\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\nPolymorphic extension resources can be instantiated using this type, using 'kind' as the discriminator property. This is a legacy model that generates a ProxyResource with a discriminator field.\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n```typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel PetExtension is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.DiscriminatedExtensionResource {\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"petName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"pets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n### Swagger Output\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"PetExtension\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Polymorphic extension resource types can be created by aliasing this type using a specific property type.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Metadata used by portal/tooling/etc to render different UX experiences for resources of the same type; e.g. ApiApps are a kind of Microsoft.Web/sites type.  If supported, the resource provider must validate and persist this value.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"pattern\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"^[-\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\w\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\._,\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\)]+$\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"x-ms-mutability\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"read\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"create\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        ]\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"discriminator\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    ],\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"allOf\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v5/types.json#/definitions/ProxyResource\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    ]\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM.Legacy-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 4. DiscriminatedProxyResource\\\\n### Description\\\\n# TypeSpec-ARM.Legacy-Models-Documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy Models Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n\\\\n## 4. DiscriminatedProxyResource\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\nDiscriminated proxy resource types can be created by instantiating using this type, with 'kind' as the discriminator property. This legacy model generates a ProxyResource with a discriminator field.\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Example\\\\n\\\\n```typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel VehicleProxy is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.DiscriminatedProxyResource {\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"vehicleName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"vehicles\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n### Swagger Output\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"VehicleProxy\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Polymorphic proxy resource types can be created by instantiating this type, using 'kind' as the discriminator property.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Metadata used by portal/tooling/etc to render different UX experiences for resources of the same type; e.g. ApiApps are a kind of Microsoft.Web/sites type.  If supported, the resource provider must validate and persist this value.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"pattern\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"^[-\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\w\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\._,\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\(\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\)]+$\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"x-ms-mutability\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"read\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"create\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        ]\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"discriminator\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    ],\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"allOf\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v5/types.json#/definitions/ProxyResource\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    ]\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#patch-resource.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Patch Resource #\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/patch-resource.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Patch Resource #\\\\n## Rules ##\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n# v1.0#patch-resource.md\\\\n\\\\n# Patch Resource #\\\\n\\\\n## Rules ##\\\\n\\\\n### General impact of violating the rules ###\\\\n\\\\nProviding support for `Patch` for as many properties as possible helps avoid accidental and unintentional updates to other properties that need not be touched. Only the property set that really needs an update are specified in a `Patch` payload thereby limiting the surface area of any potential impact. Violating these rules result in APIs across Azure becoming inconsistent with each other. Such inconsistencies degrade customer experience as they now have to deal with slightly different behaviors while interacting with each Resource Provider. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cbr\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n| RPC Guideline code | Title | Conformance level | Additional impact |  Applicable scope | Linter rule |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-01 | The request body **must** contain at least one or more properties. These properties must always be present in the request and response bodies of the corresponding put operation for same resource type. | Required | Not specifying any properties in the request body for a `Patch` operation serves no purpose for your customers. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-properties-correspond-to-put-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-02 | A `Patch` operation must not update the `id`, `name`, `type`, `location`, or `properties.provisioningState` of the resource and so these properties must not be marked as updatable in the request body of the `Patch` operation. | Required | These properties are deemed either readOnly or immutable and therefore not updatable. These properties may be defined in the request body of the `Patch` operation and if so, they **must** be marked as readOnly or immutable as appropriate. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/un-supported-patch-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-03 | Every **Tracked** resource type **must** support a **Patch** operation for the `tags` property. | Required |\\\\n\\\\nare deemed either readOnly or immutable and therefore not updatable. These properties may be defined in the request body of the `Patch` operation and if so, they **must** be marked as readOnly or immutable as appropriate. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/un-supported-patch-properties.md) | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-03 | Every **Tracked** resource type **must** support a **Patch** operation for the `tags` property. | Required | ARM exposes a centralized API to customers that allow them to update the `tags` property for any tracked resource. The implementation in ARM relies on the existence of a `Patch` operation is the Resource provider service to accomplish this. So not having a `Patch` operation for the `tags` property breaks this platform feature for customers. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/tracked-resource-patch-operation.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-04 | When Tags are patched, the tags from the request replace all existing tags for the resource | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-05 | When patching fields inside the properties envelope, Resource providers **must** follow JSON merge-patch (RFC 7396[https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396]) | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  | \\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-06 | Resource Providers **must** respond with status Code 200 if the operation is synchronous and 202 if the operation is asynchronous. Additionally, the 200 status code **must** also be specified in the Open API specification for asynchronous `Patch` operations. This is to allow the generated SDKs to discover the schema for deserializing the final response of the long running operation. | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-response-codes.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-07 |\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-11 | Resource providers may implement `Patch` for the Identity property if the service allows it to be updated. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-identity-property.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-12 | Every `Patch ` request **must** have a request body. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/request-body-must-exist-for-put-patch.md) |\\\\n\\\\nis synchronous and 202 if the operation is asynchronous. Additionally, the 200 status code **must** also be specified in the Open API specification for asynchronous `Patch` operations. This is to allow the generated SDKs to discover the schema for deserializing the final response of the long running operation. | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-response-codes.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-07 | Resource providers **must** respond with status Code 404 if the resource group or resource does not exist. | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-08 | Response body **should** contain the updated resource with the request payload of the `Patch` request applied. | Required | No additional impact. | Runtime |  |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-09 | Resource providers may implement `Patch` for the SKU property | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-sku-property.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-10 | Use Patch only to partially update the resource. Use a `Put` operation for replacing the entire resource. Do not specify required or default properties in the request payload of a `Patch` operation. | Required | No additional impact. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-body-parameters-schema.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-11 | Resource providers may implement `Patch` for the Identity property if the service allows it to be updated. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-identity-property.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| RPC-Patch-V1-12 | Every `Patch ` request **must** have a request body. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation]\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n### allOf and polymorphism using allOf\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\n## Schema Object\\\\n\\\\n### allOf and polymorphism using allOf\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec supports single inheritance of models with the `extends` keyword. This construct can be used to produce an `allOf` with a single element (the parent schema) in OpenAPI. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=main.tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  meow: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  bark: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec does not currently provide a means to produce an `allOf` with more than one element -- these are generally treated as \\\\\\\"composition\\\\\\\" in code generators and thus better represented in TypeSpec with the spread operator.\\\\r\\\\nModels with a `@discriminator` decorator can be extended to produce polymorphic schemas in either OpenAPI v2 or v3 using `allOf`.\\\\r\\\\nThis schema produced for the base model will be defined with a `discriminator` property and schemas for the child models will `allOf` the base schema and add additional properties.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@discriminator(\\\\\\\"kind\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  weight?: float32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Cat extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  meow?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog extends Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  kind: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  bark?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngenerates:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nCat:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - cat\\\\r\\\\n    meow:\\\\r\\\\n      type: integer\\\\r\\\\n      format: int32\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nDog:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      enum:\\\\r\\\\n        - dog\\\\r\\\\n    bark:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - kind\\\\r\\\\n  allOf:\\\\r\\\\n    - $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Pet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nPet:\\\\r\\\\n  type: object\\\\r\\\\n  properties:\\\\r\\\\n    kind:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n      description: Discriminator property for Pet.\\\\r\\\\n    name:\\\\r\\\\n      type: string\\\\r\\\\n    weight:\\\\r\\\\n      type: number\\\\r\\\\n      format: float\\\\r\\\\n  discriminator:\\\\r\\\\n    propertyName: kind\\\\r\\\\n    mapping:\\\\r\\\\n      cat: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Cat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      dog: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Dog\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  required:\\\\r\\\\n    - response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"The best practice for implementing an update (PATCH) operation for a resource with a discriminator (polymorphic resource) in Azure ARM TypeSpec is to use the legacy discriminated resource models provided by the Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy library. Specifically, you should define your Host resource using `DiscriminatedTrackedResource` (for tracked resources) or `DiscriminatedProxyResource` (for proxy resources), which automatically include the required discriminator property (usually `kind`) and ensure the OpenAPI output is correct.\\n\\nWhen using `ArmResourcePatchAsync` for a discriminated resource, you must ensure that the PATCH request body includes the required discriminator property definition. If you use a plain model with a discriminator, the PATCH schema may omit the required property, causing OAV to fail with `OBJECT_MISSING_REQUIRED_PROPERTY_DEFINITION`.\\n\\nHere is the recommended TypeSpec pattern:\\n\\n```typespec\\nimport \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager\\\";\\n\\nmodel Host is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.DiscriminatedTrackedResource {\\n  // Add resource-specific properties here\\n  properties: HostProperties;\\n}\\n\\nmodel HostProperties {\\n  // Host-specific properties\\n  ...\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Hosts {\\n  get is ArmResourceRead<Host>;\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync<Host>;\\n  update is ArmResourcePatchAsync<Host, HostProperties>;\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync<Host>;\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent<Host>;\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Host>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis approach ensures that the PATCH schema includes the discriminator property (e.g., `kind`) as required, and OAV will not fail with missing required property errors. If you need to further customize the PATCH request body, use `ArmCustomPatchAsync` and ensure the custom patch model includes the discriminator property.\\n\\n**Key points:**\\n- Always use the legacy discriminated resource models for polymorphic ARM resources.\\n- The PATCH operation must include the discriminator property in the request body schema.\\n- Do not use a plain model with just `@discriminator` for ARM resources; use the provided legacy types.\\n\\nThis pattern is fully compliant with Azure ARM and OpenAPI guidelines for PATCH operations on polymorphic resources.\", \"ground_truth\": \"we generally suggest that PATCH requests over discriminated types should require the discriminator property.  This may result in some lintdiff violations, but that is expected, and those cna be suppressed.  This is especially true if, as most services, your PATCH operation would need the discriminator value on the wire to determine how to apply the PATCH request to the existing reosurce.\"}"}]

expected.answer: if you are fixing bugs already in main, this is expected.  lintdiff needs to run on your spec both before and after your PR, and if before is crashing, the PR to fix it will still crash.

Looking for examples on running TypeSpec in ADO Pipelines

actual.answer: This error is expected if you are fixing bugs that already exist in the main branch. The Swagger LintDiff CI check runs on your spec both before and after your PR. If the 'before' state (main branch) is already crashing due to missing or invalid input files, then your PR to fix it will still crash in CI, because LintDiff cannot compare the two states. To resolve this, you need to ensure that the main branch is fixed first, so LintDiff can run successfully on both versions. Once the main branch is healthy, your PR should pass the LintDiff check if your changes are correct.

Since the auto-generated\\\\r\\\\n     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n       oav generate-examples openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. To find out more see https://aka.ms/devbox/hibernate\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  hibernateSupport?: HibernateSupport;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIf you just need to add a suppression for the swagger error in LintDiff, see here: \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions \\\\r\\\\nAlso left a comment here, with a correction to the instructions provided by your ARM reviewer. \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36201#discussion_r2342265620:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nCurrently, LintDiff errors can only be suppressed in readme.md, not *.tsp files or suppressions.yaml or anywhere else.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec Linter errors should be suppressed in the *.tsp themselves.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\nCheck `Swagger LintDiff` may fail for the OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec, even if there are no warnings or errors reported from the TypeSpec compiler.  Causes include bugs in the TypeSpec OpenAPI emitter, bugs in LintDiff rules, incompatibilities between TypeSpec and LintDiff, or checks duplicated in TypeSpec and LintDiff.\\\\r\\\\nWe are working to address the root causes (where possible).  Until then, we recommend you [suppress](https://aka.ms/pr-suppressions) these LintDiff errors, using a \\\\\\\"permanent suppression\\\\\\\" with a descriptive \\\\\\\"reason\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAdditionalProperties`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### data-plane\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such responses.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousTypes`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### `LongRunningResourceAction`\\\\n\\\\nThere is a known issue where `LongRunningResourceAction` in TypeSpec, generates swagger that causes `AvoidAnonymousTypes`.  These errors should be suppressed until the root cause is fixed.  https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure-pr/issues/3349\\\\n\\\\n## `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation`\\\\n\\\\nIf `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation` is failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\\n\\\\n## `IntegerTypeMustHaveFormat`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a bug in typespec-azure:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/383.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see the issue above for the suggested workaround and apply it directly to the spec TypeSpec sources.  The LintDiff error should **not** be ignored or suppressed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchPropertiesCorrespondToPutProperties`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/642\\\\n\\\\n## `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a limitation in how `azure-openapi-validator` and `oav` handle `$ref` siblings:\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/637\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/oav/issues/848\\\\r\\\\nThe recommended workaround is to add `use-read-only-status-schema: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `RequestBodyMustExistForPutPatch`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/641\\\\n\\\\n## `ResourceNameRestriction`\\\\n\\\\nWhether `ResourceNameRestriction` should be applied to enums is an open question:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/501\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/pull/714\\\\r\\\\nUntil this is resolved, suppress the errors and discuss with your ARM reviewer.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsEnumValidation`\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec using `OAuth2Auth` may generate the following OpenAPI:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"OAuth2 authentication\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"oauth2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhich causes error `XmsEnumValidation`.  The recommended workaround is to add `omit-unreachable-types: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsPageableForListCalls`\\\\n\\\\nIf `XmsPageableForListCalls` are failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n\\\\nThe path in the suppression you add must point to exactly the same element as pointed out by the error.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, if the failure link points [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/30be453a97b9a4d64b1a7a6e45d7364bfbf4d8a2/specification/subscription/resource-manager/Microsoft.Subscription/stable/2021-10-01/subscriptions.json#L137),\\\\r\\\\nthen the path should be:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` xpath\\\\r\\\\n$.paths[\\\\\\\"/providers/Microsoft.Subscription/subscriptionOperations/{operationId}\\\\\\\"].get.responses[\\\\\\\"202\\\\\\\"]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- [Example path for suppressing LintDiff code `GetOperation200`](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/24395/commits/41f8f34937be245a855ff49552ecdeb0213ca525)\\\\r\\\\n  - **IMPORTANT**: This example uses the legacy `directive/suppress` syntax.
