docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\nTo generate SDK code based on REST API specifications, you need to configure the corresponding files.\\\\r\\\\n- For TypeSpec, the configuration file is `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n- For OpenAPI, the configuration file is `readme.md`.\\\\n\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e[!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## CSharp\\\\n\\\\nSee configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\nFor more samples on configuring specific `readme.{language}.md`, refer to:\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Management Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles)\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Data Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles-dp)\\\\r\\\\n- [Config SDK Guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/code-gen)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/configuration/configuration\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Configuration\\\\n# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Configuration\\\\n\\\\nimport { FileTree } from \\\\\\\"@astrojs/starlight/components\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec compiler and libraries can be configured either via a configuration-file or command line flags.\\\\n\\\\n## Configuration file\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec configuration can be provided via the `tspconfig.yaml` configuration file.\\\\n\\\\n### Discovery\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec compiler will look for the closest `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the same directory or closest parent directory from the TypeSpec entrypoint.\\\\r\\\\nFor example if running `tsp compile /dev/foo/bar/main.tsp`, the compiler will lookup the file at the folllowing paths (in order):\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/foo/bar/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/foo/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\n\\\\n### Schema\\\\n\\\\nThe file is a `yaml` document with the following structure. See the [next section](#typespec-configuration-options) for details on each option.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel TypeSpecProjectSchema {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  parameters?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `environment-variables`?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `warn-as-error`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  `output-dir`?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  `trace`?: string | string[];\\\\r\\\\n  imports?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  emit?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  `dry-run`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  options?: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  linter?: LinterConfig;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel LinterConfig {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: RuleRef[];\\\\r\\\\n  enable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, boolean\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  disable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, string\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Extending Project Files\\\\n\\\\nThere may be instances where you want to build different folders with varying options (such as different emitters), but still want to share some common configurations.\\\\r\\\\nIn such cases, you can use the `extends` property in the configuration file.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, in `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/tspconfig.yaml`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    some-option: my-name\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    some-other-option: This is a title\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nin `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/proj2/tspconfig.yaml`, enable `emitter1` using the options specified in the parent `tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=proj2/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### What gets extended\\\\r\\\\nThe extending logic follows these rules:\\\\r\\\\n- **Root-level properties**: Shallow merge for all properties except `options`\\\\r\\\\n- **Options property**: Deep merge at one level (per emitter)\\\\r\\\\n- **Override behavior**: Properties specified in the extending file will completely override those from the extended file\\\\r\\\\n**Root-level merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nWhen extending a configuration, most properties (like `emit`, `imports`, `trace`, etc.) are merged at the root level. If the same property exists in both files, the extending file's value completely replaces the extended file's value.\\\\r\\\\n**Options merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nThe `options` property receives special treatment with a one-level deep merge:\\\\r\\\\n- Different emitters from both files are combined\\\\r\\\\n- If the same emitter is configured in both files, the extending file's emitter configuration completely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\n\\\\ncompletely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:   # Completely replaces emitter1 options\\\\r\\\\n    option-c: value-c\\\\r\\\\n  emitter3:   # Added alongside emitter2 from parent\\\\r\\\\n    option-y: value-y\\\\r\\\\n// Resulting merged config:\\\\r\\\\n// emit: [emitter3]  # Only emitter3, emitter1 is gone\\\\r\\\\n// options:\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter1: { option-c: value-c }  # Only option-c, option-a and option-b are gone\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter2: { option-x: value-x }  # Inherited from parent\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter3: { option-y: value-y }  # From extending config\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Variable interpolation\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec project file provides variable interpolation using:\\\\r\\\\n- built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n- environment variables\\\\r\\\\n- config file parameters\\\\r\\\\n- emitter options can reference each other\\\\r\\\\nVariable interpolation is done using an variable expression surrounded by `{` and `}`. (`{\\\\u003cexpression\\\\u003e}`)\\\\r\\\\nExamples:\\\\r\\\\n- `{output-dir}/my-path`\\\\r\\\\n- `{env.SHARED_PATH}/my-path`\\\\n\\\\n### Interpolation of Emitter Path Config\\\\n\\\\nemitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\r\\\\nParameters can be organized in a nested structure, to access different levels of the structure, use dots (`.`) in the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nTherefore, parameter names should not contain `.` in their name.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be utilized in the default value of these parameters.\\\\r\\\\nThese parameters can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression.\\\\r\\\\nAll parameters must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nparameters:\\\\r\\\\n  base-dir:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {base-dir}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe parameter can then be specified via `--arg` in this format `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"` and for nested structures `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-parameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\ntsp compile . --arg \\\\\\\"base-dir=/path/to/base\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Environment variables\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can specify which environment variables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\n\\\\nCertain emitter configurations can be interpolated using a specific rule designed to collapse a path.\\\\r\\\\nIf a variable is succeeded by a `/` or `.` and the emitter responsible for interpolating the config doesn't supply that variable, the path segment will be omitted.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, consider the following config value: `{service-name}/output.{version}.json`\\\\r\\\\nHere's what would be produced:\\\\r\\\\n| Service name value | Version value | Result                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------ | ------------- | ------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `\\\\\\\"v1\\\\\\\"`        | `PetStore/output.v1.json` |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `undefined`   | `PetStore/output.json`    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n| Variable name              | Scope                    | Description                                                                          |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------------- | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| `cwd`                      | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the current working directory                                              |\\\\r\\\\n| `project-root`             | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the the tspconfig.yaml file containing folder.                             |\\\\r\\\\n| `output-dir`               | emitter options          | Common `output-dir` See [output-dir](#output-dir---configure-the-default-output-dir) |\\\\r\\\\n| `emitter-name`             | emitter options          | Name of the emitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\n\\\\nvariables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options can refer to each other by using the other option's name as the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nInterpolation is only possible among emitter options from the same emitter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  @typespec/openapi3:\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: {output-dir}/{emitter-sub-folder}\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options support a nested structure, enabling complex configurations.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter-sub-folder:\\\\r\\\\n    sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo set these values via the CLI, use dots to navigate deeper levels in the definition. `--option \\\\\\\"\\\\u003coption-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-option-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\nDue to this capability, emitter option names should not contain a `.` in their name.\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec files\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Generating readme and examples files\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\\n\\\\n# Generating readme and examples files\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion\\\\r\\\\nI have this PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) to add a new resource provider's typespec.\\\\r\\\\nTwo of the validations that are failing are due to missing readme and example files.\\\\r\\\\nCould anyone point me to some documentation around generating readme files?\\\\r\\\\nI also tried generating the example files locally, but it throws the Many of them already existed in the main branch, but previously, CI failures weren\\u2019t blocking, so these issues were effectively allowed to persist unnoticed.\\\\r\\\\nNow, because your PR is part of a TypeSpec (TSP) migration, the generated Swagger includes many differences\\u2014over 3,000 diffs in total\\u2014due to normalization by the AutoRest emitter. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n2. Avocado error: I have removed an API revokeCertificate and added a new api revokeCertificates which takes an array. \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nHow do I fix both errors?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n [Added private endpoint connection, bulk revocation and c2pa certificate type by amritas \\u00b7 Pull Requ\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24553)\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nModel validation Error - Additional properties not allowed: groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState,privateEndpoint,provisioningState\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nPEC contract - \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Private endpoint connection resource.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection\\\\r\\\\n    is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations(PrivateEndpointConnection)\\\\r\\\\ninterface PrivateEndpointConnections {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Get a specific private connection */\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\n\\\\nlistPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\r\\\\nThis will then get consumed by teams authoring Azure APIs. As such, they have the Azure linting in place (naming conventions and whatnot).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe wanted to know whether definitions can also come with suppressions (not inline, as this definition is auto-importer on a regular basis), which would apply ONLY to the definitions we share, not to the rest of the consumer's project?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nThanks!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nsuppression can only be provided inline for now. response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"This error is expected if you are fixing bugs that already exist in the main branch. The Swagger LintDiff CI check runs on your spec both before and after your PR. If the 'before' state (main branch) is already crashing due to missing or invalid input files, then your PR to fix it will still crash in CI, because LintDiff cannot compare the two states. To resolve this, you need to ensure that the main branch is fixed first, so LintDiff can run successfully on both versions. Once the main branch is healthy, your PR should pass the LintDiff check if your changes are correct.\", \"ground_truth\": \"if you are fixing bugs already in main, this is expected.  lintdiff needs to run on your spec both before and after your PR, and if before is crashing, the PR to fix it will still crash.\"}"}]

actual.answer:
The issue you're experiencing—where required pipeline checks ('SDK Validation Status' and 'Swagger PrettierCheck') remain queued and do not report status—is most likely due to a permissions problem with the PR author. Specifically, the PR author needs to ensure their membership in the Azure GitHub organization is set to public (not private), and they must join the Azure SDK Partners group. Without these steps, the CI pipelines will not trigger or report status, blocking the merge.

To resolve this:
1. Make sure the PR author's Azure organization membership is public. You can verify this at https://github.com/orgs/Azure/people?query=AbhishekSinha-AEP.
2. Join the Azure SDK Partners group by following the instructions at https://aka.ms/azsdk/access.

Once these steps are completed, the required checks should start and report status, allowing you to proceed with merging your PR.

Diagnostics\\\\n# emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\\n\\\\n# Diagnostics\\\\n\\\\nThe OpenAPI emitter may produce any of the following diagnostic messages.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- Topics within this section should be ordered alphabetically for easy lookup --\\\\u003e\\\\n\\\\n## duplicate-header\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when a response header is defined more than once for a response of a specific status code.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, ensure that each response header is defined only once for each status code.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nresponses:\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"200\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    description: Successful response\\\\r\\\\n    headers:\\\\r\\\\n      X-Rate-Limit:\\\\r\\\\n        description: The number of allowed requests in the current period\\\\r\\\\n        schema:\\\\r\\\\n          type: integer\\\\r\\\\n      X-Rate-Limit:\\\\r\\\\n        description: The number of allowed requests in the current period\\\\r\\\\n        schema:\\\\r\\\\n          type: integer\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, the `X-Rate-Limit` header is defined twice for the `200` status code. To fix this issue, remove the duplicate header definition.\\\\n\\\\n## duplicate-type-name\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when a schema or parameter name is a duplicate of another schema or parameter. This generally happens when a model or parameter is renamed with the `@friendlyName` decorator, resulting in two different TypeSpec types getting the same name in the OpenAPI output.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, change the name or friendly-name of one of the models or parameters.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@friendlyName(\\\\\\\"User\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Customer {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, both `Customer` and `User` would appear as `User` in the OpenAPI output, causing a conflict.\\\\n\\\\n## inline-cycle\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when a cyclic reference is detected within inline schemas.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, refactor the schemas to remove the cyclic reference.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\ncomponents:\\\\r\\\\n  schemas:\\\\r\\\\n    Node:\\\\r\\\\n      type: object\\\\r\\\\n      properties:\\\\r\\\\n        value:\\\\r\\\\n          type: string\\\\r\\\\n        next:\\\\r\\\\n          $ref: \\\\\\\"#/components/schemas/Node\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, the `Node` schema references itself, creating a cyclic reference. To fix this issue, refactor the schema to remove the cyclic reference.\\\\n\\\\n## invalid-default\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when a default value is invalid for the specified schema type.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, ensure that the default value is valid for the schema type.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\ncomponents:\\\\r\\\\n  schemas:\\\\r\\\\n    User:\\\\r\\\\n      type: object\\\\r\\\\n      properties:\\\\r\\\\n        age:\\\\r\\\\n          type: integer\\\\r\\\\n          default: \\\\\\\"twenty\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, the `default` value for the `age` property is invalid because it is a string instead of an integer. To fix this issue, provide a valid default value, such as `20`.\\\\n\\\\n## invalid-extension-key\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued by the `@extension` decorator when the extension key does not start with \\\\\\\"x-\\\\\\\" as\\\\r\\\\nrequired by the OpenAPI v3 specification.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, change the extension name to start with \\\\\\\"x-\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@extension(\\\\\\\"invalid-name\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nShould be changed to:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@extension(\\\\\\\"x-valid-name\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## invalid-schema\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when a schema is invalid according to the OpenAPI v3 specification.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, review your TypeSpec definitions to ensure they map to valid OpenAPI schemas.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\ncomponents:\\\\r\\\\n  schemas:\\\\r\\\\n    User:\\\\r\\\\n      type: object\\\\r\\\\n      properties:\\\\r\\\\n        id:\\\\r\\\\n          type: string\\\\r\\\\n        age:\\\\r\\\\n          type: integer\\\\r\\\\n          format: \\\\\\\"int\\\\\\\" # Invalid format\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, the `format` value for the `age` property is invalid. To fix this issue, provide a valid format value such as `int32` or `int64`.\\\\n\\\\n## invalid-server-variable\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when a variable in the `@server` decorator is not defined as a string type.\\\\r\\\\nSince server variables are substituted into the server URL which is a string, all variables must have string values.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, make sure all server variables are of a type that is assignable to `string`.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"{protocol}://{host}/api/{version}\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Custom endpoint\\\\\\\", {\\\\r\\\\n  protocol: \\\\\\\"http\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"https\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  host: string,\\\\r\\\\n  version: 1, // Should be a string: \\\\\\\"1\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n})\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## path-query\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when the OpenAPI emitter finds an `@route` decorator that specifies a path that contains a query parameter. This is not permitted by the OpenAPI v3 specification, which requires query parameters to be defined separately.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, redesign the API to only use paths without query parameters, and define query parameters using the `@query` decorator.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\nInstead of:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/users?filter={filter}\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop getUsers(filter: string): User[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nUse:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/users\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop getUsers(@query filter?: string): User[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, you can leverage TypeSpec's support for URI templates:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/users{?filter}\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop getUsers(filter?: string): User[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## union-null\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when the result of model composition is effectively a `null` schema which cannot be\\\\r\\\\nrepresented in OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, review your model compositions to ensure they produce valid schemas with actual properties or types.\\\\n\\\\n## union-unsupported\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when the OpenAPI emitter finds a union of two incompatible types that cannot be represented in OpenAPI. OpenAPI has limited support for union types, and some combinations cannot be expressed.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, consider restructuring your types to avoid incompatible unions, or split the operation into multiple operations with different return types.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e This article assumes you came here from your REST API specs PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e See [this documentation section description](xref:specs-pr-guides) for details.\\\\r\\\\nOn your Azure REST API specs PR, some of the GitHub check failures (see the `Checks` tab on your PR) can be suppressed.\\\\r\\\\nThe suppression can be either just for the PR, or permanent.\\\\n\\\\n## To suppress given validation failure\\\\n\\\\n1. Determine which failing check you want to suppress: see its name in the `Checks` tab in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you have one of the [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you want to suppress the failure only for the PR, or permanently. Permanent suppression is preferred to avoid re-addressing the same issue in future PRs.\\\\r\\\\n1. Consult [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table) for instructions corresponding to your case.\\\\r\\\\n1. If you want to apply temporary suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Mention in a comment on your PR the PR assignee asking to apply the suppression. Provide justification.\\\\r\\\\n      See [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).\\\\r\\\\n1. If you applied permanent suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. It will manifest by the PR getting a label `SuppressionReviewRequired`.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Verify the suppression works by the check changing from **failed** to **neutral**.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Wait until your suppression is reviewed. If it is approved, the approved will add the `Approved-Suppression` label.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Understand the suppression won't be approved if it is not one of the  \\\\r\\\\n      [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons) as explained in relevant section.\\\\n\\\\n## Suppression `Approved-BreakingChange`                            | Not possible                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| Breaking Change(Cross-Version)     | Email [Breaking Change Board] [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintRPaaS`                                 | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-net              |\\\\n\\\\n## suppressions.yaml\\\\n\\\\nFile `suppressions.yaml` is used for all checks created in 2024 or later, like\\\\r\\\\n`TypeSpec Requirement` and `TypeSpec Validation`.\\\\r\\\\nFor simplicity, we recommend adding all suppressions to a single file at the root of your spec folder:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/myservice/suppressions.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, you can use multiple files in separate folders.  Currently, tools will use the first\\\\r\\\\ninstance of `suppressions.yaml` found walking up the directory tree.  We are planning\\\\r\\\\nfuture support for \\\\\\\"merging\\\\\\\" files up the hierarchy.\\\\r\\\\nA suppression follows this general format:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: ToolName\\\\r\\\\n  path: applies/to/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Why this can't be fixed\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`path` uses \\\\\\\"glob\\\\\\\" matching.  For syntax, see https://www.npmjs.com/package/minimatch.\\\\r\\\\nScope your `path` as narrowly as possible. Pipeline Failures\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/pipeline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\\n\\\\nThis document explains how to resolve pipeline failures in TypeSpec migration PRs.\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger BreakingChange\\\\n\\\\n### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration\\\\n\\\\nThis pipeline will fail if there is more than one OpenAPI file in the latest version. See the detailed explanation in this [issue](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216).\\\\r\\\\nTo properly identify real breaking changes, use the \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Migration Validation\\\\\\\" pipeline instead:\\\\r\\\\n1. Navigate to the TypeSpec Migration Validation pipeline\\\\r\\\\n2. Check the report on the \\\\\\\"Summary\\\\\\\" page\\\\r\\\\n3. The output should match exactly what you see in [this step](../01-get-started.md#review-and-adjust-the-typespec) on the local machine\\\\r\\\\n4. Review the changes to verify they are expected\\\\n\\\\n### Single OpenAPI File Before Migration\\\\n\\\\nIf you have only one OpenAPI file in the latest version, use this pipeline to detect breaking changes. If it fails, refer to [Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations](./faq/breakingchange.md).\\\\r\\\\n**Known Issues**: The following pipeline failures are false alerts and can be safely ignored:\\\\r\\\\n#### 1017 - ReferenceRedirection\\\\r\\\\nThis typically occurs when an inlined anonymous enum becomes a named enum.\\\\r\\\\n**Before:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"SomeModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enumProperty\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"If\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"Else\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"None\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    ],\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"EnumType\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"modelAsString\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**After:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"SomeModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enumProperty\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/EnumType\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"EnumType\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"If\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"Else\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"None\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"EnumType\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"modelAsString\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### 1023 - TypeFormatChanged\\\\r\\\\nThe error message `The new version has a different format 'uri' than the previous one ''.` on the `nextLink` property is expected because the [page template defines the `nextLink` as `uri`](./mustread.md#using-page-model-from-azurecore-library).\\\\r\\\\n#### 1047 - XmsEnumChanged\\\\r\\\\nAfter migration, all models (including enums) will have capitalized names.\\\\r\\\\n**Before:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"SomeModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"someProperty\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"If\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    ],\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"someName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"modelAsString\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**After:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"SomeModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"someProperty\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/SomeName\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"SomeName\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"If\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"SomeName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"modelAsString\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger ModelValidation\\\\n\\\\nSome validation rules may fail because TypeSpec fixes certain legacy patterns. Review the known issues below and take appropriate action.\\\\n\\\\n### INVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format uri: {nextlink}\\\\n\\\\n#### Root Cause\\\\r\\\\nThe response model of a pageable operation uses the Azure.Core.Page template:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel ResponseModel is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cItemType\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis standardized approach changes the `nextLink` type from plain `string` to `uri`. If previous example's `nextLink` value isn't a valid URI, it will cause a validation error.\\\\r\\\\n#### Resolution\\\\r\\\\nChoose one of the following options:\\\\r\\\\n1. **Update your example** to include a valid URI value, or\\\\r\\\\n2. **Modify your TypeSpec response model** to use a custom definition if the nextLink returned by the service is not a URI:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel ResponseModel {\\\\r\\\\n  @pageItems\\\\r\\\\n  value: ItemType[];\\\\r\\\\n  @nextLink\\\\r\\\\n  nextLink?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### INVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format arm-id\\\\n\\\\n#### Root Cause\\\\r\\\\nThis error typically occurs when a custom resource definition is mapped to a resource defined in common-types. See [this section](./breakingchange.md#using-resources-from-common-types) for details. The `id` property for `Resource` in common-types may use the `arm-id` format, depending on the version of common-types used.\\\\r\\\\n#### Resolution\\\\r\\\\nUpdate the value in the example file to meet the `arm-id` format requirements.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n- path: data-plane/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen in doubt, search the repo for examples:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/search?q=repo%3AAzure%2Fazure-rest-api-specs+path%3A%2F%28%5E%7C%5C%2F%29suppressions%5C.yaml%24%2F\\\\u0026type=code\\\\n\\\\n### `TypeSpec Requirement` check\\\\n\\\\nTo suppress `TypeSpec Requirement` check for given pattern of OpenAPI spec .json file paths, provide an entry with\\\\r\\\\n`tool` set to `TypeSpecRequirement`. Provide the pattern as `path` and provide a `reason`.\\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: data-plane/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Suppress AutoRest extension\\\\n\\\\nTo suppress tooling that is an AutoRest extension (see [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table)),\\\\r\\\\nfollow the AutoRest documentation:\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/generate/suppress-warnings.md\\\\r\\\\nThat documentation describes the **new syntax** for AutoRest suppression, as opposed to the old, directive-based syntax.\\\\r\\\\nYou can [search for existing usages](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AAzure%2Fazure-rest-api-specs%20suppressions%3A\\\\u0026type=code).\\\\n\\\\n### Obtain error code\\\\n\\\\nTo get error code,  i.e. the value for `- code:`:\\\\r\\\\n- For `SemanticValidation` and `ModelValidation`, refer to [error definition](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/Semantic-and-Model-Violations-Reference.md).\\\\r\\\\n- For `LintDiff` and `LintDiff(RPaaS)`, refer to [rules.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/rules.md).\\\\n\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n\\\\n### Ensure you are suppressing the right tag (API version)\\\\n\\\\nIf, for example, the error pertains to API version 2021-09-01, then the suppressions must be in\\\\r\\\\nthe `### Tag: package-2021-09-01` section, not `### Tag: package-2021-09-01-preview` or `### Tag: package-2023-04-27`.\\\\n\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n\\\\nThe path in the suppression you add must point to exactly the same element as pointed out by the error.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, if the failure link points [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/30be453a97b9a4d64b1a7a6e45d7364bfbf4d8a2/specification/subscription/resource-manager/Microsoft.Subscription/stable/2021-10-01/subscriptions.json#L137),\\\\r\\\\nthen the path should be:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` xpath\\\\r\\\\n$.paths[\\\\\\\"/providers/Microsoft.Subscription/subscriptionOperations/{operationId}\\\\\\\"].get.responses[\\\\\\\"202\\\\\\\"]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- [Example path for suppressing LintDiff code `GetOperation200`](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/24395/commits/41f8f34937be245a855ff49552ecdeb0213ca525)\\\\r\\\\n  - **IMPORTANT**: This example uses the legacy `directive/suppress` syntax. Do not use it. Use the new syntax instead.\\\\r\\\\n  - [Relevant Teams discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:0351f5f9404446e4b4fd4eaf2c27448d@thread.skype/1688105866973?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1687971321354\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=API%20Spec%20Review\\\\u0026createdTime=1688105866973)\\\\n\\\\n### Verify your 'where' path with jsonpath and ensure proper escaping\\\\n\\\\nIf you have trouble with getting the `where` clause to work, then:\\\\r\\\\n#### Ensure you are escaping _segments_\\\\r\\\\nFor example, if you want to denote `format` in following example snippet\\\\r\\\\n([original occurrence in a PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/25763/files#diff-2e82aff34a54fd667da22140fc9b9e68bf6690a968f628263493f4a837577f64R2203-R2205),  \\\\r\\\\n[comment](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/25763/files#r1385932846)):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"definitions\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"format\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"eTag\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nyou should use `where: $.definitions[\\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\"].format` and not `where: $.definitions.Azure.Core.eTag.format`.\\\\r\\\\nThe entire suppression would look like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\nsuppressions:\\\\r\\\\n  - code: ValidFormats\\\\r\\\\n    where: $.definitions[\\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\"].format\\\\r\\\\n    reason: eTag should be an allowed format\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Consider verifying your path with https://jsonpath.com/\\\\r\\\\nFor example, you can paste as JSONPath `$.definitions[\\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\"].format` and in `Inputs`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"definitions\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"Azure.Core.eTag\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"format\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"eTag\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nand observe:\\\\r\\\\nNote: tips in this subsection were originally provided in TypeSpec Specs PR channel, [in this conversation](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:609c1607ce0c4026a26c28cb260afe01@thread.skype/1699401047738?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1698964934652\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=TypeSpec%20Spec%20PRs\\\\u0026createdTime=1699401047738).\\\\n\\\\n### When in doubt: search the repository for existing suppressions\\\\n\\\\nSearch for [suppressions](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AAzure%2Fazure-rest-api-specs%20suppressions%3A\\\\u0026type=code)\\\\r\\\\nor [suppress](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AAzure%2Fazure-rest-api-specs%20suppress%3A\\\\u0026type=code).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Even if you find examples of the legacy `directive/suppress` syntax, try not to use it.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Use the new `suppressions` syntax instead.\\\\r\\\\nYou can also search for the code you are trying to suppress to find existing suppressions for it, if any.\\\\n\\\\n## Valid suppression reasons\\\\n\\\\n### Valid reasons\\\\n\\\\nYou can request suppression of validation errors if one or more of the following scenarios matches your case;\\\\r\\\\n1. Your service design forces this behavior\\\\r\\\\n   (and it's actually the correct behavior that doesn't violate Microsoft API guidelines).\\\\r\\\\n2. Specific validation rules do not apply to your service\\\\r\\\\n   (e.g. ARM specific API validation rules may not apply to data plane API validation).\\\\r\\\\n3. You are blocked on resolving this issue by external teams\\\\r\\\\n   (e.g. ARM feature that would need to be let up for you to become green).\\\\r\\\\n4. If you believe that the validation is a false positive (incorrect failure due to a bug in the tool).\\\\r\\\\n5. If you service is RPaaS service and you're blocked by a new validation rule.\\\\n\\\\n### Invalid reasons\\\\n\\\\nIf you are trying to suppress failures that do not fall under one of the valid cases enumerated\\\\r\\\\nin previous section, and the following applies to your case, then suppression will **not** be approved:\\\\r\\\\n1. You can't resolve the violations at the moment due to time constraints and planning to do it in the future.\\\\r\\\\n2. The violation reported applies to your case and is not a false positive.\\\\r\\\\n3. The violation can be resolved and there are no technical blockers.\\\\n\\\\n## Implementation details\\\\n\\\\nThe contents of this article is primarily derived from the following source code:\\\\r\\\\n- [`openapi-alps` repo] / `azure-rest-api-specs.yml` configs\\\\r\\\\n- [`openapi-alps` repo] / `requiredLabelRules.ts`\\\\r\\\\nAs such, if you find a discrepancy:\\\\r\\\\n1. The source code takes precedence.\\\\r\\\\n2. If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | \\\\r\\\\n| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |\\\\r\\\\n| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |\\\\r\\\\n| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | \\\\r\\\\n| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |\\\\r\\\\n| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |\\\\r\\\\n| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | \\\\r\\\\n| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"PR gateway pipelines not starting/waiting for long time\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# PR gateway pipelines not starting/waiting for long time\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\\n\\\\n# PR gateway pipelines not starting/waiting for long time\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team, \\\\r\\\\nwe are adding new api version to our current swagger and in that 2 pipeline checks are queued/waiting from long time and not getting the status reported due to which we cant merge the swagger as these are required ones.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n2 pending checks  \\\\r\\\\nSDK Validation Status  Expected \\u2014 Waiting for status to be reported  Required  \\\\r\\\\nSwagger PrettierCheck  Expected \\u2014 Waiting for status to be reported  Required  \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nPR - [Swagger Changes for Solution Metadata RT by AbhishekSinha-AEP \\u00b7 Pull Request #24090 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24090)\\\\r\\\\nWe also tried to create same new PR in thought that old PR may have some transient issue but in newly create same PR we are facing same issue\\\\r\\\\nNew PR: [Swagger Changes for Solution Metadata RT by AbhishekSinha-AEP \\u00b7 Pull Request #24204 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24204)\\\\r\\\\nIn both PRs. same facing same issue and cannot head towards merge.\\\\r\\\\nCan some one help here.\\\\r\\\\nThanks\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nLooks like a permissions issue. Specifically, patterns like {width}x{height} or {x}/{y}@{scale}x in your API paths are now breaking validation due to stricter parsing rules introduced in path-to-regexp@6.2.1.\\\\r\\\\nPreviously, your spec passed validation because older versions of path-to-regexp were more lenient. The recent update introduced security fixes that inadvertently caused this break.\\\\r\\\\nTo unblock your PR, we\\u2019ve deployed a temporary fix that pins path-to-regexp to an older version. This means your Swagger checks should no longer crash. Meanwhile, we\\u2019re working on a permanent solution that doesn\\u2019t rely on pinning old code.\\\\r\\\\nIf you still need to validate locally, you can manually install the older version and run oav like this:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cinstall node 20\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nmkdir testdirectory\\\\r\\\\ncd testdirectory\\\\r\\\\nnpm i oav path-to-regexp@6.2.2\\\\r\\\\nnpx oav validate-example /path/to/your/openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, you can use validate-spec instead of validate-example if you're checking the spec directly. This workaround has been confirmed to pass for your PR.\\\\r\\\\nWe\\u2019ve also applied the approved-modelvalidation and approved-semanticvalidation labels to your PR to unblock progress. testcase: RPaaSMaster branch requirement for Ring 0 services

expected.answer: Based on the available knowledge context, syncing API specs between the public 'main' branch and the private 'RPaaSMaster' branch is the responsibility of the spec owner. There is no strict requirement in the referenced documentation that all resource providers (including ring 0 services like Microsoft.Compute) must have their specs present in RPaaSMaster if they have received an explicit exemption from RPaaS onboarding. The documentation and FAQ state that if your service is not onboarded to RPaaS (and has an exception), you do not need to merge your specs into RPaaSMaster. The presence or absence of Microsoft.Compute in RPaaSMaster does not dictate requirements for other RPs; each spec owner is responsible for their own onboarding and branch sync according to their onboarding status and exemptions. If your ring 0 service has an approved exception, you can continue to manage your specs in 'main' and do not need to merge into RPaaSMaster unless instructed otherwise by the ARM or EngSys team.

actual.answer: If your service has received an explicit exception from onboarding to RPaaS, you are not required to merge your API specification into the RPaaSMaster branch before merging to the main branch in the public repository. The RPaaSMaster branch is intended for RPaaS-managed resource providers, and exceptions (such as for ring 0 services like Microsoft.Compute) mean you can follow the standard public repo process without the RPaaSMaster prerequisite. The absence of Microsoft.Compute in RPaaSMaster is consistent with this exception policy. However, you must ensure your spec is up-to-date and follows all other Azure API guidelines before merging to main.

testcase: Looking for someone to suppress CI failures https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36221

expected.answer:
Based on the information provided and the knowledge context, the Avocado CI failure in your PR (https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36221) is expected because the Compute service currently has multiple API versions in its default tag, which violates the Uniform Versioning Principle. The Avocado check (MULTIPLE_API_VERSION) was recently made a blocking error to enforce this policy.
To temporarily suppress this failure and unblock your PR, you can add the Approved-Avocado label to your PR. However, this is only a one-time suppression and should be done if:
There is an ongoing discussion and plan to resolve the uniform versioning issue for Compute.
You or your team are aware that this is a temporary measure and are working towards compliance.
Important: Regular use of this suppression is discouraged. The long-term solution is to restructure your API versions so all components under Compute adopt a uniform versioning scheme, or split into independent services as outlined in the Uniform Versioning Violation Guide.
If you are not aware of any ongoing discussion or plan for resolution, you should reach out to azversioning@service.microsoft.com for guidance.

actual.answer:
Since your PR is targeting a feature branch, CI checks are not strictly required at this stage. However, when you attempt to merge into the main branch, the Avocado check failure (due to multiple API versions) will become a blocker. The MULTIPLE_API_VERSION rule was upgraded to an error as part of the Azure-wide TypeSpec conversion effort to enforce uniform versioning. 

To address this:
- Review the guidance in the Uniform Versioning Violation Guide: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Uniform-Versioning-Violation-Guide
- If you believe the error is expected and cannot be resolved immediately, you may request a one-time suppression by contacting azversioning@service.microsoft.com.
- Do not rely on suppression as a permanent solution; you should work towards resolving the versioning issue to comply with Azure API guidelines and enable successful TypeSpec conversion.

For Avocado errors, if suppression is approved, the PR will be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label. Always provide justification for the suppression request in your PR comments.

https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32694\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\nHear directly from teams who have successfully transitioned to TypeSpec Azure and learn about their experiences:\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | \\\\r\\\\n| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |\\\\r\\\\n| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |\\\\r\\\\n| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | \\\\r\\\\n| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |\\\\r\\\\n| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |\\\\r\\\\n| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | \\\\r\\\\n| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nFor PR [Add Microsoft.Mission version 2025-05-01-preview - Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581) I was asked to consider renaming routes for some custom actions to meet naming conventions. For example, I now have this in my routes:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Community Endpoint Interface\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface CommunityEndpoints {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"Callback that triggers on approval state change.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @armResourceAction(CommunityEndpointResource)\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_12_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(\\\\r\\\\n    Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2025_05_01_preview,\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"approvalCallback\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  )\\\\r\\\\n  notifyOnApprovalCreation is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    CommunityEndpointResource,\\\\r\\\\n    ApprovalCallbackRequest,\\\\r\\\\n    ApprovalActionResponse\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis unfortunately now produces Avocado errors for [MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/blob/master/README.md#MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG) , \\\\r\\\\nThe default tag should contain all APIs. The API path \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/subscriptions/{}/resourcegroups/{}/providers/microsoft.mission/virtualenclaves/{}/enclaveendpoints/{}/approvalcallback\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nis not in the default tag. Please make sure the missing API swaggers are in the default tag.\\\\r\\\\nreadme: [specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\njson: [Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json)\\\\r\\\\nIs there something that I need to do differently to define this route renaming? \\\\r\\\\nLink to [Avocado check](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581/checks?check_run_id=45066798540). Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nAvocado doesn't handle moves/renames.  You can suppress by adding label `Approved-Avocado`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Suppress Guide\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Uniform-Versioning-Violation-Guide\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Uniform Versioning Violation Guide\\\\n## CI Validation\\\\n# Uniform-Versioning-Violation-Guide.md\\\\n\\\\n# Uniform Versioning Violation Guide\\\\n\\\\n## CI Validation\\\\n\\\\nWe have enabled a Swagger-Avocado error check [`MULTIPLE_API_VERSION`](https://github.com/azure/avocado?tab=readme-ov-file#multiple_api_version) in the specification PR CI pipeline. This check prevents new specifications from introducing uniform versioning violations early in the development process.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Missing APIs in default tag error for typespec conversion PR\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nPR: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346\\\\r\\\\nAvocado check: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44368323389 \\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to suppress the missing APIs check only for this PR since it only has typspec conversion but no update to the open API spec?\\\\r\\\\nThe check is trying to compare the APIs with previous stable release with currently published stable release.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nPart of the typespec conversion is replacing the existing swagger with a generated swagger.  The generated swagger is still used for some purposes, and Avocado protects the ability to process it. The generated swagger needs to be equivalent, but not necessarily identical.  Generally these issues reflected in the swagger will also show up in breaking change checks, which will have to be resolved (or suppressed if they are false positives)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e This article assumes you came here from your REST API specs PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e See [this documentation section description](xref:specs-pr-guides) for details.\\\\r\\\\nOn your Azure REST API specs PR, some of the GitHub check failures (see the `Checks` tab on your PR) can be suppressed.\\\\r\\\\nThe suppression can be either just for the PR, or permanent.\\\\n\\\\n## To suppress given validation failure\\\\n\\\\n1. Determine which failing check you want to suppress: see its name in the `Checks` tab in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you have one of the [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you want to suppress the failure only for the PR, or permanently. Permanent suppression is preferred to avoid re-addressing the same issue in future PRs.\\\\r\\\\n1. Consult [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table) for instructions corresponding to your case.\\\\r\\\\n1. If you want to apply temporary suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Mention in a comment on your PR the PR assignee asking to apply the suppression. Provide justification.\\\\r\\\\n      See [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).\\\\r\\\\n1. If you applied permanent suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. It will manifest by the PR getting a label `SuppressionReviewRequired`.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Verify the suppression works by the check changing from **failed** to **neutral**.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Wait until your suppression is reviewed. If it is approved, the approved will add the `Approved-Suppression` label.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Understand the suppression won't be approved if it is not one of the  \\\\r\\\\n      [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons) as explained in relevant section.\\\\n\\\\n## Suppression cases table\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| Swagger LintDiff                   | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintDiff`                                  | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |\\\\r\\\\n| Swagger LintDiff(RPaaS)            | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintRPaaS`                                 | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-net              | Not possible ([#6509])                    |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-net-track2       | Not possible ([#6509])                    |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-go               | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Go-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`         | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-java             | Not possible ([#6509]) testcase: is sdk generation required for private preview?

expected.answer:
API approval for private preview does NOT always require SDK generation or SDK configuration in your tspconfig.yaml. For private preview ARM APIs, it is acceptable to onboard and validate your API contract without including SDK emitter settings (such as for Go, Python, Java, etc.).

However, the Azure TypeSpec validation tooling (tsv) is configured to expect certain SDK emitter options in tspconfig.yaml by default, even for private preview, which is why you see SdkTspConfigValidation failures if you remove them.

The correct and supported approach is:
- Remove SDK emitter configs you do NOT want in your tspconfig.yaml.
- Add a suppressions.yaml file in the same directory as tspconfig.yaml to explicitly suppress the SdkTspConfigValidation rule (or specific sub-rules for missing SDK configs).

Here is a sample suppressions.yaml to suppress all SdkTspConfigValidation checks (recommended for your scenario):

```yaml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
  paths:
    - tspconfig.yaml
  rules:
    - SdkTspConfigValidation
  reason: 'SDK generation is not in scope for private preview onboarding.'
```

Place this suppressions.yaml alongside your tspconfig.yaml. This will allow CI and local validation to succeed without requiring SDK settings, letting you focus on API review and onboarding. When you later want to add SDK support, you can remove the suppression and add the required SDK emitter configuration.

In summary: No, API approval for private preview does not require SDK generation. Use suppressions.yaml to bypass SDK validation in tspconfig.yaml until you are ready to onboard SDKs.

actual.answer:
For ARM (management-plane) APIs in private preview, SDK generation is NOT required for API approval. Azure guidelines explicitly state that private preview versions do not require corresponding SDK package versions, and there are no SDK support requirements at this stage. You can safely proceed without SDK emitter configuration in your tspconfig.yaml.

However, the TypeSpec validation system expects certain emitter options to be present in tspconfig.yaml, even if you do not intend to generate SDKs. If you remove these options, you may encounter validation failures (e.g., SdkTspConfigValidation errors).

To resolve this, you have two options:

1. **Suppress SDK validation rules for emitters you do not support**: Add a suppressions.yaml file in your service folder and explicitly suppress the relevant SdkTspConfigValidation sub-rules for each SDK emitter you do not support (e.g., Go, Java, .NET, JS). Example:

```yaml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
  paths:
    - tspconfig.yaml
  rules:
    - SdkTspConfigValidation
  sub-rules:
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir
    # Add similar lines for other emitters as needed
  reason: 'No SDK required for private preview.'
```

2. **(Not recommended) Add minimal emitter options**: You could add placeholder emitter options for each required SDK emitter, but this is discouraged if you do not intend to generate SDKs.

**Best Practice:** Use suppressions.yaml to bypass SDK validation for emitters not in scope. This is the recommended approach for private preview ARM APIs.

When you are ready to onboard SDK generation (e.g., for public preview or GA), you should add the appropriate emitter options to tspconfig.yaml following the Azure SDK guidelines.

Summary: API approval for private preview does NOT require SDK generation. Use suppressions.yaml to pass TypeSpec validation without SDK emitter configs.

Use suppressions.yaml to pass TypeSpec validation without SDK emitter configs.\", \"context\": \"[{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n## Positive Consequences of the Azure Service Definition\\\\n# Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n\\\\n## Positive Consequences of the Azure Service Definition\\\\n\\\\nFrom the above definition, many processes and assets naturally flow, providing both Azure engineering teams and customers with great experiences:\\\\r\\\\n- Each service version is documented separately allowing a customer to reference the specific version of the service they are targeting.\\\\r\\\\n- Each service version gets its own SDK package version allowing a customer to import the SDK package version corresponding to the service version they wish to target.\\\\r\\\\n    - GA versions of a service get a stable SDK package and preview versions of a service get a beta SDK package. Each SDK package version must clearly document which service version it targets .\\\\r\\\\n    - When any preview or GA version of a service is retired, the corresponding SDK package version is deprecated (without affecting any other SDK packages). Note that Azure retires preview service versions regularly; GA service versions are retired when breaking changes are introduced or on other rare occasions. See [Azure SDK lifecycle and support policy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_support.html#azure-sdk-lifecycle-and-support-policy).\\\\r\\\\n    - When a service is retired in its entirety, all SDK packages for this service are deprecated (without affecting any other services\\u2019 SDK packages).\\\\r\\\\n    - A service version introducing a breaking change will likely break that service\\u2019s SDK package in the next version causing the new SDK package version to increment its major number as per semantic versioning.
