The namespace itself has no code and therefore never versions. \\\\r\\\\n- Within an RP namespace is 1+ control plane services and 0+ data-plane services which version uniformly over time. \\\\r\\\\n    - Private preview versions don\\u2019t have corresponding SDK package versions\\\\r\\\\n    - Public preview versions do have corresponding beta SDK package versions\\\\r\\\\n    - GA versions do have corresponding stable SDK package versions. Beta SDK package versions may also exist if the SDK package has rich functionality requiring customer testing/feedback before releasing the stable SDK package version. \\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cimg width=\\\\\\\"600\\\\\\\" height=\\\\\\\"400\\\\\\\" alt=\\\\\\\"image\\\\\\\" src=\\\\\\\"https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7b079665-2328-4524-8784-476e52e57343\\\\\\\" /\\\\u003e\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Can required fields have default values?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Can required fields have default values?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# Can required fields have default values?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nDoes typespec allow default value for required field? I ask as mandatory field states that users send a value but we want to be able to assign a default for them. The field is below. \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel StorageDiscoveryWorkspaceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The storage discovery sku.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(ApiVersion.v2025_03_01_preview, \\\\\\\"tier\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @madeRequired(ApiVersion.v2025_06_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  sku: StorageDiscoverySku;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nCan required fields have default values in TypeSpec?\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, TypeSpec does not currently support versioned default values for required fields. If you want to assign a default value to a required field, you\\u2019ll need to use the \\u201cremove/rename dance\\u201d workaround, as shown in the referenced playground. This means you\\u2019ll have to remove the old field and reintroduce it with a default value, which is not ideal but currently the only way.\\\\r\\\\nCan we delete unused preview versions and only keep the latest one?\\\\r\\\\nYes, absolutely. That is what we recommend. Azure services are moving toward maintaining only one active preview version per spec (except for ARM retention requirements, which typically apply only to public previews). Since you\\u2019re still in private preview and none of your previous versions are being used, you can safely remove them and keep only the latest one.\\\\r\\\\nDeprecation only matters if you have customers using those versions. For private previews, there are no SDK support requirements. You can simply remove the older versions from your TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nWhat\\u2019s the process for moving to public preview?\\\\r\\\\nYou should open a PR against the public repo\\u2019s main branch before the public preview announcement. You can start preparing Microsoft Learn documentation using the versions merged in the RPSaaSMaster branch. The review process for public preview is slightly easier if you\\u2019ve already been reviewed privately, but it does include required SDK checks.\\\\r\\\\nYou should only bring over the latest preview version to the public repo. It\\u2019s fine to omit .tsp files in the public repo if they\\u2019re not needed.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Process\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"## Process\\\\n1. Open a PR deleting one (or more) previews.  All of:\\\\r\\\\n   1. TypeSpec sources (`*.tsp`)\\\\r\\\\n   2. Example sources (examples closest to `*.tsp` files)\\\\r\\\\n   3. Generated swaggers and examples (`preview/YYYY-MM-DD-preview/**`)\\\\r\\\\n   4. readme.md (remove tags)\\\\r\\\\n2. PR should fail check `Swagger BreakingChange`, but pass all other checks.\\\\r\\\\n3. Run \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\noav generate-examples specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/fleet/preview/2025-07-01-preview/fleets.json\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nError \\\\r\\\\n(node:53300) [DEP0040] DeprecationWarning: The `punycode` module is deprecated. Please use a userland alternative instead.\\\\r\\\\n(Use `node --trace-deprecation ...` to show where the warning was created)\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  message: 'array details item is null, it may be caused by circular reference',\\\\r\\\\n  level: '\\\\\\\\x1B[33mwarn\\\\\\\\x1B[39m'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  message: 'fatal error: Maximum call stack size exceeded, {}',\\\\r\\\\n  level: '\\\\\\\\x1B[31merror\\\\\\\\x1B[39m'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nfatal error: Maximum call stack size exceeded, {}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nDoes any one know why this error happens TypeSpec Discussion?\\\\r\\\\nThis branch is based on branch `dev-aks-fleet-2025-07-01-preview` . For diff, pls see https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/34812\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nFirst thing to understand there are two copies of all examples when you're using TSP \\\\r\\\\nSwagger copy: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/33737ff460f78153f4cc21ef5d2d4586fcbae107/specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/fleet/preview/2025-07-01-preview/examples \\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec copy: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/33737ff460f78153f4cc21ef5d2d4586fcbae107/specification/containerservice/Fleet.Management/examples/2025-07-01-preview \\\\r\\\\nProcess is you update examples in TypeSpec copy, then run \\\\\\\"tsp compile\\\\\\\" which copies them to swagger folder \\\\r\\\\nYour TSV may have been failing, if you changed one copy but not the other \\\\r\\\\nSecond, you can generate examples manually or using `oav` , whatever you prefer, is more efficient for your workflow, etc \\\\r\\\\nIf you think you're hitting a bug in `oav`, you can open an issue here, or discuss in any of our teams channels. \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/oav/issues\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-arm-tips.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Migrate ARM spec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/checklists/migrate-arm-tips\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Migrate ARM spec\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n# migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-arm-tips.md\\\\n\\\\n# Migrate ARM spec\\\\n\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n\\\\nAzure extensible enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** reference `client.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** reference `back-compat.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations for ARM APIs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact only generated client SDKs in `client.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact both generated client SDKs and generated OpenAPI specs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** run `tsp compile .` on your specification and address all warnings\\\\n\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** name your ARM spec folder with `.Management` suffix.\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** configure your tspconfig.yaml. See: [example tspconfig.yaml][tspconfig]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** extend the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager` linter rule set in your tspconfig.yaml if not already there. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nlinter:\\\\r\\\\n  extends:\\\\r\\\\n    - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your `@service` and `@server` definitions are correct in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure `interface Operations extends Azure.ResourceManager.Operations {}` is in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your versions enum is up to date. For an initial migration we recommend migrating your latest stable API version (and the latest preview API version the service may support after the stable API version)\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure you have correct ARM common type version select with each service version. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  ...\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)  \\\\u003c---\\\\r\\\\n  v2021_10_01_preview: \\\\\\\"2021-10-01-preview\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review all enum definitions and add documentation over each value. See: [Documentation in TypeSpec][docs]\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** suppress documentation warnings\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the [standard Typespec Azure.ResourceManager and Azure.Core operation templates and data-types][standard-templates] wherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use `union` instead of `enum` to define Azure extensible enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_17.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"having trouble with examples not matching @pattern rules in github actions\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# having trouble with examples not matching @pattern rules in github actions\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_17.md\\\\n\\\\n# having trouble with examples not matching @pattern rules in github actions\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI think I'm doing something wrong when I generate my examples... what should i be doing? \\\\r\\\\nfor example this tsp:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel AcStorConfiguration is ExtensionResource\\\\u003cAcStorConfigurationProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    AcStorConfiguration,\\\\r\\\\n    NamePattern = \\\\\\\"^acstor-configuration$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthen:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\noav generate-examples ./specification/arccontainerstorage/resource-manager/Microsoft.ArcContainerStorage/preview/2024-10-01-preview/arccontainerstorage.json\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nand i run \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnpx prettier --write specification/arccontainerstorage/resource-manager/Microsoft.ArcContainerStorage/preview/2024-10-01-preview/examples/*  \\\\r\\\\n npx tsv specification/arccontainerstorage/ArcContainerStorage.Management    \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nexample github action failure:https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/23604/checks?check_run_id=46129519720\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nI think you need to manually update the auto-generated strings to satisfy the regexes.  \\\\r\\\\nmost of the errors, the example itself tells you to update the string: \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nGitHub Actions / [TEST-IGNORE] Swagger ModelValidation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nPATTERN: String does not match pattern ^acstor-configuration$: Replace this value with a string matching RegExp ^acstor-configuration$\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThis one is a little unusual, but I think just update the string to something that works, unless your spec is doing something unusual with this id property.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nGitHub Actions / [TEST-IGNORE] Swagger ModelValidation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nINVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format arm-id: gkbwmag\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExamples generation was written to produce a structure that you can update, but there is more work necessary to fully generate the placholders. It's just not been prioritized work unfortunately.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec-conversion\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n## Conversion process\\\\n### Identify the OpenAPI spec version to convert\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\\n\\\\n# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Conversion process\\\\n\\\\n### Identify the OpenAPI spec version to convert\\\\n\\\\nIt must be newest version for which SDKs have been generated, regardless of whether it was a stable or preview version.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n## Service Versioning Workflow\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2\\\\n\\\\n## Service Versioning Workflow\\\\n\\\\n**Current GA**  \\\\r\\\\n`api-version: 2019-12-01`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2193\\\\r\\\\n**Preview (Private/Public)**  \\\\r\\\\n`api-version: 2020-01-01-preview`\\\\r\\\\n- Each new preview requires a later YYYY-MM-DD\\\\r\\\\n  - Avoids breaking customers using old preview\\\\r\\\\n- When new preview releases, notify customers that previous preview retires in 90+ days\\\\r\\\\n- The preview period must not be \\\\u003e1 year\\\\r\\\\n\\u2193\\\\r\\\\n**New GA**  \\\\r\\\\n`api-version: 2020-05-01`\\\\r\\\\n- GA requires a later YYYY-MM-DD\\\\r\\\\n- When GA releases, notify customers that last preview retires in 90+ days\\\\r\\\\n- New GA should be compatible with previous GA\\\\r\\\\n  - If impossible, retire previous GA in 3+ years\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n## Implementation details\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n## Implementation details\\\\n\\\\nThe contents of this article is primarily derived from the following source code:\\\\r\\\\n- [`openapi-alps` repo] / `azure-rest-api-specs.yml` configs\\\\r\\\\n- [`openapi-alps` repo] / `requiredLabelRules.ts`\\\\r\\\\nAs such, if you find a discrepancy:\\\\r\\\\n1. The source code takes precedence.\\\\r\\\\n2. [Let us know](xref:support)!\\\\r\\\\n[#6509]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/6509\\\\r\\\\n[`openapi-alps` repo]: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_git/openapi-alps/\\\\r\\\\n[step 3 in the diagram]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/control_plane_template.md#pr-review-workflow-diagram\\\\r\\\\n[Breaking Change Board]: mailto:azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com\\\\r\\\\n[aka.ms/ci-fix]: https://aka.ms/ci-fix\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#clients#introduction.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Client Emitters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/introduction\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Client Emitters\\\\n## How to Use Emitters to Generate HTTP Clients from TypeSpec\\\\n### Introduction\\\\n# emitters#clients#introduction.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Client Emitters\\\\n\\\\n## How to Use Emitters to Generate HTTP Clients from TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n### Introduction\\\\n\\\\nThis guide will walk you through the process of using different client emitters (JavaScript, Python, Java, C#) to generate HTTP clients from TypeSpec. Please note that all client emitters are currently in **preview** and are subject to changes in future versions.\\\\r\\\\nBy following this guide, you will learn:\\\\r\\\\n1. How to set up client emitters in `package.json`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Update the client emitter configurations in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n3. How to generate HTTP clients for each specific programming language.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"SDK generation configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# SDK generation configuration\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-dp-tips.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Migrate data-plane specs\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/checklists/migrate-dp-tips\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Migrate data-plane specs\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n# migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-dp-tips.md\\\\n\\\\n# Migrate data-plane specs\\\\n\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n\\\\nwherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review model definitions and add the `@resource` decorator over models that represent resources in your service and the `@key` decorator for the resource identifier property on the model. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget name. */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"widgetName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget color. */\\\\r\\\\n  color: WidgetColor;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The ID of the widget's manufacturer. */\\\\r\\\\n  manufacturerId: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use `union` instead of `enum` to define Azure enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates from the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager` library in a data-plane specification\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** make client customizations in a `client.tsp` file\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in other files aside from client.tsp.\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** run `tsp compile .` on your specification and address all warnings\\\\n\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** configure your tspconfig.yaml. See: [example tspconfig.yaml][tspconfig]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** extend the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/data-plane` linter rule set in your tspconfig.yaml. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nlinter:\\\\r\\\\n  extends:\\\\r\\\\n    - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/data-plane\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your `@service` and `@server` definitions are correct in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the built-in [url][url-type] for endpoint specification. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"{endpoint}/widget\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget APIs\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    /**\\\\r\\\\n      * Supported Widget Services endpoints (protocol and hostname, for example:\\\\r\\\\n      * https://westus.api.widget.contoso.com).\\\\r\\\\n      */\\\\r\\\\n    endpoint: url,\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure that you have a security definition (`@useAuth`) specified for your service. See: [Security definitions in TypeSpec][security-definitions]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure you have versioning (`@versioned`) enabled over your service definition. See: [Versioning][versioning]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your versions enum is up to date. For an initial migration we recommend migrating your latest stable API version (and the latest preview API version the service may support after the stable API version)\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review all enum definitions and add documentation over each value. See: [Documentation in TypeSpec][docs]\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** suppress documentation warnings\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the [standard Typespec Azure operation templates and data-types][standard-templates] wherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review model definitions and add the `@resource` decorator over models that represent resources in your service and the `@key` decorator for the resource identifier property on the model. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget name. */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"widgetName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget color. */\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n# Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md\\\\n\\\\n# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml\\\\n\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n       output-file: \\\\\\\"{version-status}/{version}/DynamicSessions.json\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n3. **Common-types references** - Update relative paths in JSON files:\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n   // Before (in ContainerApps.json)\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#/parameters/SubscriptionIdParameter\\\\\\\"   \\\\r\\\\n   // After  \\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"../../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#/parameters/SubscriptionIdParameter\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   Fpr mgmt plane TypeSpec, we also need to specify the `arm-common-types` in tspconfig options of `@azure-tools/typespec-autorest`.\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n   options:\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       arm-types-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}/../../../../common-types/resource-management\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n4. **Suppressions.yaml** - Update paths in suppressions:\\\\r\\\\nAs GitHub recognize this refactor change as to add new API versions in the OpenAPI folder, in order to make sure the TypeSpec requirement check pass. we need to have a suppressions.yaml under serviceName folder \\\\r\\\\nand add suppression one by one like this \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: ./preview/2022-01-01-preview/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecRequirement\\\\r\\\\n  path: ./stable/2025-01-01/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## The impact to ongoing PRs\\\\n\\\\n1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to a release-* or dev-* branch which are not created or syncing from the latest main, we recommend to merge these PRs first.\\\\r\\\\n1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to public main branch, Here's the suggestion to resolve the conflict. \\\\r\\\\n      1. Merge latest main \\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n          git checkout main\\\\r\\\\n          git pull origin main // origin points to Azure rest api specs repo.\\\\r\\\\n          git merge main \\\\u003cyour-pr-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n      2. Resolve conflicts  \\\\r\\\\n        - For most of the conflicts, accept the incoming changes.  \\\\r\\\\n        - If it's unclear, please accept both and then update based on your judgement with the folder structure changes above.  \\\\r\\\\n      3. Make sure the new change is aligned with folder structure v2  \\\\r\\\\n         There are some cases where the PR is adding a new version in the original location, but the file diffs don't show as conflict. we should move them into the correct place so that it doesn't break the folder structure v2 as instructions in **Understanding Folder Migration sections** \\\\r\\\\n      4. clean up the previous folder if exists.  \\\\r\\\\n**Important**: It's strongly recommended to understand what's really changed in the folder refactor. Always ensure the new PR doesn't include any things that breaks the folder structure.\\\\n\\\\n### After Resolution\\\\n\\\\nMake sure to compile the TypeSpec project so that the TypeSpec Validation could pass.\\\\r\\\\n1. **Comprehensive validation**:\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#intro_tsp_client.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Usage\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-with-tsp-client/intro_tsp_client\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Usage\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n# howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#intro_tsp_client.md\\\\n\\\\n# Usage\\\\n\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n\\\\nUsers working with a repository that already accepts this tool can continue to the [Usage](#usage) section.\\\\r\\\\nRepo owners should follow the steps in the [tsp-client repo setup](./repo_setup.md) doc.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"SDK generation configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# SDK generation configuration\\\\n# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\nTo generate SDK code based on REST API specifications, you need to configure the corresponding files.\\\\r\\\\n- For TypeSpec, the configuration file is `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n- For OpenAPI, the configuration file is `readme.md`.\\\\n\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e[!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## CSharp\\\\n\\\\nSee configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\nFor more samples on configuring specific `readme.{language}.md`, refer to:\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Management Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles)\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Data Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles-dp)\\\\r\\\\n- [Config SDK Guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/code-gen)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n## An Azure Resource Provider and its 1+ Azure Services\\\\n# Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n\\\\n## An Azure Resource Provider and its 1+ Azure Services\\\\n\\\\nIf 2+ services want to \\u201cshare\\u201d some TypeSpec/OpenAPI files, these files must be explicitly copied into a consuming service\\u2019s folder on its desired timeline. We do not allow multiple services to reference a single copy of a service contract because it is too dangerous to allow one service to change a shared contract, forcing other services to pick up this shared contract instantly, especially if the shared contract introduces breaking changes. Each service must be in control of its own destiny.\\\\r\\\\n4.\\\\tThe ServiceName folder must have examples, preview and stable subfolders. Additional subfolders are allowed to help organize *.tsp files. The rules should ensure that only the tspconfig.yaml  and *.tsp files are in the ServiceName folder.  \\\\r\\\\n5.\\\\tThe examples folder should only have a subfolder for each api-version and each api-version folder can contain only example *.json files for this api-version.\\\\r\\\\n6.\\\\tThe preview and stable folders must only have subfolders whose name match this format: YYYY-MM-DD-preview in the preview folder and YYYY-MM-DD in the stable folder. All the files in the YYYY-MM-DD(-preview) folders must be json (OpenAPI) files.\\\\r\\\\n7.\\\\tEach YYYY-MM-DD(-preview) folder must have an examples folder containing only example *.json files for this api-version.\\\\r\\\\n8.\\\\tIt is illegal for a preview and GA version to share the same date. For example, if there is a 2024-04-01-preview, then there can never be a 2024-04-01 GA.\\\\r\\\\n9. Each new control plane api-version should be unique across all the control plane service folders for an RP Namespace. \\\\r\\\\n10.\\\\tEach service name folder must duplicate the special \\\\\\\"list operations\\\\\\\" API. \\\\r\\\\n    - While this RP (not service) operation requires an api-version query parameter, the response data is not specific to this api-version; the response is api-version neutral. In addition, the response is always the same regardless of tenant/subscription.\\\\n\\\\nA single Azure Resource Provider (RP) has an RP namespace. This RP namespace can contain 1+ control-plane services and 0+ data-plane service; each service versions as described above. Today, we want the GitHub specs repo to be structured as follows for control-plane \\\\u0026 data-plane contracts:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/\\\\r\\\\n\\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003corgName1\\\\u003e/\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 cspell.yaml\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 resource-manager/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df NOTE: For ARM schema validation; see bullet #2 below\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cRPNamespace\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df NOTE: Control-plane only (not data-plane) \\\\r\\\\n            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName1\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df Customer-facing service name; each version gets Documentation \\\\u0026 SDK package\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 tspconfig.yaml\\\\t\\u00df TypeSpec files\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 models.tsp\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df autorest readme with YAML blocks\\\\r\\\\n                \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 examples/\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df TypeSpec example folder\\\\r\\\\n                    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df One folder per service version described in TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cexample .json files\\\\u003e \\\\r\\\\n                \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 preview/ and stable/\\\\r\\\\n                    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df One folder per service version described in OpenAPI. These folders are created and populated by compiling the TypeSpec folder for the service.\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cOpenAPI .json files\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 examples/\\\\t\\u00df OpenAPI example folder\\\\r\\\\n                            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cexample .json files\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName2\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 data-plane/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName3\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this structure, Azure services are presented as an RPNamespace that is used to manage services (both with customer-facing names). Each service has versions (some preview and some GA) and each version has its own API contract, documentation, and (beta/stable) SDK package(s).\\\\n\\\\nthere can never be a 2024-04-01 GA.\\\\r\\\\n9. Each new control plane api-version should be unique across all the control plane service folders for an RP Namespace. \\\\r\\\\n10.\\\\tEach service name folder must duplicate the special \\\\\\\"list operations\\\\\\\" API. \\\\r\\\\n    - While this RP (not service) operation requires an api-version query parameter, the response data is not specific to this api-version; the response is api-version neutral. In addition, the response is always the same regardless of tenant/subscription. Whenever any other service in the RP gets a new api-version, the TypeSpec/OpenAPI for the operations service must also be updated to match this new api-version.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003cServiceName2\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 data-plane/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName3\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this structure, Azure services are presented as an RPNamespace that is used to manage services (both with customer-facing names). Each service has versions (some preview and some GA) and each version has its own API contract, documentation, and (beta/stable) SDK package(s).   \\\\r\\\\nTo enforce these rules, here are some notes about the repo structure:\\\\r\\\\n1.\\\\tIn the resource-manager folder, if it's a RPaaS service, there must be just 1 readme.md file, and 1+ service name folders under resource-manager/RPnamespace folder, but the resource types within each service folder must not duplicate except for operations, locations, checkNameAvailability etc. Which is required by RPaaS for HTTP request schema validation.\\\\r\\\\n2.\\\\tIn the data-plane folder there must be no files and at least 1 service name folder.\\\\r\\\\n3.\\\\tThe ServiceName folder must have only readme.*, tspconfig.yaml and *.tsp files in it. \\\\r\\\\n    - In the readme.md file, the latest package tag value (which represents a service version) must refer to OpenAPI files that are all in the exact same folder. Also, if the tag value is suffixed with \\u201c-preview\\u201d then all the OpenAPI paths must refer to files in the preview subfolder; else all OpenAPI paths must refer to files in the stable subfolder.\\\\r\\\\n    - If 2+ services want to \\u201cshare\\u201d some TypeSpec/OpenAPI files, these files must be explicitly copied into a consuming service\\u2019s folder on its desired timeline. We do not allow multiple services to reference a single copy of a service contract because it is too dangerous to allow one service to change a shared contract, forcing other services to pick up this shared contract instantly, especially if the shared contract introduces breaking changes. Each service must be in control of its own destiny.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"good\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# good\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# good\\\\n\\\\n- path: data-plane/Azure.Contoso.WidgetManager/preview/2022-11-01-preview/**/*.json\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such responses.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#code-generation-javascript.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Getting started with TypeSpec server code generation for JavaScript\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/code-generation-javascript\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Getting started with TypeSpec server code generation for JavaScript\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n# getting-started#code-generation-javascript.md\\\\n\\\\n# Getting started with TypeSpec server code generation for JavaScript\\\\n\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n\\\\n- Node.js and NPM (required for both TypeSpec and JavaScript server code generation)\\\\r\\\\n- Basic familiarity with TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\n- Basic knowledge of JavaScript/TypeScript and Express.js\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec-conversion\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n## Conversion scope\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec-conversion.md\\\\n\\\\n# Convert OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Conversion scope\\\\n\\\\n- Horizontal conversion: Converting existing Azure OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec should not introduce any changes to the API.\\\\r\\\\n- No version revving: No version revving will occur during this process. The focus is solely on converting the existing\\\\r\\\\nspecifications to TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n- SDKs generated for validation only: The SDKs generated from the converted TypeSpec files will be used for validation\\\\r\\\\npurposes only. They are not intended for production release.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"SDK-Validation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Table of Contents\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/SDK-Validation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Table of Contents\\\\n## Common Error Fix Guidance\\\\n### Import Resolution Errors\\\\n# SDK-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Table of Contents\\\\n\\\\n## Common Error Fix Guidance\\\\n\\\\n### Import Resolution Errors\\\\n\\\\n#### Error Pattern: `import-not-found`\\\\r\\\\n**Error Message Pattern**: `error import-not-found: Couldn't resolve import '[.*].tsp'`\\\\r\\\\n**Root Cause**: The folder containing the imported TypeSpec files is not specified in the `tspconfig.yaml` file's `additionalDirectories` setting.\\\\r\\\\n**Solution Steps**:\\\\r\\\\n1. Locate the `tspconfig.yaml` file in your TypeSpec project root\\\\r\\\\n2. Find the `additionalDirectories` array in the configuration\\\\r\\\\n3. Add the path to the folder containing the imported `.tsp` files\\\\r\\\\n4. Allowed values: `true`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Validation Rule Suppression\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n# TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n\\\\nIf you only need to bypass validation for **specific** emitter options or parameters, you can suppress individual sub-rules.\\\\r\\\\nAdd or update your `suppressions.yaml` file with the following structure, specifying the sub-rules to ignore:\\\\r\\\\nSub-rule Syntax:\\\\r\\\\n- For parameters: `parameters.\\\\u003cparameter-key\\\\u003e.default`\\\\r\\\\n- For emitter options: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003coption-key\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- For nested options (e.g., `package-details: name: \\\\\\\"xxx\\\\\\\"`), use dot notation: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific parameter's default value\\\\r\\\\n    - parameters.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e.default \\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a nested emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"For ARM (management-plane) APIs in private preview, SDK generation is NOT required for API approval. Azure guidelines explicitly state that private preview versions do not require corresponding SDK package versions, and there are no SDK support requirements at this stage. You can safely proceed without SDK emitter configuration in your tspconfig.yaml.\\n\\nHowever, the TypeSpec validation system expects certain emitter options to be present in tspconfig.yaml, even if you do not intend to generate SDKs. If you remove these options, you may encounter validation failures (e.g., SdkTspConfigValidation errors).\\n\\nTo resolve this, you have two options:\\n\\n1. **Suppress SDK validation rules for emitters you do not support**: Add a suppressions.yaml file in your service folder and explicitly suppress the relevant SdkTspConfigValidation sub-rules for each SDK emitter you do not support (e.g., Go, Java, .NET, JS). Example:\\n\\n```yaml\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\n  paths:\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\n  rules:\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\n  sub-rules:\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\n    # Add similar lines for other emitters as needed\\n  reason: 'No SDK required for private preview.'\\n```\\n\\n2. **(Not recommended) Add minimal emitter options**: You could add placeholder emitter options for each required SDK emitter, but this is discouraged if you do not intend to generate SDKs.\\n\\n**Best Practice:** Use suppressions.yaml to bypass SDK validation for emitters not in scope. This is the recommended approach for private preview ARM APIs.\\n\\nWhen you are ready to onboard SDK generation (e.g., for public preview or GA), you should add the appropriate emitter options to tspconfig.yaml following the Azure SDK guidelines.\\n\\nSummary: API approval for private preview does NOT require SDK generation. Use suppressions.yaml to pass TypeSpec validation without SDK emitter configs.\", \"ground_truth\": \"API approval for private preview does NOT always require SDK generation or SDK configuration in your tspconfig.yaml. For private preview ARM APIs, it is acceptable to onboard and validate your API contract without including SDK emitter settings (such as for Go, Python, Java, etc.).\\n\\nHowever, the Azure TypeSpec validation tooling (tsv) is configured to expect certain SDK emitter options in tspconfig.yaml by default, even for private preview, which is why you see SdkTspConfigValidation failures if you remove them.\\n\\nThe correct and supported approach is:\\n- Remove SDK emitter configs you do NOT want in your tspconfig.yaml.\\n- Add a suppressions.yaml file in the same directory as tspconfig.yaml to explicitly suppress the SdkTspConfigValidation rule (or specific sub-rules for missing SDK configs).\\n\\nHere is a sample suppressions.yaml to suppress all SdkTspConfigValidation checks (recommended for your scenario):\\n\\n```yaml\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\n  paths:\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\n  rules:\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\n  reason: 'SDK generation is not in scope for private preview onboarding.'\\n```\\n\\nPlace this suppressions.yaml alongside your tspconfig.yaml. This will allow CI and local validation to succeed without requiring SDK settings, letting you focus on API review and onboarding. When you later want to add SDK support, you can remove the suppression and add the required SDK emitter configuration.\\n\\nIn summary: No, API approval for private preview does not require SDK generation. Use suppressions.yaml to bypass SDK validation in tspconfig.yaml until you are ready to onboard SDKs.\"}"}]

```yml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
```

actual.answer:
Your TypeSpec validation is failing because the validation pipeline is enforcing the presence of Go SDK emitter configuration options in your `tspconfig.yaml`, even though your service does not require a Go SDK. This is due to the `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule, which checks for required emitter options for all supported SDK languages.

Since you do not plan to support a Go SDK for your service, the correct and supported approach is to suppress the specific Go-related validation sub-rules. You should not add dummy or placeholder Go configuration options if you are not generating a Go SDK.

To resolve this, add a `suppressions.yaml` file (or update your existing one) at the root of your service specification folder with the following content:

```yaml
- tool: TypeSpecValidation
  paths:
    - tspconfig.yaml
  rules:
    - SdkTspConfigValidation
  sub-rules:
    # Suppress validation for Go emitter options
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir
    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir
  reason: 'This service does not support a Go SDK currently.'
```

This will suppress only the Go-specific configuration checks and allow your PR to pass TypeSpec validation, while remaining compliant with Azure API guidelines. Make sure to commit this file with your PR.

If you later decide to support a Go SDK, you must remove these suppressions and add the required Go emitter options to your `tspconfig.yaml`.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\n\\nquestion: Hi TypeSpec Discussion,\\nCI has been failing constantly for our PR ([Azure Load Testing\\\\] Add 2025-03-01-preview Data-Plane APIs by Harshan01 \\u00b7 Pull Request #32585 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32585)) for Typespec Validation step. The logs show that we are missing the Go SDK configuration and I am able to produce this error locally as well. However, our service doesnt have a Go SDK and we are not planning to put it in scope right now. This check has suddenly started failing for our PRs, what should we do?\\n```\\nExecuting rule\\uff1aSdkTspConfigVa1idation\\n[SdkTspconfigVa1idation]\\uff1avalidation failed\\uff0e\\n- Failed to find \\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\".\\n- Failed to find \\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans\\u201c\\uff0ePlease add \\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans.\\n- Failed to find \\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\".\\n- Failed to find \\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\"\\uff0ePlease add\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\".\\nPlease See https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info\\uff0e\\nFor additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation.\\n```\", \"response\": \"Your TypeSpec validation is failing because the validation pipeline is enforcing the presence of Go SDK emitter configuration options in your `tspconfig.yaml`, even though your service does not require a Go SDK. This is due to the `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule, which checks for required emitter options for all supported SDK languages.\\n\\nSince you do not plan to support a Go SDK for your service, the correct and supported approach is to suppress the specific Go-related validation sub-rules. You should not add dummy or placeholder Go configuration options if you are not generating a Go SDK.\\n\\nTo resolve this, add a `suppressions.yaml` file (or update your existing one) at the root of your service specification folder with the following content:\\n\\n```yaml\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\n  paths:\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\n  rules:\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\n  sub-rules:\\n    # Suppress validation for Go emitter options\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\n  reason: 'This service does not support a Go SDK currently.'\\n```\\n\\nThis will suppress only the Go-specific configuration checks and allow your PR to pass TypeSpec validation, while remaining compliant with Azure API guidelines. Make sure to commit this file with your PR.\\n\\nIf you later decide to support a Go SDK, you must remove these suppressions and add the required Go emitter options to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\", \"ground_truth\": \"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#suppressing-sdktspconfigvalidation-rules\\nSuppressing go specific rules worked for me. Here's our suppression file:\\n```yml\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\npaths:\\n- tspconfig.yaml\\nrules:\\n- SdkTspConfigValidation\\nsub-rules:\\n- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\n- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans\\n- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\n- options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\nreason: 'Azure Load Testing does not support a Go SDK currently'\\n```\"}"}]

following structure. See the [next section](#typespec-configuration-options) for details on each option.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel TypeSpecProjectSchema {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  parameters?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `environment-variables`?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `warn-as-error`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  `output-dir`?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  `trace`?: string | string[];\\\\r\\\\n  imports?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  emit?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  `dry-run`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  options?: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  linter?: LinterConfig;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel LinterConfig {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: RuleRef[];\\\\r\\\\n  enable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, boolean\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  disable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, string\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Extending Project Files\\\\n\\\\nThere may be instances where you want to build different folders with varying options (such as different emitters), but still want to share some common configurations.\\\\r\\\\nIn such cases, you can use the `extends` property in the configuration file.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, in `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/tspconfig.yaml`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    some-option: my-name\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    some-other-option: This is a title\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nin `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/proj2/tspconfig.yaml`, enable `emitter1` using the options specified in the parent `tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=proj2/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### What gets extended\\\\r\\\\nThe extending logic follows these rules:\\\\r\\\\n- **Root-level properties**: Shallow merge for all properties except `options`\\\\r\\\\n- **Options property**: Deep merge at one level (per emitter)\\\\r\\\\n- **Override behavior**: Properties specified in the extending file will completely override those from the extended file\\\\r\\\\n**Root-level merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nWhen extending a configuration, most properties (like `emit`, `imports`, `trace`, etc.) are merged at the root level. If the same property exists in both files, the extending file's value completely replaces the extended file's value.\\\\r\\\\n**Options merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nThe `options` property receives special treatment with a one-level deep merge:\\\\r\\\\n- Different emitters from both files are combined\\\\r\\\\n- If the same emitter is configured in both files, the extending file's emitter configuration completely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\n\\\\ncompletely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:   # Completely replaces emitter1 options\\\\r\\\\n    option-c: value-c\\\\r\\\\n  emitter3:   # Added alongside emitter2 from parent\\\\r\\\\n    option-y: value-y\\\\r\\\\n// Resulting merged config:\\\\r\\\\n// emit: [emitter3]  # Only emitter3, emitter1 is gone\\\\r\\\\n// options:\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter1: { option-c: value-c }  # Only option-c, option-a and option-b are gone\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter2: { option-x: value-x }  # Inherited from parent\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter3: { option-y: value-y }  # From extending config\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Variable interpolation\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec project file provides variable interpolation using:\\\\r\\\\n- built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n- environment variables\\\\r\\\\n- config file parameters\\\\r\\\\n- emitter options can reference each other\\\\r\\\\nVariable interpolation is done using an variable expression surrounded by `{` and `}`. (`{\\\\u003cexpression\\\\u003e}`)\\\\r\\\\nExamples:\\\\r\\\\n- `{output-dir}/my-path`\\\\r\\\\n- `{env.SHARED_PATH}/my-path`\\\\n\\\\n### Interpolation of Emitter Path Config\\\\n\\\\nemitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\r\\\\nParameters can be organized in a nested structure, to access different levels of the structure, use dots (`.`) in the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nTherefore, parameter names should not contain `.` in their name.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be utilized in the default value of these parameters.\\\\r\\\\nThese parameters can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression.\\\\r\\\\nAll parameters must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nparameters:\\\\r\\\\n  base-dir:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {base-dir}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe parameter can then be specified via `--arg` in this format `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"` and for nested structures `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-parameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\ntsp compile . --arg \\\\\\\"base-dir=/path/to/base\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Environment variables\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can specify which environment variables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\n\\\\nCertain emitter configurations can be interpolated using a specific rule designed to collapse a path.\\\\r\\\\nIf a variable is succeeded by a `/` or `.` and the emitter responsible for interpolating the config doesn't supply that variable, the path segment will be omitted.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, consider the following config value: `{service-name}/output.{version}.json`\\\\r\\\\nHere's what would be produced:\\\\r\\\\n| Service name value | Version value | Result                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------ | ------------- | ------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `\\\\\\\"v1\\\\\\\"`        | `PetStore/output.v1.json` |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `undefined`   | `PetStore/output.json`    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n| Variable name              | Scope                    | Description                                                                          |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------------- | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| `cwd`                      | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the current working directory                                              |\\\\r\\\\n| `project-root`             | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the the tspconfig.yaml file containing folder.                             |\\\\r\\\\n| `output-dir`               | emitter options          | Common `output-dir` See [output-dir](#output-dir---configure-the-default-output-dir) |\\\\r\\\\n| `emitter-name`             | emitter options          | Name of the emitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\n\\\\nvariables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options can refer to each other by using the other option's name as the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nInterpolation is only possible among emitter options from the same emitter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  @typespec/openapi3:\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: {output-dir}/{emitter-sub-folder}\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options support a nested structure, enabling complex configurations.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter-sub-folder:\\\\r\\\\n    sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo set these values via the CLI, use dots to navigate deeper levels in the definition. `--option \\\\\\\"\\\\u003coption-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-option-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\nDue to this capability, emitter option names should not contain a `.` in their name.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"error duplicate-property Simply mention `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` directly in your  \\\\r\\\\nmessage with a clear description of the problem you're facing.\\\\r\\\\n**Example usage:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot: How can I describe HTTP status codes for responses in TypeSpec?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Best practices for using the bot:**\\\\r\\\\n- Start a conversation by mentioning `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` in the TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel - note that  \\\\r\\\\n  modifying existing posts won't trigger a response\\\\r\\\\n- The bot only has context from messages that directly mention it and cannot access or see messages outside of that  \\\\r\\\\n  context\\\\r\\\\n- It supports images and GitHub pull request links for better context\\\\r\\\\n- All replies are generated by AI, so please double-check to ensure the information is correct\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a bug in typespec-azure:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/383.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see the issue above for the suggested workaround and apply it directly to the spec TypeSpec sources.  The LintDiff error should **not** be ignored or suppressed.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"SDK generation configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# SDK generation configuration\\\\n# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\nTo generate SDK code based on REST API specifications, you need to configure the corresponding files.\\\\r\\\\n- For TypeSpec, the configuration file is `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n- For OpenAPI, the configuration file is `readme.md`.\\\\n\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e[!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## CSharp\\\\n\\\\nSee configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\nFor more samples on configuring specific `readme.{language}.md`, refer to:\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Management Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles)\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Data Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles-dp)\\\\r\\\\n- [Config SDK Guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/code-gen)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousTypes`\\\\n### `LongRunningResourceAction`\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousTypes`\\\\n\\\\n### `LongRunningResourceAction`\\\\n\\\\nThere is a known issue where `LongRunningResourceAction` in TypeSpec, generates swagger that causes `AvoidAnonymousTypes`. Suppression\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n# TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n\\\\nYou can suppress specific validation rules within `TypeSpecValidation` by creating or modifying a `suppressions.yaml` file in the root directory of your service specification.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Note:** Currently, only the `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule supports suppression.\\\\n\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n\\\\nThe `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule is responsible for validating emitter options and parameters defined in your `tspconfig.yaml` file. You have the flexibility to suppress this rule entirely or target specific sub-rules within it.\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress the Entire SdkTspConfigValidation Rule\\\\n\\\\nIf you need to skip **all** validation checks for emitter options and parameters within a particular `tspconfig.yaml` file, you can suppress the entire `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule.\\\\r\\\\nTo do this, add or update the `suppressions.yaml` file in your service's root folder with the following content:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n\\\\nIf you only need to bypass validation for **specific** emitter options or parameters, you can suppress individual sub-rules.\\\\r\\\\nAdd or update your `suppressions.yaml` file with the following structure, specifying the sub-rules to ignore:\\\\r\\\\nSub-rule Syntax:\\\\r\\\\n- For parameters: `parameters.\\\\u003cparameter-key\\\\u003e.default`\\\\r\\\\n- For emitter options: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003coption-key\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- For nested options (e.g., `package-details: name: \\\\\\\"xxx\\\\\\\"`), use dot notation: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific parameter's default value\\\\r\\\\n    - parameters.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e.default \\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a nested emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name \\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/configuration/configuration\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Configuration\\\\n## TypeSpec Configuration Options\\\\n### `output-dir` - Configure the default output dir\\\\n# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Configuration\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec Configuration Options\\\\n\\\\n### `output-dir` - Configure the default output dir\\\\n\\\\nSpecify the common output-dir for all emitters. See [this](#configuring-output-directory) to configure per emitter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {cwd}/typespec-build\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOutput dir can be provided using the `--output-dir` cli flag\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\ntsp compile . --output-dir \\\\\\\"./typespec-build\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOutput dir must be an absolute path in the config. Use `{cwd}` or `{project-root}` to explicitly specify what it should be relative to.\\\\r\\\\nSee [output directory configuration for mode details](#configuring-output-directory)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nWe had PR in flight: [Adding stable 2025 08 01 for completeness by risraj10 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37381 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37381)\\\\r\\\\nHowever, I see that TypeSpec migration was done couple of days ago for this folder. \\\\r\\\\nI have cancelled the above PR and trying to raise a new PR. However, just running npx tsp compile without any change is giving errors.\\\\r\\\\nAnd also it is making unintended change to OpenAPI json file even to existing version. I guess the tsp and OpenAPI json are not in sync.\\\\r\\\\nHence, wanted to check if the migration is really complete for this folder.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nMain typespec validation should always be passing are you sure you are up you are with dependencies locally?\\\\r\\\\nMake sure to follow instructions here https://aka.ms/ci-fix\\\\r\\\\nJust to reiterate, this is almost always because you need to pull the latest from the target branch into your local clone of the repo, and re-install dependencies at the root.\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n## suppressions.yaml\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# Suppress validation failures on a PR\\\\n\\\\n## suppressions.yaml\\\\n\\\\nFile `suppressions.yaml` is used for all checks created in 2024 or later, like\\\\r\\\\n`TypeSpec Requirement` and `TypeSpec Validation`.\\\\r\\\\nFor simplicity, we recommend adding all suppressions to a single file at the root of your spec folder:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/myservice/suppressions.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, you can use multiple files in separate folders.  Currently, tools will use the first\\\\r\\\\ninstance of `suppressions.yaml` found walking up the directory tree.  We are planning\\\\r\\\\nfuture support for \\\\\\\"merging\\\\\\\" files up the hierarchy.\\\\r\\\\nA suppression follows this general format:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: ToolName\\\\r\\\\n  path: applies/to/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Why this can't be fixed\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`path` uses \\\\\\\"glob\\\\\\\" matching.
