testcase: Conflicting @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi and missing-x-ms-identifiers errors

expected.answer:
You should NOT use @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]) in your Azure Resource Manager TypeSpec code. The no-openapi rule is strict: ARM specs must NOT use decorators from @typespec/openapi or @azure-tools/typespec-autorest, including $extension, because these are only processed by OpenAPI emitters and will break other emitters (like client SDKs).
For array properties, the correct approach is to use the @identifiers decorator from @azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager. This decorator is the ARM-compliant way to specify identifying properties for array items and will ensure that x-ms-identifiers is emitted in the generated OpenAPI as needed, without violating the no-openapi rule. If there are no identifying properties, you can use @identifiers([]) to indicate this.
Example:
```
@identifiers([])
myArrayField: MyItemType[];
```
If you use @identifiers, the ARM linter will recognize the array is correctly specified and will not require you to use the OpenAPI extension directly.
You should only suppress the error if you have a legitimate, ARM-approved reason (for example, for backwards compatibility or an explicit reviewer exemption). But for new fields and normal scenarios, always use the ARM-compliant decorators, NOT OpenAPI extensions.
Summary:
DO NOT use @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]) in ARM specs.
DO use @identifiers([]) or @identifiers(["propertyName"]) as appropriate for array items.
Suppression should only be used in rare, reviewer-approved cases, not as a general workaround.
This approach ensures your spec is future-proof, passes all ARM validation, and is compliant with Azure API guidelines.

actual.answer:
You should NOT use @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", #[]) directly in Azure management-plane TypeSpec specs. The use of OpenAPI decorators is explicitly forbidden by the Azure API guidelines, as these decorators are only interpreted by the OpenAPI emitter and break compatibility with other emitters and tooling. Instead, you must use the @identifiers decorator from the Azure Resource Manager TypeSpec library to specify identifying properties for array items. For example:

```typespec
model ResourceProperties {
  @identifiers(#[])
  array: Address[];
}
```

If there are no identifying properties, you should pass an empty array to @identifiers. This will satisfy the missing-x-ms-identifiers rule and avoid the no-openapi error. Do NOT suppress these errors unless you have a documented, reviewed justification and have discussed with your ARM reviewer. The correct, permanent fix is to use @identifiers, not @OpenAPI.extension.

If you are using an older TypeSpec version or emitter that does not support @identifiers, you should update your TypeSpec packages to the latest versions as specified in the azure-rest-api-specs repo. This will ensure that your spec is compliant and future-proof.

Summary:
- Use @identifiers, NOT @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-identifiers", ...)
- Do NOT suppress unless absolutely necessary and reviewed
- Update your TypeSpec packages if needed

This approach resolves both errors according to Azure guidelines and ensures your spec is valid for all emitters.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Conflicting @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi and missing-x-ms-identifiers errors\\n\\nquestion: I have this PR: [Release aks fleet 2025 08 01 preview rebase 5 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs@432d36e](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/actions/runs/19480146348/job/55749960774?pr=38867#step:4:527) which has recently starting failing Typespec validation due to two errors.\\nFor my new array fields, if I do not include a decorator such as @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[<prop>])\\nto the array, I get this error:\\n```\\nerror @azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager/missing-x-ms-identifiers: Missing identifying properties of objects in the array item, please add @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[<prop>]) to specify it. If there are no appropriate identifying properties, please add @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[]).\\n```\\nHowever, if I add that decorator, I receive this error:\\n```\\nerror @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi: Azure specs should not be using decorator \\\"$extension\\\" from @typespec/openapi or @azure-tools/typespec-autorest. They will not apply to other emitter.\\n> 28 |   @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[])\\n```\\nIs there an intermediary solution to resolve both of these conflicts or is it best to suppress these errors?\", \"response\": \"You should NOT use @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[]) directly in Azure management-plane TypeSpec specs. The use of OpenAPI decorators is explicitly forbidden by the Azure API guidelines, as these decorators are only interpreted by the OpenAPI emitter and break compatibility with other emitters and tooling. Instead, you must use the @identifiers decorator from the Azure Resource Manager TypeSpec library to specify identifying properties for array items. For example:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel ResourceProperties {\\n  @identifiers(#[])\\n  array: Address[];\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIf there are no identifying properties, you should pass an empty array to @identifiers. This will satisfy the missing-x-ms-identifiers rule and avoid the no-openapi error. Do NOT suppress these errors unless you have a documented, reviewed justification and have discussed with your ARM reviewer. The correct, permanent fix is to use @identifiers, not @OpenAPI.extension.\\n\\nIf you are using an older TypeSpec version or emitter that does not support @identifiers, you should update your TypeSpec packages to the latest versions as specified in the azure-rest-api-specs repo. This will ensure that your spec is compliant and future-proof.\\n\\nSummary:\\n- Use @identifiers, NOT @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", ...)\\n- Do NOT suppress unless absolutely necessary and reviewed\\n- Update your TypeSpec packages if needed\\n\\nThis approach resolves both errors according to Azure guidelines and ensures your spec is valid for all emitters.\", \"ground_truth\": \"You should NOT use @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[]) in your Azure Resource Manager TypeSpec code. The no-openapi rule is strict: ARM specs must NOT use decorators from @typespec/openapi or @azure-tools/typespec-autorest, including $extension, because these are only processed by OpenAPI emitters and will break other emitters (like client SDKs).\\nFor array properties, the correct approach is to use the @identifiers decorator from @azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager. This decorator is the ARM-compliant way to specify identifying properties for array items and will ensure that x-ms-identifiers is emitted in the generated OpenAPI as needed, without violating the no-openapi rule. If there are no identifying properties, you can use @identifiers([]) to indicate this.\\nExample:\\n```\\n@identifiers([])\\nmyArrayField: MyItemType[];\\n```\\nIf you use @identifiers, the ARM linter will recognize the array is correctly specified and will not require you to use the OpenAPI extension directly.\\nYou should only suppress the error if you have a legitimate, ARM-approved reason (for example, for backwards compatibility or an explicit reviewer exemption). But for new fields and normal scenarios, always use the ARM-compliant decorators, NOT OpenAPI extensions.\\nSummary:\\nDO NOT use @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[]) in ARM specs.\\nDO use @identifiers([]) or @identifiers([\\\"propertyName\\\"]) as appropriate for array items.\\nSuppression should only be used in rare, reviewer-approved cases, not as a general workaround.\\nThis approach ensures your spec is future-proof, passes all ARM validation, and is compliant with Azure API guidelines.\"}"}]

Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"troubleshoot#suppresswarnings.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to suppress warnings\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/troubleshoot/suppresswarnings\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to suppress warnings\\\\n## Workaround\\\\n# troubleshoot#suppresswarnings.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to suppress warnings\\\\n\\\\n## Workaround\\\\n\\\\nSome of the rules after review can be suppressed to get clean compile outputs using `#suppress ErrCode ReasonMsg` statement. The error code is the string reported in compiler output.\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n//suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-providerhub/no-identifier-property-in-array-item\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"Error items have no unique identifier.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n/** An array of details about specific errors that led to this reported error. */\\\\r\\\\ndetails: Error[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Missing x-ms-request-id field\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Missing x-ms-request-id field\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md\\\\n\\\\n# Missing x-ms-request-id field\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nSome newly generated swaggers may be missing the \\\\\\\"x-ms-request-id\\\\\\\" field\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"responses\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"200\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"ignore\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"schema\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/RestoreResult\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n-       }\\\\r\\\\n-       \\\\\\\"headers\\\\\\\":{\\\\r\\\\n-           \\\\\\\"x-ms-request-id\\\\\\\":{\\\\r\\\\n-               \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n-               \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"A unique ID for the current operation, service generated. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n# Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n\\\\n1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.\\\\r\\\\n2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.\\\\r\\\\n3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.\\\\r\\\\n   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Generating basic examples and then manually modify the values. It will generate two examples for each operation:\\\\r\\\\n    one contains minimal properties set, the other contains the maximal properties set. Since the auto-generated\\\\r\\\\n     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n       oav generate-examples openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. However, if you are generating the examples manually,\\\\r\\\\n     please ensure you have:\\\\r\\\\n    - include `title` field and make sure it is descriptive and unique for each operation.\\\\r\\\\n    - include `operationId`. This is used to match with declared operations in TypeSpec and correctly output in OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\n4. Add/update the `readme.md` file in the `{service}` folder to specify the version and location of the OpenAPI files. The `readme.md` is needed for both management-plane and data-plane services for REST API Docs generation.\\\\r\\\\n   Example:[sample-readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\n5. Generate OpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\r\\\\n   - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo.\\\\r\\\\n   See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches).\\\\r\\\\n#### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks\\\\r\\\\nThe CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md).\\\\r\\\\nNote:\\\\r\\\\nSince the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the\\\\r\\\\n OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nFor support \\\\u0026 help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#common-api-details.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Common API Details\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/common-api-details.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Common API Details\\\\n## Common API Response Details ##\\\\n### Error Response Content ###\\\\n# v1.0#common-api-details.md\\\\n\\\\n# Common API Details\\\\n\\\\n## Common API Response Details ##\\\\n\\\\n### Error Response Content ###\\\\n\\\\nIf the resource provider needs to return an error to any operation, it should return the appropriate HTTP error code and a message body as can be seen below. The message should be localized per the Accept-Language header specified in the original request such that it could be directly be exposed to users.\\\\r\\\\nThe resource providers must return the `code` and `message` fields; and should also follow the recommended schema for the \\\\\\\"ErrorResponse\\\\\\\" Type from the Common Types definition in the Azure Rest API Specification [repository](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/master/specification/common-types/resource-management/v2/types.json). This format is inherited from [OData v4.0 schema](http://docs.oasis-open.org/odata/odata-json-format/v4.0/os/odata-json-format-v4.0-os.html#_Toc372793091) for error responses.\\\\r\\\\n**Response Body**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"error\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"code\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"message\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"target\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"additionalInfo\\\\\\\": [],\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"details\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n Central US and WEU only\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n              \\\\\\\"policyAsssignmentId\\\\\\\": Details\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n            }\\\\r\\\\n          }\\\\r\\\\n        ]\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    ]\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}    \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n| Element name | Type | Description |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| `message` | string (required) | Describes the error in detail and provides debugging information. If Accept-Language is set in the request, it must be localized to that language. |\\\\r\\\\n| `code` | string (required) | Unlocalized string which can be used to programmatically identify the error. The code should be Pascal-cased, and should serve to uniquely identify a particular class of error, for example \\\\u0026quot;BadArgument\\\\u0026quot;. |\\\\r\\\\n| `target` | string (optional) | The target of the particular error (for example, the name of the property in error). |\\\\r\\\\n| `details` | array (optional) | An array of additional nested error response info objects, as described by this contract. |\\\\r\\\\n| `additionalInfo` | array (optional) | An array of objects with \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\" (string), and \\\\\\\"info\\\\\\\" (object) properties. The schema of \\\\\\\"info\\\\\\\" is service-specific and dependent on the \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\" string. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a bug in typespec-azure:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/383.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see the issue above for the suggested workaround and apply it directly to the spec TypeSpec sources.  The LintDiff error should **not** be ignored or suppressed.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Diagnostics\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/openapi3/diagnostics\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Diagnostics\\\\n## invalid-extension-key\\\\n# emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\\n\\\\n# Diagnostics\\\\n\\\\n## invalid-extension-key\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued by the `@extension` decorator when the extension key does not start with \\\\\\\"x-\\\\\\\" as\\\\r\\\\nrequired by the OpenAPI v3 specification.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, change the extension name to start with \\\\\\\"x-\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@extension(\\\\\\\"invalid-name\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nShould be changed to:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@extension(\\\\\\\"x-valid-name\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/pipeline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\\n## Swagger BreakingChange\\\\n### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger BreakingChange\\\\n\\\\n### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration\\\\n\\\\nThis pipeline will fail if there is more than one OpenAPI file in the latest version. See the detailed explanation in this [issue](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216).\\\\r\\\\nTo properly identify real breaking changes, use the \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Migration Validation\\\\\\\" pipeline instead:\\\\r\\\\n1. Navigate to the TypeSpec Migration Validation pipeline\\\\r\\\\n2. Check the report on the \\\\\\\"Summary\\\\\\\" page\\\\r\\\\n3. The output should match exactly what you see in [this step](../01-get-started.md#review-and-adjust-the-typespec) on the local machine\\\\r\\\\n4. Review the changes to verify they are expected\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Diagnostics\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/openapi3/diagnostics\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Diagnostics\\\\n## union-unsupported\\\\n# emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\\n\\\\n# Diagnostics\\\\n\\\\n## union-unsupported\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when the OpenAPI emitter finds a union of two incompatible types that cannot be represented in OpenAPI. OpenAPI has limited support for union types, and some combinations cannot be expressed.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, consider restructuring your types to avoid incompatible unions, or split the operation into multiple operations with different return types.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Diagnostics\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/openapi3/diagnostics\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Diagnostics\\\\n## duplicate-type-name\\\\n### Example\\\\n# emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\\n\\\\n# Diagnostics\\\\n\\\\n## duplicate-type-name\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@friendlyName(\\\\\\\"User\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Customer {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, both `Customer` and `User` would appear as `User` in the OpenAPI output, causing a conflict.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Dependencies.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"`@azure-tools/typespec-*`\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Dependencies\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"## https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `XmsEnumValidation`\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsEnumValidation`\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec using `OAuth2Auth` may generate the following OpenAPI:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"OAuth2 authentication\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"oauth2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhich causes error `XmsEnumValidation`.  The recommended workaround is to add `omit-unreachable-types: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\nCheck `Swagger LintDiff` may fail for the OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec, even if there are no warnings or errors reported from the TypeSpec compiler.  Causes include bugs in the TypeSpec OpenAPI emitter, bugs in LintDiff rules, incompatibilities between TypeSpec and LintDiff, or checks duplicated in TypeSpec and LintDiff.\\\\r\\\\nWe are working to address the root causes (where possible).  Until then, we recommend you [suppress](https://aka.ms/pr-suppressions) these LintDiff errors, using a \\\\\\\"permanent suppression\\\\\\\" with a descriptive \\\\\\\"reason\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAdditionalProperties`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### data-plane\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such responses.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousTypes`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### `LongRunningResourceAction`\\\\n\\\\nThere is a known issue where `LongRunningResourceAction` in TypeSpec, generates swagger that causes `AvoidAnonymousTypes`.  These errors should be suppressed until the root cause is fixed.  https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure-pr/issues/3349\\\\n\\\\n## `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation`\\\\n\\\\nIf `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation` is failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\\n\\\\n## `IntegerTypeMustHaveFormat`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a bug in typespec-azure:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/383.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see the issue above for the suggested workaround and apply it directly to the spec TypeSpec sources.  The LintDiff error should **not** be ignored or suppressed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchPropertiesCorrespondToPutProperties`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/642\\\\n\\\\n## `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a limitation in how `azure-openapi-validator` and `oav` handle `$ref` siblings:\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/637\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/oav/issues/848\\\\r\\\\nThe recommended workaround is to add `use-read-only-status-schema: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `RequestBodyMustExistForPutPatch`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/641\\\\n\\\\n## `ResourceNameRestriction`\\\\n\\\\nWhether `ResourceNameRestriction` should be applied to enums is an open question:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/501\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/pull/714\\\\r\\\\nUntil this is resolved, suppress the errors and discuss with your ARM reviewer.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsEnumValidation`\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec using `OAuth2Auth` may generate the following OpenAPI:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"OAuth2 authentication\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"oauth2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhich causes error `XmsEnumValidation`.  The recommended workaround is to add `omit-unreachable-types: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsPageableForListCalls`\\\\n\\\\nIf `XmsPageableForListCalls` are failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec Validation error\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec Validation error\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_31.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec Validation error\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nFiles have been changed after `tsp compile`. Run `tsp compile` and ensure all files are included in your change.\\\\r\\\\n  Error: TypeSpec Validation failed for project specification/compute/Gallery.Management run the following command locally to validate.\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\u003e npm ci\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\u003e npx tsv specification/compute/Gallery.Management\\\\r\\\\n  For more detailed docs see https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation\\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\nIs it because I have\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n  @@ -7079,8 +7079,7 @@\\\\r\\\\n             \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Optional. That is intended.\\\\n\\\\nI have error: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/actions/runs/16475997770/job/46577654359?pr=35887:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nRule Compile failed\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\\\\"not_added\\\\\\\":[],\\\\\\\"conflicted\\\\\\\":[],\\\\\\\"created\\\\\\\":[],\\\\\\\"deleted\\\\\\\":[],\\\\\\\"modified\\\\\\\":[\\\\\\\"specification/compute/resource-manager/Microsoft.Compute/GalleryRP/stable/2025-03-03/GalleryRP.json\\\\\\\"],\\\\\\\"renamed\\\\\\\":[],\\\\\\\"files\\\\\\\":[{\\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"specification/compute/resource-manager/Microsoft.Compute/GalleryRP/stable/2025-03-03/GalleryRP.json\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"index\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"working_dir\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"M\\\\\\\"}],\\\\\\\"staged\\\\\\\":[],\\\\\\\"ahead\\\\\\\":0,\\\\\\\"behind\\\\\\\":0,\\\\\\\"current\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"HEAD\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"tracking\\\\\\\":null,\\\\\\\"detached\\\\\\\":true}diff --git a/specification/compute/resource-manager/Microsoft.Compute/GalleryRP/stable/2025-03-03/GalleryRP.json b/specification/compute/resource-manager/Microsoft.Compute/GalleryRP/stable/2025-03-03/GalleryRP.json\\\\r\\\\n  index 58f42ef3f..cc93d3906 100644\\\\r\\\\n  --- a/specification/compute/resource-manager/Microsoft.Compute/GalleryRP/stable/2025-03-03/GalleryRP.json\\\\r\\\\n  +++ b/specification/compute/resource-manager/Microsoft.Compute/GalleryRP/stable/2025-03-03/GalleryRP.json\\\\r\\\\n  @@ -7079,8 +7079,7 @@\\\\r\\\\n             \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Optional. Run `tsp compile` and ensure all files are included in your change.\\\\r\\\\n  Error: TypeSpec Validation failed for project specification/compute/Gallery.Management run the following command locally to validate.\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\u003e npm ci\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\u003e npx tsv specification/compute/Gallery.Management\\\\r\\\\n  For more detailed docs see https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation\\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\nIs it because I have\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n  @@ -7079,8 +7079,7 @@\\\\r\\\\n             \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Optional.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe swagger generated by TypeSpec is constantly changing across TypeSpec versions.  Do you believe the new swagger is incorrect? \\\\r\\\\nAlso, keep in mind the version of TypeSpec may be different in main, the base and source branches of your PR, and locally.  Unless you think the new generated swagger is incorrect, you want to update forward.\\\\r\\\\nx-ms-identifier is no longer needed https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2868:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nissue 2868:\\\\r\\\\ntitle: [Deprecation] x-ms-identifiers extension is no longer useful\\\\r\\\\ncontent: As title, and confirmed by @cweining, this swagger extension is completely useless for them who is from the original team that added this extension in swagger. Please remove it from typespec-autorest emitter\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM-Decorators-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec generation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Examples generation\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Examples generation\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHello, \\\\r\\\\nI wanted to know if it was possible to provide a sample that would be used in example generation when running the `oav` command using the `@example` decorator [here](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/documentation/#:~:text=the%20resource%20type-,%40example,-(unofficial)) or if the @example decorator is supported, thanks!\\\\r\\\\nSomething like:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@example({\\\\r\\\\n  name: \\\\\\\"exampleScheduledAction\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  summary: \\\\\\\"Example of a scheduled action resource\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  value: {\\\\r\\\\n    id: \\\\\\\"/subscriptions/0000/resourceGroups/my-rg/providers/Microsoft.ScheduledActions/scheduledAction1\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    name: \\\\\\\"scheduledAction1\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    type: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.ScheduledActions/scheduledActions\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    location: \\\\\\\"eastus\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    tags: {\\\\r\\\\n      environment: \\\\\\\"test\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n    properties: {\\\\r\\\\n      schedule: \\\\\\\"0 0 * * *\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      actionType: \\\\\\\"Backup\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      enabled: true\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n})\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not use the example decorator in Azure specs.  Instead, the typespec-autorest emitter automatically matches and inserts examples by operationId, see: x-ms-examples example files | TypeSpec Azure\\\\r\\\\nRegarding how to control the values that will be generated in the examples. This is really an oav question, so notreally an expert, but I know there is a mechanism for con figuring examples, but you can find some details here: [Azure/oav: Tools for validating OpenAPI (Swagger) files](https://github.com/Azure/oav?tab=readme-ov-file#what-does-the-tool-do-what-issues-does-the-tool-catch). \\\\r\\\\nYou can also update values after the examples are generated. Can be a TypeSpec type or an ExternalType.                                                                                                                                                                      |\\\\r\\\\n| scope     | `valueof string`                               | Specifies the target language emitters that the decorator should apply. If not set, the decorator will be applied to all language emitters by default.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eYou can use \\\\\\\"!\\\\\\\" to exclude specific languages, for example: !(java, python) or !java, !python. |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a model property to a different type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Foo {\\\\r\\\\n  date: utcDateTime;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@@alternateType(Foo.date, string);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a Scalar type to a different type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nscalar storageDateTime extends utcDateTime;\\\\r\\\\n@@alternateType(storageDateTime, string, \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a function parameter to a different type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nop test(@param @alternateType(string) date: utcDateTime): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Change a model property to a different type with language specific alternate type\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Test {\\\\r\\\\n  @alternateType(unknown)\\\\r\\\\n  thumbprint?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @alternateType(AzureLocation[], \\\\\\\"csharp\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  locations: string[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Use external type for DFE case\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@alternateType(\\\\r\\\\n  {\\\\r\\\\n    identity: \\\\\\\"Azure.Core.Expressions.DataFactoryExpression\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"csharp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n)\\\\r\\\\nunion Dfe\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  T,\\\\r\\\\n  DfeExpression,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n##### Use external type with This will ensure that your spec is compliant and future-proof.\\n\\nSummary:\\n- Use @identifiers, NOT @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", ...)\\n- Do NOT suppress unless absolutely necessary and reviewed\\n- Update your TypeSpec packages if needed\\n\\nThis approach resolves both errors according to Azure guidelines and ensures your spec is valid for all emitters.\", \"ground_truth\": \"You should NOT use @OpenAPI.extension(\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\", #[]) in your Azure Resource Manager TypeSpec code. testcase: Need help with what appear like False Positives in ARM PR

expected.answer:
You should NOT manually edit the autogenerated hardware.json file to work around TypeSpec or linter errors. Instead, you must address these issues at the TypeSpec source level and via configuration, following Azure TypeSpec best practices.
1.ProvisioningState Must Be ReadOnly: The LintDiff check for `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly` is triggered because the validation expects the type schema referenced by `provisioningState` to be `readOnly`, not just the property instance. The recommended (and officially supported) solution is to update your `tspconfig.yaml` to set:
```
options:
"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest":
use-read-only-status-schema: true
```
This ensures all `ProvisioningState` schemas are emitted as `readOnly`, resolving the LintDiff error at the TypeSpec emission layer and removing the need to edit the generated Swagger.
2.Missing Examples for Subscription-level APIs: The OpenAPI validation (ModelValidation) requires an example for each operation, including subscription-level (preview) APIs. If auto-generation tools like OAV are not generating examples for these, you must:
Manually add a valid example JSON file in the `examples/<api-version>/` folder of your TypeSpec project, ensuring the `operationId` matches your operation.
There is currently NO supported way to suppress example requirements in TypeSpec or Swagger for missing examples. Suppression can sometimes be done via labels (like `Approved-ModelValidation`) to unblock a PR, but the recommended approach is to provide at least one example per operation.
General Best Practices:
Do NOT edit the emitted Swagger (`hardware.json`). Always make changes at the TypeSpec or configuration level.
If you encounter TypeSpec validation failures, refer to the TypeSpec source, emitter options, or required supporting files (such as examples or suppressions.yaml for certain rule types). For LintDiff, suppressions must be done in `readme.md` or `suppressions.yaml` (for TypeSpecRequirement errors only, not LintDiff or example requirements).
Summary:
Set `use-read-only-status-schema: true` in `tspconfig.yaml` to resolve the `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly` error.
Add missing example files for all operations, including subscription-level ones, as there is no suppression for missing examples.
Never edit the generated OpenAPI files to workaround linter errors.
Let me know if you need guidance on creating an example file or configuring the emitter options.

actual.answer:
You should not manually edit the autogenerated OpenAPI (hardware.json) to resolve validation errors. All changes to the OpenAPI must be made in the TypeSpec source and then regenerated using `tsp compile` to ensure consistency and compliance with Azure API guidelines. 

For the `provisioningState` property:
- In TypeSpec, you should mark the property as read-only using the `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` decorator on the property itself, not on the model/type. TypeSpec does not support marking an entire model as read-only—only properties can be decorated this way. For example:

```typespec
model Hardware {
  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)
  provisioningState: string;
  // other properties
}
```
This will ensure the generated OpenAPI marks `provisioningState` as `readOnly: true`.

For the missing example on a subscription-level Preview API:
- Examples must be provided as separate JSON files in the `examples/<api-version>/` folder within your TypeSpec directory. These examples are linked to operations via the `operationId` field in the example file. You should not manually add examples to the OpenAPI file. Instead, generate them using the `oav generate-examples` tool, then edit the generated example files to provide meaningful values. If the tool does not generate examples for subscription-level APIs, you can manually create the example JSON file, ensuring it includes the correct `operationId` and `title` fields.

Suppression of TypeSpec Validation errors:
- TypeSpec Validation errors (such as mismatches between TypeSpec and OpenAPI, or missing required decorators/options) cannot be suppressed for PRs. You must resolve these errors in the TypeSpec source. Only certain sub-rules (like emitter options for SDKs you do not support) can be suppressed via `suppressions.yaml`, but not core validation errors about resource shape or required examples.

Summary:
- Do not manually edit OpenAPI files. Make all changes in TypeSpec and regenerate.
- Use `@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` for read-only properties.
- Provide examples as separate JSON files linked by `operationId`.
- Suppression is not allowed for core TypeSpec Validation errors—fix them in TypeSpec.

If you continue to have issues, ensure your local environment is up to date (`git pull`, `npm ci`) and run `npx tsp compile` and `npx tsv <spec-path>` to validate locally before updating your PR.

TypeSpec encodes many fo these rules into linting checks that occur on each compilation. If you use an IDE and install the [TypeSpec IDE Tools](../../getstarted/azure-resource-manager/step00.md#installing-ide-tools), violations of rules will show up as yellow highlights in your tsp code. If you hover over these, you will get a message indicating the issue and how to fix it in your specification. The directive takes the fully-qualified name of the rule you are suppressing, and a reason for the suppression.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager/arm-resource-operation-missing-decorator\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"This is a sample suppression.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  /** Gets the MAA URL for this resource */\\\\r\\\\n  @post\\\\r\\\\n  getZeroTrustUrl(...ResourceInstanceParameters\\\\u003cZeroTrustResource\\\\u003e): ZeroTrustUrl | ErrorResponse;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOf course, in this case, the best resolution would be to follow the advice in the linting rule, and add the `@armResourceAction` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  @armResourceAction(ZeroTrustResource)\\\\r\\\\n  /** Gets the MAA URL for this resource */\\\\r\\\\n  @post\\\\r\\\\n  getZeroTrustUrl(...ResourceInstanceParameters\\\\u003cZeroTrustResource\\\\u003e): ZeroTrustUrl | ErrorResponse;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n## Valid suppression reasons\\\\n### Valid reasons\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n## Valid suppression reasons\\\\n\\\\n### Valid reasons\\\\n\\\\nYou can request suppression of validation errors if one or more of the following scenarios matches your case;\\\\r\\\\n1. Your service design forces this behavior\\\\r\\\\n   (and it's actually the correct behavior that doesn't violate Microsoft API guidelines).\\\\r\\\\n2. Specific validation rules do not apply to your service\\\\r\\\\n   (e.g. ARM specific API validation rules may not apply to data plane API validation).\\\\r\\\\n3. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n# Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## Table Of Content\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing\\\\n\\\\n1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.\\\\r\\\\n2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.\\\\r\\\\n3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.\\\\r\\\\n   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Generating basic examples and then manually modify the values. It will generate two examples for each operation:\\\\r\\\\n    one contains minimal properties set, the other contains the maximal properties set. Since the auto-generated\\\\r\\\\n     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n       oav generate-examples openapi.json\\\\r\\\\n       \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. However, if you are generating the examples manually,\\\\r\\\\n     please ensure you have:\\\\r\\\\n    - include `title` field and make sure it is descriptive and unique for each operation.\\\\r\\\\n    - include `operationId`. This is used to match with declared operations in TypeSpec and correctly output in OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\n4. Add/update the `readme.md` file in the `{service}` folder to specify the version and location of the OpenAPI files. The `readme.md` is needed for both management-plane and data-plane services for REST API Docs generation.\\\\r\\\\n   Example:[sample-readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\n5. Generate OpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI files:\\\\r\\\\n   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`git\\\\r\\\\n       git pull upstream \\\\u003ctarget-branch\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the root directory, run `npm install`\\\\r\\\\n   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.\\\\r\\\\n6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.\\\\r\\\\n7. Send a pull request .\\\\r\\\\n   - commit all your changes.\\\\r\\\\n   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.\\\\r\\\\n   - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo.\\\\r\\\\n   See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches).\\\\r\\\\n#### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks\\\\r\\\\nThe CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md).\\\\r\\\\nNote:\\\\r\\\\nSince the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the\\\\r\\\\n OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nFor support \\\\u0026 help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Running Locally\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Running Locally\\\\n# TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Running Locally\\\\n\\\\nTo ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and `tsv` on your local machine:\\\\r\\\\n1. Merge latest from parent (e.g. `main` or `RPSaaSMaster`) to your PR branch\\\\r\\\\n2. Run locally\\\\r\\\\n   1. `git clean -xdf` (may revert any local changes)\\\\r\\\\n   2. `git pull`\\\\r\\\\n   3. `npm ci`\\\\r\\\\n   4. `npx tsv specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget`\\\\r\\\\n   5. `git status`\\\\r\\\\n   6. If any changes, `git add`, `git commit`, `git push` to update your PR.\\\\r\\\\n3. If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.\\\\r\\\\n4. If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the [TypeSpec Discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) teams channel.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Typespec Validation required check\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{module-name}\\\\\\\" does not match \\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{service-dir}/{package-dir}\\\\\\\". The current failure is caused by diffs between the generated swagger included in your PR and the generated swagger when the ci compiles your spec. \\\\r\\\\nUsually this indicates that your local dependencies are out of date, and you need to pull the latest into your local branch and re-install at thetop level: \\\\r\\\\ngit fetch upstream main\\\\r\\\\ngit pull upstream main\\\\r\\\\nnpm ci\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nRunning Locally\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nTo ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and tsv on your local machine:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n1.Merge latest from parent (e.g. main or RPSaaSMaster) to your PR branch\\\\r\\\\n2.Run locally\\\\r\\\\ngit clean -xdf (may revert any local changes)\\\\r\\\\ngit pull\\\\r\\\\nnpm ci\\\\r\\\\nnpx tsv specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management\\\\r\\\\ngit status\\\\r\\\\nIf any changes, git add, git commit, git push to update your PR.\\\\r\\\\n3.If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.\\\\r\\\\n4.If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the TypeSpec Discussion teams channel.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Process\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"## Process\\\\n1. Generated swaggers and examples (`preview/YYYY-MM-DD-preview/**`)\\\\r\\\\n   4. readme.md (remove tags)\\\\r\\\\n2. PR should fail check `Swagger BreakingChange`, but pass all other checks.\\\\r\\\\n3. Determine which failing check you want to suppress: see its name in the `Checks` tab in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you have one of the [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).\\\\r\\\\n1. Determine if you want to suppress the failure only for the PR, or permanently. Permanent suppression is preferred to avoid re-addressing the same issue in future PRs.\\\\r\\\\n1. Consult [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table) for instructions corresponding to your case.\\\\r\\\\n1. If you want to apply temporary suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. Mention in a comment on your PR the PR assignee asking to apply the suppression. Provide justification.\\\\r\\\\n      See [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).\\\\r\\\\n1. If you applied permanent suppression:\\\\r\\\\n   1. It will manifest by the PR getting a label `SuppressionReviewRequired`.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Verify the suppression works by the check changing from **failed** to **neutral**.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Wait until your suppression is reviewed. If it is approved, the approved will add the `Approved-Suppression` label.\\\\r\\\\n   1. Understand the suppression won't be approved if it is not one of the  \\\\r\\\\n      [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons) as explained in relevant section.\\\\n\\\\n## Suppression cases table\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| Swagger LintDiff                   | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintDiff`                                  | See [suppress AutoRest [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-net              | Not possible ([#6509])                    | `BreakingChange-Go-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`         | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-java             | Not possible ([#6509]) diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-JavaScript-Sdk-Suppression-Approved` | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-python           | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Python-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`     | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-python-track2    | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Python-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`     | Same as **PR suppression** note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Python-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`     | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |\\\\r\\\\n| Automated merging requirements met | Not possible failed with a breaking change. possible                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| Swagger SemanticValidation         | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-SemanticValidation`
