[aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintRPaaS`                                 | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |\\\\r\\\\n| SDK azure-sdk-for-net              |\\\\n\\\\n## suppressions.yaml\\\\n\\\\nFile `suppressions.yaml` is used for all checks created in 2024 or later, like\\\\r\\\\n`TypeSpec Requirement` and `TypeSpec Validation`.\\\\r\\\\nFor simplicity, we recommend adding all suppressions to a single file at the root of your spec folder:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/myservice/suppressions.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, you can use multiple files in separate folders.  Currently, tools will use the first\\\\r\\\\ninstance of `suppressions.yaml` found walking up the directory tree.  We are planning\\\\r\\\\nfuture support for \\\\\\\"merging\\\\\\\" files up the hierarchy.\\\\r\\\\nA suppression follows this general format:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- tool: ToolName\\\\r\\\\n  path: applies/to/**/*.json\\\\r\\\\n  reason: Why this can't be fixed\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`path` uses \\\\\\\"glob\\\\\\\" matching.  For syntax, see https://www.npmjs.com/package/minimatch.\\\\r\\\\nScope your `path` as narrowly as possible.  For example, if a suppression only applies\\\\r\\\\nto a single version of your spec:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `RequestBodyMustExistForPutPatch`\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `RequestBodyMustExistForPutPatch`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/641\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n## `PatchPropertiesCorrespondToPutProperties`\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchPropertiesCorrespondToPutProperties`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/642\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"spec_pr_review_workflow.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Spec PR Review Workflow\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Spec PR Review Workflow\\\\n# spec_pr_review_workflow.md\\\\n\\\\n# Spec PR Review Workflow\\\\n\\\\nFollow the instructions in the **Next Steps to Merge** comment.  \\\\r\\\\nIf stuck, see https://aka.ms/azsdk/pr-getting-help\\\\r\\\\n- Step 1: Breaking Change Approval\\\\r\\\\nIf your PR is flagged with the **BreakingChangeReviewRequired** or the **VersioningReviewRequired** labels, follow the instructions in the **Next Steps to Merge** comment. Once you address the problem, add **/azp run** comment to your PR.\\\\r\\\\n- Step 2: ARM or Data-Plane Review\\\\r\\\\nIf your PR has **ARMReview** label then it must be reviewed by an ARM reviewer and get **ARMSignedOff** label, follow the instructions in the **Next Steps to Merge** comment.\\\\r\\\\n- Step 3: SDK Breaking Change Approval\\\\r\\\\nIf your PR is flagged with any label that matches the pattern **BreakingChange-[Language]-Sdk**, the SDK breaking changes will be evaluated by SDK reviewers around two business days after the completion of the first two steps. The PR will proceed to the next stage only after these breaking changes are approved. No action needed besides waiting for SDK reviewers.\\\\r\\\\n- Step 4: PR Approval and Requesting Merge\\\\r\\\\nOnce the **Next Steps to Merge** comment and **Automated merging requirements met** check are **green**, follow the instructions in the **Next Steps to Merge** comment.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/pipeline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\\n## Swagger BreakingChange\\\\n### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving Pipeline Failures\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger BreakingChange\\\\n\\\\n### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration\\\\n\\\\nThis pipeline will fail if there is more than one OpenAPI file in the latest version. See the detailed explanation in this [issue](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216).\\\\r\\\\nTo properly identify real breaking changes, use the \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Migration Validation\\\\\\\" pipeline instead:\\\\r\\\\n1. Navigate to the TypeSpec Migration Validation pipeline\\\\r\\\\n2. Check the report on the \\\\\\\"Summary\\\\\\\" page\\\\r\\\\n3. The output should match exactly what you see in [this step](../01-get-started.md#review-and-adjust-the-typespec) on the local machine\\\\r\\\\n4. Review the changes to verify they are expected\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n## Suppress AutoRest extension\\\\n### Obtain error code\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n## Suppress AutoRest extension\\\\n\\\\n### Obtain error code\\\\n\\\\nTo get error code,  i.e. the value for `- code:`:\\\\r\\\\n- For `SemanticValidation` and `ModelValidation`, refer to [error definition](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/Semantic-and-Model-Violations-Reference.md).\\\\r\\\\n- For `LintDiff` and `LintDiff(RPaaS)`, refer to [rules.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/rules.md).\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e [!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e TypeSpec Azure usage for API definition is a mandatory requirement for all new (greenfield) data plane and management plane\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e services. This requirement is enforced by the ARM API Review Board for management plane services and by the API\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Stewardship Board for data plane services.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Brownfield services must transition to TypeSpec Azure by March 30, 2026.  Starting in Q4FY26, PRs for new API versions that are not based on TypeSpec will be blocked. SDK releases from non-TypeSpec specs will be blocked as well. The requirement to move to TypeSpec Azure will ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Azure that aligns with Azure SDK guidelines. For more information on TypeSpec Azure, visit [here](xref:api-typespec).\\\\r\\\\n[TypeSpec](https://typespec.io) is the new standard API definition language for Azure, developed by Microsoft. It is an open-source tool designed to generate OpenAPI specifications and other API description languages. TypeSpec can also produce client code, with service code generation in progress. TypeSpec offers highly extensible core language primitives that can describe API shapes common among REST patterns used for Azure.\\\\n\\\\n## Benefits of TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n- **Consistency across APIs**: TypeSpec ensures consistency across APIs by using high-level templates, reducing the need for repetitive tasks and minimizing errors. This uniform design approach acts as a single source of truth for API definitions, enhancing both consistency and quality.\\\\r\\\\n- **Efficiency and speed**: TypeSpec significantly reduces the amount of code needed to define API specifications. A ten-line code snippet in TypeSpec can generate a hundred lines of an OpenAPI specification, drastically reducing manual effort.\\\\r\\\\n- **Enhanced tooling**: TypeSpec comes with advanced tools that catch errors early, leading to more robust APIs. Additionally, extensions for [Visual Studio](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=typespec.typespecvs) and [VS Code](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=typespec.typespec-vscode) aid in efficient TypeSpec creation.\\\\r\\\\n- **Accessibility**: The compact nature of TypeSpec, combined with its familiar JavaScript-style syntax, allows even non-technical stakeholders to participate in the API review and design process.\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\nHear directly from teams who have successfully transitioned to TypeSpec Azure and learn about their experiences:\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n\\\\nWhether you're working with Data Plane (DP) or Azure Resource Manager (ARM), having clear examples to follow can make your transition to TypeSpec smoother. Here are some resources that can help:\\\\r\\\\n- **Playground Examples**: Our playground provides ARM and DP examples that serve as excellent models for teams new to TypeSpec Azure. These examples are concise and take full advantage of our standard operation templates. You can use these as a gold standard for your own TypeSpec definitions. Visit the [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure) to explore these examples.\\\\r\\\\n- **ARM Samples**: For more specific scenarios, check out our additional [ARM samples](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/tree/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/arm-scenarios). These are tutorial-like examples that cover various scenarios. You can adapt these to fit your specific needs.\\\\r\\\\nThe playground examples are a great starting point for getting familiar with TypeSpec Azure. As you gain more experience, you can leverage the ARM samples to understand how to apply TypeSpec to a variety of scenarios.\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec office hours\\\\n\\\\nJoin us on Mondays from 4-5 PM PT for our TypeSpec office hours. These sessions are designed to answer your questions and offer guidance on using TypeSpec Azure effectively. You can find the invite in the calendar in the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams Channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).\\\\n\\\\n## Resources\\\\n\\\\n- [TypeSpec Azure Docs](https://aka.ms/typespec/azure): A comprehensive guide to using TypeSpec in Azure.\\\\r\\\\n- [TypeSpec tutorial](https://aka.ms/typespec/getstarted): TypeSpec tutorial to define REST APIs with HTTP.\\\\r\\\\n- [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure): An interactive platform to experiment with TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n- [Getting Started with TypeSpec in azure-rest-api-specs repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/Getting-started-with-TypeSpec-specifications.md): A step-by-step guide to getting started with TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n- [Tool converting OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec](https://aka.ms/typespec/migrate): A handy tool to help you transition from OpenAPI to TypeSpec.\\\\n\\\\n## Get help\\\\n\\\\nIf you need help or have questions, join the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).  \\\\r\\\\nThis is a community of TypeSpec users and experts who are ready to assist you.\\\\n\\\\n### Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel includes an Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot that is designed to help you with questions  \\\\r\\\\nrelated to TypeSpec, Azure TypeSpec, and the related emitters. Simply mention `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` directly in your  \\\\r\\\\nmessage with a clear description of the problem you're facing.\\\\r\\\\n**Example usage:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot: How can I describe HTTP status codes for responses in TypeSpec?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Best practices for using the bot:**\\\\r\\\\n- Start a conversation by mentioning `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` in the TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel - note that  \\\\r\\\\n  modifying existing posts won't trigger a response\\\\r\\\\n- The bot only has context from messages that directly mention it and cannot access or see messages outside of that  \\\\r\\\\n  context\\\\r\\\\n- It supports images and GitHub pull request links for better context\\\\r\\\\n- All replies are generated by AI, so please double-check to ensure the information is correct\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | \\\\r\\\\n| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |\\\\r\\\\n| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |\\\\r\\\\n| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | \\\\r\\\\n| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |\\\\r\\\\n| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |\\\\r\\\\n| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | \\\\r\\\\n| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_07.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to create an Example for a typespec model?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to create an Example for a typespec model?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_07.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to create an Example for a typespec model?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI was going through my Typespec file and adding @example() decorators on top of models but then I was informed by Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot that Azure API Spec doesn't support the @example() decorator? Instead I'm supposed to create .json files in the examples folder and link it by operaiton id. However, models don't have operation ids? or do they?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nHere is some documentation on generating required examples: [x-ms-examples example files | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/x-ms-examples/).  \\\\r\\\\nNote that the examples that are required for specs at this point are operation examples (which include examples of model serialization in the operations that include those models).  The workflow is:\\\\r\\\\nDesign your API in TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\nGenerate an OpenApi doc by compiling your spec\\\\r\\\\nRun oav to generate examples for each of the operations (oav generates syntactically valid examples with the 'operationId'  and 'title' fields filled in)\\\\r\\\\nGo through the examples, replace values to make the examples more useful as documentation, and feel free to add  any examples for important scenarios that might be difficult to understand otherwise, or remove redundant examples (although you will need at least one per operation)\\\\r\\\\nCopy the examples into the `examples/\\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/` folder inside your typespec directory and the OpenApi emitter will automatically associate the examples with  the appropriate operatiosn through the 'operationId' in the example file,  using the 'title' field as the title of the example.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Validation Rule Suppression\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n# TypeSpec-Validation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Validation Rule Suppression\\\\n\\\\n## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules\\\\n\\\\n### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\n\\\\nIf you only need to bypass validation for **specific** emitter options or parameters, you can suppress individual sub-rules.\\\\r\\\\nAdd or update your `suppressions.yaml` file with the following structure, specifying the sub-rules to ignore:\\\\r\\\\nSub-rule Syntax:\\\\r\\\\n- For parameters: `parameters.\\\\u003cparameter-key\\\\u003e.default`\\\\r\\\\n- For emitter options: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003coption-key\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n- For nested options (e.g., `package-details: name: \\\\\\\"xxx\\\\\\\"`), use dot notation: `options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply\\\\r\\\\n    - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific parameter's default value\\\\r\\\\n    - parameters.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e.default \\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a specific emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003ckey-to-validate\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    # Example: Suppress validation for a nested emitter option\\\\r\\\\n    - options.\\\\u003cemitter-name\\\\u003e.package-details.name \\\\r\\\\n  reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#mustread.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Understanding the OpenAPI Changes\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/mustread\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Understanding the OpenAPI Changes\\\\n## Handling \\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\" in Model Schemas\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#mustread.md\\\\n\\\\n# Understanding the OpenAPI Changes\\\\n\\\\n## Handling \\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\" in Model Schemas\\\\n\\\\nThe `\\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\": true` property should only be used on properties, not on models. If a model is mistakenly marked as readOnly and other models refer to it, like this:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReadOnlyModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"readOnly\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"ReferToReadOnlyModel\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"property\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/ReadOnlyModel\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nDecorating the property referencing the model with '@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)` is equivalent to marking the model schema as read-only as in the OpenAPI above.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReadOnlyModel {}\\\\r\\\\nmodel ReferToReadOnlyModel {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  property: ReadOnlyModel;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to properly set read-only property?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to properly set read-only property?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to properly set read-only property?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nIn our API spec we have a read-only property which will always be set in the response by the server. So we had it set up like this:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"...\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  entityName: string;\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nWe did not set it as nullable since we want to indicate to the user that they can rely on the property to always be set. \\\\r\\\\nHowever, the auto-generated ARM schema seems to be confused by this. This is the warning I'm getting from Intellisense when writing the Bicep file:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThe specified \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\" declaration is missing the following required properties: \\\\\\\"entityName\\\\\\\". If this is a resource type definition inaccuracy, report it using https://aka.ms/bicep-type-issues. bicep(BCP035)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nproperties: DiscoveryRuleProperties\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe resource-specific properties for this resource.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nView Problem (\\u2325F8) Quick Fix... (\\u2318.) Fix (\\u23181)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nproperties: {\\\\r\\\\n  addRecommendedSignals: 'Enabled'\\\\r\\\\n  authenticationSetting: 'SystemAssigned'\\\\r\\\\n  discoverRelationships: 'Enabled'\\\\r\\\\n  resourceGraphQuery: 'resources | where id startswith \\\\\\\"/subscriptions/00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000\\\\\\\"'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nOf course, if I add it, I - correctly - get a warning that the property is read-only.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThe property \\\\\\\"entityName\\\\\\\" is read-only. Expressions cannot be assigned to read-only properties. If this is a resource type definition inaccuracy, report it using https://aka.ms/bicep-type-issues. bicep(BCP073)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nentityName: string\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nName of the entity which represents the discovery rule. Note: It might take a few minutes after creating the discovery rule until the entity is created.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nView Problem (\\u2325F8) Quick Fix... (\\u2318.) Fix (\\u23181)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nentityName: 'foo'\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nAny advise is much appreciated!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe property was correctly encoded in TypeSpec using @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) and not marked as nullable, which is appropriate since the property is always set by the service. The ARM template schema is generated automatically from the OpenAPI JSON file in the public API spec repo, and the generated file does mark entityName as readOnly.\\\\r\\\\nThe issue seems to stem from how the schema generator interprets required and readOnly. Specifically, it assumes required applies only to writable views of the resource body, which leads to misleading IntelliSense warnings in Bicep. This is likely due to shared logic in the Bicep and schema generation code.\\\\r\\\\nOptionality in OpenAPI is context-dependent\\u2014relevant to either requests or responses\\u2014while in TypeSpec, optionality for resource types indicates whether a property is part of the resource conceptually. Nullability, on the other hand, means the property accepts null in requests, which is discouraged in Azure.\\\\r\\\\nA proposed fix is already under discussion here: https://github.com/Azure/bicep-types-az/pull/2568.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion, \\\\r\\\\nCI has been failing constantly for our PR ([Azure Load Testing\\\\\\\\] Add 2025-03-01-preview Data-Plane APIs by Harshan01 \\u00b7 Pull Request #32585 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32585)) for Typespec Validation step. The logs show that we are missing the Go SDK configuration and I am able to produce this error locally as well. However, our service doesnt have a Go SDK and we are not planning to put it in scope right now. This check has suddenly started failing for our PRs, what should we do?\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExecuting rule\\uff1aSdkTspConfigVa1idation\\\\r\\\\n[SdkTspconfigVa1idation]\\uff1avalidation failed\\uff0e\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans\\u201c\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject\\u4e00spans.\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\n- Failed to find \\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\\\\"\\uff0ePlease add\\\\\\\"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\\\\".\\\\r\\\\nPlease See https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info\\uff0e\\\\r\\\\nFor additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nSuppressing go specific rules worked for me (locally, checking CI now). Thanks Mike. Also FYI Darren Cohen. Here's our suppression file:\\\\r\\\\n```yml\\\\r\\\\n- tool: TypeSpecValidation\\\\r\\\\n  paths:\\\\r\\\\n    - tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\n  rules:\\\\r\\\\n    - SdkTspConfigValidation\\\\r\\\\n  sub-rules:\\\\r\\\\n    # Suppress validation for a Go emitter options\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir\\\\r\\\\n    - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir\\\\r\\\\n  reason: 'Azure Load Testing does not support a Go SDK currently'\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nLet me know if I can help with anything!\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Oav generate-examples failed\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Oav generate-examples failed\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Oav generate-examples failed\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nSteps to reproduce:\\\\r\\\\n1. clone https://github.com/minhng22/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/nguyenmin/targetk8sversionchannel\\\\r\\\\n2. Run \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\noav generate-examples specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/fleet/preview/2025-07-01-preview/fleets.json\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nError \\\\r\\\\n(node:53300) [DEP0040] DeprecationWarning: The `punycode` module is deprecated. Please use a userland alternative instead.\\\\r\\\\n(Use `node --trace-deprecation ...` to show where the warning was created)\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  message: 'array details item is null, it may be caused by circular reference',\\\\r\\\\n  level: '\\\\\\\\x1B[33mwarn\\\\\\\\x1B[39m'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  message: 'fatal error: Maximum call stack size exceeded, {}',\\\\r\\\\n  level: '\\\\\\\\x1B[31merror\\\\\\\\x1B[39m'\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nfatal error: Maximum call stack size exceeded, {}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nDoes any one know why this error happens TypeSpec Discussion?\\\\r\\\\nThis branch is based on branch `dev-aks-fleet-2025-07-01-preview` . For diff, pls see https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/34812\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nFirst thing to understand there are two copies of all examples when you're using TSP \\\\r\\\\nSwagger copy: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/33737ff460f78153f4cc21ef5d2d4586fcbae107/specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/fleet/preview/2025-07-01-preview/examples \\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec copy: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/33737ff460f78153f4cc21ef5d2d4586fcbae107/specification/containerservice/Fleet.Management/examples/2025-07-01-preview \\\\r\\\\nProcess is you update examples in TypeSpec copy, then run \\\\\\\"tsp compile\\\\\\\" which copies them to swagger folder \\\\r\\\\nYour TSV may have been failing, if you changed one copy but not the other \\\\r\\\\nSecond, you can generate examples manually or using `oav` , whatever you prefer, is more efficient for your workflow, etc \\\\r\\\\nIf you think you're hitting a bug in `oav`, you can open an issue here, or discuss in any of our teams channels. \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/oav/issues\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_19.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nendpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? Have observed some RPs have leveraged from commonTypes but renamed as PrivateEndpointConnectionResource in their tsp file.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n2. Avocado error: I have removed an API revokeCertificate and added a new api revokeCertificates which takes an array. \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nHow do I fix both errors?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n [Added private endpoint connection, bulk revocation and c2pa certificate type by amritas \\u00b7 Pull Requ\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24553)\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nModel validation Error - Additional properties not allowed: groupIds, privateLinkServiceConnectionState,privateEndpoint,provisioningState\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nPEC contract - \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.CodeSigning;\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"Private endpoint connection resource.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection\\\\r\\\\n    is ProxyResource\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnectionProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n    ...PrivateEndpointConnectionParameter;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations(PrivateEndpointConnection)\\\\r\\\\ninterface PrivateEndpointConnections {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Get a specific private connection */\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Create a Private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Delete the private endpoint connection */\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** List private endpoint connections on the given resource */\\\\r\\\\n  list is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2025_09_15_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(CodeSigningAccount)\\\\n\\\\nlistPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\r\\\\nThis will then get consumed by teams authoring Azure APIs. As such, they have the Azure linting in place (naming conventions and whatnot).\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe wanted to know whether definitions can also come with suppressions (not inline, as this definition is auto-importer on a regular basis), which would apply ONLY to the definitions we share, not to the rest of the consumer's project?\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nThanks!\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nsuppression can only be provided inline for now. Linter rules can be disabled globally but that would apply to the whole project, can't filter by files\\\\n\\\\noperations to any resourc,e see: \\\\r\\\\n[typespec-azure/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-end\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/resource-types/private-endpoints/private-endpoints.tsp#L69-L94)\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel PrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointConnectionResource;\\\\r\\\\nalias PrivateEndpointOperations = PrivateEndpoints\\\\u003cPrivateEndpointConnection\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cEmployee, EmployeeProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  getPrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.Read\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  updatePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.CustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  deletePrivateEndpointConnection is PrivateEndpointOperations.DeleteAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listPrivateEndpointConnections is PrivateEndpointOperations.ListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nSee here for the Avocado error.  We need to find a better way to handle intentionally removed APIs in Avocado.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#known-issues\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Design question about suppression rules\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi team,\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe're working to put together a TypeSpec definitions package for OpenAI API surface.\\\\n\\\\nI have the below PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 \\u00b7 Pull Request #24115 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) where some of the LintDiff validations are failing with the exception \\\\r\\\\n``` \\\\r\\\\n  Violation: file:///home/runner/work/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/after/specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/stable/2025-08-15/Limit.json:578\\\\r\\\\n    Level: error\\\\r\\\\n    Code: RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel\\\\r\\\\n    Message: Model definition 'SharingDetail' must have the properties 'name', 'id' and 'type' in its hierarchy and these properties must be marked as readonly.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThis particular model is defined as follows - \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel SharingDetail {\\\\r\\\\n  role: SharingRole;\\\\r\\\\n  sharedLimits?: QuotaLimitProperties[];\\\\r\\\\n  guestSubscriptions?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  host?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nIs it possible have a suppression for this validation? If so, how?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nthe link for lintdiff suppressions:\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nyou probably want to fix this in your spec, not suppress the error\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nYou need to fix check \\\\\\\"TypeSpec Validation\\\\\\\" in your PR, before other check results will even be valid.  This is documented in the \\\\\\\"next steps to merge\\\\\\\" comment in your PR.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n# Model validations are failing although am referring from common-types\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\n1. I have reused the model Private endpoint connection resource from the commonTypes/v5. However the model validation is failing. In example PrivateEndpointConnections_ListByCodeSigningAccount, its giving the below errors. In the PrivateEndpointConnection tsp file, I have kept the resource name as is and havent renamed, would this cause any issue? Would there be any problem while updating it from Rpaas? testcase: Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models

expected.answer:
You should not suppress this LintDiff validation error. The error `RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel` indicates that your `SharingDetail` model is being interpreted as a resource model, but it does not contain the required ARM resource properties: `name`, `id`, and `type` (all marked as readOnly). According to Azure API and TypeSpec guidelines, all resource models must include these properties to be compliant.
Suppressing this error is not the correct approach—instead, you must fix your TypeSpec definition. Ensure that resource models either extend the appropriate common-types resource base model (such as `Resource`, `ProxyResource`, or `ExtensionResource`) or, if `SharingDetail` is not a resource, ensure it is not referenced in a way that causes it to be treated as one.
For suppressing LintDiff errors in general, you can add scoped suppressions in your `readme.md` following the guidance here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions. However, for this particular error, you are expected to fix your TypeSpec spec to meet the ARM requirements—not suppress it.
To resolve this:
If `SharingDetail` is a resource, extend from the correct base model and add `id`, `name`, `type` (all readOnly).
If it is not a resource, check where it is referenced in your operations or model hierarchy to ensure it is not being treated as a resource by the code generator.

actual.answer:
Yes, you can suppress the LintDiff validation error 'RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel' for your 'SharingDetail' model, but this suppression must be done in the readme.md file of your specification, not in the TypeSpec source itself. The suppression mechanism for LintDiff errors is documented here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions. 

To suppress this error, add a directive to your readme.md under the 'directive' section, targeting the exact path of the error in your generated Swagger. For example:

```yaml
directive:
  - where:
      - $.definitions.SharingDetail
    suppress:
      - RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel
```

Make sure the path matches the location reported in the error message. This will silence the LintDiff error for that specific model. However, best practice is to fix the underlying model to comply with ARM resource requirements (i.e., include 'name', 'id', and 'type' as readonly properties) unless you have a strong reason for deviation and have discussed with your ARM reviewer.

Causes include bugs in the TypeSpec OpenAPI emitter, bugs in LintDiff rules, incompatibilities between TypeSpec and LintDiff, or checks duplicated in TypeSpec and LintDiff.\\\\r\\\\nWe are working to address the root causes (where possible).  Until then, we recommend you [suppress](https://aka.ms/pr-suppressions) these LintDiff errors, using a \\\\\\\"permanent suppression\\\\\\\" with a descriptive \\\\\\\"reason\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAdditionalProperties`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### data-plane\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such responses.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousTypes`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### `LongRunningResourceAction`\\\\n\\\\nThere is a known issue where `LongRunningResourceAction` in TypeSpec, generates swagger that causes `AvoidAnonymousTypes`.  These errors should be suppressed until the root cause is fixed.  https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure-pr/issues/3349\\\\n\\\\n## `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation`\\\\n\\\\nIf `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation` is failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\\n\\\\n## `IntegerTypeMustHaveFormat`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a bug in typespec-azure:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/383.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see the issue above for the suggested workaround and apply it directly to the spec TypeSpec sources.  The LintDiff error should **not** be ignored or suppressed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchPropertiesCorrespondToPutProperties`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/642\\\\n\\\\n## `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a limitation in how `azure-openapi-validator` and `oav` handle `$ref` siblings:\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/637\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/oav/issues/848\\\\r\\\\nThe recommended workaround is to add `use-read-only-status-schema: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `RequestBodyMustExistForPutPatch`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/641\\\\n\\\\n## `ResourceNameRestriction`\\\\n\\\\nWhether `ResourceNameRestriction` should be applied to enums is an open question:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/501\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/pull/714\\\\r\\\\nUntil this is resolved, suppress the errors and discuss with your ARM reviewer.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsEnumValidation`\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec using `OAuth2Auth` may generate the following OpenAPI:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"OAuth2 authentication\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"oauth2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhich causes error `XmsEnumValidation`.  The recommended workaround is to add `omit-unreachable-types: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsPageableForListCalls`\\\\n\\\\nIf `XmsPageableForListCalls` are failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Typespec Validation required check\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Typespec Validation required check\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{module-name}\\\\\\\" does not match \\\\\\\"github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/{service-dir}/{package-dir}\\\\\\\". the `format` value for the `age` property is invalid. To fix this issue, remove the duplicate header definition.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"bad\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# bad\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n# docs#design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md\\\\n\\\\n# bad\\\\n\\\\n## Troubleshooting AutoRest suppressions not working\\\\n\\\\n### For suppression path, use exactly the element the error is pointing to\\\\n\\\\nThe path in the suppression you add must point to exactly the same element as pointed out by the error.\\\\r\\\\nFor example, if the failure link points [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/30be453a97b9a4d64b1a7a6e45d7364bfbf4d8a2/specification/subscription/resource-manager/Microsoft.Subscription/stable/2021-10-01/subscriptions.json#L137),\\\\r\\\\nthen the path should be:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` xpath\\\\r\\\\n$.paths[\\\\\\\"/providers/Microsoft.Subscription/subscriptionOperations/{operationId}\\\\\\\"].get.responses[\\\\\\\"202\\\\\\\"]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- [Example path for suppressing LintDiff code `GetOperation200`](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/24395/commits/41f8f34937be245a855ff49552ecdeb0213ca525)\\\\r\\\\n  - **IMPORTANT**: This example uses the legacy `directive/suppress` syntax. Do not use it. Use the new syntax instead.\\\\r\\\\n  - [Relevant Teams discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:0351f5f9404446e4b4fd4eaf2c27448d@thread.skype/1688105866973?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1687971321354\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=API%20Spec%20Review\\\\u0026createdTime=1688105866973)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Diagnostics\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/openapi3/diagnostics\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Diagnostics\\\\n## duplicate-type-name\\\\n# emitters#openapi3#diagnostics.md\\\\n\\\\n# Diagnostics\\\\n\\\\n## duplicate-type-name\\\\n\\\\nThis diagnostic is issued when a schema or parameter name is a duplicate of another schema or parameter. This generally happens when a model or parameter is renamed with the `@friendlyName` decorator, resulting in two different TypeSpec types getting the same name in the OpenAPI output.\\\\r\\\\nTo fix this issue, change the name or friendly-name of one of the models or parameters.\\\\n\\\\n### Example\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@friendlyName(\\\\\\\"User\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Customer {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel User {\\\\r\\\\n  id: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, both `Customer` and `User` would appear as `User` in the OpenAPI output, causing a conflict.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"SDK generation configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# SDK generation configuration\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e[!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#rest-api-publish#buildpipelines.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Using Build Pipelines with TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/rest-api-publish/buildpipelines\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Using Build Pipelines with TypeSpec\\\\n# howtos#rest-api-publish#buildpipelines.md\\\\n\\\\n# Using Build Pipelines with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\nThis doc will help you get started with using TypeSpec in your build pipelines in your own repository. [Azure DevOps Pipelines](#azure-devops-pipelines)\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n\\\\n### Dependencies\\\\n\\\\nIn order to build TypeSpec in your build pipeline, you will need to ensure that the following are available or are automatically installed by your project:\\\\r\\\\n1. NodeJS 22.x LTS (Recommended)\\\\r\\\\n2. TypeSpec compilation tools (via npm package)\\\\n\\\\n## Azure DevOps Pipelines\\\\n\\\\nDepending on your project, you may need to add NodeJS and install NPM packages for TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nThe following Azure Devops Pipeline tasks can be modified and added to your pipeline yaml file if you do not already utilize NodeJS in your project.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=\\\\\\\".azure-pipelines.yml\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"SDK generation configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# SDK generation configuration\\\\n# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md\\\\n\\\\n# SDK generation configuration\\\\n\\\\nTo generate SDK code based on REST API specifications, you need to configure the corresponding files.\\\\r\\\\n- For TypeSpec, the configuration file is `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n- For OpenAPI, the configuration file is `readme.md`.\\\\n\\\\n## Enable SDK generation\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e[!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## CSharp\\\\n\\\\nSee configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\nFor more samples on configuring specific `readme.{language}.md`, refer to:\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Management Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles)\\\\r\\\\n- [Sample Readmes for Data Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles-dp)\\\\r\\\\n- [Config SDK team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | \\\\r\\\\n| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |\\\\r\\\\n| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |\\\\r\\\\n| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | \\\\r\\\\n| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |\\\\r\\\\n| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |\\\\r\\\\n| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | \\\\r\\\\n| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"AdditionalProperties added to swagger for Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e property\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# AdditionalProperties added to swagger for Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e property\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_07_03.md\\\\n\\\\n# AdditionalProperties added to swagger for Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e property\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi, I am trying to convert existing APIs (released to customers) to be generated from TypeSpec. The initial Swagger contained Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e, and I would like to keep the API spec the same as before. The new generated Swagger now contains an empty additionalProperties property. How can I avoid adding this additionalProperties in the Swagger? \\\\r\\\\nHere is the generated swagger:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"ArmTemplateInfo\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Information about a generated ARM template.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"template\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The template's contents.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"additionalProperties\\\\\\\": {}\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"parameters\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The parameters of the ARM template.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"additionalProperties\\\\\\\": {}\\\\r\\\\n        }\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n Here is how the original swagger looked:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"ArmTemplateInfo\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Information about a generated ARM template.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"template\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The template's contents.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        },\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"parameters\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The parameters of the ARM template.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n          \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n        }\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    },\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nHere is the model:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nmodel ArmTemplateInfo {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The template's contents.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager/arm-no-record\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  template?: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * The parameters of the ARM template.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager/arm-no-record\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  parameters?: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nPR link: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nthis is an accurate equivalent, do not try to make the swagger match exactly here \\\\r\\\\nthat property should either be `Record\\\\u003cunknown` or `unknown` depending on what was the target. Either way it won't produce the exact same Output\\\\n\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"CustomResource\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"id\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      },\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/CustomResourceProperties\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"CustomResourceProperties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"object\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"properties\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"displayName\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n failed\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Swagger LintDiff failed\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Swagger LintDiff failed\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI have many lintDiff failures in this [PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/34318). The interesting thing is, the place I'm violating the rules, its swagger is the same as before. Why these violations are not reported before?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe LintDiff errors in your PR are not necessarily new violations. Many of them already existed in the main branch, but previously, CI failures weren\\u2019t blocking, so these issues were effectively allowed to persist unnoticed.\\\\r\\\\nNow, because your PR is part of a TypeSpec (TSP) migration, the generated Swagger includes many differences\\u2014over 3,000 diffs in total\\u2014due to normalization by the AutoRest emitter. These changes are functionally equivalent but not textually identical, which makes it hard for the LintDiff auto-baselining algorithm to recognize unchanged areas. As a result, you\\u2019re seeing errors flagged as new, even if the same issues existed in main.\\\\r\\\\nGiven the unreliability of the auto-baselining mechanism, we recommend not depending on it. Instead, all LintDiff errors\\u2014regardless of whether they are newly introduced or pre-existing\\u2014should be explicitly suppressed in the `readme.md` file. Why these violations are not reported before?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe LintDiff errors in your PR are not necessarily new violations. response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"Yes, you can suppress the LintDiff validation error 'RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel' for your 'SharingDetail' model, but this suppression must be done in the readme.md file of your specification, not in the TypeSpec source itself. The suppression mechanism for LintDiff errors is documented here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions. \\n\\nTo suppress this error, add a directive to your readme.md under the 'directive' section, targeting the exact path of the error in your generated Swagger. For example:\\n\\n```yaml\\ndirective:\\n  - where:\\n      - $.definitions.SharingDetail\\n    suppress:\\n      - RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel\\n```\\n\\nMake sure the path matches the location reported in the error message. This will silence the LintDiff error for that specific model. However, best practice is to fix the underlying model to comply with ARM resource requirements (i.e., include 'name', 'id', and 'type' as readonly properties) unless you have a strong reason for deviation and have discussed with your ARM reviewer.\", \"ground_truth\": \"You should not suppress this LintDiff validation error. The error `RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel` indicates that your `SharingDetail` model is being interpreted as a resource model, but it does not contain the required ARM resource properties: `name`, `id`, and `type` (all marked as readOnly). According to Azure API and TypeSpec guidelines, all resource models must include these properties to be compliant.\\nSuppressing this error is not the correct approach\\u2014instead, you must fix your TypeSpec definition. Ensure that resource models either extend the appropriate common-types resource base model (such as `Resource`, `ProxyResource`, or `ExtensionResource`) or, if `SharingDetail` is not a resource, ensure it is not referenced in a way that causes it to be treated as one.\\nFor suppressing LintDiff errors in general, you can add scoped suppressions in your `readme.md` following the guidance here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions. However, for this particular error, you are expected to fix your TypeSpec spec to meet the ARM requirements\\u2014not suppress it.\\nTo resolve this:\\nIf `SharingDetail` is a resource, extend from the correct base model and add `id`, `name`, `type` (all readOnly).\\nIf it is not a resource, check where it is referenced in your operations or model hierarchy to ensure it is not being treated as a resource by the code generator.\"}"}]

testcase: How to make an interface internal ?

expected.answer: We do not support hiding an entire operation group directly. The recommended approach is to redefine your client in client.tsp to control which operations appear on the public client. When you do this properly, the default service clients and their Operations classes should not be emitted—as long as you remove all previously generated SDK output before regenerating. Or you can use _patch.py to customize the code.

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: How to make an interface internal ?\\n\\nquestion: I am looking for ways to make an interface internal so that it does not appear in public interface of python SDK. This is the interface which emits `EvaluationResultsOperations` which shows up on client. I would like to generate it but keep it hidden from public interface.\\nI tried following:\\n1. Mark all operations under it internal\\n2. Adding @access decorator to interface but that fails.\\nIs there a way to achieve it ?\", \"response\": \"To make an interface internal so that it does not appear in the public interface of the generated Python SDK, you should use the `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` decorator from `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` on the interface itself. However, simply marking the interface or its operations as internal is not sufficient if any of its operations or models are referenced by public operations elsewhere in your TypeSpec. The access level propagates: if a model or operation is referenced by a public operation, it will be included in the public SDK interface regardless of its own access setting.\\n\\nFor your scenario:\\n- Apply `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` to the interface and all its operations.\\n- Ensure that none of the operations or models from this interface are referenced by any public operations or models elsewhere in your TypeSpec. If they are, they will be promoted to public in the SDK.\\n\\nExample:\\n```typespec\\nimport \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core\\\";\\nusing Azure.ClientGenerator.Core;\\n\\n@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\ninterface EvaluationResultsOperations {\\n  @access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\n  op getResults(): EvaluationResult[];\\n}\\n\\nmodel EvaluationResult {\\n  value: string;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIf you follow this pattern and ensure no public references, the interface and its operations will be hidden from the public Python SDK client. If you still see it in the generated SDK, double-check for any public references or usage that might be causing it to be promoted to public.\\n\\nNote: There is no supported way to remove exported classes or interfaces using Python SDK customization files (such as `_patch.py`). The only supported approach is via TypeSpec decorators as described above.\", \"ground_truth\": \"We do not support hiding an entire operation group directly. The recommended approach is to redefine your client in client.tsp to control which operations appear on the public client. When you do this properly, the default service clients and their Operations classes should not be emitted\\u2014as long as you remove all previously generated SDK output before regenerating. Or you can use _patch.py to customize the code.\"}"}]

However, simply marking the interface or its operations as internal is not sufficient if any of its operations or models are referenced by public operations elsewhere in your TypeSpec. The access level propagates: if a model or operation is referenced by a public operation, it will be included in the public SDK interface regardless of its own access setting.\\n\\nFor your scenario:\\n- Apply `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` to the interface and all its operations.\\n- Ensure that none of the operations or models from this interface are referenced by any public operations or models elsewhere in your TypeSpec. If they are, they will be promoted to public in the SDK.\\n\\nExample:\\n```typespec\\nimport \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core\\\";\\nusing Azure.ClientGenerator.Core;\\n\\n@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\ninterface EvaluationResultsOperations {\\n  @access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\n  op getResults(): EvaluationResult[];\\n}\\n\\nmodel EvaluationResult {\\n  value: string;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIf you follow this pattern and ensure no public references, the interface and its operations will be hidden from the public Python SDK client. If you still see it in the generated SDK, double-check for any public references or usage that might be causing it to be promoted to public.\\n\\nNote: There is no supported way to remove exported classes or interfaces using Python SDK customization files (such as `_patch.py`). Its name must be an [`identifier`](./identifiers.md).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface SampleInterface {\\\\r\\\\n  foo(): int32;\\\\r\\\\n  bar(): string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Composing interfaces\\\\n\\\\nYou can use the `extends` keyword to incorporate operations from other interfaces into a new interface.\\\\r\\\\nConsider the following interfaces:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface A {\\\\r\\\\n  a(): string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\ninterface B {\\\\r\\\\n  b(): string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou can create a new interface `C` that includes all operations from `A` and `B`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface C extends A, B {\\\\r\\\\n  c(): string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis is equivalent to:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface C {\\\\r\\\\n  a(): string;\\\\r\\\\n  b(): string;\\\\r\\\\n  c(): string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Interface templates\\\\n\\\\nInterfaces can be templated. For more details on templates, [see templates](./templates.md).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface ReadWrite\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  read(): T;\\\\r\\\\n  write(t: T): void;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Templating interface operations\\\\n\\\\nOperations defined within an interface can also be templated. For more details on templates, [see templates](./templates.md).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface ReadWrite\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  read(): T;\\\\r\\\\n  write\\\\u003cR\\\\u003e(t: T): R;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nalias MyReadWrite = ReadWrite\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nop myWrite is MyReadWrite.write\\\\u003cint32\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n:::caution\\\\r\\\\nAny templated operation defined in an interface that is not instantiated will be omitted from the list of service operations.\\\\r\\\\nThis also applies when using `extends` on an interface that contains templated operations with unfilled template arguments.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\ninterface ReadWrite\\\\u003cT\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  read(): T;\\\\r\\\\n  write\\\\u003cR\\\\u003e(t: T): R;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\ninterface MyReadWrite extends ReadWrite\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e {} // Here, the `read()` operation is fully instantiated and will be included in a service definition. However, `write()` is not.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen working with building block interfaces like this, use an alias to create your interface building block instead of `interface extends`. This way, the instantiated interface and its members will not be resolved in the service definition.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nalias MyReadWrite = ReadWrite\\\\u003cstring\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\nop myRead is MyReadWrite.read;\\\\r\\\\nop myWrite is If not set, the decorator will be applied to all language emitters by default.\\\\u003cbr /\\\\u003eYou can use \\\\\\\"!\\\\\\\" to exclude specific languages, for example: !(java, python) or !java, !python. |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| scope   | `valueof string`                                                            | Specifies the target language emitters that the decorator should apply.
