certain classes for Python SDK only\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to remove certain classes for Python SDK only\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to remove certain classes for Python SDK only\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi team, \\\\r\\\\nI was expecting there to be a way to remove specific classes for only the Python SDK in TypeSpec. I tried adding `@access(Access.internal, \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\")` to those classes, but it didn\\u2019t work. Using `@removed` does remove the classes, but it removes them for all language SDKs, which isn\\u2019t what we want. \\\\r\\\\nIs there a recommended approach to exclude certain classes from generation only in the Python SDK? Any guidance would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIf you want to remove specific classes only from the Python SDK in TypeSpec, using @access(Access.internal, \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\") won\\u2019t work if the model is referenced by a public operation. To hide the model, you must also apply the decorator to the related operation that uses it.\\\\r\\\\nIn your case, the operation analyzeConversations uses the base type AnalyzeConversationTask, and the model you want to remove\\u2014LuisParameters\\u2014is a subtype of AnalysisParameters, which is used by ConversationTaskParameters. Since LuisParameters is part of a discriminated model (TargetIntentResult), it cannot be hidden from the wire-level API.\\\\r\\\\nIf the Python SDK board has recommended removing these types and you agree, then yes\\u2014adding @removed(version) is the only way to exclude them across all SDKs. Since the C# SDK has already shipped with these types, you could remove them in a C# patch release or the next planned release. This approach is acceptable for Python, but you need to confirm with the .NET team.\\\\r\\\\nAlso, it\\u2019s not possible to remove exported classes using _patch.py customization in the Python SDK.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-client-libraries#03client.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Clients\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/03client\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Two Operation Groups\\\\n\\\\nTwo clients that separate the operations can be declared using the `@client` decorator and the `@operationGroup` decorator from `typespec-client-generator-core`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=\\\\\\\"main.tsp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/feed\\\\\\\") op feed(): void;\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/pet\\\\\\\") op pet(): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec title=\\\\\\\"client.tsp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"./main.tsp\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport PetStore,\\\\r\\\\n})\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStoreRenamed; // this namespace will be the namespace of the clients and operation groups defined in this customization file\\\\r\\\\n@operationGroup\\\\r\\\\ninterface OpGrp1 {\\\\r\\\\n  feed is PetStore.feed;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@operationGroup\\\\r\\\\ninterface OpGrp2 {\\\\r\\\\n  pet is PetStore.pet;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n// generated _client.py\\\\r\\\\nclass PetStoreClient:\\\\r\\\\n    def __init__(self, endpoint: str, **kwargs: Any) -\\\\u003e None: ...\\\\r\\\\n// generated operations/_operations.py\\\\r\\\\nclass OpGrp1Operations:\\\\r\\\\n    @distributed_trace\\\\r\\\\n    def feed(self, **kwargs: Any) -\\\\u003e None:\\\\r\\\\nclass OpGrp2Operations:\\\\r\\\\n    @distributed_trace\\\\r\\\\n    def pet(self, **kwargs: Any) -\\\\u003e None:\\\\r\\\\n//usage sample\\\\r\\\\nfrom response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To make an interface internal so that it does not appear in the public interface of the generated Python SDK, you should use the `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` decorator from `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` on the interface itself. However, simply marking the interface or its operations as internal is not sufficient if any of its operations or models are referenced by public operations elsewhere in your TypeSpec. The access level propagates: if a model or operation is referenced by a public operation, it will be included in the public SDK interface regardless of its own access setting.\\n\\nFor your scenario:\\n- Apply `@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")` to the interface and all its operations.\\n- Ensure that none of the operations or models from this interface are referenced by any public operations or models elsewhere in your TypeSpec. If they are, they will be promoted to public in the SDK.\\n\\nExample:\\n```typespec\\nimport \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core\\\";\\nusing Azure.ClientGenerator.Core;\\n\\n@access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\ninterface EvaluationResultsOperations {\\n  @access(Access.internal, \\\"python\\\")\\n  op getResults(): EvaluationResult[];\\n}\\n\\nmodel EvaluationResult {\\n  value: string;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIf you follow this pattern and ensure no public references, the interface and its operations will be hidden from the public Python SDK client. If you still see it in the generated SDK, double-check for any public references or usage that might be causing it to be promoted to public.\\n\\nNote: There is no supported way to remove exported classes or interfaces using Python SDK customization files (such as `_patch.py`). The only supported approach is via TypeSpec decorators as described above.\", \"ground_truth\": \"We do not support hiding an entire operation group directly. The recommended approach is to redefine your client in client.tsp to control which operations appear on the public client. When you do this properly, the default service clients and their Operations classes should not be emitted\\u2014as long as you remove all previously generated SDK output before regenerating. Or you can use _patch.py to customize the code.\"}"}]

Handling multiple API versions using typespec

actual.answer: No, TypeSpec does not support conditional imports based on API version in main.tsp or anywhere else. All imports are static and apply to the entire compilation context, regardless of version. To exclude a resource type or model from a new API version, you must use the versioning decorators provided by the @typespec/versioning library. Specifically, you should mark the types, models, or operations you want to remove with the @removed decorator for the new version. This ensures that those elements are omitted from the generated OpenAPI spec for that version, while remaining present in previous versions. If you are working with preview versions, Azure policy is to only have a single active preview version at a time, so you may also consider deleting the resource type file if it is no longer needed. Conditional imports are not supported; versioning decorators are the correct and supported approach.

We have some properties that we don't want to include in a stable release just yet, but don't want that to hold us from releasing the other properties in a stable release.\\\\r\\\\nCan we have multiple versions marked with @previewVersion? How do we handle a property that is in multiple preview versions, but we want to keep out of stable versions? \\\\r\\\\nFor a practical example, we have the faultSimulation apis in our spec in 2024-11-01-preview, 2025-03-01-preview, 2025-06-01-preview, and 2025-07-01-preview. If I mark 2025-07-01-preview with @previewVersion and faultSimulation with @added(versions.v2025_07_01_preview), the generation removes it from the previous preview specs.\\\\n\\\\n## EmployeeProperties {\\\\n\\\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2024-10-01`,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2025-07-01-preview version */\\\\r\\\\n @added(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\\\r\\\\n  age?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** City of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** Profile of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-07-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @encode(\\\\\\\"base64url\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  profile?: bytes;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last operation. */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nshowing two propertties (EmployeeProperties.age and EmployeeProperties.profile) that use versioning.  'age' appears in the second, stable version and all subsequent versions,  'profile' appears in the first (preview) version, is removed in the stable version, and then added back again in the subsequent preview version.\\\\r\\\\nNotably, this practice of adding a property at each preview version and removing it at each stable is easy to get wrong.   \\\\r\\\\nthe official Azure policy is to have only one active preview, as much as that is possible with api retention requirements.  So that, when you introduce a new preview version, the older preview is removed, ideally, this means that, especially when you just had a stable release, you remove support for the previous preview when (or soon after) you add the new preview version. \\\\r\\\\nYou can see more details about versioning in typespec here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/versioning/)\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.  It can be added back using `@added` [Here is a\\\\n\\\\nthe following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.  It can be added back using `@added` [Here is a playground](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D\\\\%2BQAoWVudW3oARNzIHsKICDELjIwMjEtMTAtMDEtcHJldmlld8g1xDQgIEB1c2VEZXBlbmRlbmN5KPUBLy7IVi52MV8wX1DGSF8xKcRAYXJtQ29tbW9uVOQBz8cq10jLKctUNcRIYPIAqWAsCuoAxTTGHP8Avf8Avf8Avf8Avf4AvecAoe0AtTUtMDf%2FAXr%2FAL3%2FAL3%2FAL3%2FAL3qAL3vAKlgLAp95gJtQegCb%2BsCiCDoA6rkAMhtb2RlbCBFbXBsb3llZSBpcyBUcmFja2Vk6ACCPMgcUHJvcGVydGllcz7lAp4uLukApuQDUFBhcmFtZXRlcskxPjvoAIbJX3DJRNJ8ymDpAv1BZ2Ugb2YgZcg%2F5gF4YWRk6wN%2BLuwBveQBEGFnZT86IGludDMyO%2BgBzENpdHnSSmNpdHk%2FOiBzdHLlBIPHLFByb2ZpbNR5cmVtb3bce%2FQAm%2FABm8UoZW5jb2RlKCJiYXNlNjR1cmwixBdwxno%2FOiBieXRlc%2BkAklRoZSBzdGF0dXPkAJV0aGUgbGFzdCDkAS9hdGlvbuUE4CAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAkphZMddxCDlBW9TdGF0xGflAhXMFOkBssRzzDLlAIDlARRh6QI%2FxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQDHNFU5QHO5gFk6QNcxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QaJ6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBuHHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"language-basics#imports.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Imports\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/imports\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Imports\\\\n# language-basics#imports.md\\\\n\\\\n# Imports\\\\n\\\\nImports are used to include files or libraries into your TypeSpec program. When compiling a TypeSpec file, you specify the path to your root TypeSpec file, typically named \\\\\\\"main.tsp\\\\\\\". From this root file, any imported files are added to your program. If a directory is imported, TypeSpec will search for a `main.tsp` file within that directory.\\\\r\\\\nThe path specified in the import must either start with `\\\\\\\"./\\\\\\\"` or `\\\\\\\"../\\\\\\\"`, or be an absolute path. The path should either point to a directory, or have an extension of either \\\\\\\".tsp\\\\\\\" or \\\\\\\".js\\\\\\\". The examples below illustrate how to use imports to assemble a TypeSpec program from multiple files:\\\\n\\\\n## Importing a TypeSpec file\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"./models/foo.tsp\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Importing a JavaScript file\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"./decorators.js\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Importing a library\\\\n\\\\nThe import value can be the name of one of the package dependencies.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"/rest\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n// ./node_modules/@typespec/rest/package.json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"exports\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\".\\\\\\\": { \\\\\\\"typespec\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"./lib/main.tsp\\\\\\\" }\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis results in `./node_modules/@typespec/rest/lib/main.tsp` being imported.\\\\n\\\\n### Package resolution algorithm\\\\n\\\\nWhen trying to import a package TypeSpec follows the following logic\\\\r\\\\n1. Parse the package name from the import specificier into `pkgName` and `subPath` (e.g. `@scope/lib/named` =\\\\u003e pkgName: `@scope/lib` subpath: `named` )\\\\r\\\\n1. Look to see if `pkgName` is itself(Containing package)\\\\r\\\\n1. Otherwise lookup for a parent folder with a `node_modules/${pkgName}` sub folder\\\\r\\\\n1. Reading the `package.json` of the package\\\\r\\\\n   a. If `exports` is defined respect the [ESM logic](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/main/doc/api/esm.md) to resolve the `typespec` condition(TypeSpec will not respect the `default` condition)\\\\r\\\\n   b. If `exports` is not found or for back compat the `.` export is missing the `typespec` condition fallback to checking `tspMain` or `main`\\\\n\\\\n## Importing a directory\\\\n\\\\nIf the import value is a directory, TypeSpec will check if that directory is a Node package and follow the npm package [lookup logic](#importing-a-library), or if the directory contains a `main.tsp` file.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"./models\\\\\\\"; // equivalent to `import \\\\\\\"./models/main.tsp\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"./path/to/local/module\\\\\\\"; // Assuming this path is a TypeSpec package, it will load it using the tspMain file.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003e [!IMPORTANT]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e TypeSpec Azure usage for API definition is a mandatory requirement for all new (greenfield) data plane and management plane\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e services. This requirement is enforced by the ARM API Review Board for management plane services and by the API\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Stewardship Board for data plane services.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Brownfield services must transition to TypeSpec Azure by March 30, 2026.  Starting in Q4FY26, PRs for new API versions that are not based on TypeSpec will be blocked. SDK releases from non-TypeSpec specs will be blocked as well. The requirement to move to TypeSpec Azure will ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Azure that aligns with Azure SDK guidelines. For more information on TypeSpec Azure, visit [here](xref:api-typespec).\\\\r\\\\n[TypeSpec](https://typespec.io) is the new standard API definition language for Azure, developed by Microsoft. It is an open-source tool designed to generate OpenAPI specifications and other API description languages. TypeSpec can also produce client code, with service code generation in progress. TypeSpec offers highly extensible core language primitives that can describe API shapes common among REST patterns used for Azure.\\\\n\\\\n## Benefits of TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n- **Consistency across APIs**: TypeSpec ensures consistency across APIs by using high-level templates, reducing the need for repetitive tasks and minimizing errors. This uniform design approach acts as a single source of truth for API definitions, enhancing both consistency and quality.\\\\r\\\\n- **Efficiency and speed**: TypeSpec significantly reduces the amount of code needed to define API specifications. A ten-line code snippet in TypeSpec can generate a hundred lines of an OpenAPI specification, drastically reducing manual effort.\\\\r\\\\n- **Enhanced tooling**: TypeSpec comes with advanced tools that catch errors early, leading to more robust APIs. Additionally, extensions for [Visual Studio](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=typespec.typespecvs) and [VS Code](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=typespec.typespec-vscode) aid in efficient TypeSpec creation.\\\\r\\\\n- **Accessibility**: The compact nature of TypeSpec, combined with its familiar JavaScript-style syntax, allows even non-technical stakeholders to participate in the API review and design process.\\\\n\\\\n## Case Studies\\\\n\\\\nHear directly from teams who have successfully transitioned to TypeSpec Azure and learn about their experiences:\\\\n\\\\n### Azure Batch\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"There's definitions in Swagger, but \\u2026 TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export.\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n### MS Learn\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\u201cOne of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.\\u201d\\\\n\\\\n### Azure AI Content Safety\\\\n\\\\n[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e \\\\\\\"I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.\\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n\\\\nWhether you're working with Data Plane (DP) or Azure Resource Manager (ARM), having clear examples to follow can make your transition to TypeSpec smoother. Here are some resources that can help:\\\\r\\\\n- **Playground Examples**: Our playground provides ARM and DP examples that serve as excellent models for teams new to TypeSpec Azure. These examples are concise and take full advantage of our standard operation templates. You can use these as a gold standard for your own TypeSpec definitions. Visit the [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure) to explore these examples.\\\\r\\\\n- **ARM Samples**: For more specific scenarios, check out our additional [ARM samples](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/tree/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/arm-scenarios). These are tutorial-like examples that cover various scenarios. You can adapt these to fit your specific needs.\\\\r\\\\nThe playground examples are a great starting point for getting familiar with TypeSpec Azure. As you gain more experience, you can leverage the ARM samples to understand how to apply TypeSpec to a variety of scenarios.\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec office hours\\\\n\\\\nJoin us on Mondays from 4-5 PM PT for our TypeSpec office hours. These sessions are designed to answer your questions and offer guidance on using TypeSpec Azure effectively. You can find the invite in the calendar in the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams Channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).\\\\n\\\\n## Resources\\\\n\\\\n- [TypeSpec Azure Docs](https://aka.ms/typespec/azure): A comprehensive guide to using TypeSpec in Azure.\\\\r\\\\n- [TypeSpec tutorial](https://aka.ms/typespec/getstarted): TypeSpec tutorial to define REST APIs with HTTP.\\\\r\\\\n- [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure): An interactive platform to experiment with TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n- [Getting Started with TypeSpec in azure-rest-api-specs repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/Getting-started-with-TypeSpec-specifications.md): A step-by-step guide to getting started with TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n- [Tool converting OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec](https://aka.ms/typespec/migrate): A handy tool to help you transition from OpenAPI to TypeSpec.\\\\n\\\\n## Get help\\\\n\\\\nIf you need help or have questions, join the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).  \\\\r\\\\nThis is a community of TypeSpec users and experts who are ready to assist you.\\\\n\\\\n### Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel includes an Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot that is designed to help you with questions  \\\\r\\\\nrelated to TypeSpec, Azure TypeSpec, and the related emitters. Simply mention `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` directly in your  \\\\r\\\\nmessage with a clear description of the problem you're facing.\\\\r\\\\n**Example usage:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot: How can I describe HTTP status codes for responses in TypeSpec?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Best practices for using the bot:**\\\\r\\\\n- Start a conversation by mentioning `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` in the TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel - note that  \\\\r\\\\n  modifying existing posts won't trigger a response\\\\r\\\\n- The bot only has context from messages that directly mention it and cannot access or see messages outside of that  \\\\r\\\\n  context\\\\r\\\\n- It supports images and GitHub pull request links for better context\\\\r\\\\n- All replies are generated by AI, so please double-check to ensure the information is correct\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Creating stable API version with select properties omitted?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Creating stable API version with select properties omitted?\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\\n\\\\n# Creating stable API version with select properties omitted?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nIs it possible on typeSpec to add a new preview with some new parameters and a new stable for all other properties that we already have? @added(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\\\r\\\\n  age?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** City of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** Profile of employee */\\\\r\\\\n EmployeeProperties.profile) that use versioning.  'age' appears in the second, stable version and all subsequent versions,  'profile' appears in the first (preview) version, is removed in the stable version, and then added back again in the subsequent preview version.\\\\r\\\\nNotably, this practice of adding a property at each preview version and removing it at each stable is easy to get wrong.   \\\\r\\\\nthe official Azure policy is to have only one active preview, as much as that is possible with api retention requirements.  So that, when you introduce a new preview version, the older preview is removed, ideally, this means that, especially when you just had a stable release, you remove support for the previous preview when (or soon after) you add the new preview version. \\\\r\\\\nYou can see more details about versioning in typespec here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/versioning/)\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions. Supporting TypeSpec files for the service\\\\r\\\\n- `examples/\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e/` - TypeSpec examples organized by API version\\\\r\\\\n**README and configuration files**:\\\\r\\\\n- `readme.md` - Central file that groups APIs into different tags for tooling purposes\\\\r\\\\n- `readme.lang.md` - Language-specific README files for SDK generation (deprecated when TypeSpec is used)\\\\r\\\\n**Generated OpenAPI specifications**:\\\\r\\\\n- `stable/\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e/` - Contains stable API version specifications\\\\r\\\\n- `preview/\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e/` - Contains preview API version specifications\\\\r\\\\nThe `stable` and `preview` folders contain OpenAPI specifications in their respective [lifecycle stages][aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions], organized in structure:\\\\r\\\\n- **main.tsp**: Entry point for the TypeSpec specification containing service information\\\\r\\\\n- **{resource-name}.tsp**: Resource-specific operations for each ARM resource type\\\\r\\\\n- **routes.tsp**: All other operations that don't belong to specific resources\\\\r\\\\n- **models.tsp**: All the model definitions used across operations\\\\r\\\\n- **(optional) openapi.2.0.yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/FileTree\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nGenerating separate specs for each version ensures backward compatibility, provides clear documentation for developers to understand differences between versions, and simplifies maintenance by allowing independent updates to each version's specifications.\\\\r\\\\nBy encapsulating different versions of the API within the context of the same TypeSpec project, we can manage all versions in a unified manner. There is special logic we do with api version parameters:\\\\r\\\\n1. These api version parameters get elevated up to the client level (if the service is versioned)\\\\r\\\\n2. We set the client default for these parameters to be the default api version for your service.\\\\r\\\\nThere are cases where you have an api-versioning parameter without the explicit name `api-version`. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"remove Library\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/extending-typespec/basics\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Creating a TypeSpec Library\\\\n## Step 2: Adding TypeSpec types to your library\\\\n# extending-typespec#basics.md\\\\n\\\\n# Creating a TypeSpec Library\\\\n\\\\n## Step 2: Adding TypeSpec types to your library\\\\n\\\\nOpen `./lib/main.tsp` and add any types you want to be available when users import this library. It's strongly recommended to put these types in a namespace that corresponds with the library name. For example, your `./lib/main.tsp` file might look like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"../dist/index.js\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nnamespace MyLibrary;\\\\r\\\\nmodel Person {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  age: uint8;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\\n\\\\n# Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi folks, \\\\r\\\\nDo you have any process or script to execute when creating a new api version with TypeSpec which is similar to current [Copy-ApiVersion.ps1](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/eng/scripts/Copy-ApiVersion.ps1) script with API Spec?  \\\\r\\\\nAs within the TypeSpec, those examples needs to be added manually and change the api version in it. I wonder if there are any existing script for doing this. Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIn TypeSPec, this is much simpler.  You don't need to replicate your old APIs, you just encode the changes in the api and tag them with decorators from the versioning library, as discussed here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/) \\\\r\\\\nYou will need to copy the example files from the example directory from the last version into a new example directory for the new version, and add any new examples. \\\\r\\\\nIf you run into any issues, don't hesitate to ask questions here, or come to our office hours on Monday.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"or specific areas\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/configuration/configuration\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# or specific areas\\\\n### `imports` - Configure additional imports\\\\n# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# or specific areas\\\\n\\\\n### `imports` - Configure additional imports\\\\n\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nimports:\\\\r\\\\n  - sidecar.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nSpecify additional TypeSpec files to import\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\ntsp compile . --import \\\\\\\"sidecar.tsp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getstarted#azure-core#step09.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"9. Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/azure-core/step09\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# 9. Versioning\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n# getstarted#azure-core#step09.md\\\\n\\\\n# 9. Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n\\\\nthe `Versions` enum:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou will also need to add the `@useDependency` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, you can express changes to your service using the `@added` and `@removed` decorators. response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"No, TypeSpec does not support conditional imports based on API version in main.tsp or anywhere else. All imports are static and apply to the entire compilation context, regardless of version. To exclude a resource type or model from a new API version, you must use the versioning decorators provided by the @typespec/versioning library. Specifically, you should mark the types, models, or operations you want to remove with the @removed decorator for the new version. This ensures that those elements are omitted from the generated OpenAPI spec for that version, while remaining present in previous versions. If you are working with preview versions, Azure policy is to only have a single active preview version at a time, so you may also consider deleting the resource type file if it is no longer needed. Conditional imports are not supported; versioning decorators are the correct and supported approach.\", \"ground_truth\": \"no, you have to mark the models/types and everything that you want to remove with the @removed decorator using the versioning library\\nif you are in preview version I think also the policy is to only have a single preview version in the spec repo at the timme now so you could also just delete it\"}"}]

TypeSpec: How can I change only descriptions/comments between versions while keeping models identical?

actual.answer: The best practice is to update the documentation (model descriptions) in all API versions, not just the latest. Documentation-only changes are not considered breaking changes in Azure TypeSpec projects, and they do not trigger SDK releases or require version-specific handling. If TypeSpec validation fails due to documentation changes not being present in older specs, you should simply update those older specs with the improved descriptions. There is no need to change the output path in tspconfig.yaml to only generate the current version; doing so would not be compliant with Azure API versioning guidelines and would reduce reproducibility and traceability across versions. Instead, keep generating all versions and ensure documentation improvements are reflected everywhere. Any CI checks that flag documentation-only changes as breaking can be safely approved, as these do not impact wire shape or client compatibility.

Example: '$filter=kind eq 'v1'\\n*/\\n@query(\\\"$filter\\\")\\n$filter?: string;\\n}\\n>;\\n```\\nHowever, the versioning breaks. It does not work if I change to:\\n```\\n@removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\nlistBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<QuantumSuiteOffer>;\\n@added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\nlistBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<\\nQuantumSuiteOffer,\\nParameters = {\\n/**\\n* The filter to apply to the operation. Example: '$filter=kind eq 'v1'\\n*/\\n@query(\\\"$filter\\\")\\n$filter?: string;\\n}\\n>;\\n```\\nOr\\n```\\n@removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\nlistBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<QuantumSuiteOffer>;\\n@added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\nlistBySubscriptionV2 is ArmListBySubscription<\\nQuantumSuiteOffer,\\nParameters = {\\n/**\\n* The filter to apply to the operation. Example: '$filter=kind eq 'v1'\\n*/\\n@query(\\\"$filter\\\")\\n$filter?: string;\\n}\\n>;\\n```\\nCould anyone provide suggestions how I can fix this issue? Thanks\", \"response\": \"To correctly version your `listBySubscription` operation to support a new filter parameter in the Quantum RP offering API, you should use the TypeSpec versioning decorators to indicate when the old operation is removed and the new one is added. However, you must ensure that the new operation signature is actually different\\u2014typically by adding a new parameter model for the filter, and using the `Parameters` template argument of `ArmListBySubscription`.\\n\\nHere's the recommended approach:\\n\\n1. **Define a parameters model for the filter** (and any other query parameters you want to support):\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel OfferingListParameters {\\n  @query(\\\"filter\\\")\\n  filter?: string;\\n  // Add other query parameters as needed\\n}\\n```\\n\\n2. **Version the operation using @removed and @added decorators**. The new operation should use the `Parameters` argument:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Offerings {\\n  // Old operation (no filter)\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering>;\\n\\n  // New operation (with filter)\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering, Parameters = OfferingListParameters>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\n**Key points:**\\n- The operation name (`listBySubscription`) can stay the same if you use @removed/@added to version the signature. The TypeSpec compiler will emit the correct operation for each version.\\n- If you want to keep both operations for some reason, you can use different names (e.g., `listBySubscriptionV2`), but the standard pattern is to keep the name and version the signature.\\n- Make sure your `Versions` enum is up to date and referenced correctly.\\n- The filter parameter should be optional unless you want to require it for all requests.\\n\\n**Why your previous attempts failed:**\\n- If you use the same operation signature for both @removed and @added, TypeSpec sees no difference and may not emit the correct versioned API. You must change the operation signature (by adding the parameters model) for the new version.\\n\\n**Example:**\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Offerings {\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering>;\\n\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering, Parameters = OfferingListParameters>;\\n}\\n```\\nThis will generate the correct OpenAPI for each version: the old version without filter, and the new version with filter support.\\n\\nIf you need to support more query parameters, you can extend `OfferingListParameters` or use intersection types as shown in the references.\", \"ground_truth\": \"For a case like this, just decorating the filter property with `@added` in the same operation is the simplest mechanism.  Versioning the request and response data in an operation like this is usually the most straightforward way to version an operation.\\nFor more complex operation versioning, you can use the remove/rename/sharedRoute mechanism described here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/#converting-an-operation-from-synchronous-to-asynchronous)\\nNote also that you should name the property 'filter', the `@query(\\\"$filter\\\")` decorator actually sets the name on the wire,  you generally want to follow standard naming rules for parameters:\\n```\\n// v2 (new preview)\\nlistBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<\\nQuantumSuiteOffer,\\nParameters = {\\n/**\\n* The filter to apply to the operation. Example: '$filter=kind eq \\\"v1\\\"'\\n*/\\n@added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n@query(\\\"$filter\\\")\\nfilter?: string;\\n}\\n>;\\n```\"}"}]

The new operation should use the `Parameters` argument:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Offerings {\\n  // Old operation (no filter)\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering>;\\n\\n  // New operation (with filter)\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering, Parameters = OfferingListParameters>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\n**Key points:**\\n- The operation name (`listBySubscription`) can stay the same if you use @removed/@added to version the signature. The TypeSpec compiler will emit the correct operation for each version.\\n- If you want to keep both operations for some reason, you can use different names (e.g., `listBySubscriptionV2`), but the standard pattern is to keep the name and version the signature.\\n- Make sure your `Versions` enum is up to date and referenced correctly.\\n- The filter parameter should be optional unless you want to require it for all requests.\\n\\n**Why your previous attempts failed:**\\n- If you use the same operation signature for both @removed and @added, TypeSpec sees no difference and may not emit the correct versioned API. You must change the operation signature (by adding the parameters model) for the new version.\\n\\n**Example:**\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Offerings {\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering>;\\n\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering, Parameters = OfferingListParameters>;\\n}\\n```\\nThis will generate the correct OpenAPI for each version: the old version without filter, and the new version with filter support.\\n\\nIf you need to support more query parameters, you can extend `OfferingListParameters` or use intersection types as shown in the references.\", \"context\": \"[{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"ARM Resource Operations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/resource-operations\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n### Resource List Operations (GET)\\\\n# howtos#arm#resource-operations.md\\\\n\\\\n# ARM Resource Operations\\\\n\\\\n## TypeSpec Operation Templates and Interface Templates\\\\n\\\\n### Resource List Operations (GET)\\\\n\\\\nArm Resource list operations return a list of Tracked or Proxy Resources at a particular scope.\\\\r\\\\n- All resources _should_ include a list operation at its immediate parent scope\\\\r\\\\n  - For **Tenant Resources**, this is at the tenant scope\\\\r\\\\n  - For **Extension Resources**, this is at the scope of resources they are extending\\\\r\\\\n  - For **Tracked Resources**, this is at the resource group scope.\\\\r\\\\n  - For **Child Resources**, this is at the scope of the resource parent.\\\\r\\\\n- Tracked resources _must_ include a list operation at the Subscription level.\\\\r\\\\n| Operation          | TypeSpec                                                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| ListByParent       | `listByWidget is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cResourceType\\\\u003e`     |\\\\r\\\\n| ListBySubscription | `listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cResourceType\\\\u003e` |\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#common-api-details.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Common API Details\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/common-api-details.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Common API Details\\\\n## Request Query Parameters ##\\\\n# v1.0#common-api-details.md\\\\n\\\\n# Common API Details\\\\n\\\\n## Request Query Parameters ##\\\\n\\\\nARM will proxy request parameters (e.g. $filter; $expand; $skipToken; etc.) as-is to the Resource Providers. appropriate for list responses.  \\\\r\\\\nI see we can override the properties for ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync and ArmResourcePatchAsync, but I don't see a way to do this for ArmResourceRead or required. The only way I can see to do this would be to make it appear optional but return an error is the user tried to set it to empty or null.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"notificationHubName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The name of the NotificationHubResource\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": true,\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"pattern\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9-./_]*$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"authorizationRuleName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The name of the SharedAccessAuthorizationRuleResource\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": true,\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"pattern\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z0-9!()*-._]+$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExpected: [This](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/5351ac8e1e6fdf48933bae2cd879434b93b36ac0/specification/notificationhubs/resource-manager/Microsoft.NotificationHubs/preview/2023-10-01-preview/notificationhubs.json#L417-L425) \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/parameters/NamespaceName\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/parameters/HubName\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/parameters/AuthorizationRuleName\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nis the original swagger. There is limitations on minLength and maxLength.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nYes, because the actual path parameters do not come from the resource, you would need to decorate the parameters in the LegacyOperations instantiation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWhen you construct the LegacyOperations interface, you pass in the parameters - those passed-in parameters would need to be decorated.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nI wonder if we shouldn't have a legacy resource template that omits the name parameter, just to avoid confusion, it is literally unused in this context.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you need to decorate the name parameter, you will need to define them directly, or name the resulting model, so they can be decoratred.  You can decorate a model statement, but not a model expression.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n# First experience of TSP ApiVersion introduction - passed all CI checks, what's next?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi TypeSpec friends!\\\\n\\\\n`TypeSpec.Http.OkResponse` which causes problems in downstream. Can we remove this model? (omit-unreachable-types: true does not work)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nIf the `OkResponse` model is being emitted but not actually referenced, that does sound like a bug \\u2014 we shouldn't be generating unused models. Especially in cases like this where you're doing a long-running POST action and the 200 response is effectively empty, it\\u2019s more accurate to model the operation with just a `202` and an error response.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFor your case, you can avoid using `OkResponse` entirely by switching to `ArmResourceActionNoResponseContentAsync` or passing `never` as the third argument. That will prevent the generation of the unnecessary `OkResponse` model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAlso, keep in mind that for LROs, the POST operation typically doesn't return 200 anyway. That response is just a placeholder in the old pattern to signal \\\\\\\"void\\\\\\\". If you're converting from existing Swagger, and it doesn\\u2019t actually return 200, you should be able to safely drop that response from the Swagger and avoid the breaking change.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, if you do need to customize the final response for the LRO, `getLroResponse` can be used to override the response returned at the end of the operation \\u2014 no need to rely on `OkResponse` at all.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n# TSP Install fails with below error\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nI am trying to install TSP and its dependencies and it fails with below error. In such cases the Resource Provider should also mark the Resource State as \\\\u0026quot;Suspended.\\\\u0026quot;  We recommend that you treat this as a soft-delete: GET/DELETE management APIs must continue to function, yet PUT/PATCH/POST must not. **Don't emit any usage. Any emitted usage will be ignored.**|\\\\r\\\\n| **Deleted** | The customer has cancelled their Windows Azure subscription and its content \\\\\\\\*must\\\\\\\\* be cleaned up by the resource provider.The resource provider does \\\\\\\\*not\\\\\\\\* receive a DELETE call for each resource \\u2013 this is expected to be handled internally by the RP as a \\\\u0026quot;cascade\\\\u0026quot; deletion. Because this subscription lifecycle handling bypasses ARM's linked notification handling, a given RP will also be responsible for this internal deletion of any associated extension resources.|\\\\r\\\\n| **Unregistered** | Either the customer has not yet chosen to use the resource provider, or the customer has decided to stop using the Resource Provider. Only GETs are permitted. In the case of formerly registered subscriptions, all existing tracked resources would already have been deleted by the customer explicitly. RP extension resources would require an internal \\\\u0026quot;cascade\\\\u0026quot; delete cleanup similar to the **Deleted** case above.|\\\\n\\\\n**Allowed Actions when 'Warned' or 'Suspended'**\\\\r\\\\nWhen configured correctly inside a given RP manifest, ARM will handle filtering actions (example: not allowing PUT/POST/PATCH) and returning a 409 when a given action is not allowed for a current state. This filtering does not need to be managed directly by the RP.\\\\r\\\\n| SubscriptionState | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|-------------| ----------------|\\\\r\\\\n| **Registered** | The subscription was entitled to use your \\\\u0026quot;ResourceProviderNamespace\\\\u0026quot;.   Azure will use this subscription in future communications. You may also do any initial state setup as a result of this notification type.  When a subscription is \\\\u0026quot;fixed\\\\u0026quot; / restored from being suspended, it will return to the \\\\u0026quot;Registered\\\\u0026quot; state.  All management APIs must function (PUT/PATCH/DELETE/POST/GET), all resources must run normally; Bill normally.|\\\\r\\\\n| **Warned** | The subscription has been warned (generally due to forthcoming suspension resulting from fraud or non-payment). Resources must be offline but in running (or quickly recoverable state).  Do **not** deallocate resources.   GET/DELETE management APIs must function; PUT/PATCH/POST must not.  **Don't emit any usage. Any emitted usage will be ignored.**|\\\\r\\\\n| **Suspended** | The subscription has been suspended (generally due to fraud or non-payment) and the Resource Provider should stop the subscription from generating any additional usage. Pay-for-use resource should have access rights revoked when the subscription is disabled.   In such cases the Resource Provider should also mark the Resource State as \\\\u0026quot;Suspended.\\\\u0026quot;  We recommend that you treat this as a soft-delete: GET/DELETE management APIs must continue to function, yet PUT/PATCH/POST must not. **Don't emit any usage. Any emitted usage will be ignored.**|\\\\r\\\\n| **Deleted** | The customer has cancelled their Windows Azure subscription and its content \\\\\\\\*must\\\\\\\\* be cleaned up by the resource provider.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_resource_manager_rpc\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"v1.0#uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Uri format and arguments for CRUD APIs on resources #\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Uri format and arguments for CRUD APIs on resources #\\\\n## Overview ##\\\\n### Uri format ###\\\\n# v1.0#uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md\\\\n\\\\n# Uri format and arguments for CRUD APIs on resources #\\\\n\\\\n## Overview ##\\\\n\\\\n### Uri format ###\\\\n\\\\nARM has a prescriptive uri scheme that it requires all service teams to implement. This is because ARM acts as a front door for all control plane APIs and a standardized uri scheme allows it to route these APIs appropriately. ARM requires specific operations to have a specific number of segments in the uri. For eg: a PUT operation must always be performed against an even segmented uri path. ARM also interprets the intent of an operation based on the number of segments and applies custom logic to API invocations. For eg: A list call is distinguished from a GET on a single object based on detecting an odd segmented API path. When LIST calls are issued at the subscription or resource group scope, the call is fanned out to all regions where the resource type is registered in order to create a consolidated view of all resources in the collection.\\\\r\\\\nHere is the uri scheme that must be implemented for each scope\\\\r\\\\n| Scope | Http Methods [Variant] | URI |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| Tenant | PUT, GET, PATCH, DELETE | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/providers/{namespace}/{resourceType}/{resourceName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n| Tenant | PUT, GET, PATCH, DELETE [Singleton] | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/providers/{namespace}/{resourceType}/default?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n| Tenant | POST | https://\\\\u0026lt;endpoint\\\\u0026gt;/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/{namespace}/{resourceType}/{resourceName}?api-version={api-version} |\\\\r\\\\n| Subscription | GET [List] | Guide\\\\n## Splitting a Monolithic SDK Package into Service-Specific Packages\\\\n# Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n\\\\n## Splitting a Monolithic SDK Package into Service-Specific Packages\\\\n\\\\nnot accurately reflect the name of the remaining service. We\\u2019ll have to decide on the package name on a case-by-case basis.  \\\\r\\\\nThe Azure Breaking Change and Azure SDK Architecture Boards are aware of this scenario and have agreed to approve these 1-time breaks related to splitting a monolithic SDK package into multiple service-specific packages so that engineering and customers can get on a long-term sustainable future. The Azure API Stewardship and ARM review Boards are also aware of this.  \\\\r\\\\nCurrently, several Azure service teams have already decided to split their monolithic SDK package into service specific SDK packages: Compute, Monitor, Container Registry, Observability, AI Language, AI Speech, and more.\\\\n\\\\nFor service teams violating the above service versioning rules, their current monolithic SDK package must be split into separate service-specific SDK packages. The good news is that this 1-time break for customers is fairly simple for them.  \\\\r\\\\nFirst, a customer can continue to use the SDK package they\\u2019re using today but this SDK package may never version ever again (more about this later).   \\\\r\\\\nWhen a service introduces a new version, that service will now get its own/new SDK package that hereafter versions 1:1 with the service itself. A customer that wants to leverage the new service version will have to import a new SDK package that they never imported before. However, all the structures, classes, \\\\u0026 methods in this new package are identical to what they were called in the old monolithic package. Depending on the language, some customers may just have to import a new namespace or rename a package name in their code; the code that actually references the structures, classes, \\\\u0026 methods requires no change.  \\\\r\\\\nThe last service to split-off from the monolithic SDK package may either get its own/new SDK package and name (as described in the previous paragraph) or it may stay in a new version of the original SDK package (same name as before). But, in this new package version, everything related to the already split-out services no longer exists. This latter scenario reduces some customer pain, but the name of the package may not accurately reflect the name of the remaining service. We\\u2019ll have to decide on the package name on a case-by-case basis.  \\\\r\\\\nThe Azure Breaking Change and Azure SDK Architecture Boards are aware of this scenario and have agreed to approve these 1-time breaks related to splitting a monolithic SDK package into multiple service-specific packages so that engineering and customers can get on a long-term sustainable future. The Azure API Stewardship and ARM review Boards are also aware of this.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getstarted#azure-resource-manager#step05.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"6.
