notification message */\\\\r\\\\n  message: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** If true, the notification is urgent */\\\\r\\\\n  urgent: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Users {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    User,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cUser, UserProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  /** Send a notification to the user */\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"notify\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  NotifyUser is ArmResourceActionNoContentSync\\\\u003cUser, NotificationDetails\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/** An address resource belonging to a user resource */\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(User)\\\\r\\\\nmodel AddressResource is ProxyResource\\\\u003cAddressResourceProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003cAddressResource, KeyName = \\\\\\\"addressName\\\\\\\", SegmentName = \\\\\\\"addresses\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/** The properties of AddressResource */\\\\r\\\\nmodel AddressResourceProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The street address */\\\\r\\\\n  streetAddress: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The city of the address */\\\\r\\\\n  city: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The state of the address */\\\\r\\\\n  state: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The zip code of the address */\\\\r\\\\n  zip: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last operation */\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Addresses {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cAddressResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cAddressResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    AddressResource,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      AddressResource,\\\\r\\\\n      AddressResourceProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cAddressResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByParent is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cAddressResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  checkGlobalName is checkGlobalNameAvailability;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\nHere's a complete example `main.tsp` file based on all of the snippets in this README:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/rest\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Rest;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Azure.Core;\\\\r\\\\nusing Azure.ResourceManager;\\\\r\\\\n/** Contoso Resource Provider management API */\\\\r\\\\n@armProviderNamespace\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"ContosoProviderHubClient\\\\\\\", version: \\\\\\\"2021-01-01-preview\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.ContosoProviderHub;\\\\r\\\\ninterface Operations extends Azure.ResourceManager.Operations {}\\\\r\\\\n@lroStatus\\\\r\\\\nunion ProvisioningState {\\\\r\\\\n  ResourceProvisioningState,\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being provisioned. */\\\\r\\\\n  Provisioning: \\\\\\\"Provisioning\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being updated. */\\\\r\\\\n  Updating: \\\\\\\"Updating\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource is being deleted. */\\\\r\\\\n  Deleting: \\\\\\\"Deleting\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** The resource provisioning request has been accepted. */\\\\r\\\\n  Accepted: \\\\\\\"Accepted\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/** The properties of User Resource */\\\\r\\\\nmodel UserProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The user's full name */\\\\r\\\\n  fullName: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The user's email address */\\\\r\\\\n  emailAddress: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last operation */\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/** A User Resource */\\\\r\\\\nmodel User is TrackedResource\\\\u003cUserProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Address name */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"userName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @segment(\\\\\\\"users\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/** The details of a user notification */\\\\r\\\\nmodel NotificationDetails {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The notification message */\\\\r\\\\n  message: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** If true, the notification is urgent */\\\\r\\\\n  urgent: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Users {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  create is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    User,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003cUser, UserProperties\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteSync\\\\u003cUser\\\\u003e;\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n## An Azure Resource Provider and its 1+ Azure Services\\\\n# Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Service Versioning Guide\\\\n\\\\n## An Azure Resource Provider and its 1+ Azure Services\\\\n\\\\nIf 2+ services want to \\u201cshare\\u201d some TypeSpec/OpenAPI files, these files must be explicitly copied into a consuming service\\u2019s folder on its desired timeline. We do not allow multiple services to reference a single copy of a service contract because it is too dangerous to allow one service to change a shared contract, forcing other services to pick up this shared contract instantly, especially if the shared contract introduces breaking changes. Each service must be in control of its own destiny.\\\\r\\\\n4.\\\\tThe ServiceName folder must have examples, preview and stable subfolders. Additional subfolders are allowed to help organize *.tsp files. The rules should ensure that only the tspconfig.yaml  and *.tsp files are in the ServiceName folder.  \\\\r\\\\n5.\\\\tThe examples folder should only have a subfolder for each api-version and each api-version folder can contain only example *.json files for this api-version.\\\\r\\\\n6.\\\\tThe preview and stable folders must only have subfolders whose name match this format: YYYY-MM-DD-preview in the preview folder and YYYY-MM-DD in the stable folder. All the files in the YYYY-MM-DD(-preview) folders must be json (OpenAPI) files.\\\\r\\\\n7.\\\\tEach YYYY-MM-DD(-preview) folder must have an examples folder containing only example *.json files for this api-version.\\\\r\\\\n8.\\\\tIt is illegal for a preview and GA version to share the same date. For example, if there is a 2024-04-01-preview, then there can never be a 2024-04-01 GA.\\\\r\\\\n9. Each new control plane api-version should be unique across all the control plane service folders for an RP Namespace. \\\\r\\\\n10.\\\\tEach service name folder must duplicate the special \\\\\\\"list operations\\\\\\\" API. \\\\r\\\\n    - While this RP (not service) operation requires an api-version query parameter, the response data is not specific to this api-version; the response is api-version neutral. In addition, the response is always the same regardless of tenant/subscription.\\\\n\\\\nA single Azure Resource Provider (RP) has an RP namespace. This RP namespace can contain 1+ control-plane services and 0+ data-plane service; each service versions as described above. Today, we want the GitHub specs repo to be structured as follows for control-plane \\\\u0026 data-plane contracts:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nspecification/\\\\r\\\\n\\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003corgName1\\\\u003e/\\\\r\\\\n    \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 cspell.yaml\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 resource-manager/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\t\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df NOTE: For ARM schema validation; see bullet #2 below\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cRPNamespace\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df NOTE: Control-plane only (not data-plane) \\\\r\\\\n            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName1\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df Customer-facing service name; each version gets Documentation \\\\u0026 SDK package\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 tspconfig.yaml\\\\t\\u00df TypeSpec files\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 models.tsp\\\\r\\\\n                \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 readme.md\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df autorest readme with YAML blocks\\\\r\\\\n                \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 examples/\\\\t\\\\t\\u00df TypeSpec example folder\\\\r\\\\n                    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df One folder per service version described in TypeSpec\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cexample .json files\\\\u003e \\\\r\\\\n                \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 preview/ and stable/\\\\r\\\\n                    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003capi-version\\\\u003e/\\\\t\\u00df One folder per service version described in OpenAPI. These folders are created and populated by compiling the TypeSpec folder for the service.\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u251c\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cOpenAPI .json files\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n                        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 examples/\\\\t\\u00df OpenAPI example folder\\\\r\\\\n                            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cexample .json files\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n            \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName2\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 data-plane/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName3\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this structure, Azure services are presented as an RPNamespace that is used to manage services (both with customer-facing names). Each service has versions (some preview and some GA) and each version has its own API contract, documentation, and (beta/stable) SDK package(s).\\\\n\\\\nthere can never be a 2024-04-01 GA.\\\\r\\\\n9. Each new control plane api-version should be unique across all the control plane service folders for an RP Namespace. \\\\r\\\\n10.\\\\tEach service name folder must duplicate the special \\\\\\\"list operations\\\\\\\" API. \\\\r\\\\n    - While this RP (not service) operation requires an api-version query parameter, the response data is not specific to this api-version; the response is api-version neutral. In addition, the response is always the same regardless of tenant/subscription. Whenever any other service in the RP gets a new api-version, the TypeSpec/OpenAPI for the operations service must also be updated to match this new api-version.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003cServiceName2\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n    \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 data-plane/\\\\r\\\\n        \\u2514\\u2500\\u2500 \\\\u003cServiceName3\\\\u003e/\\\\t// Customer-facing service name; contents identical to above structure\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this structure, Azure services are presented as an RPNamespace that is used to manage services (both with customer-facing names). Each service has versions (some preview and some GA) and each version has its own API contract, documentation, and (beta/stable) SDK package(s).   \\\\r\\\\nTo enforce these rules, here are some notes about the repo structure:\\\\r\\\\n1.\\\\tIn the resource-manager folder, if it's a RPaaS service, there must be just 1 readme.md file, and 1+ service name folders under resource-manager/RPnamespace folder, but the resource types within each service folder must not duplicate except for operations, locations, checkNameAvailability etc. Which is required by RPaaS for HTTP request schema validation.\\\\r\\\\n2.\\\\tIn the data-plane folder there must be no files and at least 1 service name folder.\\\\r\\\\n3.\\\\tThe ServiceName folder must have only readme.*, tspconfig.yaml and *.tsp files in it. \\\\r\\\\n    - In the readme.md file, the latest package tag value (which represents a service version) must refer to OpenAPI files that are all in the exact same folder. Also, if the tag value is suffixed with \\u201c-preview\\u201d then all the OpenAPI paths must refer to files in the preview subfolder; else all OpenAPI paths must refer to files in the stable subfolder.\\\\r\\\\n    - If 2+ services want to \\u201cshare\\u201d some TypeSpec/OpenAPI files, these files must be explicitly copied into a consuming service\\u2019s folder on its desired timeline. We do not allow multiple services to reference a single copy of a service contract because it is too dangerous to allow one service to change a shared contract, forcing other services to pick up this shared contract instantly, especially if the shared contract introduces breaking changes. Each service must be in control of its own destiny.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Summarize-Impact.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Troubleshooting details\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Summarize-Impact\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"## Troubleshooting details\\\\n### Suppression change without triggering `Suppression Review Required`\\\\n# Summarize-Impact.md\\\\n\\\\n## Troubleshooting details\\\\n\\\\n### Suppression change without triggering `Suppression Review Required`\\\\n\\\\nIn certain circumstances, devs can can modify the suppressions for a readme, _without_ requiring a suppression review. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36645/files) is one such example. It is adding two new suppressions to a new API version, but the suppressions themselves _already exist_ for a previous API version. In this case, `summarize impact` _intentionally_ evaluates this PR to not need suppression review. If the RP was approved previously, it should be approved for this new api version as well.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Home.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Home\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"Welcome to the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo. This wiki contains some (but not all) documentation for the repo. Documentation updated frequently lives in the wiki, while documentation updated less often lives here:\\\\r\\\\n1. [`/documentation` directory in this repo](../blob/main/documentation)\\\\r\\\\n2. (Microsoft-internal) [Microsoft Azure SDK team documentation at aka.ms/azsdkdocs](https://aka.ms/azsdkdocs) \\\\r\\\\nIf you need help with a specification update PR submitted to this repository, consult:\\\\r\\\\n- [aka.ms/azsdk/pr-getting-help](https://aka.ms/azsdk/pr-getting-help)\\\\r\\\\nRead next: [[About the Wiki]].\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Adding Request Query or Header Parameters\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Request Query or Header Parameters\\\\n\\\\nThe `Parameters` template parameter allows you to specify additional parameters after the operation path (for example, query and header parameters) in the form of a model, with each model property corresponding to a parameter. You may use intersection to combine multiple separate parameters.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// All list query params\\\\r\\\\nop listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n  Widget,\\\\r\\\\n  Parameters = Azure.Core.StandardListQueryParameters\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n// Intersecting individual parameters\\\\r\\\\nop listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n  Widget,\\\\r\\\\n  Parameters = Azure.Core.TopQueryParameter \\\\u0026 Azure.Core.SkipQueryParameter\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\\\\n\\\\nhere's a Versioning\\\\n## Versioning Decorators\\\\n### @removed\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning Decorators\\\\n\\\\n### @removed\\\\n\\\\nTo remove models, properties, or operations starting from a specific version, use the `@removed` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n- The `version` argument is the version where the element is removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The element will not be present in that version or any later versions.\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Removing a property and a model across versions**\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// v1: Employee model with 'city' property\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v2: Remove 'city' property\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v3: Remove Employee model entirely\\\\r\\\\n@removed(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Removing an operation**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\\n\\\\n# Release new api version process with TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi folks, \\\\r\\\\nDo you have any process or script to execute when creating a new api version with TypeSpec which is similar to current [Copy-ApiVersion.ps1](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/eng/scripts/Copy-ApiVersion.ps1) script with API Spec?  \\\\r\\\\nAs within the TypeSpec, those examples needs to be added manually and change the api version in it. I wonder if there are any existing script for doing this. Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIn TypeSPec, this is much simpler.  You don't need to replicate your old APIs, you just encode the changes in the api and tag them with decorators from the versioning library, as discussed here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/) \\\\r\\\\nYou will need to copy the example files from the example directory from the last version into a new example directory for the new version, and add any new examples. \\\\r\\\\nIf you run into any issues, don't hesitate to ask questions here, or come to our office hours on Monday.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi Team, \\\\r\\\\nI am releasing a new API version and looks there is a new validation to check existing swagger with new tsp file  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nWe want to keep both old and new api versoins. What is the suggestion here? Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. You could alternatively decorate the core parameter definition (e.g., with an augment decorator), but that would affect every usage\\u2014so for localized changes, use operation-specific ones. Since this is a method parameter, the APIs are equivalent and the change has no SDK impact.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec: How can I change only descriptions/comments between versions while keeping models identical?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec: How can I change only descriptions/comments between versions while keeping models identical?\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_21.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec: How can I change only descriptions/comments between versions while keeping models identical?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion,  \\\\r\\\\nWhat\\u2019s the recommended way to change only the documentation (description/comments) between API versions while keeping all properties and models the same?\\\\r\\\\nFrom what I understand, versioning decorators don\\u2019t apply to descriptions/comments, so doc changes propagate to all emitted JSON/OpenAPI versions. I tried versioning a property by removing and re-adding it with an updated comment, but the compiler fails with:\\\\r\\\\n`Model already has a property named 'sku'`\\\\r\\\\nAttempted snippet (simplified): \\\\r\\\\nmodel CapacityReservationUpdate extends UpdateResource {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * Properties of the Capacity reservation.\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-private-usage\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  @Azure.ResourceManager.Private.conditionalClientFlatten\\\\r\\\\n  properties?: CapacityReservationProperties; \\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * OLD description...\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_04_01)\\\\r\\\\n  sku?: Sku; \\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * NEW description for v2025_04_01...\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_04_01)\\\\r\\\\n  sku?: Sku;\\\\r\\\\n} \\\\r\\\\nQuestion:\\\\r\\\\nIs there a supported approach to have version-specific descriptions (model-level or property-level) without duplicating and renaming the model/property? If not, what\\u2019s the best-practice pattern to achieve doc-only differences while keeping the wire shape unchanged?\\\\r\\\\nContext:\\\\r\\\\nGoal: same schema and property names across versions; only descriptions/comments differ.\\\\r\\\\nError seen: `Model already has a property named 'sku'`.\\\\r\\\\nThanks in advance for any guidance!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nxjaXR5Pzogc3Ry5QRzxyxQcm9maWz0ALtlbmNvZGUoImJhc2U2NHVybOUAnXDGMD86IGJ5dGVzyUhUaGUgc3RhdHVzxEt0aGUgbGFzdCDkAYphdGlvbuUEhiAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAqVhZMddxCDlBRVTdGF0xGflAnDMFOkCDcRzzDLlAIDlAMph6QKaxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQDd9FU5QIp5gEa6QO3xF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXDkAkXlAN5Bxw46ICLICyLWUGnEQOQAtOkAwchE7ACcOiAizA%2FaTOUCy8RPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QYv6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBofHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QTC6QQ85ANd6QHK6QQ%2BTW92ZVLHFegEN8RzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA1DLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBVDmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJm5AemT%2BgDlHMgZXh0ZW5kc%2FYIaC7LKXt9CuUIRMgjyhvLWegAzeYFeGdldOQBp0HKNeQD5%2BwF1SDnAntPcuUCp%2BUB1ssvQ8cdUmVwbGFjZUFzeW5jzj%2FmBcLHN0N1c3RvbVBhdGNoU8QqCiAgIOkAkyzFDvYA50ZvdW7kAybkBWrIHOYAkU3kAYTGSdBLyhDqBm%2FFGT4KICDlAJ3mAprvANTlApdlV2l0aG91dE9r8wDUbGlzdEJ5yDBHcm91cM9ETMUiUGFyZW501DxTdWJzY3JpcOUCecY7xjPMGcw56AbCIHNhbXBs6wNmYWPFRHRoYXTmAmPpBiN0byBkaWZmZeQAhO8C5sUp7gCyQcVI5QGWyHcs7ANxyA3mAujzAJJIRUFE6gZMxH5jaGVja%2BoAqmV4aXN0ZW7mCIsgxh5FyRTvAljNHe4IZg%3D%3D\\\\u0026e=%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-autorest\\\\u0026vs=%7B%7D)), however this is not advised for documentation changes - documentation changes should be made regardless of versioning.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Age of employee with updated docs */\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  age?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** Age of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"age\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  ageOld?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** City of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** Profile of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  @encode(\\\\\\\"base64url\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  profile?: bytes;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last operation. */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nDocumentation changes that improve the documentation should be made without regard to versioning.  Any listed breaking changes in ci checks that are only related to documentation will be easily accepted.  Documentation changes also do not trigger releases of new SDKs. \\\\r\\\\nIt is almost always possible to make versioned changes (for example, using the add/remove/rename pattern [like this](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D\\\\%%%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXDkAkXlAN5Bxw46ICLICyLWUGnEQOQAtOkAwchE7ACcOiAizA%2FaTOUCy8RPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QYv6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBofHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QTC6QQ85ANd6QHK6QQ%\\\\n\\\\nDocumentation changes that improve the documentation should be made without regard to versioning.  Any listed breaking changes in ci checks that are only related to documentation will be easily accepted.  Documentation changes also do not trigger releases of new SDKs.\\\\n\\\\nDocumentation changes that improve the documentation should be made without regard to versioning.  Any listed breaking changes in ci checks that are only related to documentation will be easily accepted.  Documentation changes also do not trigger releases of new SDKs. \\\\r\\\\nIt is almost always possible to make versioned changes (for example, using the add/remove/rename pattern [like\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"troubleshoot#versioning_operation_template_changes.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How can I change the operation template of an operation in newer versions\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/troubleshoot/versioning_operation_template_changes\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How can I change the operation template of an operation in newer versions\\\\n## Workaround\\\\n# troubleshoot#versioning_operation_template_changes.md\\\\n\\\\n# How can I change the operation template of an operation in newer versions\\\\n\\\\n## Workaround\\\\n\\\\nIn the example below, you are switch from an old deprecated operation template to the new one. Note the uses of `@sharedRoute` and `renamedFrom` to avoid name and route conflict errors.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress \\\\\\\"deprecated\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"back compat\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"delete\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  deleteOld is ArmResourceDeleteAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Please note**: In the `delete is ArmResourceDeleteAsync` example above, if you are RPSaaS service, you CAN do a direct replacement with `delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync`. This is because RPSaaS will never send `200 OK`. Update in-place is just an API spec bug fix.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\\\\n\\\\nhere's a Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** reference `client.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** reference `back-compat.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations for ARM APIs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact only generated client SDKs in `client.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact both generated client SDKs and generated OpenAPI specs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** run `tsp compile .` on your specification and address all warnings\\\\n\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** name your ARM spec folder with `.Management` suffix.\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** configure your tspconfig.yaml. See: [example tspconfig.yaml][tspconfig]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** extend the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager` linter rule set in your tspconfig.yaml if not already there. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nlinter:\\\\r\\\\n  extends:\\\\r\\\\n    - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your `@service` and `@server` definitions are correct in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure `interface Operations extends Azure.ResourceManager.Operations {}` is in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your versions enum is up to date. For an initial migration we recommend migrating your latest stable API version (and the latest preview API version the service may support after the stable API version)\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure you have correct ARM common type version select with each service version. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  ...\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)  \\\\u003c---\\\\r\\\\n  v2021_10_01_preview: \\\\\\\"2021-10-01-preview\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review all enum definitions and add documentation over each value. See: [Documentation in TypeSpec][docs]\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** suppress documentation warnings\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the [standard Typespec Azure.ResourceManager and Azure.Core operation templates and data-types][standard-templates] wherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use `union` instead of `enum` to define Azure extensible enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n### Customizing Request Payload Parameter Names\\\\n# migrate-swagger#faq#breakingchange.md\\\\n\\\\n# Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations\\\\n\\\\n## Migrating ARM Specifications\\\\n\\\\n### Customizing Request Payload Parameter Names\\\\n\\\\nFor operations with request bodies (PUT, POST, PATCH), TypeSpec operation templates provide default names for request parameters. You can use augment decorators to customize these parameter names and other parts of the operation signature.\\\\r\\\\nThe following sections show how to do this for each operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### CreateOrUpdate (PUT) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a PUT operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cWidget\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `resource`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.createOrUpdate::parameters.resource, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any PUT operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### Update (PATCH) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a PATCH operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cWidget, WidgetProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `properties`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.update::parameters.properties, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any PATCH operation template.\\\\r\\\\n#### Action (POST) APIs\\\\r\\\\nGiven a POST operation, for example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  mungeWidget is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cWidget, MungeRequest, MungeResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe name of the request body parameter is `body`. You can change the name in clients using an augment decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Widgets.mungeWidget::parameters.body, \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdesired-request-body-parameter-name\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis works for any POST operation template.\\\"}]\"}"}]

response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To correctly version your `listBySubscription` operation to support a new filter parameter in the Quantum RP offering API, you should use the TypeSpec versioning decorators to indicate when the old operation is removed and the new one is added. However, you must ensure that the new operation signature is actually different\\u2014typically by adding a new parameter model for the filter, and using the `Parameters` template argument of `ArmListBySubscription`.\\n\\nHere's the recommended approach:\\n\\n1. **Define a parameters model for the filter** (and any other query parameters you want to support):\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel OfferingListParameters {\\n  @query(\\\"filter\\\")\\n  filter?: string;\\n  // Add other query parameters as needed\\n}\\n```\\n\\n2. **Version the operation using @removed and @added decorators**. The new operation should use the `Parameters` argument:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Offerings {\\n  // Old operation (no filter)\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering>;\\n\\n  // New operation (with filter)\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering, Parameters = OfferingListParameters>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\n**Key points:**\\n- The operation name (`listBySubscription`) can stay the same if you use @removed/@added to version the signature. The TypeSpec compiler will emit the correct operation for each version.\\n- If you want to keep both operations for some reason, you can use different names (e.g., `listBySubscriptionV2`), but the standard pattern is to keep the name and version the signature.\\n- Make sure your `Versions` enum is up to date and referenced correctly.\\n- The filter parameter should be optional unless you want to require it for all requests.\\n\\n**Why your previous attempts failed:**\\n- If you use the same operation signature for both @removed and @added, TypeSpec sees no difference and may not emit the correct versioned API. You must change the operation signature (by adding the parameters model) for the new version.\\n\\n**Example:**\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Offerings {\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering>;\\n\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Offering, Parameters = OfferingListParameters>;\\n}\\n```\\nThis will generate the correct OpenAPI for each version: the old version without filter, and the new version with filter support.\\n\\nIf you need to support more query parameters, you can extend `OfferingListParameters` or use intersection types as shown in the references.\", \"ground_truth\": \"For a case like this, just decorating the filter property with `@added` in the same operation is the simplest mechanism.  Versioning the request and response data in an operation like this is usually the most straightforward way to version an operation.\\nFor more complex operation versioning, you can use the remove/rename/sharedRoute mechanism described here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/#converting-an-operation-from-synchronous-to-asynchronous)\\nNote also that you should name the property 'filter', the `@query(\\\"$filter\\\")` decorator actually sets the name on the wire,  you generally want to follow standard naming rules for parameters:\\n```\\n// v2 (new preview)\\nlistBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<\\nQuantumSuiteOffer,\\nParameters = {\\n/**\\n* The filter to apply to the operation. Example: '$filter=kind eq \\\"v1\\\"'\\n*/\\n@added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n@query(\\\"$filter\\\")\\nfilter?: string;\\n}\\n>;\\n```\"}"}]

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Swagger generation fails due to duplicate operations in interface irrespective of different models.\\n\\nquestion: Hi,\\nWe\\u2019re trying to add a new API version with different property settings, but generating the Swagger keeps failing with the following error for all operations in the interface.\\nIn our `policy.tsp` file, we have a model `LeafCertificateConfiguration` where the property `validityPeriodInDays` has a maximum value of 30 for API version `2025-08-01-preview`. For the new version `2025-11-01-preview`, this needs to be updated to a maximum value of 90.\\nI used `@renamedFrom`, which worked initially, but it required changes to the root models to use the same annotation. This ended up updating the `armResourceOperations` interface.\\nTypeSpec is treating this as a duplicate operation, even though it uses a different model.\\nCould anyone please help with this?\\nLinking draft PR: [Am/private.device registry 2025 11 01 preview by amathamsetty \\u00b7 Pull Request #25221 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-r\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25221/files#diff-a5db74a835313381d2df910fad2d6293fa3bdcbb5273630a4d9615f0b270058a)\\n```\\nError: interface.specification/iotworkspaces/DeviceRegistry.Management/policy.tsp:161:3 - error @typespec/http/duplicate-operation: Duplicate operation \\\"getV1\\\" routed at \\\"get /subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/resourceGroups/{resourceGroupName}/providers/Private.DeviceRegistry/namespaces/{namespaceName}/credentials/default/policies/{policyName}\\\".\\n> 161 |   getV1 is ArmResourceRead<PolicyV1>;\\n```\", \"response\": \"The duplicate operation error in TypeSpec occurs because the HTTP emitter detects two operations with the same HTTP method and route, regardless of whether they use different models or property settings. In TypeSpec, versioning decorators like @added, @removed, and @renamedFrom are designed to help you evolve your API across versions, but they do not change the route or operation signature for the emitter. If you define two operations (e.g., 'getV1') with the same HTTP route in the same interface\\u2014even if they use different models for different versions\\u2014the emitter will treat them as duplicates and fail.\\n\\nTo resolve this, you should not duplicate the operation for each version. Instead, use versioning decorators on the model or property itself to indicate the change in the property constraint (such as the maximum value). For example, you can use @added or @removed on the property or model to specify when the change applies. If the constraint (e.g., maximum value) cannot be versioned directly, you may need to create a new model for the new version and use @renamedFrom to indicate the change, but ensure that only one operation per route exists in the interface, and the model is versioned appropriately.\\n\\nIf you need to change the model for a specific version, use the add/remove/rename pattern for the property or model, and decorate the operation to use the correct model for the target version. Do not duplicate the operation itself\\u2014this will always cause a duplicate operation error.\\n\\nHere is a simplified example of how to version a property constraint in a model:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel LeafCertificateConfiguration {\\n  validityPeriodInDays: int32 @maxValue(30);\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  validityPeriodInDaysV2: int32 @maxValue(90);\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Policies {\\n  get is ArmResourceRead<LeafCertificateConfiguration>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIn this example, only one 'get' operation exists, and the model is versioned using property decorators. If you need to change the model entirely, use @renamedFrom on the model, not the operation, and ensure only one operation per route is present.\\n\\nIf you still encounter issues, review your interface to ensure you do not have multiple operations with the same route and method, and apply versioning decorators to models and properties, not to duplicate operations.\", \"ground_truth\": \"To update the maximum value of `validityPeriodInDays` from 30 to 90 for only the new API version (`2025-11-01-preview`) in your TypeSpec definition, you must use TypeSpec's versioning patterns for breaking model changes. However, TypeSpec currently does not support versioning decorators on decorator arguments (like changing the `@maxValue` parameter per version). Directly updating the decorator value would affect all versions.\\nThe correct Azure-compliant pattern is:\\nCreate a new property (with a different internal name) for the updated constraint.\\nUse `@removed` and `@renamedFrom` on the old property, and `@added` on the new property, both on the same model. This allows you to apply different constraints in different API versions without affecting other versions or causing duplicate operation errors.\\nIf the operation signature/model type is changed for only the new version, use the add/remove/rename pattern and use `@sharedRoute` on both versions of the operation (see linked examples). This avoids the duplicate operation error and ensures correct OpenAPI emission for each version.\\nExample:\\n```\\nmodel LeafCertificateConfiguration {\\n// Old property: max 30 days, removed in new version\\n@maxValue(30)\\n@removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n@renamedFrom(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview, \\\"validityPeriodInDays\\\")\\nvalidityPeriodInDaysV1: int32;\\n// New property: max 90 days, only in new version\\n@added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n@maxValue(90)\\nvalidityPeriodInDays: int32;\\n}\\n```\\nIn your operation/interface, you may need to do the same if the operation signature changes. If you want to have different models for different versions but keep the same route, use the `@sharedRoute` decorator and the `@renamedFrom` pattern for the operation as well (see the \\\"Converting an Operation from Synchronous to Asynchronous\\\" example in the docs).\\nThis pattern will:\\nPrevent duplicate operation errors (since each operation/model is only present in one version)\\nEmit the correct schema per version\\nNot require changing the operation name at the API surface (the renaming is internal)\\nSummary:\\nUse the add/remove/rename pattern for versioned property changes that affect validation/constraints.\\nUse `@sharedRoute` and `@renamedFrom` for operations if the operation signature changes with the model.\\nDo NOT update decorator arguments directly for just one version\\u2014they affect all versions.\"}"}]

groundedness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"The duplicate operation error in TypeSpec occurs because the HTTP emitter detects two operations with the same HTTP method and route, regardless of whether they use different models or property settings. In TypeSpec, versioning decorators like @added, @removed, and @renamedFrom are designed to help you evolve your API across versions, but they do not change the route or operation signature for the emitter. If you define two operations (e.g., 'getV1') with the same HTTP route in the same interface\\u2014even if they use different models for different versions\\u2014the emitter will treat them as duplicates and fail.\\n\\nTo resolve this, you should not duplicate the operation for each version. Instead, use versioning decorators on the model or property itself to indicate the change in the property constraint (such as the maximum value). For example, you can use @added or @removed on the property or model to specify when the change applies. If the constraint (e.g., maximum value) cannot be versioned directly, you may need to create a new model for the new version and use @renamedFrom to indicate the change, but ensure that only one operation per route exists in the interface, and the model is versioned appropriately.\\n\\nIf you need to change the model for a specific version, use the add/remove/rename pattern for the property or model, and decorate the operation to use the correct model for the target version. Do not duplicate the operation itself\\u2014this will always cause a duplicate operation error.\\n\\nHere is a simplified example of how to version a property constraint in a model:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel LeafCertificateConfiguration {\\n  validityPeriodInDays: int32 @maxValue(30);\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  validityPeriodInDaysV2: int32 @maxValue(90);\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Policies {\\n  get is ArmResourceRead<LeafCertificateConfiguration>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIn this example, only one 'get' operation exists, and the model is versioned using property decorators. If you need to change the model entirely, use @renamedFrom on the model, not the operation, and ensure only one operation per route is present.\\n\\nIf you still encounter issues, review your interface to ensure you do not have multiple operations with the same route and method, and apply versioning decorators to models and properties, not to duplicate operations.\", \"context\": Watch the ticket for updates from the docs team.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\\\\n\\\\nhere's a [playground](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D\\\\%2BQAoWVudW3oARNzIHsKICDELjIwMjUtMTAtMDEtcHJldmlld8g1xDQgIOQA10NvbW1vblTkAY%2FHQCj1ATcuyykuyGoudjUpCiAgYNJpYCwK8ACFN%2F8Ahf8Ahf8AhesAhclpYCwKfeYBOEHoATrrAVMg6AJ15ACIbW9kZWwgRW1wbG95ZWUgaXMgVHJhY2tlZOgAgjzIHFByb3BlcnRpZXM%2B5QFpLi7pAKbkAhtQYXJhbWV0ZXLJMT476ACGyV9wyUTSfMpg6QHIQWdlIG9mIGXIP%2BUBOGFnZT86IGludDMyO%2BgBbENpdHnSKmNpdHk%2FOiBzdHLlAy7HLFByb2ZpbNNZQGVuY29kZSgiYmFzZTY0dXJsIuQBYHDGMD86IGJ5dGVzyUhUaGUgc3RhdHVzxEt0aGUgbGFzdCDkAMVhdGlvbuUDQSAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAeBhZMddxCDlA9BTdGF0xGflAavMFOkBSMRzzDLlAIDlAMph6QHVxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQCctFU5QFk5gEa6QKyxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QTq6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBULHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QP96QN3bW926gHK6QN5TW92ZVLHFegDcsRzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA1DLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBIvmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJ\\\\n\\\\nSAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAeBhZMddxCDlA9BTdGF0xGflAavMFOkBSMRzzDLlAIDlAMph6QHVxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQCctFU5QFk5gEa6QKyxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QTq6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBULHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QP96QN3bW926gHK6QN5TW92ZVLHFegDcsRzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA1DLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBIvmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJm5AZhT%2BgDlHMgZXh0ZW5kc%2FYHIy7LKXt9CuUG%2F8gjyhvLWegAzeYEs2dldOQBp0HKNeQD5%2BwFEOQEEHJl5Ab6ZEZyb23pBw4u9QXFICLmAqlPcuUC1WXlBI9AcmXkAPzqB0rVPMUqc2hhcmVkUm91dGXkBQ7NTE9sZO8ArEPHIFJlcGxhY2VBc3luY%2BwAvN9RxU71AVVMZWdhY3ku1WAKICAg6QFGLMUOT3DkAWZhbOcCm0JvZHkgPSB0cnXEdOUAiOUD%2FMZxcm1DdXN0b21QYXRjaFPXUvYAl0ZvdW7kBCvkAUPIHOYAy03kAonGSdBLyhDqBq%2FFGT7o I wonder if there are any existing script for doing this. Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIn TypeSPec, this is much simpler.  You don't need to replicate your old APIs, you just encode the changes in the api and tag them with decorators from the versioning library, as discussed here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/) \\\\r\\\\nYou will need to copy the example files from the example directory from the last version into a new example directory for the new version, and add any new examples. \\\\r\\\\nIf you run into any issues, don't hesitate to ask questions here, or come to our office hours on Monday.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action\\\\n\\\\nWhether you're working with Data Plane (DP) or Azure Resource Manager (ARM), having clear examples to follow can make your transition to TypeSpec smoother. Here are some resources that can help:\\\\r\\\\n- **Playground Examples**: Our playground provides ARM and DP examples that serve as excellent models for teams new to TypeSpec Azure. These examples are concise and take full advantage of our standard operation templates. You can use these as a gold standard for your own TypeSpec definitions. Visit the [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure) to explore these examples.\\\\r\\\\n- **ARM Samples**: For more specific scenarios, check out our additional [ARM samples](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/tree/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/arm-scenarios). These are tutorial-like examples that cover various scenarios. You can adapt these to fit your specific needs.\\\\r\\\\nThe playground examples are a great starting point for getting familiar with TypeSpec Azure. As you gain more experience, you can leverage the ARM samples to understand how to apply TypeSpec to a variety of scenarios.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. Could anyone advise on the best approach to make these updates in the new version without impacting the old version? \\\\r\\\\nExample:\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nOLD:\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"The Branch resource type.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Neon.Postgres.Versions.v2_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(Project)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Branch is ProxyResource\\\\u003cBranchProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Resource = Branch,\\\\r\\\\n    KeyName = \\\\\\\"branchName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    SegmentName = \\\\\\\"branches\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    NamePattern = \\\\\\\"^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S.{0,62}\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$|^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nUpdated:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"The Branch resource type.\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@added(Neon.Postgres.Versions.v2_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@parentResource(Project)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Branch is ProxyResource\\\\u003cBranchProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Resource = Branch,\\\\r\\\\n    KeyName = \\\\\\\"branchName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    SegmentName = \\\\\\\"branches\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003cspan style=\\\\\\\"background-color:#DF9299\\\\\\\"\\\\u003eNamePattern = \\\\u003c/span\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"\\\\u003cspan style=\\\\\\\"background-color:#DF9299\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S.{0,126}\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$|^\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\S$\\\\u003c/span\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nTo update a model in a new API version without affecting the old one, especially when changing a pattern or adding fields, the challenge is that decorator contents (like NamePattern) are not versioned in TypeSpec. So, modifying them directly will affect all versions.\\\\r\\\\nThere are two main approaches:\\\\r\\\\nWorkaround with a new model: You can create a new model with a different name and use @renamedFrom, but this leads to a cascade of renames across operations, which is not ideal.\\\\r\\\\nApply the change across all versions: If the new regex is backwards compatible, and the change reflects how the service actually behaves across all versions, then it\\u2019s appropriate to update the existing model and apply the change to all API versions. response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"The duplicate operation error in TypeSpec occurs because the HTTP emitter detects two operations with the same HTTP method and route, regardless of whether they use different models or property settings. In TypeSpec, versioning decorators like @added, @removed, and @renamedFrom are designed to help you evolve your API across versions, but they do not change the route or operation signature for the emitter. If you define two operations (e.g., 'getV1') with the same HTTP route in the same interface\\u2014even if they use different models for different versions\\u2014the emitter will treat them as duplicates and fail.\\n\\nTo resolve this, you should not duplicate the operation for each version. Instead, use versioning decorators on the model or property itself to indicate the change in the property constraint (such as the maximum value). For example, you can use @added or @removed on the property or model to specify when the change applies. If the constraint (e.g., maximum value) cannot be versioned directly, you may need to create a new model for the new version and use @renamedFrom to indicate the change, but ensure that only one operation per route exists in the interface, and the model is versioned appropriately.\\n\\nIf you need to change the model for a specific version, use the add/remove/rename pattern for the property or model, and decorate the operation to use the correct model for the target version. Do not duplicate the operation itself\\u2014this will always cause a duplicate operation error.\\n\\nHere is a simplified example of how to version a property constraint in a model:\\n\\n```typespec\\nmodel LeafCertificateConfiguration {\\n  validityPeriodInDays: int32 @maxValue(30);\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n  validityPeriodInDaysV2: int32 @maxValue(90);\\n}\\n\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Policies {\\n  get is ArmResourceRead<LeafCertificateConfiguration>;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nIn this example, only one 'get' operation exists, and the model is versioned using property decorators. If you need to change the model entirely, use @renamedFrom on the model, not the operation, and ensure only one operation per route is present.\\n\\nIf you still encounter issues, review your interface to ensure you do not have multiple operations with the same route and method, and apply versioning decorators to models and properties, not to duplicate operations.\", \"ground_truth\": \"To update the maximum value of `validityPeriodInDays` from 30 to 90 for only the new API version (`2025-11-01-preview`) in your TypeSpec definition, you must use TypeSpec's versioning patterns for breaking model changes. However, TypeSpec currently does not support versioning decorators on decorator arguments (like changing the `@maxValue` parameter per version). Directly updating the decorator value would affect all versions.\\nThe correct Azure-compliant pattern is:\\nCreate a new property (with a different internal name) for the updated constraint.\\nUse `@removed` and `@renamedFrom` on the old property, and `@added` on the new property, both on the same model. This allows you to apply different constraints in different API versions without affecting other versions or causing duplicate operation errors.\\nIf the operation signature/model type is changed for only the new version, use the add/remove/rename pattern and use `@sharedRoute` on both versions of the operation (see linked examples). This avoids the duplicate operation error and ensures correct OpenAPI emission for each version.\\nExample:\\n```\\nmodel LeafCertificateConfiguration {\\n// Old property: max 30 days, removed in new version\\n@maxValue(30)\\n@removed(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n@renamedFrom(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview, \\\"validityPeriodInDays\\\")\\nvalidityPeriodInDaysV1: int32;\\n// New property: max 90 days, only in new version\\n@added(Versions.v2025_11_01_preview)\\n@maxValue(90)\\nvalidityPeriodInDays: int32;\\n}\\n```\\nIn your operation/interface, you may need to do the same if the operation signature changes. If you want to have different models for different versions but keep the same route, use the `@sharedRoute` decorator and the `@renamedFrom` pattern for the operation as well (see the \\\"Converting an Operation from Synchronous to Asynchronous\\\" example in the docs).\\nThis pattern will:\\nPrevent duplicate operation errors (since each operation/model is only present in one version)\\nEmit the correct schema per version\\nNot require changing the operation name at the API surface (the renaming is internal)\\nSummary:\\nUse the add/remove/rename pattern for versioned property changes that affect validation/constraints.\\nUse `@sharedRoute` and `@renamedFrom` for operations if the operation signature changes with the model.\\nDo NOT update decorator arguments directly for just one version\\u2014they affect all versions.\"}"}]
