actual.answer:
You are correct that you should NOT manually add the pattern restriction to the JSON file generated by `tsp compile`. All changes to resource name validation must be made in your TypeSpec source, not in the generated OpenAPI/Swagger output.

Regarding versioning: Currently, TypeSpec does NOT support versioning of decorator contents (such as `@pattern`)—if you add a pattern restriction to the resource name parameter, it will apply to ALL API versions, not just the new one. This is a known limitation in TypeSpec and is documented in the Azure TypeSpec guidance and community discussions.

The recommended approach is:
- If your service actually validates resource names differently across API versions, you must create a new resource type/model for the new version, with the updated pattern restriction, and use `@added`/`@removed` decorators to control which version each model appears in. This can be cumbersome and is only justified if the service behavior truly differs by version.
- If the pattern restriction is a bug fix or an accurate reflection of how your service has always validated names, you should apply the pattern restriction to ALL versions. This is the standard guidance, as client SDKs do not use name patterns for validation, and the pattern is only for documentation and server-side validation.

In summary: Unless your service truly validates names differently between versions, you should add the pattern restriction to the resource name parameter in your TypeSpec, and let it apply to all versions. If this causes a breaking change warning, you may need to go through the breaking change review process, but this is the correct modeling approach.

You cannot scope a pattern restriction to only new versions using TypeSpec decorators at this time.

Pull Request #24362 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24362)\", \"response\": \"You are correct that you should NOT manually add the pattern restriction to the JSON file generated by `tsp compile`. All changes to resource name validation must be made in your TypeSpec source, not in the generated OpenAPI/Swagger output.\\n\\nRegarding versioning: Currently, TypeSpec does NOT support versioning of decorator contents (such as `@pattern`)\\u2014if you add a pattern restriction to the resource name parameter, it will apply to ALL API versions, not just the new one. This is a known limitation in TypeSpec and is documented in the Azure TypeSpec guidance and community discussions.\\n\\nThe recommended approach is:\\n- If your service actually validates resource names differently across API versions, you must create a new resource type/model for the new version, with the updated pattern restriction, and use `@added`/`@removed` decorators to control which version each model appears in. This can be cumbersome and is only justified if the service behavior truly differs by version.\\n- If the pattern restriction is a bug fix or an accurate reflection of how your service has always validated names, you should apply the pattern restriction to ALL versions. This is the standard guidance, as client SDKs do not use name patterns for validation, and the pattern is only for documentation and server-side validation.\\n\\nIn summary: Unless your service truly validates names differently between versions, you should add the pattern restriction to the resource name parameter in your TypeSpec, and let it apply to all versions. If this causes a breaking change warning, you may need to go through the breaking change review process, but this is the correct modeling approach.\\n\\nYou cannot scope a pattern restriction to only new versions using TypeSpec decorators at this time.\", \"ground_truth\": \"You cannot directly version a decorator such as @pattern in TypeSpec; decorators themselves are not versioned. This means that if you update a pattern in your TypeSpec model, it will apply to all API versions emitted by TypeSpec, not just a new version. This is a deliberate design choice to avoid hidden inconsistencies between the declared API surface and the actual backend behavior.\\nIf you need different validation patterns (such as a new regex for a resource name) for a specific API version and newer, you have two supported options in TypeSpec:\\nIf the new pattern applies to all versions: Update the @pattern decorator in the model directly. This is the common and recommended path if your backend enforces the new pattern for all versions.\\nIf the pattern truly differs by API version (rare, and usually discouraged): You must explicitly version the type. For example, you can introduce a new scalar type or model for the new version, and use the @typeChangedFrom or @renamedFrom decorators to describe the transition between versions. This approach requires you to manage versioning logic in TypeSpec, not in the generated OpenAPI/JSON files. You should not edit the generated files by hand, and manual changes to JSON files are not supported.\\nHere's a sketch of the pattern versioning approach:\\n```\\n/** Legacy pattern type for old API versions */\\n@pattern(\\\"^[a-z0-9]{3,18}$\\\")\\nscalar ResourceNameLegacy extends string;\\nmodel MyResource {\\n@key(\\\"resourceName\\\")\\n@typeChangedFrom(Versions.v2, ResourceNameLegacy)\\n@pattern(\\\"^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*(-[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*$\\\")\\nname: string;\\n}\\n```\\nIn this example, TypeSpec will emit the old pattern for older API versions and the new pattern for v2 and above, but you must structure your code accordingly. Note that this approach can lead to more complicated TypeSpec code and is only justified if your backend actually enforces different rules per API version.\\nSummary: Do not manually edit JSON files generated by TypeSpec. Use versioning decorators and, if necessary, versioned types to achieve per-version differences. But for most cases, apply the new pattern universally if the service behavior matches. This approach keeps your TypeSpec code clear and maintainable.\"}"}]

similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Versioning the LRO headers\\n\\nquestion: I am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header:\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader<FinalResult = RuleSet> and ArmLroLocationHeader<FinalResult = RuleSet>.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations)\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\", \"response\": \"To version LRO headers and related behavior (such as using Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia, ArmAsyncOperationHeader, and ArmLroLocationHeader) in TypeSpec for a new API version, you should use TypeSpec's versioning decorators and operation templates in combination with @sharedRoute and operation renaming/removal. \\n\\nHere's the recommended approach:\\n\\n1. **Use @sharedRoute and Operation Renaming/Removal**: \\n   - Define the old operation (without LRO headers and with a required request body) and the new operation (with LRO headers, optional request body, and new LRO behavior) on the same route using @sharedRoute.\\n   - Use @renamedFrom and @removed decorators to indicate when the old operation is replaced by the new one.\\n\\n2. **Version the Operation, Not the LRO Header Directly**: \\n   - You cannot directly put @added(version) on the LRO header types (like ArmAsyncOperationHeader or ArmLroLocationHeader), but you can version the operation itself. The operation template (e.g., Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync) will take the LRO header as a parameter, so the new operation will use the new header and behavior only in the new version.\\n\\n3. **Make the Request Body Optional for Backwards Compatibility**: \\n   - In the new version, use the OptionalRequestBody = true parameter in the operation template to allow the request body to be optional.\\n\\n4. **Example TypeSpec**:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Employees {\\n  get is ArmResourceRead<Employee>;\\n\\n  // Old operation (removed in new version)\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-07-preview`, \\\"createOrUpdate\\\")\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-07-preview`)\\n  @sharedRoute\\n  createOrUpdateOld is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync<Employee>;\\n\\n  // New operation (added in new version)\\n  @sharedRoute\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync<\\n    Employee,\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\n  >;\\n  // ... other operations ...\\n}\\n```\\n\\n- The old operation is removed in the new version, and the new operation (with LRO headers and optional request body) is used instead.\\n- The @sharedRoute decorator ensures both operations use the same route.\\n- The new operation uses the correct LRO header and behavior for the new version.\\n\\nThis approach is fully aligned with Azure API versioning best practices and TypeSpec's versioning model. You do not need to (and cannot) put @added directly on the LRO header types; versioning the operation is the correct and recommended way.\\n\\nIf you need to see a full playground example, see the [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D&c=aW1wb3J0ICJAdHlwZXNwZWMvaHR0cCI7...) for a working sample.\", \"ground_truth\": \"here's a [playground](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D&%2BQAoWVudW3oARNzIHsKICDELjIwMjUtMTAtMDEtcHJldmlld8g1xDQgIOQA10NvbW1vblTkAY%2FHQCj1ATcuyykuyGoudjUpCiAgYNJpYCwK8ACFN%2F8Ahf8Ahf8AhesAhclpYCwKfeYBOEHoATrrAVMg6AJ15ACIbW9kZWwgRW1wbG95ZWUgaXMgVHJhY2tlZOgAgjzIHFByb3BlcnRpZXM%2B5QFpLi7pAKbkAhtQYXJhbWV0ZXLJMT476ACGyV9wyUTSfMpg6QHIQWdlIG9mIGXIP%2BUBOGFnZT86IGludDMyO%2BgBbENpdHnSKmNpdHk%2FOiBzdHLlAy7HLFByb2ZpbNNZQGVuY29kZSgiYmFzZTY0dXJsIuQBYHDGMD86IGJ5dGVzyUhUaGUgc3RhdHVzxEt0aGUgbGFzdCDkAMVhdGlvbuUDQSAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAeBhZMddxCDlA9BTdGF0xGflAavMFOkBSMRzzDLlAIDlAMph6QHVxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQCctFU5QFk5gEa6QKyxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QTq6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBULHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QP96QN3bW926gHK6QN5TW92ZVLHFegDcsRzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA1DLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBIvmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJm5AZhT%2BgDlHMgZXh0ZW5kc%2FYHIy7LKXt9CuUG%2F8gjyhvLWegAzeYEs2dldOQBp0HKNeQD5%2BwFEOQEEHJl5Ab6ZEZyb23pBw4u9QXFICLmAqlPcuUC1WXlBI9AcmXkAPzqB0rVPMUqc2hhcmVkUm91dGXkBQ7NTE9sZO8ArEPHIFJlcGxhY2VBc3luY%2BwAvN9RxU71AVVMZWdhY3ku1WAKICAg6QFGLMUOT3DkAWZhbOcCm0JvZHkgPSB0cnXEdOUAiOUD%2FMZxcm1DdXN0b21QYXRjaFPXUvYAl0ZvdW7kBCvkAUPIHOYAy03kAonGSdBLyhDqBq%2FFGT7oAJ3mA5%2FvAVzlA5xlV2l0aG91dE9r8wFcbGlzdEJ5yDBHcm91cM9ETMUiUGFyZW501DxTdWJzY3Jp5QE%2BxzvGM8wZzDnoB2Ugc2FtcGzrBGthY8VEdGhhdOYDaOkHKHRvIGRpZmZl5ACE7wPrxSnuALJBxUjlAZbIdyzsBHbIDeYD7fMAkkhFQUTqB1HEfmNoZWNr6gCqZXhpc3RlbuYIyyDGHkXJFO8C4M0d7gim&e=%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-autorest&vs=%7B%7D) showing how you would version a required to optional request body for a templated async put operation:\\n```\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Employees {\\nget is ArmResourceRead<Employee>;\\n@renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-07-preview`, \\\"createOrUpdate\\\")\\n@removed(Versions.`2025-10-07-preview`)\\n@sharedRoute\\ncreateOrUpdateOld is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync<Employee>;\\n@sharedRoute\\ncreateOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync<\\nEmployee,\\nOptionalRequestBody = true\\n>;\\nupdate is ArmCustomPatchSync<\\nEmployee,\\nAzure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel<\\nEmployee,\\nEmployeeProperties\\n>\\n>;\\ndelete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync<Employee>;\\nlistByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent<Employee>;\\nlistBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription<Employee>;\\n/** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\nmove is ArmResourceActionSync<Employee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse>;\\n/** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\ncheckExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence<Employee>;\\n}\\n```\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\"}"}]

The 201 response contains a `Location` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync` is a PUT operation that uses the 'resource' definition in the request body, and returns a `200` response and a `201` response, both of which contain the created/updated resource in the response payload. The 201 response contains an `Azure-AsyncOperation` LRO header.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op createOrUpdate is ArmCreateOrUpdateAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async PATCH Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmTagsPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that only allows changing the resource tags (the minimum for Azure Resource Manager).\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmTagsPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourcePatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that uses the visibility settings to select properties for the PATCH request body (any property with no visibility setting, or including visibility \\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\"). It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation.\\\\n\\\\nthe `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, ResourceProperties\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmCustomPatchAsync` is a PATCH operation that allows you to customize the PATCH request body.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003cResource, PatchRequestBody\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async POST (Action) Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceActionAsync` is a POST operation that allows you to specify the request and response body for a resource action operation. It follows the required 202 pattern to resolve the LRO via location, although this can be customized using the `LroHeaders` parameter.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuff is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no request body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffNoRequest is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, void, ActionResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // With no response body\\\\r\\\\n  op doStuffCommand is ArmResourceActionAsync\\\\u003cResource, ActionRequest, void\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Templates for Async DELETE Operations\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, will return a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOKAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- `ArmResourceDeleteAsync` is a DELETE operation that uses no request body, and returns a `200` response in the case of a successful synchronous delete, a `202` response in the case of an asynchronous delete operation, and a `204` response in case the resource does not exist.\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  op delete is ArmResourceDeleteAsync\\\\u003cResource\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM-Models-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec ARM Model Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec ARM Model Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 11. I wonder if there are any existing script for doing this. Thanks!\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nIn TypeSPec, this is much simpler.  You don't need to replicate your old APIs, you just encode the changes in the api and tag them with decorators from the versioning library, as discussed here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/) \\\\r\\\\nYou will need to copy the example files from the example directory from the last version into a new example directory for the new version, and add any new examples. \\\\r\\\\nIf you run into any issues, don't hesitate to ask questions here, or come to our office hours on Monday.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec\\\\n# Swagger-LintDiff.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\nCheck `Swagger LintDiff` may fail for the OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec, even if there are no warnings or errors reported from the TypeSpec compiler.  Causes include bugs in the TypeSpec OpenAPI emitter, bugs in LintDiff rules, incompatibilities between TypeSpec and LintDiff, or checks duplicated in TypeSpec and LintDiff.\\\\r\\\\nWe are working to address the root causes (where possible).  Until then, we recommend you [suppress](https://aka.ms/pr-suppressions) these LintDiff errors, using a \\\\\\\"permanent suppression\\\\\\\" with a descriptive \\\\\\\"reason\\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAdditionalProperties`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousParameter`\\\\n\\\\n### data-plane\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### resource-manager\\\\n\\\\nAs an exception to the previous note, resource-manager specs **may** be able to suppress `AvoidAnonymousTypes`, but only if the error is inside a 202 response from a long-running operation (LRO).  It is known that SDKs do not need to generate type names for such responses.\\\\n\\\\n## `AvoidAnonymousTypes`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n### `LongRunningResourceAction`\\\\n\\\\nThere is a known issue where `LongRunningResourceAction` in TypeSpec, generates swagger that causes `AvoidAnonymousTypes`.  These errors should be suppressed until the root cause is fixed.  https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure-pr/issues/3349\\\\n\\\\n## `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation`\\\\n\\\\nIf `EvenSegmentedPathForPutOperation` is failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\\n\\\\n## `IntegerTypeMustHaveFormat`\\\\n\\\\nData-plane specs can suppress violations of this rule, since it only exists for the benefit of SDKs generated from swagger, and data-plane SDKs are generated directly from TypeSpec.  Resource-manager specs should **not** suppress violations of this rule, since resource-manager SDKs are generated from OpenAPI, and rely on these errors being fixed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchBodyParameterSchema`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a bug in typespec-azure:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/383.\\\\r\\\\nPlease see the issue above for the suggested workaround and apply it directly to the spec TypeSpec sources.  The LintDiff error should **not** be ignored or suppressed.\\\\n\\\\n## `PatchPropertiesCorrespondToPutProperties`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/642\\\\n\\\\n## `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`\\\\n\\\\nThe use of `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e` in TypeSpec is discouraged, and there is a TypeSpec lint rule to enforce this.  If you still need to use `Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e`, the OpenAPI spec generated will cause many LintDiff errors of types `AvoidAdditionalProperties` and `PropertiesTypeObjectNoDefinition`.  You will need to suppress both the TypeSpec violation (in TypeSpec source code) and the LintDiff violations.\\\\n\\\\n## `ProvisioningStateMustBeReadOnly`\\\\n\\\\nThe root cause is a limitation in how `azure-openapi-validator` and `oav` handle `$ref` siblings:\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/637\\\\r\\\\n- https://github.com/Azure/oav/issues/848\\\\r\\\\nThe recommended workaround is to add `use-read-only-status-schema: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `RequestBodyMustExistForPutPatch`\\\\n\\\\nWe believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/641\\\\n\\\\n## `ResourceNameRestriction`\\\\n\\\\nWhether `ResourceNameRestriction` should be applied to enums is an open question:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/501\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/pull/714\\\\r\\\\nUntil this is resolved, suppress the errors and discuss with your ARM reviewer.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsEnumValidation`\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec using `OAuth2Auth` may generate the following OpenAPI:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\` yaml\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"OAuth2 authentication\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"oauth2\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ]\\\\r\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhich causes error `XmsEnumValidation`.  The recommended workaround is to add `omit-unreachable-types: true` to your `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\n\\\\n## `XmsPageableForListCalls`\\\\n\\\\nIf `XmsPageableForListCalls` are failing for OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec using `@singleton` (OpenAPI path ends with `/default`), we believe this is a false positive: https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/issues/646\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Handling multiple API versions using typespec\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi Team, \\\\r\\\\nI am releasing a new API version and looks there is a new validation to check existing swagger with new tsp file  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nWe want to keep both old and new api versoins. What is the suggestion here? Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. You could alternatively decorate the core parameter definition (e.g., with an augment decorator), but that would affect every usage\\u2014so for localized changes, use operation-specific ones. Since this is a method parameter, the APIs are equivalent and the change has no SDK impact.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@added`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.added) decorator is used to indicate that a model or operation was added in a specific version of the API. This allows you to manage changes and additions to your API over time.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Adding a New Model in a Specific Version\\\\n\\\\nLet's add a `Toy` model that is only available in version 2 of the API:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @minLength(1)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @minValue(0)\\\\r\\\\n  @maxValue(100)\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  kind: petType;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nenum petType {\\\\r\\\\n  dog: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  cat: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  fish: \\\\\\\"fish\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  bird: \\\\\\\"bird\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  reptile: \\\\\\\"reptile\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Toy {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- The `Toy` model is defined with the `@added(Versions.v2)` decorator to indicate that it was added in version 2 of the API.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning the LRO headers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_10_10.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning the LRO headers\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nI am reaching out to seek advice about versioning the LRO header: \\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Define contract for Batch RuleSet feature by mangoo1 \\u00b7 Pull Request #37879 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-s\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37879)\\\\r\\\\nis about to extend an existing RuleSet PUT endpoint to allow it accepting an optional request body, the feature would be turned on when we specify a bool flag to true and the PUT endpoint would be extend to 201 LRO.  \\\\r\\\\nThis behavior would be available on the new ApiVersion, so I would like to put the Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia annotation to the new ApiVersion, along with LRO/Async headers ArmAsyncOperationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e and ArmLroLocationHeader\\\\u003cFinalResult = RuleSet\\\\u003e.  But I still won't be able to find a way to put the @added(version) annotations to them.  \\\\r\\\\nCan I version the operation to achieve this?  [Versioning | TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/getting-started-rest/06-versioning/#version-specific-operations) \\\\r\\\\nWhat would be the recommended way to do this?\\\\r\\\\n(1.The original put request doesn't have a request body, so I make the put request body optional for backwards compatibility.\\\\r\\\\n2.There is an optional bool flag in the optional request body to turn the feature requires LRO ON.)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n@sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  update is ArmCustomPatchSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ResourceUpdateModel\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      Employee,\\\\r\\\\n      EmployeeProperties\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  delete is ArmResourceDeleteWithoutOkAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listByResourceGroup is ArmResourceListByParent\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample resource action that move employee to different location */\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, MoveResponse\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** A sample HEAD operation to check resource existence */\\\\r\\\\n  checkExistence is ArmResourceCheckExistence\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nthe trick is to use @sharedRoute in the old and new operations and to rename and remove the old operation in the new version.\\\\n\\\\nhere's a [playground](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D\\\\%2BQAoWVudW3oARNzIHsKICDELjIwMjUtMTAtMDEtcHJldmlld8g1xDQgIOQA10NvbW1vblTkAY%2FHQCj1ATcuyykuyGoudjUpCiAgYNJpYCwK8ACFN%2F8Ahf8Ahf8AhesAhclpYCwKfeYBOEHoATrrAVMg6AJ15ACIbW9kZWwgRW1wbG95ZWUgaXMgVHJhY2tlZOgAgjzIHFByb3BlcnRpZXM%2B5QFpLi7pAKbkAhtQYXJhbWV0ZXLJMT476ACGyV9wyUTSfMpg6QHIQWdlIG9mIGXIP%2BUBOGFnZT86IGludDMyO%2BgBbENpdHnSKmNpdHk%2FOiBzdHLlAy7HLFByb2ZpbNNZQGVuY29kZSgiYmFzZTY0dXJsIuQBYHDGMD86IGJ5dGVzyUhUaGUgc3RhdHVzxEt0aGUgbGFzdCDkAMVhdGlvbuUDQSAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAeBhZMddxCDlA9BTdGF0xGflAavMFOkBSMRzzDLlAIDlAMph6QHVxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQCctFU5QFk5gEa6QKyxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QTq6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBULHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QP96QN3bW926gHK6QN5TW92ZVLHFegDcsRzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA1DLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBIvmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJ\\\\n\\\\nSAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAeBhZMddxCDlA9BTdGF0xGflAavMFOkBSMRzzDLlAIDlAMph6QHVxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQCctFU5QFk5gEa6QKyxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QTq6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBULHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QP96QN3bW926gHK6QN5TW92ZVLHFegDcsRzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA1DLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBIvmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJm5AZhT%2BgDlHMgZXh0ZW5kc%2FYHIy7LKXt9CuUG%2F8gjyhvLWegAzeYEs2dldOQBp0HKNeQD5%2BwFEOQEEHJl5Ab6ZEZyb23pBw4u9QXFICLmAqlPcuUC1WXlBI9AcmXkAPzqB0rVPMUqc2hhcmVkUm91dGXkBQ7NTE9sZO8ArEPHIFJlcGxhY2VBc3luY%2BwAvN9RxU71AVVMZWdhY3ku1WAKICAg6QFGLMUOT3DkAWZhbOcCm0JvZHkgPSB0cnXEdOUAiOUD%2FMZxcm1DdXN0b21QYXRjaFPXUvYAl0ZvdW7kBCvkAUPIHOYAy03kAonGSdBLyhDqBq%2FFGT7o we will generate the api surface area for that one version.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(My.Service.Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\nnamespace My.Service;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2023_11_01: \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel StableModel {\\\\r\\\\n  stableFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop stableFunctionality(@body stableModel: StableModel): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\nimport pytest\\\\r\\\\nfrom my.service import MyServiceClient, models\\\\r\\\\nclient = MyServiceClient(endpoint=..., credential=...)\\\\r\\\\n// client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nstable_model = models.StableModel(stable_feature=\\\\\\\"present\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nprint(stable_model)\\\\r\\\\nclient.stable_functionality(stable_model) # call goes through\\\\r\\\\npreview_client = MyServiceClient(endpoint=..., credential=..., api_version=\\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n// python allows you to override the api version, even if only one version is defined in the spec\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`csharp\\\\r\\\\n//ServiceVersion enum\\\\r\\\\npublic enum ServiceVersion\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n    /// \\\\u003csummary\\\\u003e Service version \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\". \\\\u003c/summary\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    V2023_11_01 = 1,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nUri endpoint = new Uri(\\\\\\\"\\\\u003chttps://my-service.azure.com\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\nServiceClient client = new ServiceClient(endpoint);\\\\r\\\\n//client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nStableModel stableModel = new StableModel(\\\\\\\"\\\\u003cstableFeature\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\nResponse response = client.StableFunctionality(stableModel);\\\\r\\\\nUri endpoint = new Uri(\\\\\\\"\\\\u003chttps://my-service.azure.com\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\nServiceClientOptions options = new ServiceClientOptions(ServiceVersion.V2023_11_01);\\\\r\\\\nServiceClient client = new ServiceClient(endpoint, options);\\\\r\\\\n//You can specify the service api-version when create client instance. Now client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typescript\\\\r\\\\nexport interface StableModel {\\\\r\\\\n  stableFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nexport function stableModelSerializer(item: StableModel): any {\\\\r\\\\n  return { stableFeature: item[\\\\\\\"stableFeature\\\\\\\"] };\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nServiceClientOptions options = new ServiceClientOptions(ServiceVersion.V2023_11_01);\\\\r\\\\nServiceClient client = new ServiceClient(endpoint, options);\\\\r\\\\n//You can specify the service api-version when create client instance. Now client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typescript\\\\r\\\\nexport interface StableModel {\\\\r\\\\n  stableFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nexport function stableModelSerializer(item: StableModel): any {\\\\r\\\\n  return { stableFeature: item[\\\\\\\"stableFeature\\\\\\\"] };\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/** Known values of {@link Versions} that the service accepts. */\\\\r\\\\nexport enum KnownVersions {\\\\r\\\\n  V20231101 = \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nexport async function stableFunctionality(\\\\r\\\\n  context: Client,\\\\r\\\\n  stableModel: StableModel,\\\\r\\\\n  options: response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To version LRO headers and related behavior (such as using Azure.Core.useFinalStateVia, ArmAsyncOperationHeader, and ArmLroLocationHeader) in TypeSpec for a new API version, you should use TypeSpec's versioning decorators and operation templates in combination with @sharedRoute and operation renaming/removal. \\n\\nHere's the recommended approach:\\n\\n1. **Use @sharedRoute and Operation Renaming/Removal**: \\n   - Define the old operation (without LRO headers and with a required request body) and the new operation (with LRO headers, optional request body, and new LRO behavior) on the same route using @sharedRoute.\\n   - Use @renamedFrom and @removed decorators to indicate when the old operation is replaced by the new one.\\n\\n2. **Version the Operation, Not the LRO Header Directly**: \\n   - You cannot directly put @added(version) on the LRO header types (like ArmAsyncOperationHeader or ArmLroLocationHeader), but you can version the operation itself. The operation template (e.g., Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync) will take the LRO header as a parameter, so the new operation will use the new header and behavior only in the new version.\\n\\n3. **Make the Request Body Optional for Backwards Compatibility**: \\n   - In the new version, use the OptionalRequestBody = true parameter in the operation template to allow the request body to be optional.\\n\\n4. **Example TypeSpec**:\\n\\n```typespec\\n@armResourceOperations\\ninterface Employees {\\n  get is ArmResourceRead<Employee>;\\n\\n  // Old operation (removed in new version)\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-07-preview`, \\\"createOrUpdate\\\")\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-07-preview`)\\n  @sharedRoute\\n  createOrUpdateOld is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync<Employee>;\\n\\n  // New operation (added in new version)\\n  @sharedRoute\\n  createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Legacy.CreateOrReplaceAsync<\\n    Employee,\\n    OptionalRequestBody = true\\n  >;\\n  // ... other operations ...\\n}\\n```\\n\\n- The old operation is removed in the new version, and the new operation (with LRO headers and optional request body) is used instead.\\n- The @sharedRoute decorator ensures both operations use the same route.\\n- The new operation uses the correct LRO header and behavior for the new version.\\n\\nThis approach is fully aligned with Azure API versioning best practices and TypeSpec's versioning model. You do not need to (and cannot) put @added directly on the LRO header types; versioning the operation is the correct and recommended way.\\n\\nIf you need to see a full playground example, see the [TypeSpec Azure similarity_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Creating stable API version with select properties omitted?\\n\\nquestion: Is it possible on typeSpec to add a new preview with some new parameters and a new stable for all other properties that we already have? We have some properties that we don't want to include in a stable release just yet, but don't want that to hold us from releasing the other properties in a stable release.\\nCan we have multiple versions marked with @previewVersion? How do we handle a property that is in multiple preview versions, but we want to keep out of stable versions?\\nFor a practical example, we have the faultSimulation apis in our spec in 2024-11-01-preview, 2025-03-01-preview, 2025-06-01-preview, and 2025-07-01-preview. If I mark 2025-07-01-preview with @previewVersion and faultSimulation with @added(versions.v2025_07_01_preview), the generation removes it from the previous preview specs.\", \"response\": \"Yes, in TypeSpec you can create a stable API version that omits select properties, while allowing those properties to exist in multiple preview versions. The recommended approach is to use the @added and @removed decorators to precisely control which versions a property appears in. \\n\\nHere's how it works:\\n- When you introduce a property in a preview version, use @added(Versions.<preview_version>). This will include the property in that preview and all subsequent versions unless you explicitly remove it.\\n- To exclude the property from a stable version, use @removed(Versions.<stable_version>). This will remove the property from the stable version and all subsequent versions, unless you add it back with another @added decorator in a later preview.\\n- If you want the property to appear in multiple preview versions but not in any stable version, you must use @added and @removed in combination for each version transition.\\n\\nFor example, suppose you have preview versions 2024-11-01-preview, 2025-03-01-preview, 2025-06-01-preview, and 2025-07-01-preview, and stable versions in between. You can do:\\n\\n```tsp\\nmodel MyResourceProperties {\\n  // Property appears in first preview\\n  @added(Versions.v2024_11_01_preview)\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_03_01)\\n  faultSimulation?: FaultSimulationType;\\n\\n  // Property reappears in next preview\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_03_01_preview)\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_06_01)\\n  faultSimulation?: FaultSimulationType;\\n\\n  // Property reappears in next preview\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_06_01_preview)\\n  @removed(Versions.v2025_07_01)\\n  faultSimulation?: FaultSimulationType;\\n\\n  // Property reappears in latest preview\\n  @added(Versions.v2025_07_01_preview)\\n  faultSimulation?: FaultSimulationType;\\n}\\n```\\n\\nThis pattern ensures that faultSimulation is present only in the preview versions and omitted from all stable releases. However, this approach can be error-prone and verbose, so it's best to minimize the number of active preview versions. The official Azure policy is to have only one active preview version at a time, retiring older previews when a new one is introduced.\\n\\nYou can have multiple versions marked with @previewVersion, but only the latest preview should be active according to Azure guidelines. When you add a new preview, you should remove support for the previous preview soon after.\\n\\nFor more details and best practices, see the Azure TypeSpec versioning documentation and the example provided in the references.\", \"ground_truth\": \"TypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.  It can be added back using `@added` [Here is a playground](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D&%2BQAoWVudW3oARNzIHsKICDELjIwMjEtMTAtMDEtcHJldmlld8g1xDQgIEB1c2VEZXBlbmRlbmN5KPUBLy7IVi52MV8wX1DGSF8xKcRAYXJtQ29tbW9uVOQBz8cq10jLKctUNcRIYPIAqWAsCuoAxTTGHP8Avf8Avf8Avf8Avf4AvecAoe0AtTUtMDf%2FAXr%2FAL3%2FAL3%2FAL3%2FAL3qAL3vAKlgLAp95gJtQegCb%2BsCiCDoA6rkAMhtb2RlbCBFbXBsb3llZSBpcyBUcmFja2Vk6ACCPMgcUHJvcGVydGllcz7lAp4uLukApuQDUFBhcmFtZXRlcskxPjvoAIbJX3DJRNJ8ymDpAv1BZ2Ugb2YgZcg%2F5gF4YWRk6wN%2BLuwBveQBEGFnZT86IGludDMyO%2BgBzENpdHnSSmNpdHk%2FOiBzdHLlBIPHLFByb2ZpbNR5cmVtb3bce%2FQAm%2FABm8UoZW5jb2RlKCJiYXNlNjR1cmwixBdwxno%2FOiBieXRlc%2BkAklRoZSBzdGF0dXPkAJV0aGUgbGFzdCDkAS9hdGlvbuUE4CAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAkphZMddxCDlBW9TdGF0xGflAhXMFOkBssRzzDLlAIDlARRh6QI%2FxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQDHNFU5QHO5gFk6QNcxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QaJ6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBuHHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QRn6QPh5AMh6QHK6QPjTW92ZVLHFegD3MRzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA5rLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBPXmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJm5AgAT%2BgDlHMgZXh0ZW5kc%2FYIwi7LKXt9CuUInsgjyhvLWegAzeYFHWdldOQBp0HKNeQD5%2BwFeiDnAntPcuUCp%2BUB1ssvQ8cdUmVwbGFjZUFzeW5jzj%2FlAvfIN0N1c3RvbVBhdGNoU8QqCiAgIOkAkyzFDvYA50ZvdW7kAybkBQ7IHOYAkU3kAYTGSdBLyhDqBhTFGT4KICDlAJ3mAprvANTlApdlV2l0aG91dE9r8wDUbGlzdEJ5yDBHcm91cM9ETMUiUGFyZW501DxTdWJzY3JpcOUCecY7xjPMGcw56AbKIHNhbXBs6wNmYWPFRHRoYXTmAmPpBm10byBkaWZmZeQAhO8C5sUp7gCyQcVI5QGWyHcs7ANxyA3mAujzAJJIRUFE6gZMxH5jaGVja%2BoAqmV4aXN0ZW7mCDAgxh5FyRTvAljNHe4ICw%3D%3D&e=%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-autorest&vs=%7B%7D)\\n```\\n/** Contoso API versions */\\nenum Versions {\\n/** 2021-10-01-preview version */\\n@useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\n`2021-10-01-preview`,\\n/** 2024-10-01 version */\\n@useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\n`2024-10-01`,\\n/** 2025-07-01-preview version */\\n@useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\n`2025-07-01-preview`,\\n}\\n/** A ContosoProviderHub resource */\\nmodel Employee is TrackedResource<EmployeeProperties> {\\n...ResourceNameParameter<Employee>;\\n}\\n/** Employee properties */\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\n/** Age of employee */\\n@added(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\nage?: int32;\\n/** City of employee */\\ncity?: string;\\n/** Profile of employee */\\n@removed(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\n@added(Versions.`2025-07-01-preview`)\\n@encode(\\\"base64url\\\")\\nprofile?: bytes;\\n/** The status of the last operation. */\\n@visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\nprovisioningState?: ProvisioningState;\\n}\\n```\\nshowing two propertties (EmployeeProperties.age and EmployeeProperties.profile) that use versioning.  'age' appears in the second, stable version and all subsequent versions,  'profile' appears in the first (preview) version, is removed in the stable version, and then added back again in the subsequent preview version.\\nNotably, this practice of adding a property at each preview version and removing it at each stable is easy to get wrong.\\nthe official Azure policy is to have only one active preview, as much as that is possible with api retention requirements.  So that, when you introduce a new preview version, the older preview is removed, ideally, this means that, especially when you just had a stable release, you remove support for the previous preview when (or soon after) you add the new preview version.\\nYou can see more details about versioning in typespec here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/versioning/)\"}"}]

@useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2025-07-01-preview`,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n/** A ContosoProviderHub resource */\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee is TrackedResource\\\\u003cEmployeeProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Age of employee */\\\\r\\\\n @removed(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-07-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @encode(\\\\\\\"base64url\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  profile?: bytes;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last operation. */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nshowing two propertties (EmployeeProperties.age and EmployeeProperties.profile) that use versioning.  'age' appears in the second, stable version and all subsequent versions,  'profile' appears in the first (preview) version, is removed in the stable version, and then added back again in the subsequent preview version.\\\\r\\\\nNotably, this practice of adding a property at each preview version and removing it at each stable is easy to get wrong.   \\\\r\\\\nthe official Azure policy is to have only one active preview, as much as that is possible with api retention requirements.  So that, when you introduce a new preview version, the older preview is removed, ideally, this means that, especially when you just had a stable release, you remove support for the previous preview when (or soon after) you add the new preview version. \\\\r\\\\nYou can see more details about versioning in typespec here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/versioning/)\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions. 2023-11-02\\\\n\\\\nBy default our emitters will only generate the surface used by the latest api version if there are multiple defined. This includes generating only the models used in the surface area of the latest api version.\\\\r\\\\nDocumentation and enums showing the available api versions will still include all of the known api versions, meaning there will be documentation for both the preview and stable releases.\\\\r\\\\nFor the below example, all languages will generate the api surface of default version `v2023_11_01`. There will be no generation of the operation `previewFunctionality`, and we will also not generate the `PreviewModel` because it's only used in `previewFunctionality`, and therefore is not used in the api surface of `v2023_11_01`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(My.Service.Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\nnamespace My.Service;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2023_11_01_preview: \\\\\\\"2023-11-01-preview\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2023_11_02: \\\\\\\"2023-11-02\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel PreviewModel {\\\\r\\\\n  betaFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel StableModel {\\\\r\\\\n  stableFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2023_11_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n@removed(Versions.v2023_11_02)\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/preview\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop previewFunctionality(@body previewModel: PreviewModel): void;\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/stable\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop stableFunctionality(@body stableModel: StableModel): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\nimport pytest\\\\r\\\\nfrom my.service import MyServiceClient, models\\\\r\\\\nclient = MyServiceClient(endpoint=..., credential=...)\\\\r\\\\n// client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-02\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nstable_model = models.StableModel(stable_feature=\\\\\\\"present\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nprint(stable_model)\\\\r\\\\nclient.stable_functionality(stable_model) # call goes through\\\\r\\\\nwith pytest.expect(ImportError):\\\\r\\\\n  preview_model = models.PreviewModel(preview_functionality=\\\\\\\"not present\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nwith pytest.expect(AttributeError):\\\\r\\\\n  client.preview_functionality({\\\\\\\"previewFunctionality\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"not present\\\\\\\"})\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`csharp\\\\r\\\\n//ServiceVersion enum\\\\r\\\\npublic enum ServiceVersion\\\\r\\\\n{\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n\\\\nThese examples show how to add models, operations, properties, and parameters in specific versions using TypeSpec versioning decorators.\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario demonstrates how to change a decorator\\u2019s usage across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you have a model property with a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the next version (v2), the visibility changes so that the property can be read or created. To achieve this, you can use a combination of `@removed`, `@added`, and `@renamedFrom` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"experience\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldExperience: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Adding a Parameter to an Operation and Making Another Parameter Optional\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario shows how to add a parameter and make another optional in an operation.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following operation in v1:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you want to:\\\\r\\\\n- Make the `location` header parameter optional.\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new optional query parameter `orderBy`.\\\\r\\\\nYou can achieve this using the `@madeOptional` and `@added` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @madeOptional(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location?: string;\\\\r\\\\n      @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @query(\\\\\\\"order-by\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n      orderBy?: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@madeOptional(Versions.v2)` makes `location` optional starting in v2.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the `orderBy` query parameter in v2 and later.\\\\n\\\\n### Converting an Operation from Synchronous to Asynchronous\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario illustrates converting a synchronous operation to an asynchronous one across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following synchronous operation in `v1`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you update this operation to be asynchronous as follows:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdateV1 is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@removed(Versions.v2)` removes the original synchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")` keeps the original name for v1.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the new asynchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@sharedRoute` ensures both operations can use the same route.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n# howtos#arm#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\nThis document explains how to manage versioning in TypeSpec projects, including how to add, remove, or modify resources, operations, and properties across API versions.\\\\n\\\\n## Introduction\\\\n\\\\nVersioning allows you to evolve your API without breaking existing clients. By using versioning decorators, you can specify when resources, operations, or properties are added, removed, or changed.\\\\n\\\\n## Declaring Versions\\\\n\\\\nDefine your API versions in an enum. For each version, specify dependencies and common types as needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** Contoso API versions */\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2021-10-01-preview version */\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2022-11-01-preview version */\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  v2,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAfter defining your enum, link it to your namespace using the `@versioned` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.ContosoProviderHub;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e **Note:** Add dependencies and common types for each version. After defining a new version, the emitter will produce outputs for all versions. You can then adapt your TypeSpec code for the latest version.\\\\n\\\\n## Simple Scenarios\\\\n\\\\nThese examples show how to add models, operations, properties, and parameters in specific versions using TypeSpec versioning decorators.\\\\n\\\\n### Adding Decoration to an Existing Type\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario demonstrates how to change a decorator\\u2019s usage across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you have a model property with a decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn the next version (v2), the visibility changes so that the property can be read or created. To achieve this, you can use a combination of `@removed`, `@added`, and `@renamedFrom` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"experience\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldExperience: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read, Lifecycle.Create)\\\\r\\\\n  experience: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Adding a Parameter to an Operation and Making Another Parameter Optional\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario shows how to add a parameter and make another optional in an operation.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following operation in v1:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you want to:\\\\r\\\\n- Make the `location` header parameter optional.\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new optional query parameter `orderBy`.\\\\r\\\\nYou can achieve this using the `@madeOptional` and `@added` decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  listBySubscription is ArmListBySubscription\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      @madeOptional(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @header\\\\r\\\\n      location?: string;\\\\r\\\\n      @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      @query(\\\\\\\"order-by\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n      orderBy?: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@madeOptional(Versions.v2)` makes `location` optional starting in v2.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the `orderBy` query parameter in v2 and later.\\\\n\\\\n### Converting an Operation from Synchronous to Asynchronous\\\\n\\\\nThis scenario illustrates converting a synchronous operation to an asynchronous one across versions.\\\\r\\\\nSuppose you start with the following synchronous operation in `v1`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn version `v2`, you update this operation to be asynchronous as follows:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdateV1 is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceSync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @sharedRoute\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Explanation:**\\\\r\\\\n- `@removed(Versions.v2)` removes the original synchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"createOrUpdate\\\\\\\")` keeps the original name for v1.\\\\r\\\\n- `@added(Versions.v2)` adds the new asynchronous operation in v2 and later.\\\\r\\\\n- `@sharedRoute` ensures both operations can use the same route.\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning Decorators\\\\n\\\\n### @added\\\\n\\\\nYou can add new models, properties, or operations in a specific version and all subsequent versions using the `@added` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n- The `version` argument is the version where the element is introduced.\\\\r\\\\n- The element will be present in that version and all later versions.\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Adding a model and property across versions**\\\\r\\\\nFor example, suppose you want to add a new model and then add a property to it in a later version:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// v1: No Employee model exists\\\\r\\\\n// v2: Add Employee model\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v3: Add 'city' property to Employee\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Adding an operation in a later version**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  // v3: Add createOrUpdate operation\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### @removed\\\\n\\\\nTo remove models, properties, or operations starting from a specific version, use the `@removed` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n- The `version` argument is the version where the element is removed.\\\\r\\\\n- The element will not be present in that version or any later versions.\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Removing a property and a model across versions**\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// v1: Employee model with 'city' property\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v2: Remove 'city' property\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v3: Remove Employee model entirely\\\\r\\\\n@removed(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Removing an operation**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v3)\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### @madeRequired and @madeOptional\\\\n\\\\nUse these decorators to change whether a property is required or optional in a specific version.\\\\r\\\\n- Use `@madeOptional(Versions.version)` to make a property optional starting in that version.\\\\r\\\\n- Use `@madeRequired(Versions.version)` to make a property required starting in that version.\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Changing a property from required to optional, then back to required**\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// v1: movingStatus is required\\\\r\\\\nmodel MoveResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  movingStatus: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v2: movingStatus becomes optional\\\\r\\\\nmodel MoveResponse {\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  movingStatus?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### @renamedFrom\\\\n\\\\nUse `@renamedFrom` to rename models, properties, operations, enums, etc., in a specific version.\\\\r\\\\n- The `version` argument is the version where the name changed.\\\\r\\\\n- The `oldName` argument is the previous name.\\\\r\\\\n**Example: Renaming a property and a model across versions**\\\\r\\\\nFor example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n// v1: Model and property have original names\\\\r\\\\nmodel WorkerProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  state?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v2: Rename property 'state' to 'city'\\\\r\\\\nmodel WorkerProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"state\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// v3: Rename model 'WorkerProperties' to 'EmployeeProperties'\\\\r\\\\n@renamedFrom(Versions.v3, \\\\\\\"WorkerProperties\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"state\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## FAQ\\\\n\\\\n### How do I version a pattern?\\\\n\\\\nI have this model and I would like to change the pattern in v2\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-z]+$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  state: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n:::caution\\\\r\\\\nUpdating a pattern could be a breaking change:\\\\r\\\\n- A **more restrictive pattern** for input data would break existing clients that send previously valid data\\\\r\\\\n- A **less restrictive pattern** for output data could break client assumptions and validation logic\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\r\\\\nThe key question is: **Does the pattern change apply to all API versions, or only to the new version?**\\\\r\\\\n#### 1. Pattern changes for all versions\\\\r\\\\nIf the pattern change reflects how your service actually behaves across all versions, update the pattern directly. The specification should accurately reflect the current state of your service.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`diff lang=tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n-  @pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-z]+$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n+  @pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z]+$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n   state: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n:::note\\\\r\\\\nThis will update all openapi specs versions with the new pattern which is the desired behavior.\\\\r\\\\n:::\\\\r\\\\n#### 2. Different patterns per version (**Very unlikely**)\\\\r\\\\nIf older API versions truly enforce a different pattern than newer versions, you need to model this explicitly using versioning decorators:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-z]+$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.v2, \\\\\\\"state\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldState: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  @pattern(\\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z]+$\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  state:
