begin\\\\n\\\\n### Overview of TypeSpec\\\\n\\\\n[TypeSpec](https://typespec.io) is the new standard API definition language for Azure, developed by Microsoft.\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec offers many [benefits for Azure API definition](api-typespec.md), including consistency, efficiency, enhanced tooling,\\\\r\\\\nand accessibility. By using TypeSpec, you can ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across Azure services.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_api_guidelines\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"azure#Guidelines.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Microsoft Azure REST API Guidelines\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/Guidelines.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Microsoft Azure REST API Guidelines\\\\n## Common API Patterns\\\\n### API Versioning\\\\n# azure#Guidelines.md\\\\n\\\\n# Microsoft Azure REST API Guidelines\\\\n\\\\n## Common API Patterns\\\\n\\\\n### API Versioning\\\\n\\\\n**DO** use `YYYY-MM-DD` date values, with a `-preview` suffix for preview versions, as the valid values for `api-version`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-api-version-missing\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-api-version-missing\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** return HTTP 400 with error code \\\\\\\"MissingApiVersionParameter\\\\\\\" and message \\\\\\\"The api-version query parameter (?api-version=) is required for all requests\\\\\\\" if client omits the `api-version` query parameter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-api-version-unsupported\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-api-version-unsupported\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** return HTTP 400 with error code \\\\\\\"UnsupportedApiVersionValue\\\\\\\" and message \\\\\\\"Unsupported api-version '{0}'. The supported api-versions are '{1}'.\\\\\\\" if client passes an `api-version` value unrecognized by the service. For the supported api-versions, just list all the stable versions still supported by the service and just the latest public preview version (if any).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`text\\\\r\\\\nPUT https://service.azure.com/users/Jeff?api-version=2021-06-04\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-use-later-date\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-use-later-date\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** use a later date for each new preview version\\\\r\\\\nWhen releasing a new preview, the service team may completely retire any previous preview versions after giving customers at least 90 days to upgrade their code\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-no-breaking-changes\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-no-breaking-changes\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** introduce any breaking changes into the service.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-no-version-in-path\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-no-version-in-path\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** include a version number segment in any operation path.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-use-later-date-2\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-use-later-date-2\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** use the same date when transitioning from a preview API to a GA API. If the preview `api-version` is '2021-06-04-preview', the GA version of the API **must be** a date later than 2021-06-04\\\\n\\\\nany breaking changes into the service.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-no-version-in-path\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-no-version-in-path\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** include a version number segment in any operation path.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-use-later-date-2\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-use-later-date-2\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** use the same date when transitioning from a preview API to a GA API. If the preview `api-version` is '2021-06-04-preview', the GA version of the API **must be** a date later than 2021-06-04\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-preview-goes-ga-within-one-year\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-preview-goes-ga-within-one-year\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:no_entry:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO NOT** keep a preview feature in preview for more than 1 year; it must go GA (or be removed) within 1 year after introduction.\\\\r\\\\n#### Use Extensible Enums\\\\r\\\\nWhile removing a value from an enum is a breaking change, adding value to an enum can be handled with an _extensible enum_.  An extensible enum is a string value that has been marked with a special marker - setting `modelAsString` to true within an `x-ms-enum` block.  For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`json\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"createdByType\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The type of identity that created the resource.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"enum\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"User\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"Application\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"ManagedIdentity\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"Key\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   ],\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"createdByType\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"modelAsString\\\\\\\": true\\\\r\\\\n   }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-use-extensible-enums\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-use-extensible-enums\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:ballot_box_with_check:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **YOU SHOULD** use extensible enums unless you are positive that the symbol set will **NEVER** change over time.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#deprecation\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"deprecation\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e\\\\n\\\\nAzure services need to change over time. However, when changing a service, there are 2 requirements:\\\\r\\\\n 1. Already-running customer workloads must not break due to a service change\\\\r\\\\n 2. Customers can adopt a new service version without requiring any code changes (Of course, the customer must modify code to leverage any new service features.)\\\\r\\\\n*NOTE: the [Azure Breaking Change Policy](http://aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy) has tables (section 5) describing what kinds of changes are considered breaking. Breaking changes are allowable (due to security/compliance/etc.) if approved by the [Azure Breaking Change Reviewers](mailto:azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com) but only following ample communication to customers and a lengthy deprecation period.*\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-review-required\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-review-required\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** review any API changes with the Azure API Stewardship Board\\\\r\\\\nClients specify the version of the API to be used in every request to the service, even requests to an `Operation-Location` or `nextLink` URL returned by the service.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-api-version-query-param\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-api-version-query-param\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** use a required query parameter named `api-version` on every operation for the client to specify the API version.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-date-based-versioning\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-date-based-versioning\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** use `YYYY-MM-DD` date values, with a `-preview` suffix for preview versions, as the valid values for `api-version`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003ca href=\\\\\\\"#versioning-api-version-missing\\\\\\\" name=\\\\\\\"versioning-api-version-missing\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e:white_check_mark:\\\\u003c/a\\\\u003e **DO** return HTTP 400 with error code \\\\\\\"MissingApiVersionParameter\\\\\\\" and message \\\\\\\"The api-version query parameter (?api-version=) is required for all requests\\\\\\\" if client omits the `api-version` query spec\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/checklists/migrate-arm-tips\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Migrate ARM spec\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n# migrate-swagger#checklists#migrate-arm-tips.md\\\\n\\\\n# Migrate ARM spec\\\\n\\\\n## Initial pass through checklist\\\\n\\\\nAzure extensible enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** reference `client.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** reference `back-compat.tsp` in `main.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations for ARM APIs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact only generated client SDKs in `client.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** add customizations that impact both generated client SDKs and generated OpenAPI specs in `back-compat.tsp`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** run `tsp compile .` on your specification and address all warnings\\\\n\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** name your ARM spec folder with `.Management` suffix.\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** configure your tspconfig.yaml. See: [example tspconfig.yaml][tspconfig]\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** extend the `@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager` linter rule set in your tspconfig.yaml if not already there. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nlinter:\\\\r\\\\n  extends:\\\\r\\\\n    - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-rulesets/resource-manager\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your `@service` and `@server` definitions are correct in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure `interface Operations extends Azure.ResourceManager.Operations {}` is in main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure your versions enum is up to date. For an initial migration we recommend migrating your latest stable API version (and the latest preview API version the service may support after the stable API version)\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** ensure you have correct ARM common type version select with each service version. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n  ...\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)  \\\\u003c---\\\\r\\\\n  v2021_10_01_preview: \\\\\\\"2021-10-01-preview\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** review all enum definitions and add documentation over each value. See: [Documentation in TypeSpec][docs]\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** suppress documentation warnings\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use the [standard Typespec Azure.ResourceManager and Azure.Core operation templates and data-types][standard-templates] wherever possible. Standard operation templates should be used as much as possible\\\\r\\\\n\\u2705 **DO** use `union` instead of `enum` to define Azure extensible enums. See: [Defining enums for Azure services][no-enum]. Example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** The color of a widget. */\\\\r\\\\nunion WidgetColor {\\\\r\\\\n  string,\\\\r\\\\n  /** Red Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Red: \\\\\\\"Red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Green Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Green: \\\\\\\"Green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  /** Blue Widget Color */\\\\r\\\\n  Blue: \\\\\\\"Blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use templates `xxx.Private` namespaces\\\\r\\\\n\\u274c **DON'T** import or use `@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core` in files other than `client.tsp` or `back-compat.tsp`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-Requirement.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Overview\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Requirement\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Overview\\\\n# TypeSpec-Requirement.md\\\\n\\\\n# Overview\\\\n\\\\nCheck `TypeSpec Requirement` enforces the rule that all \\\\\\\"new\\\\\\\" specs must use TypeSpec (instead of hand-written Swagger).  A \\\\\\\"new\\\\\\\" spec is defined as any spec that does **not** have a `stable` version in `main`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/typespec-for-openapi-dev\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n# getting-started#typespec-for-openapi-dev.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec for OpenAPI Developers\\\\n\\\\nThis guide introduces TypeSpec using concepts familiar to developers who build or use API definitions in OpenAPI v2 or v3.\\\\r\\\\nIn many cases, this will also describe how the typespec-autorest and openapi3 emitters translate\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec designs into OpenAPI.\\\\r\\\\nThe document is organized around the features of an OpenAPI v2 or v3 definition.\\\\r\\\\nThe idea is that if you know how to describe some API feature in OpenAPI, you can just navigate\\\\r\\\\nto the section of this document for that feature.\\\\n\\\\n## Data Types\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI [v2](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#data-types)/[v3](https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#data-types), data types are specified using the `type` and `format` fields in a schema.\\\\r\\\\nThe TypeSpec equivalents of OpenAPI data types are the TypeSpec primitive types or [built-in models](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/built-in-types).\\\\n\\\\n### type and format\\\\n\\\\n| RFC 3339 date with offset                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `password`  | `@secret string` |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean` |             | `boolean`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\nYou can also define a property with no type specified using the TypeSpec `unknown` type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /** This property has no `type` defined. */\\\\r\\\\n  noType?: unknown;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOpenAPI allows any string as a format, and there is a [registry of common formats][Format Registry].\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec supports some of these directly.\\\\r\\\\n[Format Registry]: https://spec.openapis.org/registry/format\\\\r\\\\n| `type:`   | `format:`    | TypeSpec type | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------- | ------------ | ------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `decimal`    | `decimal`     |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `double-int` | `safeint`     |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int8`       | `int8`        |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int16`      | `int16`       |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `uint8`      | `uint8`       |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `uri`        | `url`         |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor formats that are not supported directly, you can use the built-in `@format` decorator to specify\\\\r\\\\nthe format explicitly.\\\\n\\\\nThe following table shows how common OpenAPI types map to TypeSpec types:\\\\r\\\\n| `type:`   | `format:`   | TypeSpec type    | Notes                                                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| --------- | ----------- | ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int32`     | `int32`          |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `integer` | `int64`     | `int64`          |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `float`     | `float32`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `number`  | `double`    | `float64`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  |             | `string`         |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `byte`      | `bytes`          | for content-type == 'application/json' or 'text/plain'                    |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `binary`    | `bytes`          | for \\\\\\\"binary\\\\\\\" content types, e.g. 'application/octet-stream', 'image/jpeg' |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date`      | `plainDate`      |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date-time` | `utcDateTime`    | RFC 3339 date in coordinated universal time (UTC)                         |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `date-time` | `offsetDateTime` | RFC 3339 date with offset                                                 |\\\\r\\\\n| `string`  | `password`  | `@secret string` |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\n| `boolean` |             | `boolean`        |                                                                           |\\\\r\\\\nYou can also define a property with no type specified using the TypeSpec `unknown` type.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  /** This property has no `type` defined. */\\\\n\\\\n### JSON Schema assertions\\\\n\\\\nOpenAPI supports a variety of \\\\\\\"assertions\\\\\\\" that can be used to further restrict the values allowed for a data type.\\\\r\\\\nThese are actually borrowed into OpenAPI from JSON Schema.\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: integer` and `type: number` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct           | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ---------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minimum: value`            | `@minValue(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maximum: value`            | `@maxValue(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: string` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct            | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ----------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minLength: value`          | `@minLength(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maxLength: value`          | `@maxLength(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `pattern: regex`            | `@pattern(regex)` decorator   |       |\\\\r\\\\nFor `type: array` data types:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI/JSON Schema keyword | TypeSpec construct           | Notes |\\\\r\\\\n| --------------------------- | ---------------------------- | ----- |\\\\r\\\\n| `minItems: value`           | `@minItems(value)` decorator |       |\\\\r\\\\n| `maxItems: value`           | `@maxItems(value)` decorator |       |\\\\n\\\\n### enum\\\\n\\\\nThere are two ways to define an `enum` data type in TypeSpec. One is with the [TypeSpec `enum` statement](https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/enums), e.g.:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- To retain the quotes from the enum values --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- prettier-ignore-start --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Color {\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"red\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"blue\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"green\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c!-- prettier-ignore-end --\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\nAnother is to use the union operation to define the enum values inline, e.g.:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  size?: \\\\\\\"small\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"medium\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"large\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"x-large\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### default\\\\n\\\\nA model property that specifies a default value using \\\\\\\"=\\\\\\\" will produce a `default` field in the schema for this property.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel Example {\\\\r\\\\n  answer?: int32 = 42;\\\\r\\\\n  color?: string = \\\\\\\"purple\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nproduces\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=openapi.yaml\\\\r\\\\nanswer:\\\\r\\\\n  type: integer\\\\r\\\\n  format: int32\\\\r\\\\n  default: 42\\\\r\\\\ncolor:\\\\r\\\\n  type: string\\\\r\\\\n  default: purple\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Host / BasePath / Servers\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI v2, the `host` and `basePath` fields at the top-level of the API definition combine to form the base URL for the API. The paths defined in the `paths` object are appended to this base URL to form the absolute URL for an operation.\\\\r\\\\nIn OpenAPI v3, the top-level `servers` field specifies an array of `server` objects [[v3][v3-server]] with a base URL, which may be parameterized, to which the operation path is appended.\\\\r\\\\n[v3-server]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#server-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, the `host` in OpenAPI v2 or `servers` in OpenAPI v3 can be specified with the `@server` decorator\\\\r\\\\non the namespace (from `@typespec/http` library). You can use this decorator multiple times to specify multiple servers.\\\\n\\\\n## Paths Object\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI, the `paths` object [[v2][v2-paths], [v3][v3-paths]] is the top-level structure for defining the operations of the API, organized by the \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\" for the operation.\\\\r\\\\n[v2-paths]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#paths-object\\\\r\\\\n[v3-paths]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#paths-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, you can specify the path for a namespace, interface, or operation using the `@route` decorator.\\\\r\\\\nWhen the value of the `@route` decorator contains path parameters, operations within the scope of the decorator\\\\r\\\\nmust declare parameters with the same name and type. If an operation declares a path parameter that is not present\\\\r\\\\nin the route, this defines a new path that is the value from the `@route` decorator with the path parameter appended.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/pets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Pets {\\\\r\\\\n  op create(@body pet: Pet): Pet; // uses path \\\\\\\"/pets\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  op read(@path petId: int32): Pet; // uses path \\\\\\\"/pets/{petId}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhen the `@route` decorator is used within a namespace or interface that also has a `@route` decorator, the path is\\\\r\\\\nobtained by concatenating the routes.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Widgets {\\\\r\\\\n  // widgets operations\\\\r\\\\n  @route(\\\\\\\"/{id}/parts\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  namespace Parts {\\\\r\\\\n    op list(@path id: string): Part[] | Error; // uses path \\\\\\\"/widgets/{id}/parts\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Path Item Object\\\\n\\\\nIn OpenAPI, a path item object [[v2][v2-pathitem], [v3][v3-pathitem]] describes the operations available on a single path. A path may have at most one `get`, `put`, `post`, `patch`, `delete`, or `head` operation.\\\\r\\\\n[v2-pathitem]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/main/versions/2.0.md#path-item-object\\\\r\\\\n[v3-pathitem]: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/3.0.3/versions/3.0.3.md#path-item-object\\\\r\\\\nIn TypeSpec, operations are defined within a namespace or interface with a syntax similar to typescript functions.\\\\r\\\\nThe HTTP method for an operation can be specified explicitly using a decorator: `@get`, `@put`, `@post`, `@patch`, `@delete`, or `@head`.\\\\r\\\\nIf an HTTP method decorator is not specified then the default is `post` if there is a body and `get` otherwise.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@tag(\\\\\\\"Gadgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@route(\\\\\\\"/gadgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Gadgets {\\\\r\\\\n  op create(@body gadget: Gadget): Gadget | Error; // uses \\\\\\\"post\\\\\\\" method\\\\r\\\\n  op read(@path id: string): Gadget | Error; // uses \\\\\\\"get\\\\\\\" method\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOther path item fields:\\\\r\\\\n| OpenAPI `pathItem` field | TypeSpec construct | Notes                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------------ | ------------------ | ------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| `summary`                | Versioning\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n# getting-started#getting-started-rest#06-versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Using the `@added` Decorator\\\\n\\\\nThe [`@added`](../../../libraries/versioning/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Versioning.added) decorator is used to indicate that a model or operation was added in a specific version of the API. This allows you to manage changes and additions to your API over time.\\\\n\\\\n### Example: Adding a New Model in a Specific Version\\\\n\\\\nLet's add a `Toy` model that is only available in version 2 of the API:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp title=main.tsp tryit=\\\\\\\"{\\\\\\\"emit\\\\\\\": [\\\\\\\"@typespec/openapi3\\\\\\\"]}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Pet Store\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@server(\\\\\\\"https://example.com\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"Single server endpoint\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace PetStore;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1: \\\\\\\"1.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2: \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel Pet {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  @minLength(1)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @minValue(0)\\\\r\\\\n  @maxValue(100)\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  kind: petType;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nenum petType {\\\\r\\\\n  dog: \\\\\\\"dog\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  cat: \\\\\\\"cat\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  fish: \\\\\\\"fish\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  bird: \\\\\\\"bird\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  reptile: \\\\\\\"reptile\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-start\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Toy {\\\\r\\\\n  id: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// highlight-end\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nIn this example:\\\\r\\\\n- The `Toy` model is defined with the `@added(Versions.v2)` decorator to indicate that it was added in version 2 of the API.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#generate-client-libraries#10versioning.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/10versioning\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Versioning\\\\n## Single api Version\\\\n# howtos#generate-client-libraries#10versioning.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Single api Version\\\\n\\\\nIf there is just one api version in the spec, we will generate the api surface area for that one version.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cClientTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(My.Service.Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@service\\\\r\\\\nnamespace My.Service;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2023_11_01: \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel StableModel {\\\\r\\\\n  stableFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nop stableFunctionality(@body stableModel: StableModel): void;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\nimport pytest\\\\r\\\\nfrom my.service import MyServiceClient, models\\\\r\\\\nclient = MyServiceClient(endpoint=..., credential=...)\\\\r\\\\n// client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nstable_model = models.StableModel(stable_feature=\\\\\\\"present\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nprint(stable_model)\\\\r\\\\nclient.stable_functionality(stable_model) # call goes through\\\\r\\\\npreview_client = MyServiceClient(endpoint=..., credential=..., api_version=\\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n// python allows you to override the api version, even if only one version is defined in the spec\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`csharp\\\\r\\\\n//ServiceVersion enum\\\\r\\\\npublic enum ServiceVersion\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n    /// \\\\u003csummary\\\\u003e Service version \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\". \\\\u003c/summary\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n    V2023_11_01 = 1,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nUri endpoint = new Uri(\\\\\\\"\\\\u003chttps://my-service.azure.com\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\nServiceClient client = new ServiceClient(endpoint);\\\\r\\\\n//client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nStableModel stableModel = new StableModel(\\\\\\\"\\\\u003cstableFeature\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\nResponse response = client.StableFunctionality(stableModel);\\\\r\\\\nUri endpoint = new Uri(\\\\\\\"\\\\u003chttps://my-service.azure.com\\\\u003e\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\nServiceClientOptions options = new ServiceClientOptions(ServiceVersion.V2023_11_01);\\\\r\\\\nServiceClient client = new ServiceClient(endpoint, options);\\\\r\\\\n//You can specify the service api-version when create client instance. Now client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typescript\\\\r\\\\nexport interface StableModel {\\\\r\\\\n  stableFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nexport function stableModelSerializer(item: StableModel): any {\\\\r\\\\n  return { stableFeature: item[\\\\\\\"stableFeature\\\\\\\"] };\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nServiceClientOptions options = new ServiceClientOptions(ServiceVersion.V2023_11_01);\\\\r\\\\nServiceClient client = new ServiceClient(endpoint, options);\\\\r\\\\n//You can specify the service api-version when create client instance. Now client's api_version will be \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typescript\\\\r\\\\nexport interface StableModel {\\\\r\\\\n  stableFeature: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nexport function stableModelSerializer(item: StableModel): any {\\\\r\\\\n  return { stableFeature: item[\\\\\\\"stableFeature\\\\\\\"] };\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/** Known values of {@link Versions} that the service accepts. */\\\\r\\\\nexport enum KnownVersions {\\\\r\\\\n  V20231101 = \\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nexport async function stableFunctionality(\\\\r\\\\n  context: Client,\\\\r\\\\n  stableModel: StableModel,\\\\r\\\\n  options: StableFunctionalityOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },\\\\r\\\\n): Promise\\\\u003cvoid\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`java\\\\r\\\\n// ServiceVersion enum\\\\r\\\\npublic enum ServiceServiceVersion implements ServiceVersion {\\\\r\\\\n    V2023_11_01(\\\\\\\"2023-11-01\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n    public static ServiceServiceVersion getLatest() {} // V2023_11_01\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n// Client API\\\\r\\\\nServiceClientClient serviceClientClient = new ServiceClientClientBuilder()\\\\r\\\\n    // override the api version, even if only one version is defined in the spec\\\\r\\\\n    .serviceVersion(ServiceServiceVersion.V2023_11_01)\\\\r\\\\n    // other configurations\\\\r\\\\n    .buildClient();\\\\r\\\\n// client's api-version will be 2023-11-01\\\\r\\\\nStableModel stableModel = new StableModel(\\\\\\\"present\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n// call goes through\\\\r\\\\nserviceClientClient.stableFunctionality(stableModel);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`go\\\\r\\\\ntype StableModel struct Versioning\\\\n# getstarted#versioning.md\\\\n\\\\n# Versioning\\\\n\\\\nVersioning lets you evolve your API without breaking existing clients. This guide covers the basics of declaring versions and adding new resources, operations, and properties in a clear, easy-to-follow way. For more advanced scenarios, see the [full versioning documentation](../howtos/ARM/versioning.md).\\\\n\\\\n## Declaring Versions\\\\n\\\\nTo support multiple API versions, define them in an enum. After defining your enum, link it to your namespace using the `@versioned` decorator. For each version, specify your dependencies:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n/** Contoso API versions */\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  v2,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.ContosoProviderHub;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Adding a Resource or Operation\\\\n\\\\nTo introduce a new model or operation in a specific version (and all later versions), use the `@added` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n**Add a model in v2:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Add an operation in v2:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  createOrUpdate is ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Adding a Property or Parameter\\\\n\\\\nYou can also add new properties or parameters to models and operations in a specific version:\\\\r\\\\n**Add a property in v2:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee {\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Add a parameter in v2:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n    Employee,\\\\r\\\\n    Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n      name: string;\\\\r\\\\n      @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n      department?: string;\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## Adding New Operations\\\\n\\\\nYou can add new operations to an interface for a specific version:\\\\r\\\\n**Add a new operation in v2:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface Employees {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.v2)\\\\r\\\\n  move is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003cEmployee, MoveRequest, `output-file`\\\\n# emitters#typespec-autorest#reference#emitter.md\\\\n\\\\n# Emitter usage\\\\n\\\\n## Emitter options\\\\n\\\\n### `output-file`\\\\n\\\\n**Type:** `string`\\\\r\\\\nName of the output file.\\\\r\\\\nOutput file will interpolate the following values:\\\\r\\\\n- service-name: Name of the service if multiple\\\\r\\\\n- version: Version of the service if multiple\\\\r\\\\n- azure-resource-provider-folder: Value of the azure-resource-provider-folder option\\\\r\\\\n- version-status: Only enabled if azure-resource-provider-folder is set. `preview` if version contains preview, stable otherwise.\\\\r\\\\nDefault: `{azure-resource-provider-folder}/{service-name}/{version-status}/{version}/openapi.json`\\\\r\\\\nExample: Single service no versioning\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.yaml`\\\\r\\\\nExample: Multiple services no versioning\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.Org1.Service1.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.Org1.Service2.yaml`\\\\r\\\\nExample: Single service with versioning\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.v1.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.v2.yaml`\\\\r\\\\nExample: Multiple service with versioning\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.Org1.Service1.v1.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.Org1.Service1.v2.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.Org1.Service2.v1.0.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `openapi.Org1.Service2.v1.1.yaml`\\\\r\\\\nExample: azureResourceProviderFolder is provided\\\\r\\\\n- `arm-folder/AzureService/preview/2020-01-01.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `arm-folder/AzureService/preview/2020-01-01.yaml`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_09_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Changing Property to Optional with Default\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi everyone, \\\\r\\\\nI am making a property optional in typespec and to be a non-breaking change, I see that is required to have a default. However my change seems to also change the existing version instead of only the new version. \\\\r\\\\nBefore:\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists: SubResource[]; \\\\r\\\\nAfter:\\\\r\\\\n  @madeOptional(Versions.v2025_10_01_preview)\\\\r\\\\n  @OpenAPI.extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", #[])\\\\r\\\\n  dnsResolverDomainLists?: SubResource[] = #[]; \\\\r\\\\n1) How can I make the change in typespec so that the generation of the openapi jsons will not affect the existing version? Currently generation also adds the empty array default to the existing API version (2025-05-01) which causes the breaking change CI to flag.\\\\r\\\\n2) Is there a way I can default the SubResource[] array to null instead? \\\\r\\\\nThis is in accordance to the documentation here (Made optional with/without default case): [non-breaking-versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/non-breaking-versioning/#-incorrect)\\\\r\\\\nMy PR: [Release 2025-10-01-preview for DNS Resolver by jamesvoongms \\u00b7 Pull Request #24470 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-res\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24470)\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should not add OpenApi extensions directly - x-ms-identifiers are automatically added based on the `@key` properties of a model,  or you should use the `@identifiers` decorator if you need to override the default setting. \\\\r\\\\nThe problem is that this is two changes (making a property optional and providing a default), but there is only versioning decoration for one change.  Compounding this, there is no versioning decoration for adding a default value, this is being tracked here: [Add additional versioning decorators \\u00b7 Issue #2761 \\u00b7 microsoft/typespec](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues/2761).  Ideally we should combine these two changes into a single decorator to promote non-breaking changes. \\\\r\\\\nMeanwhile, you can do this using the added/removed/rename pattern to replace one property with another property in a new version, as this example.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`, \\\\\\\"stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  oldStuff: string[];\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-10-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"The stuff\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  stuff?: string[] = #[];\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"howtos#versioning#preview-version.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"How to define a preview version\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/versioning/preview-version\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# How to define a preview version\\\\n## Usage Examples\\\\n### New preview Version\\\\n# howtos#versioning#preview-version.md\\\\n\\\\n# How to define a preview version\\\\n\\\\n## Usage Examples\\\\n\\\\n### New preview Version\\\\n\\\\nIn the following example we introduce a new preview version called `v3Preview` which includes everything from `v2` plus adds a new property to the `Widget` resource.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`diff lang=tsp\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/http\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/rest\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Http;\\\\r\\\\nusing Rest;\\\\r\\\\nusing Versioning;\\\\r\\\\nusing Azure.Core;\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Widget Service\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\nnamespace DemoService;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v1,\\\\r\\\\n  v2,\\\\r\\\\n+  @previewVersion\\\\r\\\\n+  v3Preview\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n/**\\\\r\\\\n * Model defining the Widget resource\\\\r\\\\n */\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * Identifier of the Widget Resource\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  @key id: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * Weight of the widget\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  weight: int32;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * Color of the widget;\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  color: \\\\\\\"red\\\\\\\" | \\\\\\\"blue\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * Nickname of the Widget resource\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n+  @added(Versions.v3Preview) nickname: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Creating stable API version with select properties omitted?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Creating stable API version with select properties omitted?\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_08_29.md\\\\n\\\\n# Creating stable API version with select properties omitted?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nIs it possible on typeSpec to add a new preview with some new parameters and a new stable for all other properties that we already have? We have some properties that we don't want to include in a stable release just yet, but don't want that to hold us from releasing the other properties in a stable release.\\\\r\\\\nCan we have multiple versions marked with @previewVersion? How do we handle a property that is in multiple preview versions, but we want to keep out of stable versions? \\\\r\\\\nFor a practical example, we have the faultSimulation apis in our spec in 2024-11-01-preview, 2025-03-01-preview, 2025-06-01-preview, and 2025-07-01-preview. If I mark 2025-07-01-preview with @previewVersion and faultSimulation with @added(versions.v2025_07_01_preview), the generation removes it from the previous preview specs.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nLlBIPHLFByb2ZpbNR5cmVtb3bce%2FQAm%2FABm8UoZW5jb2RlKCJiYXNlNjR1cmwixBdwxno%2FOiBieXRlc%2BkAklRoZSBzdGF0dXPkAJV0aGUgbGFzdCDkAS9hdGlvbuUE4CAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAkphZMddxCDlBW9TdGF0xGflAhXMFOkBssRzzDLlAIDlARRh6QI%2FxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQDHNFU5QHO5gFk6QNcxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QaJ6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBuHHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QRn6QPh5AMh6QHK6QPjTW92ZVLHFegD3MRzbW92xGhmcm9tIGxvY%2BYAvMVuxBPxA5rLM3RvzzF0b8ov9wCVc3BvbnPrBPXmAJbHFuwAl%2B4DbMU%2BxWTGfOYC7s1uaW50ZXJm5AgAT%2BgDlHMgZXh0ZW5kc%2FYIwi7LKXt9CuUInsgjyhvLWegAzeYFHWdldOQBp0HKNeQD5%2BwFeiDnAntPcuUCp%2BUB1ssvQ8cdUmVwbGFjZUFzeW5jzj%2FlAvfIN0N1c3RvbVBhdGNoU8QqCiAgIOkAkyzFDvYA50ZvdW7kAybkBQ7IHOYAkU3kAYTGSdBLyhDqBhTFGT4KICDlAJ3mAprvANTlApdlV2l0aG91dE9r8wDUbGlzdEJ5yDBHcm91cM9ETMUiUGFyZW501DxTdWJzY3JpcOUCecY7xjPMGcw56AbKIHNhbXBs6wNmYWPFRHRoYXTmAmPpBm10byBkaWZmZeQAhO8C5sUp7gCyQcVI5QGWyHcs7ANxyA3mAujzAJJIRUFE6gZMxH5jaGVja%2BoAqmV4aXN0ZW7mCDAgxh5FyRTvAljNHe4ICw%3D%3D\\\\u0026e=%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-autorest\\\\u0026vs=%7B%7D) \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n/** Contoso API versions */\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2021-10-01-preview version */\\\\r\\\\n  @useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2021-10-01-preview`,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2024-10-01 version */\\\\r\\\\n  @useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2024-10-01`,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2025-07-01-preview version */\\\\r\\\\n  @useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2025-07-01-preview`,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n/** A ContosoProviderHub resource */\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee is TrackedResource\\\\u003cEmployeeProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\n\\\\n@armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2024-10-01`,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** 2025-07-01-preview version */\\\\r\\\\n  @useDependency(Azure.ResourceManager.Versions.v1_0_Preview_1)\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2025-07-01-preview`,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n/** A ContosoProviderHub resource */\\\\r\\\\nmodel Employee is TrackedResource\\\\u003cEmployeeProperties\\\\u003e {\\\\r\\\\n  ...ResourceNameParameter\\\\u003cEmployee\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n/** Employee properties */\\\\r\\\\nmodel EmployeeProperties {\\\\r\\\\n  /** Age of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\\\r\\\\n  age?: int32;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** City of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  city?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** Profile of employee */\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Versions.`2024-10-01`)\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Versions.`2025-07-01-preview`)\\\\r\\\\n  @encode(\\\\\\\"base64url\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  profile?: bytes;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n  /** The status of the last operation. */\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningState?: ProvisioningState;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nshowing two propertties (EmployeeProperties.age and EmployeeProperties.profile) that use versioning.  'age' appears in the second, stable version and all subsequent versions,  'profile' appears in the first (preview) version, is removed in the stable version, and then added back again in the subsequent preview version.\\\\r\\\\nNotably, this practice of adding a property at each preview version and removing it at each stable is easy to get wrong.   \\\\r\\\\nthe official Azure policy is to have only one active preview, as much as that is possible with api retention requirements.  So that, when you introduce a new preview version, the older preview is removed, ideally, this means that, especially when you just had a stable release, you remove support for the previous preview when (or soon after) you add the new preview version. \\\\r\\\\nYou can see more details about versioning in typespec here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/versioning/)\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec versioning works in the following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.  It can be added back using `@added` [Here is a\\\\n\\\\nthe following way:\\\\r\\\\nAll types in the spec are automatically part of the initial api-version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a new api-version is introduced,  any new types `use@added(VERSION)` decorators to indicate they were added in that version, they are impliciutly included in every subsequent version\\\\r\\\\nWhen a type does not appear in one version, then you use `@removed(VERSION)` to remove the type at that version, by default, it will not appear any subsequent versions.  It can be added back using `@added` [Here is a playground](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D\\\\%2BQAoWVudW3oARNzIHsKICDELjIwMjEtMTAtMDEtcHJldmlld8g1xDQgIEB1c2VEZXBlbmRlbmN5KPUBLy7IVi52MV8wX1DGSF8xKcRAYXJtQ29tbW9uVOQBz8cq10jLKctUNcRIYPIAqWAsCuoAxTTGHP8Avf8Avf8Avf8Avf4AvecAoe0AtTUtMDf%2FAXr%2FAL3%2FAL3%2FAL3%2FAL3qAL3vAKlgLAp95gJtQegCb%2BsCiCDoA6rkAMhtb2RlbCBFbXBsb3llZSBpcyBUcmFja2Vk6ACCPMgcUHJvcGVydGllcz7lAp4uLukApuQDUFBhcmFtZXRlcskxPjvoAIbJX3DJRNJ8ymDpAv1BZ2Ugb2YgZcg%2F5gF4YWRk6wN%2BLuwBveQBEGFnZT86IGludDMyO%2BgBzENpdHnSSmNpdHk%2FOiBzdHLlBIPHLFByb2ZpbNR5cmVtb3bce%2FQAm%2FABm8UoZW5jb2RlKCJiYXNlNjR1cmwixBdwxno%2FOiBieXRlc%2BkAklRoZSBzdGF0dXPkAJV0aGUgbGFzdCDkAS9hdGlvbuUE4CAgQHZpc2liaWxpdHkoTGlmZWN5Y2zkAkphZMddxCDlBW9TdGF0xGflAhXMFOkBssRzzDLlAIDlARRh6QI%2FxXdAbHJvxDt1cwp1buQDHNFU5QHO5gFk6QNcxF%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXB0ZWTEZyAgQccOOiAiyAsi1lBpxEDkALTpAMHIROwAnDogIswP2kx1cGRhdMRPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QaJ6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBuHHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"azure#apiVersionEvolution.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Scenarios for API Evolution\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Scenarios for API Evolution\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with a new Stable and a Preview API (previous stable API exists)\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n# azure#apiVersionEvolution.md\\\\n\\\\n# Scenarios for API Evolution\\\\n\\\\nThis document describe how to evolute api version for a management plane services.\\\\n\\\\n## Scenarios to Consider\\\\n\\\\nadd a new stable version\\\\r\\\\nadd a new preview version\\\\r\\\\nMaking a preview api stable\\\\r\\\\nReplacing a preview API with a new preview API\\\\r\\\\nReplacing a preview API with a stable API\\\\r\\\\nReplacing a preview API with a stable API and a new preview API\\\\r\\\\nAdding a preview API (previous stable API)\\\\r\\\\nConverting existing specs with mixes of preview and stable APIs\\\\r\\\\nNote that, in this new scenario, new services will always have only a single version in their specs until they have their first stable version.  This should drastically reduce the amount of decoration in preview APIs\\\\n\\\\n## Add a new stable version\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n1. Check the Latest Version\\\\r\\\\n   1. Determine whether the latest version is a preview version or a stable (GA) version.\\\\r\\\\n2. If the Latest Version is Stable (GA):\\\\r\\\\n   1. Add a new entry for the new stable version at the bottom of the Versions enumeration\\\\r\\\\n   2. Add a new example folder for the new version and copy any still-relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n   3. Make changes to the API using versioning decorators to mark each change\\\\r\\\\n3. if the latest version is preview version: \\\\r\\\\n   1. Add a new stable (GA) version enum before the existing preview enum value.\\\\r\\\\n   2. Add a new example folder for the new version and copy any still-relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n   3. Update all items that are GA\\u2019ing:\\\\r\\\\n      1. Change their @added version value to match the new GA enum value.\\\\r\\\\n   4. Handle remaining preview-only features:\\\\r\\\\n      1. If some features are not GAed, create a new preview version and Decorate non-GA items with @added pointing to the new preview version.\\\\r\\\\n      2. If all features in the preview version are GAed, delete the existing preview version.\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with a new Preview API (Adding a Preview API to a spec with an active preview)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Use 'rename symbol' to rename the version in the \\\\\\\"versions\\\\\\\" enumeration and all references to match the new preview api-version\\\\r\\\\n- rename the example folder to use the new version\\\\r\\\\n- Remove any api changes not in the new version (simply remove types or type change decorators that do not apply)\\\\r\\\\n- Change the API inline decorating any type changes or new types in the new versionSome tooling to pick which resources, types, and operations are part of the new API could be useful.\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tag to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n### CI Checks and Process\\\\n\\\\n- Investigate whether ci checks will flag existing swagger generated from previous typespec and adjust checks as necessary\\\\r\\\\n- Cleanup process for retired api-versions\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with a Stable API (Adding a stable API to a spec with an active preview)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Use 'rename symbol' to rename the version in the \\\\\\\"versions\\\\\\\" enumeration and all references to match the new stable api-version. \\\\r\\\\n- Remove any @previewVersion decorator\\\\r\\\\n- rename the example folder to use the new stable api version\\\\r\\\\n- Remove any api changes not in the new stable API version. Some tooling to pick which resources, types, and operations are part of the new API could be useful.\\\\r\\\\n- Add any api changes in the new stable version, using versioning decorators unless it is the only api-version\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tag to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n### CI Checks and Process\\\\n\\\\n- Investigate whether ci checks will flag existing swagger generated from previous typespec and adjust checks as necessary\\\\r\\\\n- Cleanup process for retired api-versions\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with a new Stable and a Preview API (previous stable API exists)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Use 'rename symbol' to rename the preview version in the \\\\\\\"versions\\\\\\\" enumeration to match the new preview version and all references\\\\r\\\\n- Add a new Stable version entry immediately before the renamed version entry\\\\r\\\\n- rename the example folder to use the new preview api version\\\\r\\\\n- Create a new example folder for the stable API and copy relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n- Relabel any api changes in the new stable API version, that is, any changes in the preview that are now considered stable. \\\\r\\\\n    - Some tooling to pick which resources, types, and operations from the previous preview became stable and which ones became part of the new preview APIs.\\\\r\\\\n- Add any api changes in the new stable version, using versioning decorators (automatically included in the new preview version)\\\\r\\\\n- Add any api changes still in preview in the new preview API-version, using versioning decorators\\\\n\\\\n### Check-in Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Add new tags to readme (can this be automated)?\\\\n\\\\n### CI Checks and Process\\\\n\\\\n- Investigate whether ci checks will flag existing swagger generated from previous typespec and adjust checks as necessary\\\\r\\\\n- Cleanup process for retired api-versions\\\\n\\\\n## Replacing a Preview API with the first Stable API and a new Preview API (no previous stable api)\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n- Replace the current versions enum member with the new stable api-version (first) and the new preview api-version (last)\\\\r\\\\n- Decorate the preview api-version with the @previewVersion decorator\\\\r\\\\n- Rename the example folder to use the new preview api version and update examples as needed\\\\r\\\\n- Create a new example folder for the stable API and copy relevant examples\\\\r\\\\n- Leave any resources, types and operations in the new stable version undecorated (automatically included in both the new stable and the new preview version)\\\\r\\\\n- Decorate any resources, types, and operations only in the new preview API version, that is, any types that are not considered stable. This should drastically reduce the amount of decoration in preview APIs\\\\n\\\\n## Add a new stable version\\\\n\\\\n### TypeSpec Steps\\\\n\\\\n1. Check the Latest Version\\\\r\\\\n   1. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\\\\" \\\\r\\\\nWe want to keep both old and new api versoins. What is the suggestion here? Do you suggest to create different TSP file for each version/use versioning in existing TSP?  \\\\r\\\\nIf second case, can you share some example where APIs/Properties are added/removed in a newer version\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nThe idea behind TypeSpec versioning is to model the diffs in your API, encouraging best practices for API evolution. If you have questions about modeling particular changes, feel free to ask.\\\\r\\\\nAbout your concern: fixing a new validation causing changes to older APIs\\u2014this usually happens when new changes are added without using the appropriate version decorators. For example:\\\\r\\\\nIf you added properties or made a property optional, but didn\\u2019t annotate them with @added or @madeOptional, then they would apply to all versions by default, including older ones.\\\\r\\\\nThat\\u2019s likely why your stable version (e.g., 2024-12-01) got unintentionally updated when you only meant to target 2025-07-01-preview.\\\\r\\\\nTo avoid this, always use decorators like @added and @madeOptional to indicate version-specific changes.\\\\r\\\\nAs for the location field and the read/create mutability warning:\\\\r\\\\nThat rule is a warning meant to be advisory. In your case, it doesn\\u2019t seem to apply\\u2014so this is a good example where you should not change the service behavior just to satisfy a linting rule. It's fine to ignore the warning here.\\\\r\\\\nRegarding your question on renaming an API response (e.g., from MoveResponse to MoveResult):\\\\r\\\\nIf the new name is meant for a specific version, ensure it\\u2019s versioned properly in your TypeSpec. In your repro, the naming appears correct\\u2014MoveResult in 2021-10-01-preview, and MoveResponse in 2024-10-01-preview\\u2014so it\\u2019s working as expected.\\\\r\\\\nFinally, for adding or removing a parameter in only the new version:\\\\r\\\\nUnfortunately, you can\\u2019t directly decorate a spread parameter. The best way is to use operation-specific parameters, which you can decorate with versioning decorators. You could alternatively decorate the core parameter definition (e.g., with an augment decorator), but that would affect every usage\\u2014so for localized changes, use operation-specific ones. Since this is a method parameter, the APIs are equivalent and the change has no SDK impact.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_to_swagger_mapping\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"TypeSpec-ARM-Decorators-Documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"TypeSpec ARM Decorator Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# TypeSpec ARM Decorator Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n## 1. @armCommonTypesVersion\\\\n### Description\\\\n# TypeSpec-ARM-Decorators-Documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec ARM Decorator Mapping to Swagger Documentation\\\\n\\\\n## 1. @armCommonTypesVersion\\\\n\\\\n### Description\\\\n\\\\nThis decorator is used either on a namespace or a version enum value to indicate the version of the Azure Resource Manager common-types to use for refs in emitted Swagger files.\\\\r\\\\n**TypeSpec Example:**\\\\r\\\\n```typescript\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@typespec/versioning\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nusing Azure.ResourceManager;\\\\r\\\\nusing TypeSpec.Versioning;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@armProviderNamespace\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"ContosoProviderHubClient\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.ContosoProviderHub;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  @armCommonTypesVersion(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Versions.v5)\\\\r\\\\n  `2021-10-01-preview`,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n**Swagger Output:**\\\\r\\\\n```json\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"swagger\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"2.0\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"info\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"title\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"ContosoProviderHubClient\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"version\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"2021-10-01-preview\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"x-typespec-generated\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n      {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"emitter\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    ]\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"schemes\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"https\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"host\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"management.azure.com\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"produces\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"consumes\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"application/json\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"security\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"azure_auth\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"user_impersonation\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      ]\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  ],\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"securityDefinitions\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"azure_auth\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"oauth2\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"Azure Active Directory OAuth2 Flow.\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"flow\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"implicit\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"authorizationUrl\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/oauth2/authorize\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n      \\\\\\\"scopes\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"user_impersonation\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"impersonate your user account\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n  },\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"tags\\\\\\\": [],\\\\r\\\\n {}\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"getstarted#azure-core#step09.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"9. Versioning\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/azure-core/step09\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# 9. Versioning\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n# getstarted#azure-core#step09.md\\\\n\\\\n# 9. Versioning\\\\n\\\\n## Versioning your service\\\\n\\\\nthe `Versions` enum:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou will also need to add the `@useDependency` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, you can express changes to your service using the `@added` and `@removed` decorators. Here's an example of adding a new property to `Widget` and removing an old one:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\\r\\\\n@resource(\\\\\\\"widgets\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Widget {\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget name. */\\\\r\\\\n  @key(\\\\\\\"widgetName\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  @visibility(Lifecycle.Read)\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The widget color. */\\\\r\\\\n  @added(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions.v2022_11_30)\\\\r\\\\n  color: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /** The ID of the widget's manufacturer. */\\\\r\\\\n  @removed(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions.v2022_11_30)\\\\r\\\\n  manufacturerId: string;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e You can do a lot more with versioning decorators, so consult the `typespec-versioning` [README.md](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/versioning#enable-versioning-for-service-or-library) for more information on how you can use them to annotate your service and describe changes between different versions.\\\\n\\\\nIt is inevitable that service specifications will change over time. It is a best practice to add versioning support to your specification from the first version. To do that, you will need to define an `enum` containing your service versions and then apply the `@versioned` decorator to your service namespace.\\\\r\\\\nHere is an example for the `WidgetManager` service:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"Contoso Widget Manager\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\n@versioned(Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions)\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Contoso.WidgetManager;\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThere are a few things to point out here:\\\\r\\\\n- We define an `enum` called `Versions` inside of the service namespace. For each service version, we map a version symbol like `v2022_08_31` to a version string like `2022-08-31`. This service currently only has a single version, but we can add more to this enum as things change over time.\\\\r\\\\n- We add the `@versioned` decorator and reference the `Versions` enum we defined using the fully-qualified name `Contoso.WidgetManager.Versions`. This marks the service as being versioned and specifies the set of versions.\\\\r\\\\n- We change the `@useDependency` decorator we used previously to now link each service version to a specific version of `Azure.Core`. See the [Using Azure.Core Versions](#using-azurecore-versions) section for more information.\\\\r\\\\nImagine that it's 3 months later and you want to release a new version of your service with some slight changes. Add a new version to the `Versions` enum:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nYou will also need to add the `@useDependency` decorator:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nenum Versions {\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_08_31: \\\\\\\"2022-08-31\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  v2022_11_30: \\\\\\\"2022-11-30\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, you can express changes to your service using the `@added` and `@removed` decorators. Here's an example of adding a new property to `Widget` and removing an old one:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n/** A widget. */\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_06_26.md\\\\n\\\\n# Need advice on how to change operation parameters on a breaking change\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nHi all.  My team (Microsoft Translator) is trying to update our POST translate call with a breaking change.  The PR is: [Update translate call to 2025-05-01 by SG-MS \\u00b7 Pull Request #33410 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/33410) \\\\r\\\\nThe old version (3.0) is being updated to a new version (2025-05-01-preview).  The big change to our typespec definition is that we will be moving most of the request properties from query parameters to the request body.  In 3.0, the only property in the request body was an array of InputTextItem.  InputTextItem is just a string.  All the other relevant data was passed in as query parameters. \\\\r\\\\nIn 2025-05-01-preview, we want to add a number of additional properties to the request body, so rather than the body consisting of InputTextItem, we want the body to contain a TranslateBody definition, which in turn contains all of our properties.  I'm not sure how to represent this in the tsp files in a compliant way.   \\\\r\\\\nOur translate operation in the routes.tsp file is \\\\r\\\\nop translate is CustomOperation\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n InputTextItem[],\\\\r\\\\n TranslateParameters,\\\\r\\\\n TranslationResult,\\\\r\\\\n ErrorResponse\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\u003e; \\\\r\\\\nThe first member of the template is the request body and I need it to be InputTextItem[] for 3.0 and I need it to be TranslateBody for 2025-05-01-preview.  Otherwise one of them will have the wrong set of arguments.  I considered simply updating InputTextItem to contain all the needed parameters in TranslateBody and then removing the unused ones with @added decorators, but the problem is we have a number of other operators in 2025-05-01-preview which use InputTextItem and require it to be just the text string.   \\\\r\\\\nIs there anyway to have two different translate operations such that one is called by 3.0 and one is called by 2025-05-01-preview?  I think that's what would really get what I need.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nchanges for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe sharedRoute might be sharing the new property to the old versions and not honoring the @added and @removed decorators.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you mark the whole model like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n@added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_06_01_preview)  \\\\r\\\\nmodel ManagedServiceIdentityUpdate  \\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n\\u2026errors may occur if parts of the model were added in older versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nOne workaround was to use ManagedServiceIdentityProperty instead of Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ManagedServiceIdentity\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nLintDiff errors like AvoidAnonymousTypes seem to be coming from the MSI additionalProperties section. This error wasn\\u2019t there before setting use-read-only-status-schema: true, but it\\u2019s unclear why that config causes it.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWarnings like \\\\\\\"Use the latest version v5 of types.json\\\\\\\" for old API versions or EnumInsteadOfBoolean for new ones can be ignored \\u2014 warnings are not required to change for check-in, only errors.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFalse positives (like Avocado errors) may also occur when using @removed and @added in the same API version \\u2014 especially for preview versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf everything is tagged properly and using the latest compiler version, you should be able to get it approved. After that, just follow the normal PR process (e.g., sign-offs, label like WaitForARMFeedback).\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nThere is some documentation on this here: [Versioning | TypeSpec Azure](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/arm/versioning/#converting-an-operation-from-synchronous-to-asynchronous) (this is for ARM, but the same principle applies)\\\\n\\\\nthe post below might be helpful. It also involves adding a \\\\\\\"adding\\\\\\\" a newer API on the same route with different method signature. You'd need to add `@sharedRoute` on both methods and point it to the same route.\\\\r\\\\n[Jocelyn Wei: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustom... | Azure SDK \\\\u003e TypeSpec Discussion | Microsoft Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf@thread.skype/1721233288788?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47\\\\u0026groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121\\\\u0026parentMessageId=1721233288788\\\\u0026teamName=Azure%20SDK\\\\u0026channelName=TypeSpec%20Discussion\\\\u0026createdTime=1721233288788):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\ntitle: Changing interface's `update` from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nquestion:\\\\r\\\\nHi TypeSpec Discussion,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nI am attempting to follow the playground example here TypeSpec Azure to get past a LintDiff error after adding an MSI to my resource. However, adding the new update model as well as changing the interface from update is ArmResourcePatchAsync\\\\u003c... to update is ArmCustomPatchAsync\\\\u003c... is generating breaking changes for older api versions.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to only change the update is.. for the newest api version? I tried using the @added and @removed decorators but the interface complained about duplicate update.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nSummary of answer:\\\\r\\\\nTo change the update operation from ArmResourcePatchAsync to ArmCustomPatchAsync without generating breaking changes for older API versions:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nYou also need to use @renamedFrom(\\\\\\\"update\\\\\\\", newVersion) on the old update operation and put @sharedRoute on both.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nMake sure you don\\u2019t use a model that is not available in a certain version and carry over the @added/@removed if needed.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf a property like userAssignedIdentities was marked as added in 2023, but the model it depends on (ManagedServiceIdentity) was only added later, it doesn\\u2019t make sense \\u2014 this can be the result of composing shared models.\\\"}]\"}"}]
